fields.episode_descript: Our program's very first broadcast.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Joe Franklin, host of the longest running talk show in television history, to get advice for his new radio show.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: After he goes to Jerusalem and sleeps on what is supposedly the very spot where Jesus was crucified, Kevin Kelly has a revelation: that he should live the next six months as if he would die at the end of them. So he gives away nearly everything he owns, and tries to live each day as if his death is imminent — which turns out to be a great challenge.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Ira calls his parents Shirley Glass and Barry Glass in Baltimore to ask them for advice about his new radio show.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: When filmmaker and performance artist Lawrence Steger found out he was HIV positive, he was just about to go out on across country road trip with a friend of his.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Ed Ryder, who was wrongly imprisoned for twenty years and recently released. The whole time Ryder was in prison, he dreamt of starting up a band.

fields.episode_descript: Small-scale stories on the nature of small-scale sin.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Three teenage boys—going under the pseudonyms "K-Rad", "Mr. Warez", and "Fred"—spill their guts about their forays into low-level credit card hacking and computer fraud.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: The Golden Peacock. Playwright Jeff Dorchen creates an original radio play inspired by the musings of the three boys in the previous story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Poet Michael Warr talks with Ira and reads some of his poems inspired by his childhood. Warr grew up as a Jehovah's Witness and found that he had some problems with the religion's rules.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: In the 1990s, Eli was a member of MOD, one of the most infamous and accomplished computer hacking groups in history. He was eventually arrested and served time in a minimum-security prison and home confinement.

fields.episode_descript: Stories decrying the wonders of turkeys, chickens, and other fowl.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: When Danielle's family serves poultry at their dinner table, no one utters the word "chicken." Instead, it is always called "fish." Danielle explains why with the help of her friend "Duki." (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Julie Showalter, who grew up on a turkey farm, tells the story of the night 3,000 turkeys died.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: A poultry-themed poem by Luis Rodriguez.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Verda Mae Grosvenor, host of NPR's Seasonings, shows Ira how to tell a chicken is done simply by listening the sound of the grease.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Act Five
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris tells of the giddiness he felt when he purchased a taxidermy turkey head — attached to its foot.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Act Six
episode_acts.summary: Starting on radio station WCFL in Chicago, "Chickenman" was a much-loved radio feature in the 1960s. Ira presents the first new "Chickenman" episode since 1969.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about vacations gone awry—or perhaps vacations that never should have happened.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass shares photos (on the radio) of his family vacation in Hawaii.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Writer/singer/performer Sandra Tsing Loh reads a story about a family vacation arranged by her mother, who believed that vacations couldn't be merely for leisure—they had to be educational. Which is how the family ended up vacationing in...Ethiopia.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Contributor David Sedaris tells a story about discovering the possibilities—and pitfalls—of travel by hitchhiking.

fields.episode_descript: Stories that reveal the societal "trend" toward anger and away from genuine forgiveness.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads a list of words that former U.S. Representative Newt Gingrich had recommended Republican candidates use when referring to their Democratic opponents.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Former Harpers magazine editor and TAL contributor Jack Hitt wrote an editorial about Susan Smith, who murdered her two children in South Carolina. The editorial redirected the rage from Smith toward Hitt.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Performance artists Iris Moore and Larry Steeger provide monologues on forgiveness.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: In the last few years, laws and sentencing guidelines have become much harsher. Sociologically this has had some good effects.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Glen Fitzgerald, a Chicago missionary who works with gang members, talks about his concept of forgiveness, and how important it is to being Christian.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Act Five
episode_acts.summary: A story by Cheryl Trykv, read by the author in front of a live audience at The Hothouse, illustrates what it means when the sinner makes no attempt to seek forgiveness.

fields.episode_descript: A Christmas tree story by Chicago playwright/musician Beau O'Reilly. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A Christmas radio play by David Sedaris and the Pinetree Gang.
episode_acts.byline: By The Pinetree Gang, Ira Glass, David Sedaris

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: A Christmas tree story by Chicago playwright/musician Beau O'Reilly.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: A story about Christmas at Juvenile Court by Chicago novelist/editor Reginald Gibbons.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Peter Clowney reports on Christmas at the Faith Tabernacle Baptist Church.		Music from Faith Tabernacle Baptist Church all through the hour.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who quit everything in their lives that they hated—and what happened to them afterwards.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Evan Harris was entrenched in her life, stalled and going nowhere both personally and professionally. A silly conversation with a co-worker about the letter "Q" led her to start a magazine called Quitter Quarterly. That one conversation changed her life completely.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: A story about quitting by Sandra Tsing Loh.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Ira explores the question of when it's time to quit a relationship through rare recordings of bickering between roommates—recorded by the next-door neighbors.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Lisa Buscani reads a two-part story about not being able to quit something or someone. The piece was written for This American Life.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Dwight Okita reads the poem "Farewell Samba" from his book Crossing with the Light.Ira Glass reads Philip Larkin's poem "Poetry of Departures." (3 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Stories that reflect back on 1995.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about recently released archival television interviews with the Beatles, who suddenly seem a little less magic — and a lot more pedestrian (4 minutes).

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Eighteen-year-old Claudia Perez takes Ira on a tour of her Chicago neighborhood and looks at what 1995 was like for her community.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Karen Hutt, Director of Religious Education for the First Unitarian Church of Chicago, who one Sunday gave a sermon at the church about her experience as the first black child to integrate the Philadelphia public school system. The sermon inspired a project: Hutt, along with Laura Finnegan, collected an oral history of the experiences of African American members of the congregation about their own experiences as the "first" integrators of their neighborhoods or organizations.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Claudia Perez returns to talk about her year from a more personal perspective.

fields.episode_descript: When comedian Julia Sweeney and her brother both got cancer, she decided to tell the story the best way she knew how: in a comedy club. It might seem like a strange choice, but what resulted is halfway between standup comedy and true-life diary entries.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about the adage "Comedy equals tragedy plus time." Usually it's true, he says, though today's show is devoted to someone who decided to go on stage the same week she was experiencing some horrible things — and talk about those things.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Julia's Brother Gets Cancer
episode_acts.summary: Julia talks about her brother Michael's cancer. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkins lymphoma, stage four.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Julia Gets Cancer
episode_acts.summary: In the second half of the show, she talks about her own cancer — cervical cancer that was diagnosed six months after her brother got sick. Julia eventually turned some of these vignettes into a one-woman show called God Said, Ha!, which Quentin Tarantino made into a movie and Julia released as a book.

fields.episode_descript: People living their lives, just like the rest of us. Plus an extra life.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Susan Bergman's father was a family man, head of the church choir, and, secretly, having sex with men. He died before his children had a chance to really talk to him about what they should make of his hidden life.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Book Tour
episode_acts.summary: When Susan Bergman wrote a book about her family's experience, other gay men tried to explain her father's actions to her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dad In The Closet
episode_acts.summary: A talk with a father who's deceiving his own children.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lighten Up
episode_acts.summary: Sketches from the neo-futurists on the subject of double lives.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Sins Of The Fathers
episode_acts.summary: Susan Bergman returns to read an excerpt from her book.

fields.episode_descript: A story of a friendship between two adolescent boys that was destroyed through the manipulative acts of one of them.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dave's Love
episode_acts.summary: Bob and Dave were close childhood friends — until their relationship began to lead their peers to believe that it might be more than a friendship. The accusations led to Dave turning on Bob.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dave's Hatred
episode_acts.summary: The story of Dave and Bob continues. For reasons that Bob never fully understood, Dave successfully turned everyone in their school against his former friend, even forming clubs devoted to hating Bob.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Dave's Response
episode_acts.summary: Ira reaches current-day Dave, who is a born-again Christian living with his parents. According to Dave, Bob was at fault for the breakdown in their relationship, because Bob had decided to become friends with someone else.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Another Dave
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Thyre reads author David Sedaris' "The Last Time You'll Ever Hear from Me," a story of the ultimate Machiavellian scheming.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the animalness of animals, the irreducible ways in which they are not human.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Samantha Martin trains raccoons to play basketball and rats to bowl. She says that what we want from animals is for them to imitate humans.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Food Chain In A New York Apartment
episode_acts.summary: This American Life contributor Paul Tough visits Catherine Chalmers. She raises small animals and insects in her apartment, feeds them to each other, and photographs them eating each other.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: More Animals Eating Other Animals
episode_acts.summary: An original radio drama called "Kathleen on the Carpet," in which animals talk and hold their own "animal court." It's a comedy by David Sedaris, starring our own radio theater company, the Pinetree Gang.
episode_acts.byline: By The Pinetree Gang, David Rakoff, David Sedaris

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Moment When Humans Stopped Being Animals
episode_acts.summary: Anthropologists agree that humans stopped being animals when they started walking upright, on two legs. But scientists don't agree on why our ancestors did this.

fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass explores a self-help cassette tape that promises to bring the listener peace about being single. The only problem is that it achieves this by having you envision your perfect romantic partner. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explores a self-help cassette tape that promises to bring the listener peace about being single. The only problem is that it achieves this by having you envision your perfect romantic partner.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Yearning
episode_acts.summary: Artist Julie Laffin talks about the inspiration for her "kissing projects." Jessica Yu's film Breathing Lessons is about Mark O'Brien, a man using an "iron lung." In this excerpt, Mark talks about the yearning he tries to quell through the use of sex surrogates. Poet Luis Rodriguez reads his poem "Waiting." Writer Dolores Wilbur tells a story of wanting love.
episode_acts.byline: By Ira Glass, Luis Rodriguez, Doris Wilbur

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sex
episode_acts.summary: Audio artist Gregory Whitehead weaves a story of sexual discovery. And This American Life producer Nancy Updike makes an odd discovery about condom use ... or the lack thereof.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Wedding
episode_acts.summary: Ira describes a wedding held in the dingy basement room of the City of Chicago's Marriage Court.

fields.episode_descript: What unites these stories on the surface is that they're all made from old tapes, recordings found in attics and thrift stores. What unites them under that surface — and not far under it — is that they all end up being stories about fathers and the legacies that fathers leave their children.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with some tape he recorded of a high school senior prom. Kids goof around in the car after the prom and get lost looking for a friend's house.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Berrien Springs, Michigan
episode_acts.summary: A Midwestern family records a "letter on tape" to their son, who is in medical school in California. Three decades later, the recording somehow ends up in a thrift store.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Baltimore
episode_acts.summary: Ira plays tapes of his own father, Barry, who was a radio deejay in the mid-1950s. Barry gave up spinning records when he decided that he couldn't make a decent living at it, and for over a decade he was against his son going into radio, not wanting him to waste time the way he did.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Chicago
episode_acts.summary: Nora Moreno with tapes of her father, a pioneer in Spanish-language broadcasting in America. Her mother fell in love with her father because of his poetic character on the radio, but in real life, the very things that attracted her to him over the radio drove them apart.

fields.episode_descript: Writer Jack Hitt goes on a search for a mysterious neighbor from his childhood in Charleston, South Carolina, and stumbles onto an epic story of the Old South, the New South, gender confusion, Chihuahuas, and changing values in American journalism.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Who are the people we remember as significant figures from our childhood? What is their hold on our imaginations as we age? Ira visits McCosh Elementary on Chicago's South Side, where a man everyone calls "Mr. Lewis" is the surrogate dad for hundreds of kids — a nearly mythic figure.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dawn
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt's quest to find out the truth about the man who lived down the street from him 30 years ago in South Carolina: Gordon Langley Hall, a.k.a. Dawn Langley Hall Simmons.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dawn Again
episode_acts.summary: Two-and-a-half years after Jack Hitt wrote the story that makes up Act One of our show, he returned to the tale of Dawn Langley Simmons.

fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass brings together a panel of Republicans to discuss their lack of excitement about then-presumptive Republican Presidential nominee Bob Dole. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Presumptiveness
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass brings together a panel of Republicans to discuss their lack of excitement about then-presumptive Republican Presidential nominee Bob Dole.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Economy
episode_acts.summary: Temporary employment agencies' business has exploded in the last few years as corporations lay off their full-time employees, especially technical workers. This American Life "hired" two temp workers, Lee and Tito, to document their experiences as temps. Ira invites Tito and Lee into the studio to spin some music "appropriate" for temp employees.
episode_acts.byline: By Ira Glass, Alix Spiegel, Nancy Updike

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Dad
episode_acts.summary: Poet/performer Lisa Buscani tells a story about her father.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Economic Development, Chicago Style
episode_acts.summary: Ira takes a look at the remarkably successful $156 million renovation of Chicago's Navy Pier. He talks with seven employees working at the businesses on the pier.

fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass talks changing the name of the show from Your Radio Playhouse and stumbles on a more fundamental truth about naming things: The people with an investment in the name can be incredibly divisive. He consults television talk show host Joe Franklin for advice. Joe actually likes the new name: This American Life. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks changing the name of the show from Your Radio Playhouse and stumbles on a more fundamental truth about naming things: The people with an investment in the name can be incredibly divisive. He consults television talk show host Joe Franklin for advice.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pier Pressure
episode_acts.summary: Navy Pier's renovation was presented as a success in last week's show, but recent press reveals that the pier is bleeding money. WBEZ personality Aaron Freeman and his kids take Ira on a tour of the pier, looking at it from a child's perspective.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fan Dance
episode_acts.summary: Barbara Adams, a former member of the Whitewater trial jury, showed up for jury duty wearing a full-scale costume from Star Trek: The Next Generation. Ira dissects a discussion on an Internet mailing list about fandom, inspired by Adams' celebrity. Also: Temple University professor Cindy Patton's childhood infatuation with G.I.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fan, Not Fan
episode_acts.summary: The first in a series of pieces in the coming months on This American Life: Non-journalists covering aspects of the Presidential campaign. First up: Chicago playwright David Isaacson presents a piece on Pat Buchanan.

fields.episode_descript: April first is the one day of the year when we're allowed to enjoy deceiving others. But April Fools' Day is for amateur deceivers. The real pros are the people who can't control their lying, who lie without even knowing what the truth is. Everyone's known someone like this, but it's a topic that's only rarely studied or discussed publicly. Journalist and former This American Life contributing editor Margy Rochlin co-hosts.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lies
episode_acts.summary: The story of a woman whose husband lies to her compulsively. At some point, she starts to ask him questions that'll make him lie to her, just to amuse herself.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: More Lies
episode_acts.summary: A girl who adored her father tries to figure out what to think after he takes some of her college money and lies to her about it. Also, a woman whose fiancé runs up $10,000 in credit card charges on her Visa card and vanishes.

fields.episode_descript: Corporate CEO Maurice "Morry" Taylor, Jr. was a Republican candidate for President, and he never had a chance to win the nomination. That didn't stop political reporter and author Michael Lewis from covering Morry's bizarre campaign. Lewis reads from his diaries about life on the road with Morry. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Grizz
episode_acts.summary: Corporate CEO  Maurice "Morry" Taylor, Jr. was a Republican candidate for President, and he never had a chance to win the nomination. That didn't stop political reporter and author Michael Lewis from covering Morry's bizarre campaign.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Citizen Kane
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt reviews the strange case of William Kane, his mistress, his family, and fifteen vials of frozen sperm.

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Candidate, A Voter, And A Room Full Of Pigs
episode_acts.summary: Michael Lewis continues readings from his diaries of Morry Taylor's Presidential campaign.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Another Mixed Legacy
episode_acts.summary: The late Ron Brown, the former U.S. Secretary of Commerce, could have had an easy life, but chose instead to take on stressful, difficult tasks.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of hero worship, of people admiring someone from afar, and trying to get closer to them.

episode_acts.name: Act One: In Search Of The Miraculous
episode_acts.summary: Erika Yeomans sees a young man's photo in an art magazine and decides to track him down. Problem is: he's Dutch, he's a performance artist, and he's dead.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Meet Your Hero
episode_acts.summary: Writer Quincy Troupe talks about how, as a boy, he idolized Miles Davis, and how, as a man, he actually became one of Davis's closest friends. And how his picture of the man changed.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Snuggles
episode_acts.summary: A man in New York runs an apology line.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: 1000 Women Become Selena
episode_acts.summary: Eighteen-year-old correspondent Claudia Perez goes to an audition where a thousand Mexican women and girls dress up to play the slain Mexican pop star Selena in an upcoming film about her life. Feelings about Selena run so high that when her fans talk about her, they often cry.

fields.episode_descript: Scott Carrier documents a group in Manti, Utah, that left the Mormon church and formed its own polygamous church. The members started fighting, broke up, and no longer speak. Scott is the author of Running After Antelope. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Religious Faction
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier documents a group in Manti, Utah, that left the Mormon church and formed its own polygamous church. The members started fighting, broke up, and no longer speak.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Political Faction
episode_acts.summary: Chicago writer Beau O'Reilly writes about a group of close friends who formed an activist group in the seventies. They split apart because of one woman.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Racial Factions
episode_acts.summary: Ira speaks with Professor Glenn Loury. Loury failed to stand up for a light-skinned friend at a black unity rally in the sixties.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of the difficult relationships between parents and their grown children, including two long stories from Sandra Tsing Loh about her father.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira's mom is invited to speak to a group of Jewish mothers who only discuss one topic: their relationships with their adult children.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Me and My Mom
episode_acts.summary: Ira continues the story about his conversation with his mom. Then he calls her up on the air.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sandra's Dad
episode_acts.summary: A story about how the adult children in Sandra Tsing Loh's family deal with her father.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: My Father's Chinese Wives
episode_acts.summary: Sandra's father decides, at age 70, to take a Chinese wife.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of the people who fall for a life in the theater.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: As high-school freshmen, Kim, Tiffany, and Laura were enamored of their fellow students who netted the leads in all the school plays. They're seniors now, and they're the ones landing all the lead roles.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads his story of getting the drama bug.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Lost In Yonkers
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass follows the last month of rehearsals of Oak Park and River Forest High School's production of Neil Simon's Lost In Yonkers.

episode_acts.name: Act One: More Drama
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris continues his story.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: From The Audience Seats
episode_acts.summary: Mark O'Brien is in an iron lung and comes out for short periods of time. What does he do with those precious moments free of the machinery that keeps him alive? He goes to the theater.

fields.episode_descript: Jo Carol Pierce released a CD, "Bad Girls Upset by the Truth," which documents in part her teenage years. Host Ira Glass shares a couple of songs from the CD and some of the stories behind them. (16 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Kara instructs some of her male friends on the proper ways to treat a girl.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Texas Girl
episode_acts.summary: Jo Carol Pierce released a CD, "Bad Girls Upset by the Truth," which documents in part her teenage years. Host Ira Glass shares a couple of songs from the CD and some of the stories behind them.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Suburban Girl
episode_acts.summary: Chicago writer/musician Rennie Sparks, a member of the independent band The Handsome Family, reads "Skanks," a story of a girl struggling in a situation where some rules are strict, but other rules are up for grabs.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Good Girl
episode_acts.summary: Producer/sound artist Gregory Whitehead presents his piece "This Mindless Thing." (7 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Chicagoans' dreams of the Bulls, including interviews with Chicagoans. (8 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Bulls in Our Hearts
episode_acts.summary: Chicagoans' dreams of the Bulls, including interviews with Chicagoans.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Bulls in a Barber Shop
episode_acts.summary: Documentary story about a South Side Chicago barbershop where men gather to watch basketball.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Meaning of Basketball
episode_acts.summary: Chicago playwright David Isaacson, on hating the Bulls.Then, Nancy Updike presents a sound portrait of a Philadelphia woman and her basketball trophies.
episode_acts.byline: By Ira Glass, David Isaacson, Nancy Updike

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Basketball and Commerce
episode_acts.summary: Chicago playwright Beau O'Reilly goes with Ira to the Scottie Pippen Dodge Store.Then, singer/songwriter/playwright Jeff Dorchen on Niketown.
episode_acts.byline: By Jeff Dorchen, Ira Glass, Beau O'Reilly

episode_acts.name: Act Five: One More Dream
episode_acts.summary: A Bulls dream from Chicagoan Brett Grossman, and an acoustic guitar cover of Bulls theme music from Chicago musician Rick Karr.

fields.episode_descript: Ira's own father, Barry Glass, co-hosts this special Father's Day show.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How the World Sees Your Father
episode_acts.summary: LA writer/performer Sandra Tsing Loh discovers that a local rock band has recorded a song about her own father, wildly misinterpreting who he is. They think he's a free spirit; she believes he's a worried, miserly grump.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Father's Music
episode_acts.summary: Sherman Alexie's story "Because My Father was the Only Indian Who Saw Jimi Hendrix Play the Star Spangled Banner at Woodstock." (15 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Moment Dad Left
episode_acts.summary: Audio artist Jay Allison and writer Dan Robb present an audio montage on the moment Robb's parents divorced.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Reconciling With Dad
episode_acts.summary: Chicago playwright Beau O'Reilly talks about how he reconciled with his estranged father years ago by becoming an alcoholic just like him.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about kids being mean to each other, including a mysterious handbook for bullies, a surprising experiment conducted by a teacher who wants to make kids be nice, and a story of youthful backstabbing told by David Sedaris.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A first-grader explains to host Ira Glass how bullies become bullies. His explanation: They read a book on how to be a bully.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Like Guys
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads one of his funniest and most affecting stories from his book Naked before a live audience. As an adolescent boy, David feared he might be a homosexual.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Man In The Well
episode_acts.summary: Original fiction by Ira Sher about a group of children who find a man trapped in a well but decide not to get him any help.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Human Nature, The View From Kindergarten
episode_acts.summary: Author and kindergarten teacher (and MacArthur Genius Grant recipient) Vivian Paley tells the story of an experiment she conducted in her classroom to make children less cruel to each other. She instituted a rule: "You can't say 'You can't play.'" In other words, if two children are playing, and a third child comes over and wants to join them, they can't tell him or her to get lost.

fields.episode_descript: Writer David Sedaris recalls the days when his mother and sister played armchair detective — until a very odd crime wave hit within their own home. Plus, host Ira Glass goes out on surveillance with a real-life private eye.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about one of the purest expressions of ordinary folks' desire to be detectives: a child's detective notebook — full of information, secret codes, cases, and an application to become an FBI agent.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Wannabe
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris remembers the days his mother and sister played armchair detective, and the odd crime wave that hit their own home. This story, titled "True Detective," appears in David's book Naked.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Real World
episode_acts.summary: Ira went out on surveillance with a real private eye in Chicago expecting it to be drudge work with none of the glamour of movie detectives. He was wrong.

fields.episode_descript: Unusual perspectives on the presumptive Republican nominee.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira wonders what the Dole campaign is thinking.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Campaign Diaries
episode_acts.summary: We hear campaign diaries from author Michael Lewis, who is on the campaign trail for the New Republic magazine.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How You Can Be Bob Dole
episode_acts.summary: Former Saturday Night Live writer Robert Smigel — who impersonates Dole on Late Night with Conan O'Brien and the deceased Dana Carvey Show — gives step-by-step instructions on how to imitate the Republican nominee.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: TV Politics
episode_acts.summary: We give Danny Drennan, the writer behind the website Inquisitor Mediarama, a little assignment.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of obsession and compulsion. What happens when a little idea starts to control you. Co-hosted by Paul Tough.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: A woman obsessed with the number 2.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Further Out
episode_acts.summary: A story by Lauren Slater about getting obsessive compulsive disorder.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Sacred Versus Profane
episode_acts.summary: An Orthodox Jew talks about whether Hasidic Judaism is like an obsession.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Heroic Obsessions
episode_acts.summary: A story of a woman who made a kitchen out of beads.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people whose lives are transformed by music.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When You Talk Music
episode_acts.summary: Dael Orlandersmith's funny, moving story from her Obie-award winning show Beauty's Daughters. Though she's an African-American woman, she transforms herself in this story into a loudmouthed Italian guy. At a wedding, this character meets a woman who reminds him of who he was before he got married and had kids: a guy who loved jazz, a different guy than he is now.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Brother Who Struggles To Be A Star
episode_acts.summary: Radio producer Dan Gediman's story about his older brother, "Alex Jones," who he idolized when they were kids. After many unsuccessful attempts to become a rock star, he finally made it in music, as a Tom Jones impersonator.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Choosing Fandom
episode_acts.summary: A reading from the zine Motorbooty about the crisis of World Band Overpopulation. Then, This American Life contributor Sarah Vowell on someone who is not part of the world band overpopulation problem: Scott Lee, the world's greatest fan of the Fastbacks, a respected, semi-obscure Seattle alternative band.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Life In Music
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Sam Franco, a 72-year-old Chicagoan who spent his life playing and teaching accordion. He never became famous.

fields.episode_descript: Unusual stories about day-to-day life at the Republican Convention.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Normal Life In An Abnormal Setting
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass follows a delegation to find out what people actually do at a convention.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Sex advice columnist Dan Savage tells the odd story of how he became a Republican state convention delegate even though he's a Democrat and gay.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Campaign Diaries
episode_acts.summary: More campaign diaries from The New Republic's Michael Lewis.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Party in the Killing Fields
episode_acts.summary: Cassandra Smith's father and grandfather were both Republican, and they were trying to change the Republican Party from the inside.

fields.episode_title: A Night at the Wiener Circle
fields.episode_descript: Ira meets the workers of the Wiener Circle; they're screaming and cursing at each other, and the customers, and they actually seem really happy. And then we meet some of the customers. (15 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira introduces what we're about to listen to: a casette tape of the show.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Ira meets the workers of the Wiener Circle; they're screaming and cursing at each other, and the customers, and they actually seem really happy. And then we meet some of the customers.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Customer
episode_acts.summary: Playwright and contributor Beau O'Reilly talks about a more typical relationship between restaurant and customer.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Parable of Politics
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Shirley Jahad investigates the politics of the Chicago hot dog on Navy Pier.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Fast Food Heart
episode_acts.summary: Cassandra Smith has temptation in Kyoto.

fields.episode_descript: Nancy Updike goes to Iraq to try to figure out what it's like to be a private citizen working in the middle of a war zone.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass wonders what the Democrats stand for, and then goes in search of an answer.

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Little Tour Inside the Message Machine
episode_acts.summary: The secret games delegates play to amuse themselves, differences between Republican and Democratic convention delegates, and more.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Campaign Diaries
episode_acts.summary: The latest installment of Michael Lewis's campaign diaries.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Neighbors
episode_acts.summary: One of the boys from the book There Are No Children Here goes back to his old neighborhood across from the Convention site.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: TV Show
episode_acts.summary: Webmaster and Beverly Hills 90210 expert Danny Drennan on the convention. Danny runs the site Inquisitor Mediarama.

fields.episode_descript: All kinds of little stories that we ordinarily can't use on the radio show because they are just too short.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to Navy Pier to visit the clearance sales.

episode_acts.name: Act One: In the Nude
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads from his story "Naked." (21 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Haiku at the Scrimmage Line
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier's Haiku stories. Scott is the author of Running After Antelope.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Everyday Anthropology
episode_acts.summary: Found zoophilia letters read.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Grandma and Easy
episode_acts.summary: Carmen Delzell/Jay Allison's story on a guitar player.

fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass and playwright David Hauptschein took out advertisements in Chicago inviting people to come to a small theater with letters they've received, sent, or found.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: People came for two nights and read their letters onstage. Some were funny.

fields.episode_title: The Job That Takes Over Your Life
fields.episode_descript: Radio producer Scott Carrier quit his job at a low moment in his life. His wife left him and took the kids. And he got a job interviewing schizophrenics for some medical researchers. After doing it a while, he began to wonder if he was a schizophrenic himself. And more stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass on his relationship to his job, and your relationship to yours.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Test
episode_acts.summary: Radio producer Scott Carrier quit his job at a low moment in his life. His wife left him and took the kids.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Tribe
episode_acts.summary: This American Life associate producer Peter Clowney visits a modern-day touring company of Hair. They don't just believe they're doing a job as professional actors. They're living as a modern-day tribe of hippies — with all the tensions of any communal living.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Port Chicago 50
episode_acts.summary: The story of the worst stateside disaster during World War II, at Port Chicago, an ammunition dump for the navy just north of San Francisco. Black workers were assigned to load ammo onto ships under such unsafe conditions that on July 17, 1944, two ships blew up, killing 320 men.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Orientation
episode_acts.summary: Even the most innocent office job can take over your life. A story by fiction writer Daniel Orozco about one such job.

fields.episode_descript: Simulated worlds, Civil War reenactments, wax museums, simulated coal mines, fake ethnic restaurants, an ersatz Medieval castle and other re-created worlds that thrive all across America.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays clips from Jessica Yu's documentary Men of Reenaction about Civil War reenactments, where the real battle is the one over who is properly authentic and who is not.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Travels in Hyperreality
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass uses Italian author Umberto Eco's essay Travels in Hyperreality as a guidebook to American simulated worlds. Eco says that the urge to create these miniature simulated worlds is a very American impulse — a significant American aesthetic — and one that's not often discussed.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dinosaur Exhibit
episode_acts.summary: Writer Jack Hitt discovers that the world of dinosaurs is a man-made creation, a simulated world that may or may not accurately reflect what happened on earth 100 million years ago. Talking with dinosaur experts like Jack Horner (whose work was the basis of much of the film Jurassic Park), Hitt finds that most of what you think you know about dinosaurs is probably wrong, and that Americans' ideas about dinosaurs go through "fashions" that reflect the national mood: We believed dinosaurs were more aggressive when we were on the brink of World Wars One and Two.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Medieval Times
episode_acts.summary: Ira takes a Medieval scholar from the University of Chicago, Michael Camille, to Medieval Times — a chain of fake castles where visitors eat Medieval food and drink Medieval Pepsi and watch a supposed recreation of a Medieval jousting tournament. The scholar finds that there are many historical inaccuracies, but that Medieval Times does capture something essential and interesting about the spirit of the Middle Ages.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Simulating Worlds On The Radio
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass worked for NPR's Morning Edition and All Things Considered for seventeen years, and shares a few thoughts on the devices he and his colleagues used to simulate the real world on those shows.

fields.episode_descript: The surprisingly entertaining story of how the U.S. got itself into a housing crisis.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to people who gather every week to watch the TV show Dark Shadows. (1 minute)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dark Shadows
episode_acts.summary: Ira continues his story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Scientists in a Haunted House
episode_acts.summary: An excerpt from Your Radio is Haunted. (6 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Vampire Girl
episode_acts.summary: An interview with Vampire Girl.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Evil Within
episode_acts.summary: Julie Showalter, on a costume she wore as a kid.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Gang Girl
episode_acts.summary: Gang Girl, on a body they thought was fake that turned out to be real.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Screams
episode_acts.summary: Greg Whitehead, with screams from the This American Life audience.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from acclaimed storyteller Spalding Gray and others.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Ski Lesson
episode_acts.summary: An excerpt from Spalding Gray's monologue It's a Slippery Slope. Gray has been called "America's premiere storyteller." His monologue Swimming To Cambodia was made into a feature film.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Swimming Lesson
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier's wife and mother-in-law insist that Scott's three-and-a-half year old daughter enroll in swimming classes.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Shooting Lesson
episode_acts.summary: Kitty Felde explores the mystic link between boys and guns when her cousin's husband, a liberal in Berkeley, gives her lessons in his newest toy: a gun that shoots potatoes 450 feet in the air. The "spud gun" has a special property: Any man who sees it instantly wants one.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Found Tape
episode_acts.summary: Excerpts from lessons found on old record, especially a Helen Gurley Brown disc called How to Love a Man, which instructs men on how to have an affair.

fields.episode_descript: Campaign diarist Michael Lewis, on his transformation into a television reporter, and on an inspiring moment in American politics between two supposed political enemies from the 1960's.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Life in the White House
episode_acts.summary: A visit to a replica of the White House outside San Francisco, the home of Norman and Rosemary Eckersly.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Television Man
episode_acts.summary: Campaign diarist Michael Lewis, on his transformation into a television reporter, and on an inspiring moment in American politics between two supposed political enemies from the 1960's.MIT Professor Henry Jenkins, on how candidates today campaign on cable and govern on the networks. (19 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Losers
episode_acts.summary: Radical right wing Mexican-American activist Daniel D.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Inspiration
episode_acts.summary: Michael Lewis, on McCain and Ifshin.

fields.episode_descript: Three stories of people trying to forget the past and move on.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When You're In Love, The Whole World Is Jewish
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the drama of trying to be "just friends" with an ex-girlfriend. The meaning of the title will be clear if you hear the piece.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Wishing For Amnesia
episode_acts.summary: Fiction writer George Saunders reads his story "Offloading for Mrs Schwartz," from his book CivilWarLand in Bad Decline. It's the story of someone who can't get over the death of his ex-wife.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Finding Amnesia
episode_acts.summary: Who among us has not wanted amnesia to help get over someone or something? But the problem with amnesia is that it happens a lot more in TV shows and movies and novels than it does in real life. We send reporter Scott Carrier to find someone who really has had amnesia.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dangerous Minds
episode_acts.summary: LuAnne Johnson is a teacher who sold her story to Hollywood and saw it made into the film and TV series Dangerous Minds, in which a character named LuAnne Johnson does things the real LuAnne believes are unethical and silly.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Undiscovered Country
episode_acts.summary: Found tape of a conversation about bringing back the dead.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Voyager
episode_acts.summary: Alix Spiegel tells the story of her friend Jayna, who made a Faustian bargain at 11 years old.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Carmen Becomes Faust
episode_acts.summary: Carmen Delzell on a deal she made with the devil when she turned 30.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: First Contact
episode_acts.summary: Daniel Pinkwater reads his children's picture book Devil in the Drain. (4 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: In the midst of the five biggest poultry-consumption weeks of the year—the five weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas, when Americans consume one-fourth of all the turkey they eat in a year—This American Life presents stories about turkeys, chickens, ducks, and fowl of all kinds.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Duki
episode_acts.summary: When Danielle's family serves poultry at their dinner table, no one utters the word "chicken." Instead, it is always called "fish." Danielle explains why with the help of her friend "Duki." (16 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Five Preview: Chickenman
episode_acts.summary: Chickenman was a short daily radio show airing from 1966 to 1969, and it was incredibly popular. It started locally on WCFL in Chicago, then proceeded to spread to over 1,500 radio stations.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Turkey
episode_acts.summary: Julie Showalter, who grew up on a turkey farm, tells the story of the night 3,000 turkeys died.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris tells of the giddiness he felt when he purchased a taxidermy's turkey head— attached to its foot.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: South African Chicken Blood
episode_acts.summary: Michael Stumm on the uses of chickens in South African sangoma (witch doctor) culture.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Chickenman, Like The Phoenix
episode_acts.summary: We invited Dick Orkin to create a new Chickenman episode for our Poultry Slam.

fields.episode_descript: Four stories about people struggling at the fringes of our nation's media/music/infotainment industry.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How To Get Famous
episode_acts.summary: Writer Sandra Tsing Loh on how she staged stunts to get press attention. She was wildly successful, featured in the Wall Street Journal, NPR, People Magazine, CNN, and in a Tonight Show monologue.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Whoring In Radio News
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier took a job in commercial radio working for a network correspondent he refers to as "The Friendly Man." Every story was supposed to be upbeat, a tale of people coming together in the heartwarming spirit of community. And every story they sent him on turned out to be a sham.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Small Personal Act
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell on the joy of making mix tapes of your favorite songs to send to loved ones. She spots an ad for someone who makes them for money. "Prostitute," she thinks.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Lifestyles Of The Rich And Famous
episode_acts.summary: Chicago writer Cheryl Trykv on her own close encounter with Hollywood, the media, and a famous maid.

fields.episode_descript: Though being gay no longer has much of a stigma in some parts of the country, being a sissy still does — even among gay men. In this show we have a number of surprising and unusual stories of sissies, their families, and why people still get so upset about them.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Anti-Oedipus
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Nancy Updike on a family where the father was one kind of sissy and the son was another kind, and how the family was destroyed despite the fact that no one wanted it to be.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Instructions For Sissies
episode_acts.summary: Chicago performance artist John Conners reads from a 1942 book called How To Improve Your Personality, from a chapter instructing men on how to avoid being sissies.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Pansy Kings Sing Songs Of Love
episode_acts.summary: Chicago writer and actor Dave Awl, who runs a show called the Pansy King Cotillion, on how he accidentally discovered how not to get picked on as a sissy in high school.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Other Love That Dare Not Speak Its Name
episode_acts.summary: Seattle writer and syndicated sex columnist Dan Savage, on how there's a stigma against sissies even among gay men. Gay personals ads are filled with men who want "straight acting/straight appearing" partners.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the intersection of Christmas and retail, originally broadcast in 1996 when our show was only a year old. Including David Sedaris's story "Santaland Diaries," which first aired on NPR's Morning Edition in a much shorter version.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Toys R Us
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to one of the epicenters of modern Christmas — the world's biggest toy store — minutes before closing on Christmas Eve.  (5 1/2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Santaland Diaries
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris's true account of two Christmas seasons he spent working as an elf at Macy's department store in New York.  When a shorter version of this story first aired on NPR's Morning Edition, it generated more tape requests than any story in the show's history to that point.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Christmas Freud
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff tells about his experience playing Sigmund Freud in the window of upscale Barney's department store in Manhattan. For Christmas. This was the first of dozens of appearances on our show by David Rakoff, who died in 2012.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Tapes recorded in a Chicago home Christmas morning, more than 50 years ago.

fields.episode_descript: They can't pronounce the names, can't read the maps, don't know the history, and are on an idealistic quest for justice that so far has not flowered. Kitty Felde, on Americans at the War Crimes Trial for the former Yugoslavia.

episode_acts.name: Act One: International Justice
episode_acts.summary: They can't pronounce the names, can't read the maps, don't know the history, and are on an idealistic quest for justice that so far has not flowered. Kitty Felde, on Americans at the War Crimes Trial for the former Yugoslavia.Interview with Michael Ignatieff about war crimes trials and truth commissions.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kids
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier visits a courtroom where teenagers are tried and convicted by their teenage peers in Tucson, Arizona.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Everyday Justice
episode_acts.summary: Tapes from the Apology Line and interview with "Mrs. Apology," Marissa Bridge.

fields.episode_descript: There’s one thing that has been proven to cut the achievement gap between black and white students by half: integration.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Samantha Martin trains raccoons to play basketball and rats to bowl. She says that what we want from animals is for them to imitate humans.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Food Chain In A New York Apartment
episode_acts.summary: Paul Tough visits Catherine Chalmers. She raises small animals and insects in her apartment, feeds them to each other, and photographs them eating each other.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: More Animals Eating Other Animals
episode_acts.summary: An original radio drama called "Kathleen on the Carpet," in which animals talk and hold their own "animal court." It's a comedy by David Sedaris, starring our own radio theater company, the Pinetree Gang.
episode_acts.byline: By The Pinetree Gang, David Rakoff, David Sedaris

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Moment When Humans Stopped Being Animals
episode_acts.summary: Anthropologists agree that humans stopped being animals when they started walking upright, on two legs. But scientists don't agree on why our ancestors did this.

fields.episode_descript: Kevin Kelly was in Jerusalem. For reasons too complicated to go into here, he ended up sleeping on the spot where Jesus was supposedly crucified. After Kevin awoke, he got rid of all his possessions. He visited his parents and brothers and sisters for the last time. That, and other stories of starting life over, including a visit to a courtroom in Los Angeles where people go to change their names.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira with a girl gang member about the day she nearly died.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Die In Six Months
episode_acts.summary: Kevin Kelly is interviewed.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Maybe Six Months
episode_acts.summary: The day Lawrence Steger left the AIDS clinic for the big road trip.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Claudia Perez talks about how her 21-year-old brother was shot and the family thought he'd die.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Hope
episode_acts.summary: Cheryl Trykv hears she's gonna live.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: On the Edge of the World
episode_acts.summary: The day Matthew Goulish saw Brigid.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who handle dead animals. Don't worry — it's not as gross as it sounds. In fact, not disgusting at all. A story by George Saunders about an animal control man who falls in unrequited love. A woman who studies illuminated manuscripts, whose pages look like paper but are in fact animals. And other stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira with an expert in medieval manuscripts, Sandy Hindman.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I'm Ferdinand. I'm Glad to be Your Steak Tonight
episode_acts.summary: Jay Allison presents a woman who "talks" to animals and a slaughterhouse owner.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The 400 Pound CEO
episode_acts.summary: Short fiction by George Saunders.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Dead Animal Man
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Clarence Hicks, who picks up dead animals for a living.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Redemption
episode_acts.summary: Jay Allison's story about Leo Brillo in Los Angeles who saves animals.

fields.episode_descript: Civil War reenactments, wax museums, simulated coal mines, fake ethnic restaurants, an ersatz Medieval castle, and other re-created worlds that thrive all across America.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Story of a romance that began in a mental hospital. Sometimes, the line between crazy and not crazy is blurry; certain behavior could mean either thing.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Girl, Interrupted
episode_acts.summary: Susanna Kaysen reads from her account of living at McLean psychiatric hospital for about two years, starting when she was eighteen. Her book, Girl, Interrupted, describes daily life on the ward.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Guided By Voices
episode_acts.summary: Dr Patricia Deegan hears voices in her head. She's a psychologist and she believes that the only way mental health workers can really understand what their patients go through is if they hear voices themselves.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Plague Of Tics
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris tells a story from his boyhood, when a voice inside his head commanded him to lick every light switch and tap his forehead with his heel. It's from his book Naked.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: You Don't Have To Be Crazy To Work Here, But It Helps
episode_acts.summary: Joel Lovell tells a story about working in a mental institution, and what it's like when it feels like your grip on the keys isn't so steady.

fields.episode_descript: For Valentine's Day, stories about our parents falling in love. And troubles with their love. From Hilton Als, Scott Carrier, Julie Showalter, a magazine column called Men My Mother Dated and others. The idea for this show was inspired by Delmore Schwartz's classic 1937 work of American fiction about his parents' courtship: In Dreams Begin Responsibilities and Other Stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira reads from In Dreams Begin Responsibilities. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lighten Up
episode_acts.summary: Brett Leveridge reads from his column for Might magazine, which he turned into the book Men My Mother Dated and Other Mostly True Tales.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mom, Dad, Bats
episode_acts.summary: A story by Bia Lowe.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It's Not the Heat
episode_acts.summary: Writer Julie Showalter on her parents' romance.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Negress
episode_acts.summary: Hilton Als reads an excerpt from his book The Women. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Parent And Child
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Scott Carrier and his eleven-year-old daughter Jesse. Scott wrote Running After Antelope.

fields.episode_descript: Stories, tributes, and attempts to understand the Chairman of the Board.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass, with a recording of a 1962 Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr., appearance at the Villa Venice, a club outside Chicago. What's fascinating about Sinatra is how he is so many different people at once, and they're all on display in this recording: sentimental crooner, cruel woman-baiter, bully, goofball.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Death Of Frank Sinatra
episode_acts.summary: Michael Ventura, who grew up Sicilian in New York, says that as a kid he thought Sinatra was in his family. His book The Death of Frank Sinatra is not really about Sinatra.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: One Sinatra Fan ... Versus All Of Network TV
episode_acts.summary: Before Sinatra died, Sarah Vowell appeared on this radio program and made a prediction about how network news would cover Sinatra's death ... and she made a simple plea. We hear whether her prediction came true.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: History Lesson
episode_acts.summary: Ira and music contributor John Conners on Sinatra's worst songs. And a brief history of what makes that 1950s Sinatra sound so great, with Will Friedwald, author of the definitive book on Sinatra's music, Sinatra! The Song Is You: A Singer's Art.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Sinatra Has A Cold
episode_acts.summary: Gay Talese reads from his classic 1966 Esquire article, in which he followed around Sinatra at the height of Sinatra's power.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: How Sinatra Affects Us
episode_acts.summary: New York writer Camden Joy tells what happened when in a greasy spoon restaurant filled with cabbies and club kids when Frank's film The Manchurian Candidate came on television. The whole place got silent, watched the film, and choked up.

fields.episode_title: Three Women and the Sex Industry
fields.episode_descript: A story about someone who's desperately trying – against long odds – to make it to the United States and become an American.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Sarah, who did phone sex and nude dancing.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Susan
episode_acts.summary: Sandy Tolan interviewed Susan's friends and family to make an unusual and powerful documentary about who she was and about the world she inhabited.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Striptease
episode_acts.summary: A story by therapist Lauren Slater about a case she had with a tough man obsessed with porn and how he changed.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people changing their name — some to create a new identity, some to con people. Name changes are particularly American stories: they're the dream of starting over with a clean slate. They're Ellis Island and 12-step programs, the move westward and self help, Marilyn Monroe and Malcolm X and the Artist Formerly Known as Prince, all rolled up in one.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass's grandmother.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Procedure
episode_acts.summary: A story by Margy Rochlin.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Baby Remember My Name
episode_acts.summary: A 17 year old tricks an entire resort town into believing he is someone he is not. By Jack Hitt and Christopher Cerf.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: As Seen On Tv
episode_acts.summary: Dishwasher Pete on Letterman.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Nom De Plume, Nom De Guerre
episode_acts.summary: How a guy named Tom became Camden Joy — and what he gained and what he lost. With Sarah Vowell.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the delivery business and the people in it. UPS men, bike messengers, FedEx dispatchers.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to the Federal Express hub at Memphis to watch 1.2 million pieces of overnight mail get sorted in one night and to talk to the adrenaline junkies in the FedEx Command Center.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Speed
episode_acts.summary: Tony Starbucks, interviewed by Dierdre Dolan and Paul Tough.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Who You Meet
episode_acts.summary: "Edison, New Jersey," a story about delivering pool tables from Junot Diaz's book Drown.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: World Premiere
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris play, with Toby Wherry and Penelope Boyer.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Check Out the Package on That Guy
episode_acts.summary: Nancy Updike and UPS Men.

fields.episode_descript: We head to some of the happiest places on earth: amusement parks!

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The small town dilemma.

episode_acts.name: Act One: City Mouse, Country Mouse
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell and her family.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How Do You Keep Them Down On The Farm? Marry Them
episode_acts.summary: Singles in Agriculture. By reporter Liz Weil and Alix Spiegel.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Small Town In The Big City
episode_acts.summary: Paul Johnson, Carlos Appleby, and Sanantonio Brooks talk about how their housing project is like a small town.

fields.episode_descript: Civil War reenactments, wax museums, simulated coal mines, fake ethnic restaurants, an ersatz Medieval castle, and other re-created worlds that thrive all across America.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Firestarter
episode_acts.summary: Why one teenager set fires and then stopped setting them. Paul Tough interview.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Centralia
episode_acts.summary: An inextinguishable subterranean fire on the edge of a small Pennsylvania town, and why the residents are not afraid of it. Host Ira Glass and This American Life contributor Alix Spiegel.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fearless
episode_acts.summary: Producer Nancy Updike with Ki Kim, who's not afraid of walking on coals. But maybe he should have been.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Big Picture
episode_acts.summary: Professor Stephen Pyne.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Fire Within
episode_acts.summary: Rennie Sparks from the band The Handsome Family.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Kaddish
episode_acts.summary: An Allen Ginsberg poem and Ira Glass.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Undertaking
episode_acts.summary: Thomas Lynch reads from his book The Undertaking: Life Studies from the Dismal Trade.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Forbidden Zone
episode_acts.summary: Michael Lesy reads.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fireman
episode_acts.summary: Actor Michael Stumm reads from fireman and fiction writer Larry Brown's book On Fire.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Smugglers
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris on an unwelcome surprise in a toilet — a turd.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Happiest Death Worker
episode_acts.summary: Meema Spadola with Lou Zeidberg.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong. When you leave the normal realm of human error, fumble, mishap, and mistake and enter the territory of really huge breakdowns. Fiascos. Things go so awry that normal social order collapses. This week's show is a philosophical inquiry in the nature of fiascos — perhaps the first ever.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Opening Night
episode_acts.summary: Writer Jack Hitt tells the story of a small town production of Peter Pan, in which the flying apparatus smacks the actors into the furniture, and Captain Hook's hook flies off his arm and hits an old woman in the stomach. By the end of the evening, firemen have arrived and all the normal boundaries between audience and actors have completely dissolved.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What We Wanted To Do
episode_acts.summary: A medieval village, a 1900-pound brass kettle, marauding visigoths, and a plan to drench invaders with boiling oil that goes awry. From Ron Carlson's book The Hotel Eden, read by Chicago actor Jeff Dorchen.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Car Wars
episode_acts.summary: Wisconsin Public Radio wanted to do something simple: start running Car Talk, the most popular single hour on public radio. But to do this, they had to move their local car show, About Cars, from the morning to the afternoon.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Fiascos As A Force For Good
episode_acts.summary: Journalist Margy Rochlin on her first big assignment to do a celebrity interview. It was 1982.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to get rich quick or otherwise make something for nothing. As everyone knows, there's no such thing as something for nothing. You always pay a price.

episode_acts.name: Lottery Players
episode_acts.summary: Ira visits the lottery stand in Chicago that sells more lottery tickets than any other: Hannah's Finer Food & Liquors. There he meets two men who want to get rich quick.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hands On A Hardbody
episode_acts.summary: A contest held every year by a Nissan dealership in Longview, Texas in which twenty-four people stand around a $15,000 hard body pickup truck. When the starting whistle blows, each person puts one hand on the truck.
episode_acts.byline: By Rob Bindler, Kevin Morse, Chapin Wilson

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Guinea Pig Zero
episode_acts.summary: Ira interviews Bob Helms, creator of the zine Guinea Pig Zero, which is about people who make their living by donating their bodies to science for medical experiments. Bob says he wouldn't do spinal tap studies or psychoactive drugs (he calls the people who do the latter "brain sluts").

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Tao Of The Dumpster
episode_acts.summary: Writer Dirk Jamison, who gave up a 9-to-5 job and succeeded in getting something for nothing: he decided he'd feed the family by diving into dumpsters for free food. His father's very zen attitude about this, and how it affected the family.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Another Success Story
episode_acts.summary: Hollywood is all about the idea of getting something for nothing, and no show on the subject would be complete without a Hollywood story. Writer Sandra Tsing Loh provides it.

fields.episode_descript: Freezing dead people so scientists can reanimate them in the future is a lot harder than it sounds.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with a gang kid who turned to Jesus with the same ferocity and dedication with which he served his old street gang.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Life Without Leanne
episode_acts.summary: A story by Larry Doyle.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Inescapable Logic
episode_acts.summary: Beau O'Reilly tells the story of a man who tried to run for President as a utopian nudist.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: More Than One Thing
episode_acts.summary: How journalist Philip Weiss came to agree with some Clinton conspiracy theorists but not to follow their cause. With Paul Tough.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Quitting Quitting
episode_acts.summary: This American Life gets a return visit from Evan Harris, the woman who used to believe that quitting was the one thing at the heart of all human existence.

fields.episode_descript: Stories for the start of summer. We want summer to be this wonderful break, but so often it fails to deliver. We hear Ron Carlson's short story about a summer job delivering tanks of oxygen to the infirm, Scott Carrier takes a river vacation, and more.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Julie throws up.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Ron Carlson's short story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: On The Green River
episode_acts.summary: We begin to hear a story by Scott Carrier.

fields.episode_descript: Notes and stories about the Canadians among us. Are they in fact any different from red-blooded Americans? They claim they're not. Skeptical Americans put their position to the test.

episode_acts.name: Passing
episode_acts.summary: The true story of a dinner conversation in which several Americans came to realize how many iconic Americans are, in fact, Canadian. "If William Shatner's Canadian," one insists, "then I could be Canadian." Another opines that there should be a law against Peter Jennings, a Canadian, hosting a network news program.

episode_acts.name: Act One: White Like Me
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff on how he tried to pass as a local once he moved from Toronto to New York. He claims that there must be a chip in his head — or something like it — that automatically tells him when someone or something famous is Canadian.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The World's Most Perfect Pneumatic Vacuum
episode_acts.summary: Canadians not getting any respect in two locales: A town called Little Canada, Minnesota; and in Canada, where a guy doing a Canadian-heritage art project gets ribbed by his neighbors, who joke that there is no Canadian culture to celebrate. Then, Sarah Vowell speaks with Ian Brown, formerly the host of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's long-running program Sunday Morning. They arm wrestle over what it means to be a Canadian, what it means to be an American, and whether the two are the same.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Outing
episode_acts.summary: Or is that "Ooting?" 90210 expert Danny Drennan on the pro-Canadian bias in the hit TV show Beverly Hills 90210 now that Canadian Jason Priestly is not just a star of the show, but a producer and director as well.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Who's Canadian?
episode_acts.summary: A tale of two siblings — separated, but not at birth. Reporter Paul Tough and his sister grew up in Toronto, the most American of Canadian cities.

fields.episode_descript: No description available.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: No summary available.

fields.episode_descript: Could it be more obvious? Stories in which someone's dream is someone else's nightmare. All of us get into these situations with strangers, with the people we love most, with our own parents, with our children.

episode_acts.name: Your House, My Nightmare
episode_acts.summary: Ira with 19-year-old Claudia Perez at a furniture store in Claudia's Mexican neighborhood.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Noise
episode_acts.summary: Writer Sarah Vowell goes to Rock-n-Roll Fantasy Camp in Miami Beach.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Colors
episode_acts.summary: An interracial couple takes a plantation tour.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Motion
episode_acts.summary: Jay Allison on people moving into their dream neighborhoods, and their new neighbors' reactions.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Blood
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Sedaris on parents' dreams and children's nightmares.

fields.episode_descript: A locksmith tells the story of an act of kindness he committed, hoping for a small reward. That, and other stories of kindness in New York City.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains that today's show begins in 1865 and ends today. Ira reads briefly from Lincoln's Second Inaugural address, which describes slavery as America's Original Sin of sorts.

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Modern Politician, His God, And The Confederate Flag
episode_acts.summary: South Carolina native Jack Hitt discusses the Confederate Flag's prominent place over the statehouse.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Nelson Mandela And Abraham Lincoln
episode_acts.summary: Some stunning parallels between the political strategies of the two leaders, by John Matisonn.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Good Blacks, Bad Blacks
episode_acts.summary: Writer Malcolm Gladwell, reads from a story that he first wrote for the New Yorker magazine about his cousins, who immigrated to the U.S. from Jamaica 12 years ago.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Good Whites, Bad Whites
episode_acts.summary: A documentary by Cecilia Vaisman and Christina Egloff, with Jay Allison, about a white woman named Carolyn Wren Shannon, who grew up hating blacks in a Catholic neighborhood, and how her attitudes change.
episode_acts.byline: By Jay Allison, Christina Egloff, Cecilia Vaisman

fields.episode_descript: How many of our parents move to some place — some dream house — with some vision of a new life in the new place, and move the family with them, hoping it works out for the kids. Three stories on this theme.

episode_acts.name: Commune Dream House
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Amanda, who's 16 and lives with her mom in a Christian commune in Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Meema's Adventure
episode_acts.summary: A family dreams of life in rural Maine, moves there, and then things get really complicated.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Blue Sky Dream
episode_acts.summary: David Beers explains the gorgeous, modern vision that drew his family, and tons of other families, to California, and then what happened after they arrived.

fields.episode_descript: Richard Lyons, from the band Negativland, tells the story of a Xeroxed book he put together for a few friends. It's photos of smashed-up cars in a junkyard. Next to each crumpled car is reprinted the text of a note or letter or list found in the car. The effect is poignant. Lyons describes the photos and reads from the notes and letters found in the cars. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Pete found a bag of maybe a hundred letters in a dumpster and found himself completely wrapped up in the lives of the two people in the letters.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dead Letters
episode_acts.summary: Richard Lyons, from the band Negativland, tells the story of a Xeroxed book he put together for a few friends. It's photos of smashed-up cars in a junkyard.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Thief
episode_acts.summary: There can be consequences for reading other people's mail.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Saviors
episode_acts.summary: If you work for the post office and read other people's mail, you can lose your job or go to prison. Unless you work at a Mail Recovery Center.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Golden Rule
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell puts her foot down. She says that contrary to all the wide-eyed voyeurs we've heard up until this point in the program, reading other people's mail is wrong, simply wrong.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when of a group of public school students in the Bronx goes to visit an elite private school three miles away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Walt Strommer, on Dreams of Disabled People.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Road Trip
episode_acts.summary: Photographer Joel Meyerowitz decided to go on a last big trip with his father, Hy, who has Alzheimer's. Joel also brought his own son.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: My World Record
episode_acts.summary: A hemophiliac teenager who tries to set world records and to motocross.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Iron Man
episode_acts.summary: Mark O'Brien is a writer in California, who lives most of each day in an iron lung, thanks to a childhood case of polio. It's an excerpt from Jessica Yu's Oscar-winning documentary.

fields.episode_descript: An idiosyncratic first-person travelogue about race relations and tourism from radio producer Rich Robinson and television producer Josh Seftel. Their radio story is about a trip they took to the new South Africa. Rich Robinson is black. Josh Seftel is white. The interracial pair travel through the still mostly-segregated society and have very different opinions about what they see, especially when it comes to some distant relatives of Josh's in South Africa.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: More than England, or Japan or Israel.... When we think of South Africa, it's a more interesting mirror of the United States than nearly any country, because we glimpse a distant echo of the most frightening parts of American society — and the most inspiring.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: The first part of Josh Seftel and Rich Robinson's documentary about South Africa. Josh meets people who may be distant South African relatives.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Josh Seftel and Rich Robinson's trek across South Africa continues. They head to the "South African Woodstock" and to a group that's half Nancy Reagan's "Just Say No" campaign and half terrorist campaign.

fields.episode_descript: The darker side of the art world: petty jealousies, competitiveness, failure. And also what's so great about art.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
