episode_acts.summary: Foreign correspondent Jim Biederman reports from a cell phone inside the Louvre, in front of the Mona Lisa, on what people say while they're standing in front of some of the world's greatest works of art. It turns out to be pretty banal.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Life In A Bubble
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Paul Tough talks with Aaron Hsu-Flanders, an acknowledged master in the field of animal balloons, who says that artistic jealousies have ruined his life. Even in the world of latex giraffes and doggies, there are artistic rivalries and bitterness.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Still Life
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris recounts his shameful career as a performance artist. Recorded before a live audience by KUOW Seattle.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Reverb
episode_acts.summary: Ellery Eskelin never met his father but always heard he was a musical genius. Years after his father's death, Ellery started finding recordings of his musical output: he was the king of "song-poems." These are the songs that result when people answer those ads in the backs of magazines that say, "Send us your lyrics, and we'll write and record your song." Ellery's father's musical output was prodigious — and very odd.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Grace Note
episode_acts.summary: After all this doom and gloom about the difficult lives of artists, we end the show with a more hopeful story from Joel Kostman, a New York City locksmith, who tells us about an incident that happened to him on the job. Joel is author of Keys to the City: Tales of a New York City Locksmith.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when people with one common interest gather in monstrous, fluorescent-lit halls for the weekend? Sometimes they drive each other crazy, sometimes they fall in love.

episode_acts.name: Convention worker
episode_acts.summary: Andrea worked at a bakery under a convention hotel in Chicago. The conventioneers used to drive her crazy because people act so different when they're in a crowd of their own kind.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dark Shadows
episode_acts.summary: John Connors has very mixed emotions about attending a convention for viewers of the TV program Dark Shadows.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dish Out Of Water
episode_acts.summary: Dishwasher Pete, author of the book Dishwasher: One Man's Quest to Wash Dishes in All Fifty States, went to the National Restaurant Association convention on assignment from This American Life.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When Worlds Collide
episode_acts.summary: John Perry Barlow, a founder of the Electronic Frontier Foundation and former rancher and Grateful Dead lyricist, on an experience that began at the boundary of two conventions.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of the kindness of strangers and where it leads. Also, the unkindness of strangers and where that can lead. All of today's stories take place in the city most people think of as the least kind city in America: New York.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Brett Leveridge was standing on the subway. A guy comes walking down the platform, stopping in front of each passenger and delivering a quiet verdict: "You're in.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Tarzan Finds A Mate
episode_acts.summary: New York City locksmith Joel Kostman tells the story of an act of kindness he committed, hoping for a small reward. From his book: Keys to the City: Tales of a New York City Locksmith.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Runaway
episode_acts.summary: In 1940, Jack Geiger, at the age of fourteen, left his middle-class Jewish home and knocked on the door of a black actor named Canada Lee. He asked Lee if he could move in with him.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Unkindness Of Strangers
episode_acts.summary: How two next-door neighbors start treating each other badly, and how, once they start, they become obsessed with each other. Paul Tough reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Chairman Of The Block
episode_acts.summary: An odd occurrence at 124 East Fourth Street in Manhattan's East Village. For the last five weeks, a singer named Nick Drakides has stood on the stoop singing Sinatra songs late at night to the delight of his neighbors.

fields.episode_descript: The mob as portrayed in movies, and as it is in real life. And its hold over us.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Danny Toro, a member of a Chicago street gang for ten years, explains what gangster movies he liked most in his gang years and why. Scarface, with Al Pacino, was a good movie to get him pumped up to go out with his boys. A Lucky Luciano film taught him a lesson in how to be more compassionate with members of his own gang.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Freshman
episode_acts.summary: Writer Sarah Vowell explains why she watched The Godfather every day while she was in college. The film, she says, depicted a world with an understandable moral system to it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Gangster's Daughter
episode_acts.summary: Susan Berman, author of the memoir Easy Street, the True Story of a Gangster's Daugher, reads from her book about her father Davie Berman, a Jewish gangster and one of the men — with Meyer Lansky and Bugsy Siegel — who created modern Las Vegas. (7 minutes) Act Two continues after the break.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Neighbors To The Mob
episode_acts.summary: Jerry Capeci, dean of the New York reporters who cover organized crime, on the decline of the mob in recent years. And Alec Wilkinson of the New Yorker magazine, who discusses a photo his wife took of his old neighbors, the Gambino crime family.

fields.episode_descript: Can the secular world and the religious world understand each other? We ask that question while visiting Colorado Springs, Colorado, where Pastor Ted Haggard at the New Life Church has put in place a project to pray in front of the home of every person in the city, systematically, block by block and house by house. He's also helped organize a 24-hour, 365-day-a-year "prayer shield" over the city; all-night prayer vigils; and more.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Mary and Manfred Rauer have been married 22 years. He's a devout Christian, goes to church every week, reads the Bible every day, was head of his congregation.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Exodus
episode_acts.summary: Alix Spiegel in Colorado Springs, where a massive prayer project is underway to pray for every person, business, and school. When she arrives, she finds the Christians speak a kind of Christian jargon she does not understand.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kings
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier in Salt Lake City with a story about whether it's possible to be a good person if you're not a Christian.

fields.episode_descript: How bad is bad enough to count? To go to hell?

episode_acts.name: Act One: How Bad Is Stealing $800?
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to three teenage boys who buy computer equipment using stolen credit card numbers.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Golden Peacock
episode_acts.summary: We told Chicago playwright Jeff Dorchen about what the three boys in Act One said, and he created a brief original radio play picking up where they left off.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How Bad Is This Relationship?
episode_acts.summary: The people of Chicago speak out.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: How Bad Is That Movie?
episode_acts.summary: Howard Rabinowitz and The Truth About Cats and Dogs. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Act Five
episode_acts.summary: First, an interview with Jim Nelson, then, an interview with Eli, a computer hacker who was thrown in prison by federal authorities for his crimes.

fields.episode_descript: People stuck in the wrong decade, or simply carrying a lot of the props from another decade.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A communist, the filmmaker Marcel Ophuls, the band Camper Van Beethoven, and other people who may be stuck in the wrong decade.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Wedding Game
episode_acts.summary: Karl T. Wright's and Wendy Miller's game show wedding.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Stuck As A Teenager
episode_acts.summary: A former addict and a former prisoner discuss the developmental retardation their experiences caused.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Perv Walk
episode_acts.summary: New York writer Sarah Miller talks about two men she knows.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Nostalgia: The Final Frontier
episode_acts.summary: Jeff Dorchen reads Italo Calvino's short story All At One Point from Calvino's book Cosmicomics.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people engaged in a battle with nature — a battle they don't stand much chance of winning. Most of the show is Scott Carrier's story of trying for twelve years to chase down and catch an antelope by foot.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass, on the beach with Chris McKinney, a boy scout who is single-handedly trying to stop erosion on one stretch of beach in Mason Neck State Park in Virginia.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Running After Antelope
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier in Salt Lake City with the latest installment in his 12-year quest to chase down and catch an antelope. This story and others are included in his book Running After Antelope.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Natural Disaster
episode_acts.summary: How an audience of children derailed Late Night with Conan O'Brien.

fields.episode_descript: Americans who love their guns, and the Americans who love them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads an ad from American Handgunner. People who love guns and people who hate them have a hard time seeing eye to eye, but this ad bridges the gap. As this week's show does.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Nra Vs Nea
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell goes home to Montana to try and understand her gunsmith dad a little better.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fists And Guns
episode_acts.summary: Geoffrey Canada, author of the book Fist Stick Knife Gun: A Personal History of Violence in America, talks about what it's like to carry a gun. He also talks about what poor neighborhoods in New York were like before the proliferation of handguns among young people.  When he grew up in the South Bronx, kids had fistfights in a very formal arrangement with formal rules that everyone lived by. He reads from his book and talks with Ira.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Shooter
episode_acts.summary: Chicago Playwright Bryn Magnus with a quintessential gun story from his childhood in Wisconsin.  It contains both the fear of guns and the pleasure of shooting one.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Potato Potahto
episode_acts.summary: Two people who've nearly died in gun battles describe what it's like, getting shot at. They draw opposite conclusions from their near death experiences.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Straw Man
episode_acts.summary: Chicago writer Tori Marlan with a man who sold guns to criminals for two years, and what he makes of the experience. Most of the illegal guns on the street were actually purchased legally.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are haunted, not by ghosts or phantoms, but by other people.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira reads an excerpt from James Ellroy's memoir My Dark Places.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hearing Voices
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Lynnette Nyman, who, as a girl, recorded her parents fighting with a cassette recorder she got for Christmas.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Binjamin Wilkomirski and New York writer Blake Eskin try and figure out if they are related. NOTE: A few years after this interview aired, Binjamin Wilkomirski and his Holocaust memoir Fragments were shown to be fabrications. Blake Eskin chronicled this story in his 2002 book A Life In Pieces: The Making and Unmaking of Binjamin Wilkomirski.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ashes
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris, on his mother's lung cancer.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Ghost Story
episode_acts.summary: An excerpt from Heather Woodbury's epic eight-hour solo show WhatEver: An American Odyssey in Eight Acts.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with "Jim Steel," who tells a story about the social rules at his high school in Wisconsin.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Crap Life
episode_acts.summary: Writer Tim Melley.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: My Worklife
episode_acts.summary: Independent producer Dan Collison, on Pilottown and a feature story that fell apart.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: My Church Life
episode_acts.summary: Susan Bergman and the Christian convention. Susan is the author of Anonymity.

fields.episode_descript: The story of Harold Washington, the greatest politician you've probably never heard of, and the white backlash that was set off when he became Chicago's first black mayor. This weekend is the 30th anniversary of his death.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A look at the Chicago political machine in the days before our story begins.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Yesterday
episode_acts.summary: A history of the brief mayoral career of Harold Washington, and its lessons for black and white America, as told by people close to him. Many are activists and politicians: Lu Palmer, Judge Eugene Pincham, Congressman Danny Davis, then-alderman Eugene Sawyer.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Present and the Future
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks with David Axelrod, who was an advisor to Harold Washington and to Barack Obama as well. In 2007, when we last broadcast this show, Ira recorded an interview with Axelrod who was riding on Obama’s campaign bus, during the Democratic Primary in Iowa.

fields.episode_descript: What’s recovery mean, anyway?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads from a letter Benjamin Franklin wrote, and discusses it with Jack Hitt.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Chicken Diva
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt reports on one woman's opera about Chicken Little.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Headless Chicken In Topless Bar
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Lloyd Natoff, on killing chickens.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Duck Warrior
episode_acts.summary: Michael Lewis on duck hunting.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Trying To Respect A Chicken
episode_acts.summary: Ira with chicken photographer Tamara Staples.

fields.episode_title: How to Take Money from Strangers
fields.episode_descript: Two stories of how to get money from strangers. In both stories, the money is made by people who make the strangers feel good about themselves and about their nation.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Saint Nick
episode_acts.summary: A con man named Nick Ward who's so good he's thanked.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What Makes Grammy Run?
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell, on selling the secrets of art dealer Graham Arader.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from David Sedaris's book of Christmas stories, Holidays on Ice, read onstage by David, Julia Sweeney and actor Matt Malloy.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: How David Sedaris became a Christmas writer — and how he started writing stories about the holiday that are so dark that sometimes it seems that he's trying to single handedly destroy Christmas. We hear from members of David's own family, and from David, all of whom insist that David loves Christmas.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Front Row Center With Thaddeus Bristol
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads this story. A high-powered theater critic applies his critical skills to the Christmas pageants at local elementary schools.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Seasons Greetings To Our Friends And Family!
episode_acts.summary: Julia Sweeney reads this story. She's a former Saturday Night Live cast member and star of the sad and comic memoir of life with cancer, God Said, "Ha!," which played on Broadway.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Based On A True Story
episode_acts.summary: A Hollywood TV producer tries to convince a church of evangelical Christians to sell out a member of their own congregation. Matt Malloy reads. He was one of the stars of the acclaimed independent film In the Company of Men.Also in this act: Dickens vs.
episode_acts.byline: By Ira Glass, Matt Malloy, David Sedaris

fields.episode_descript: Numbers lie. Numbers cover over complicated feelings and ambiguous situations. In this week's show, stories of people trying to use numbers to describe things that should not be quantified.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When she began working as a temp secretary in San Francisco, learning the computers, wasting time, Andrea put together a graph with Microsoft Excel. Its title: My Love Life: A Ten Year Span. It made her feel good.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Corporate Culture
episode_acts.summary: D. Travers Scott and his boyfriend spent six months gathering data on their own relationship and put together a report on it in the form of a corporate annual report.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Paint By Numbers
episode_acts.summary: Alex Melamid and Vitaly Komar hired a polling firm to investigate what people want to see in paintings. Then, using the data, they painted what people want.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When Days Are Numbered
episode_acts.summary: Jerry Davidson has been keeping a list of everything he's done since 1955 when he was ten years old. What makes it on the lists is very odd, and what isn't included is most of his feelings.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Salesman
episode_acts.summary: Will Powers — his real name — decided to try to use all the tools of modern brand marketing to sell himself to his own wife. It turned out to help their marriage.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Break It Down
episode_acts.summary: A man tries to calculate what love costs. From Lydia Davis's book Break It Down, read by actor Matt Malloy.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Two quick real life fables about the power of sibling rivalry.

episode_acts.name: Act One: He Is Heavy, He's My Brother
episode_acts.summary: True tales of sibling cruelty.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Drama Of The Gifted Child's Sister
episode_acts.summary: Tamar Brott, on growing up with two music prodigies, and Sandra Tsing Loh's sister Kaitlin, a ballet prodigy.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Destiny
episode_acts.summary: Deb Monroe's two daughters as they fight.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Fraternity Is Destiny
episode_acts.summary: Writer Donald Antrim's The Hundred Brothers, and the question: What happens when we grow up? (24 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Stories of who we are on the phone, of things we learn on the phone, and of things that happen on the phone that don't happen anywhere else.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains why some old answering machine messages from a decade ago have such power for him: there's a special power to recordings of phone conversations. The phone is intimate — more intimate than a photograph.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When The Wall Came Tumbling Down
episode_acts.summary: The story of a teenager, illegal drug use, lying, stealing, and a kid's life changed completely when he heard how he sounded on the phone.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: When The Telephone Is Your Medium
episode_acts.summary: Sure you can try to get your pop songs onto records, or on the radio, or onto MTV. But what happens if your medium of choice is ... the telephone? Before they had record contracts, the band They Might Be Giants distributed their songs through the medium of Answering Machine.
episode_acts.byline: By They Might Be Giants, Sarah Vowell

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Phone As History
episode_acts.summary: We think of our phone calls and phone messages as so transient. We have another example of phones recording personal history: this story from Barrett Golding in Bozeman, Montana, comprised of telephone messages about his father.

fields.episode_descript: David Cale's Lillian. Mild sexual content in this story. (26 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: An American Girl Turns 18
episode_acts.summary: Sylvia's parents are immigrants who want her to be a traditional girl.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 33 Million Dollar Box
episode_acts.summary: Barry Miller, a Cincinnati millionaire who robbed a bank — and was caught. Alex Blumberg reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Feeling You Want, And The Feeling You Get
episode_acts.summary: David Cale's Lillian.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about those moments when someone tries to tell you a little bit more about themselves than you'd really rather know.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Margy's a reporter. When she told her dad that she wanted to write a story about him, he said sure.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Father's Day
episode_acts.summary: Margy Rochlin sees a new side of her father when, in his seventies, he becomes a monologist like Spalding Gray. Her dad, Fred Rochlin, is a huge hit.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mama, Can You Hear Me?
episode_acts.summary: In which Dan Savage, who makes his living writing a nationally syndicated sex advice column, admits that there's one group of people he does not want to discuss sex with. Ever.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Unmasking
episode_acts.summary: A story of guys who wear real masks, like superheroes, in their jobs as costumed wrestlers in a kind of Mexican wrestling called Lucha Libre. Writer RJ Smith has them talk about how much smaller they feel, how humiliated, when they have to take the masks off.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about couples that all take place decades after that moment their eyes first meet.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Richard Klein of Cornell University explains that the way we view love really began with love poems in the 13th century — an illusion.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Before And After
episode_acts.summary: Richard Bausch reads his story Letter to the Lady of the House.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: I Met Him In The Yogurt Store, And Now He Is Not My Leader Of The Pack
episode_acts.summary: Linda Howard and Richard Bloom, in Boca Raton Florida, had been married years when she started flirting with another man.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Without
episode_acts.summary: Poet Donald Hall reads about his wife Jane Kenyon, who contracted leukemia, went through treatment, and died. His book is also called Without: Poems.

fields.episode_descript: What happens during a "how-to," and what our how-to's say about us. Most how-to's promise that you'll not only learn skills, you'll be transformed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Brooklyn schoolteacher Melissa Cantor, who reads from a how-to manual written by a sixth-grade student. It's about how to protect yourself against unwanted visitors.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Roadrunner
episode_acts.summary: Ira teaches Sarah Vowell how to drive with some advice from Tom and Ray Maggliozi, the hosts of NPR's Car Talk. It turns out that although we think of how-to's as the most rational thing in the world — follow the simple instructions and you'll learn — in real life, they're anything but simple.
episode_acts.byline: By Ira Glass, Tom and Ray Maggliozi, Sarah Vowell

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How To Date A Browngirl, Blackgirl, Whitegirl, Or Halfie
episode_acts.summary: A how-to by Junot Diaz, from his book Drown.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How To Increase Your Value As A Person
episode_acts.summary: In which we tackle the biggest possible how-to we could think of: how to make your life worth more. And we get answers — real, practical answers — from the people whose job it is to think about this issue: insurance adjusters.

fields.episode_descript: How should we react to people who are in non-monogamous relationships? What should we think of these struggles with monogamy?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In the early stages of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, there was a period when one of the questions raised by the whole affair had to do with monogamy. Around that time, Roy Romer, the Governor of Colorado and Chair of the Democratic Party, admitted that for 16 years he'd had a relationship with an aide that his wife and family knew about.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Scientific Experiment
episode_acts.summary: Chris and Sylvere, and how they tried to contain a marriage-threatening crush, and how difficult that is.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Love And Happiness
episode_acts.summary: Writer and nationally syndicated sex columnist Dan Savage explains what actually happens in non-monogamous couples, how they make it work, and whether they're happy.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Istanbul
episode_acts.summary: Ian Brown of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation on the normal struggle most people experience when they try to stay monogamous.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when of a group of public school students in the Bronx goes to visit an elite private school three miles away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Jan Tomare, who spent three years in the Auschwitz concentration camp.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Book Of Job
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Scott Carrier does a story about Harvey "Job" Matusow.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: God Of War
episode_acts.summary: In Vietnam, Jeffrey Harris, with one year of grad school, judged which soldiers stayed and which went home.

fields.episode_descript: An assault on the idea of wackiness. And then, an appreciation of wackiness, and an analysis of wackiness in American culture. Thirteen ways to describe wackiness.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and the movie Fast, Cheap & Out of Control. Advertised as wacky, it is anything but.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Negative
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris tells true stories of photographers who try to take pictures of him which will make him seem more "wacky" than in fact he is, interlaced with a fictional depiction of what one of these photographers is like.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Good, The Bad, And The Wacky
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Josh Glenn, editor of Hermenaut, who explains the difference between Good Wacky and Bad Wacky.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Politics Of Wackiness
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Michael Lewis, author of Losers: The Road to Everyplace but the White House and many other books, who says that in the '96 Presidential Election all the candidates with new ideas, all the candidates capable of talking the way real people act in their real lives, were shunned by the media as "wacky." (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Eleven: Self-Made Wacky
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Maria, who took out a personals ad in the Chicago Reader advertising herself as "wacky and warm." (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Twelve: Evading Wacky And Serious
episode_acts.summary: Robert Krulwich's stories, on NPR, CBS and ABC, are neither wacky nor pompously serious. He explains, though, that if you try to occupy the territory between wacky and serious, there are dangers.

episode_acts.name: Act Thirteen: Dr. Jeckyl And Mr. Wacky
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell with Jim Nayder, host of Magnificent Obsession and The Annoying Music Show, who personifies our culture's split between seriousness and wackiness as well as anyone.

fields.episode_descript: Manny Howard talks with Paul Tough about why he loved fighting in bars and on the street, and about how hard it is to quit. Manny is the author of My Empire of Dirt: How One Man Turned His Big-City Backyard into a Farm. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Pierre, a ten year old who boxes in an amateur team on Chicago's south side, and what Muhammad Ali had to do to psych up to win a fight.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I'd Probably Slug Jesus
episode_acts.summary: Manny Howard talks with Paul Tough about why he loved fighting in bars and on the street, and about how hard it is to quit. Manny is the author of My Empire of Dirt: How One Man Turned His Big-City Backyard into a Farm.
episode_acts.byline: By The Kitchen Sisters, Paul Tough

episode_acts.name: Act Two: To Boldly Go Where No Woman Has Gone Before
episode_acts.summary: Meema Spadola follows Maritza, a New Yorker who loves to box and has the skill to go pro, but who's not going pro.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Hard Work
episode_acts.summary: Frankie Cruz Junior takes on all contenders at a nightclub in Chicago, and nearly always wins. It's a terrible job that pays badly and has no insurance or other benefits.

fields.episode_title: I Enjoy Being A Girl, Sort Of
fields.episode_descript: Variations on what it means to be a girl and what it means to be a woman.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A high school student named Rebecca tells the story of a friend of hers who changed over the course of four years from a preppy alternative kid to a member of the Latina clique to a ghetto girl to a Clueless girl (a girl who models herself after the girls in the film and TV show Clueless). It's hard to imagine many boys changing style this quickly, this willfully, this many times.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fatty Suit
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris with a parable of the pressures on modern women, and how one woman — his sister — responded. David's father thought it was very important that his daughters be thin.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How To Be A Man
episode_acts.summary: Writer Sarah Miller attends a class on how to walk and talk and act like a man. It's not easy.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Strength In Numbers
episode_acts.summary: Ira with "The Hens," a group of nine middle-aged women who've known each other since girlhood. They play recordings of their recent three-day road trip from Chicago to a casino in a cotton field in Mississippi.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Taking Sisterhood One Step Further
episode_acts.summary: Ira with Elizabeth Joseph, who is in a polygamous marriage with eight wives and one husband. She says polygamy is the ultimate feminist lifestyle.

fields.episode_descript: For the 100th episode of This American Life, a radio show about the pleasures of radio. About what makes radio so great, and what makes it so terrible.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about those ephemeral, thrilling radio moments that you happen to catch in passing on stations far away that you never find again. Flipping through the channels.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Brigadoon
episode_acts.summary: Iggy Scam describes how he searched for an illegal radio station that keeps appearing and disappearing and appearing again in the mist.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Invisible Leading The Blind
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt talks about a radio station he chanced upon while on a long drive. The station seems to ignore the last six decades of broadcasting history and convention.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Radio Most People Listen To
episode_acts.summary: How the science of radio enabled V103 to become tied for number one in the Chicago market. And how it cost DJ Ida Hackele her job.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Noble Calling
episode_acts.summary: Now in exile, Jose Ramos Horta spent two decades as the leading international spokesman against the invasion of his country by Indonesia. He won a Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts.

fields.episode_descript: The story of Niagara Falls, a town that started with something huge—the falls—and built nothing lasting from it. During this hour, a special edition of our show: Stories about Niagara Falls, half of them from documentary producer Alix Spiegel, who went to the Falls and interviewed people living there; and half from playwright David Kodeski, who grew up in the town of Niagara Falls.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The modern history of Niagara Falls can be divided roughly into three phases: Schemers who came in trying to exploit the Falls for tourism and failed; schemers who came in and tried to exploit the Falls for hydroelectric power, who've all gone; and the people who are left in Niagara today. Our show is about this last group: People who live in the aftermath.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Alix Spiegel and playwright David Kodeski tell stories about Niagara Falls. During the hour we hear from Paul Gromosiak, a man who's obsessed with the Falls, writes about them, thinks about them all the time, but never goes there, because "they've ruined the falls." We hear a man who went over the falls in a barrel, and we hear the recordings he made inside the barrel as he went over. There's a man who picks up the bodies of people who've jumped over the Falls.

fields.episode_descript: With so many songs, movies, and books about the joy of the open road, it's hard to take just a normal road trip without huge expectations.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with a guy who hit the road after his mother's death, hoping for some experience that would change him and shed light on what just happened. This never happens to him, or to most of us.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Road Trip in a Tuxedo
episode_acts.summary: What happens when being on the road is your job, and has been your job for decades? Reporter Margy Rochlin recalls a trip she took with 92-year-old George Burns and his tiny entourage.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Merci
episode_acts.summary: A road trip can be a profound test of any relationship. It can save a marriage or destroy it.
episode_acts.byline: By The Moth, Carmen Rivera, Candido Tirado

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Busman's Holiday
episode_acts.summary: Dishwasher Pete, an itinerant dishwasher and author of the book Dishwasher: One Man's Quest to Wash Dishes in All Fifty States, loves taking the bus as he moves from city to city every few weeks. In this act, he takes a tape recorder with him, hoping to capture the stories he always hears from his fellow passengers.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Paw Paw for Jesus
episode_acts.summary: What we want on the road — many of us — is adventure. And what is adventure but a moment you never could've predicted before you left home? Chicago writer Cheryl Trykv tells the story of one such moment.

fields.episode_descript: We asked listeners to send us their best coincidence stories, and we got more than 1,300 submissions!

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks about a man named Paul Cowan, who wrote a story about becoming ill for The Village Voice.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Scenes from a Transplant
episode_acts.summary: After years of covering stories about medicine, NPR Reporter Rebecca Perl enters the hospital as a patient. She moves from the world of healthy people into the world of sick ones.

fields.episode_descript: What's frustrating about music lessons, what's miraculous about them, and what they actually teach us. This show was recorded in front of a live audience at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, with help from KQED-FM, during the 1998 Public Radio Conference in San Francisco.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Durrell was a professional musician. He toured Asia, Brazil, Canada, gigs in Paris.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Papa Was Not A Rolling Stone
episode_acts.summary: A case study of how children are asked to live the unlived lives of their parents. Author David Sedaris had a father who loved jazz but played no instrument himself.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Toccata and Fugue In Me, a Minor
episode_acts.summary: As a teenager, Sarah Vowell was not casual about music lessons — music became her life. She was in marching band, jazz band, Band One, symphony band, pep band and the Bozeman Recorder Ensemble.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Knockin' On Heaven's Door
episode_acts.summary: Writer Anne Lamott presents an example of what we can learn from music outside of formal classes. She tells the story of an airplane trip, a song, and a small miracle.

fields.episode_descript: Two stories of people who try to cross the color line — and why it's still so hard. We hear the story of a failed interracial marriage and the story of a teenager from a poor inner city neighborhood (Cedric Jennings, pictured) who ends up at an Ivy League University — and how he barely survives there.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira reads from an editorial from a 1957 newspaper in Jackson, Mississippi. It tries to scare white southerners about the NAACP by describing a Chicago human rights campaign called "Take a Negro Boy Home Tonight." The idea behind the campaign? "Racism can be combated by intimate relationships between Negro boys and white girls." No such campaigns really existed in Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Interracial Marriage
episode_acts.summary: Rich Robinson's father is black, his mother is white. They married during the civil rights movement, believing the whole nation was moving toward greater and greater integration.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Economic Integration
episode_acts.summary: Cedric Jennings grew up in Southeast Washington, in one of the poorest communities in the country. Wall Street Journal reporter Ron Suskind followed him for over two-and-a-half years, as Cedric tried to make it through high school and work his way into an Ivy League university. Once he gets there, he discovers that all the qualities that got him out of the ghetto make him an outcast in the Ivy League.

fields.episode_descript: More tape of Chana and her father Bob Wiliford discussing all the things they've never talked about before. Though Chana grew up in Waco, Texas, she left to go to college in Philadelphia. Her dad works for the phone company. Her parents have been married and divorced and re-married to each other three times, but she doesn't understand why. In this interview, she gets to ask about it. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We ask 18-year-old Chana Wiliford and her father in Texas if they'd be willing to have a conversation on tape in which each of them gets to ask the other the questions they've never asked before. In the conversation, Chana is half his child, half his peer.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pandora's Box
episode_acts.summary: More tape of Chana and her father Bob Wiliford discussing all the things they've never talked about before. Though Chana grew up in Waco, Texas, she left to go to college in Philadelphia.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mack Daddies
episode_acts.summary: In this part of the show, stories about fathers who haven't gotten quite so close with their children. Two-thirds of all African American children are raised in single parent homes, usually by mothers and/or grandmothers.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bond, Dammit, Bond
episode_acts.summary: Another case study of a dad who's waiting to feel closer to his kid. Writer Dan Savage writes the syndicated sex advice column Savage Love. He and his boyfriend Terry spent months trying to adopt and finally adopted a baby boy.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Age Of Enchantment
episode_acts.summary: This is a story about an odd breach of trust between father and child, done unintentionally, and what happens next. Lawrence Weschler is an author and journalist. He and his 11-year-old daughter Sara tell the tale.

fields.episode_descript: Writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister re-trace the "Trail of Tears" — the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson. On the way, Sarah and her sister visit the land they would have grown up in had the Cherokees not been expelled, Andrew Jackson's home, and the land in Oklahoma where the Cherokee nation settled (and where Sarah and her sister were born). They reflect on their own American-ness and Cherokee-ness, and on the more difficult question: What's history good for, anyway?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass describes what thousands of people do all over America on our holiday weekends: we go to historic sites with our kids and stare at bricks and statues, trying to feel some connection with the past. It's not easy.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell and her twin sister Amy re-trace the Trail of Tears. They visit the town in Georgia that was the capital of the Cherokee Nation before the Cherokee were expelled.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell's story continues. She and Amy visit the home of President Andrew Jackson, the villain in the Trail of Tears drama.

fields.episode_title: Truth and Lies at Age Ten
fields.episode_descript: One car dealership tries to make its monthly quota: 129 cars. It is way more chaotic than we expected.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talk with Claire, who obsessed over a Chilean friend — and then started to tell people she was Chilean herself.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I, Danny
episode_acts.summary: In this special half-hour story produced by Jay Allison as part of his Life Stories series, Dan Gediman tracks down the original Zoom cast members to find out what his life would've been like if he had achieved his childhood dream of being on Zoom.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Truth or Consequences
episode_acts.summary: Mary Kay Prucha tells her story about the lies she told herself to deal with cystic fibrosis.

fields.episode_descript: People who love summer camp say that non-camp people simply don't understand what's so amazing about it. We attempt to bridge this gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Camp kids explain how their non-camp friends and their non-camp loved ones have no idea why camp is the most important thing in their lives. Most of this hour takes place at a pair of camps in Michigan—Lake of the Woods, a girls camp, and Greenwoods, a boys camp.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mr. Popular
episode_acts.summary: David Himmel is a college sophomore and a former camper who became a counselor. He says all the best experiences of his life have been at camp or with camp people.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fear
episode_acts.summary: Sure, kids today are sophisticated. But get them living in the woods for a few days, and they revert to some of the most stupidly primitive forms of entertainment known since the dawn of civilization.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You
episode_acts.summary: We asked listeners to call and write with their camp stories. Hundreds did.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Ritual
episode_acts.summary: Camp Lake of the Woods holds a fake Indian powwow during the summer. This kind of fake Native American-ness has been a part of camping in America since organized camping began a century ago.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: How The Israeli Army Is Just Like Summer Camp
episode_acts.summary: NPR's Adam Davidson tells a true story from his own childhood. He was sent to a camp run by the Israeli army at its own training facility.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Color Days
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Julie Snyder reports on a three-day competition called "Color Days." It's most kids' favorite time at camp — despite the fact that the girls, at least, spend most of the three days crying and screaming. It's thrilling to be part of a team at this level of intensity.

fields.episode_descript: Five ways of mapping the world. One story about people who make maps the traditional way — by drawing things we can see. And other stories about people who map the world using smell, sound, touch, and taste. The world redrawn by the five senses.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ralph Gentles and five other people spent each summer creating a map of every crack, every depression, every protrusion, every pothole in the sidewalks of New York City. We hear why, and we hear all the things their map does not include.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Sight
episode_acts.summary: Denis Wood talks with host Ira Glass about the maps he's made of his own neighborhood, Boylan Heights in Raleigh, North Carolina. They include a traditional street locator map, a map of all the sewer and power lines under the earth's surface, a map of how light falls on the ground through the leaves of trees, a map of where all the Halloween pumpkins are each year, and a map of all the graffiti in the neighborhood.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hearing
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt visits Toby Lester, who has mapped all the ambient sounds in his world: the hum of the heater, the fan on the computer. Jack's most recent book is Bunch of Amateurs.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Smell
episode_acts.summary: A story about a device that charts the world through smell — and only smell. TAL producer Nancy Updike visits Cyrano Sciences in Pasadena, California, where researchers are creating an electronic nose.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Touch
episode_acts.summary: Deb Monroe reports on how she has been mapping her own body through her sense of touch.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Taste
episode_acts.summary: Los Angeles Times food writer Jonathan Gold goes to the places on Pico Boulevard in Los Angeles that he visited back in the early 1980s. He tells the story of how he decided to map an entire street using his sense of taste, and how doing this changed his life.

fields.episode_descript: I thought this was supposed to be easy. Tales from the simple life.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Eustace Conway was 17, he abandoned his normal life and decided to move to the woods.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Two brothers set out with a friend to cross America on horseback. They take a tape recorder with them to make a kind of audio journal of their trip.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: When Larry leaves his old life behind and joins a monastery, Ethan struggles to understand his best friend's decision.

fields.episode_descript: Exactly how much are the animals that live in our home caught up in everyday family dynamics?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The story of a White House scandal from the year 1881. President James Garfield lay dying of a gunshot wound during that summer.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Biblical Thinking In A Digital World
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Hanna Rosen did an investigation of those new antibacterial products—the antibacterial soaps and lotions, the antibacterial pizza cutter and linen and underwear. In her article, she mocked these products as ineffective.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 20th Century Germ
episode_acts.summary: Germs were first understood at the turn of the 20th century and it turns out that the aesthetics of everyday life during this century—the way we dress, the way we groom ourselves, the way we make our homes—are all partly a response to this newfangled idea of germs.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ladies And Germs
episode_acts.summary: The burden of keeping germs from hurting us in our everyday lives has fallen mostly on women, from the time science fully understood about the existence of germs. After all, women had to keep the home clean, had to prepare food safely.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: You Gonna Eat That?
episode_acts.summary: Reporter, author and apple farmer Frank Browning on how irrational fear of germs means that you aren't going to get good apple cider in your local supermarket this fall.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Conqueror Germ
episode_acts.summary: Sean Collins on the germs within us, the germs that can kill us, and the germs that do kill us. He tells the story of the battle with germs that his friend Christopher lost, and contemplates what the germ won when it defeated his friend.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when you suddenly strike it rich. And the power money has over our lives, for good and bad.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Todd Powell won $27 million dollars from the Florida State lottery. The windfall ended his marriage.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Reservations
episode_acts.summary: Alix Spiegel reports on an entire community that's turned its back on easy money—for now. Nine years ago a native American community in Minnesota—the Mille Lacs band of Ojibwe—built a casino.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: But Baby It's Cold Outside
episode_acts.summary: Seattle writer Dan Savage on how a windfall check he got in the mail is hurting his family life.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Money Is Good
episode_acts.summary: How one woman learned to stop worrying and start spending. Liz Gilbert and her husband Michael Cooper explain how their different ideas about handling money always divided them—until they stumbled into a $10,000 windfall.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Pot Of Gold
episode_acts.summary: Writer Scott Carrier in Salt Lake City tells the story of someone's life that improved with a huge insurance settlement—even though the money never arrived.

fields.episode_descript: A Guatemalan immigrant living near Boston gets a phone call with some very strange news about his past.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads famous last words from Bing Crosby, Oscar Wilde, W.C. Fields, and talks about what we want from people's last words.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Actions Speak Louder
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell tells the story of Page Smith and Eloise Pickard Smith. They were married for over five decades, and died a day apart.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Unknown Soldier
episode_acts.summary: Forty-five people read Luc Sante's story The Unknown Soldier, in which we hear about people's final moments, final thoughts.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How The Living Use The Dead
episode_acts.summary: Writer Greil Marcus explains what rock fans use dead rock stars for.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Rosebud
episode_acts.summary: An act about which the less said, the better.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Black Box
episode_acts.summary: We go through transcripts from those black box flight recorders recovered from airplane crashes to see what people say. One pilot declares "I love you" to someone, another is doing his job like always and suddenly says, "uh-oh." It's an interview with Malcolm McPherson, author of The Black Box: All-New Cockpit Voice Recorder Accounts of In-Flight Accidents.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: What Goes Through Your Head
episode_acts.summary: Writer Tobias Wolff reads his story "Bullet in the Brain" from his collection of stories The Night in Question, about a bank robbery and a man who's shot, and what he thinks about before he dies.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of the first day on the job, the first day in a relationship, the first day in school. On the first day, any first day, we're expected to live by the rules and customs of the culture we're entering, but we don't know those rules and customs just yet. These are stories of people trying to make the transition—and the difficulty of making the transition—in a new place, from outsider to insider.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Writer Jack Hitt talks about his daughter Tarpeley's first day in her new school. It was her first "first day" of any kind.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lost At Sea
episode_acts.summary: Dishwasher Pete tells the story of his first day washing dishes on an oil rig off the coast of Louisiana. He'd heard he'd get a hazing when he stepped foot on the rig.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Squirrel Cop
episode_acts.summary: The first day inevitably means mistakes, mishaps, fiascos. A true story, told by a former rookie cop.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bad Sex With Bud Kemp
episode_acts.summary: Los Angeles writer Sandra Tsing Loh on the first day of a relationship. A failing relationship.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: When Businesses Act Like Humans
episode_acts.summary: Then Chicago-radio-listener and writer Alex Blumberg (he's now one of our producers) tells the story of encountering a corporation on its first day. It made all the human errors anyone does on a first day: exhibiting false confidence, pretending it wasn't the first day, trying too hard.

fields.episode_descript: Last year, a woman named Karen Davis started a national letter writing campaign to try to get This American Life to stop the very program we are broadcasting today—the annual Poultry Slam. In this portion of our show, she explains what it is that we just don't understand about poultry, and why the whole idea of this poultry show was wrong-headed from the start. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When is a chicken your friend? When is he your dinner? This American Life's former webmeister Elizabeth Meister talks with Kamiko Overs, an 11-year-old girl at the annual poultry exhibition run by the American Poultry Association in Columbus, Ohio. Elizabeth Meister is a producer with Long Haul Productions.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Still Life With Chicken
episode_acts.summary: Food writer Jonathan Gold tells what it's like to panfry a chicken—with a live chicken watching you the entire time.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Last Meal
episode_acts.summary: When Francois Mitterand knew he was about to die, he decided that the last food to cross his lips would be poultry...a tiny bird that is actually illegal to eat in France. It's a bird that, by tradition, is eaten with a napkin covering your head.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: People Who Love Chickens And Hate This American Life
episode_acts.summary: Last year, a woman named Karen Davis started a national letter writing campaign to try to get This American Life to stop the very program we are broadcasting today—the annual Poultry Slam.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Meaning Of A Bird
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Rakoff explains how his life was changed—in a single evening—in a room of 5000 chickens.

fields.episode_descript: The family table is stage on which many family dramas are played out. We hear three stories, of three families, at three meals.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the role of mealtime in family dynamics.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Breakfast
episode_acts.summary: A story by Jay Allison and Annie Cheney, from Jay's Life Stories series. Annie tells a story of eating and not eating, and a life seen through one meal.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Lunch
episode_acts.summary: Family dynamics seen strictly from the parents' perspective. A story by Ian Frazier, Laws Concerning Food and Drink; Household Principles; Lamentations of the Father. Read by Peter Sagal, the host of NPR's quiz show Wait Wait ...

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Dinner
episode_acts.summary: To end this show about parents and children at mealtime, a story about what happens when children have to become the parents. Dave Eggers' mother and father died when he was 21 and his brother Toph was 8.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about seeing and being seen. Taped before a live audience in Town Hall in New York City in December 1998, this was a co-production with WNYC New York, featuring live music by the pop band They Might Be Giants and the This American Life Orchestra.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Cornell University Professor Richard Klein, on how seeing isn't just seeing. Seeing implies a kind of power over someone else.

episode_acts.name: Act One: American Goth
episode_acts.summary: There are the people who take two hours to get dressed every day, who dress primarily to be seen, and then there are most of the rest of us. Writer Sarah Vowell decides to make the leap into the two-hours group.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Lifesavers
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the story of Lucia Lopez, a former gang member who would beat you up if she caught you looking at her...and how her life changed when she put herself in a position where hundreds of people were looking at her.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Climb Every Mountain
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Rakoff travels to a place where everyone seems to be looking at him, a place where no one follows the customs people follow back home in New York City, a place called...New Hampshire.

fields.episode_descript: With the number of prisoners in the United States rising rapidly, we present stories of their lives and the lives of their families and children.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with jazz musician Ed Ryder, who was in prison in Pennsylvania for twenty years for a murder it was later proven he did not commit. Ryder played jazz in the pen and out of the pen.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Mess With Texas
episode_acts.summary: Over two decades ago, not long after he got out of Texas prison for robbery, Ray Hill got a job at his local public radio station, KPFT in Houston. He started a weekly program about Texas prisons that's now the leading muckraking voice in the state when it comes to exposing graft and corruption in prison facilities there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mother's Day
episode_acts.summary: As the number of female prisoners climbs, visiting rooms are packed on Mother's Day. Eighty percent of female inmates have children at home.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who's Your Daddy?
episode_acts.summary: A reading of a pamphlet written by ex-con Stephen Donaldson for heterosexual men who are about to enter prison, about how to "hook up" with a stronger man —"daddy" or "jocker"—who'll provide protection in return for sex. He explains the rules and mores that govern this part of American prison culture.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Open Your Big Mouth
episode_acts.summary: What happens when you go into a place—in this case a prison—where there are all sorts of codes about what you're never supposed to say...and you say every one of them. Rick Reynolds tells a story from his one-man show (and CD) All Grown Up and No Place to Go, about performing stand-up comedy at a maximum security prison just before Christmas a few years ago.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Color Bar
episode_acts.summary: Former South African political prisoner Breyten Breytenbach, on how prison changes all your perceptions in ways that last after you've been released. The painter and poet was interviewed by New Yorker writer Lawrence Weschler for a radio series called Territories of Art, for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles in 1986.

fields.episode_title: Be Careful Who You Pretend to Be
fields.episode_descript: We go to the Lower 9th Ward in New Orleans to talk to residents about what matters most to them ten years after the hurricane.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Viola disguises herself as a man, takes a job working for this guy with whom she promptly falls in love. He believes the pretense: He thinks Viola is a man, so he never gives her a second look.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Doing Good By Doing Bad
episode_acts.summary: Ron Copeland is a historical interpreter at the Conner Prairie Living History Museum, outside of Indianapolis. For several months a year, in his job, he pretends to be a slaveowner in the old south.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Psychobabble, Qu'est-ce Que C'est
episode_acts.summary: There's the pretending we do as individuals, and there's the organized pretending that happens in group therapy sessions, in the roleplaying games that are done in some clinical settings. Jack Hitt tells the story of the Mother of All Roleplaying Games.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: What's So Funny About Peace, Love And Understanding?
episode_acts.summary: Alix Spiegel travels with a group of white suburbanites as they pretend to be runaway slaves, at the Conner Prairie Living History Museum. Her goal: to find out what it is that people actually get out of this elaborate game of pretend.

fields.episode_descript: One thing that makes our country different from most others is this idea that you can re-create yourself as someone you'd prefer to be...sell everything off, head out west, start a new life.  But what happens if you're too good at it?  At throwing everything out and starting over?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The tendency toward self-reinvention is so deep in American culture that we have an entire industry, a self-help industry, telling us how to transform ourselves into someone new. And usually, we see this as a positive thing.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Over the course of his life, Keith Aldrich was a child of the Depression; an aspiring Hollywood actor; a self-styled Beat writer, a member of the New York literati, and then a hippie. Then in the 80's, he became a born-again Christian.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Gillian's story continues.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Meet The Ball And Chain
episode_acts.summary: When Anne Staggs started to fall for an inmate named Charles in the Texas prison system, she was up against odds as daunting as they ever get for two people. It was against the rules, possibly dangerous, and could have gotten her fired.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mucho Corazon
episode_acts.summary: A man in Amsterdam and a woman in Cuba fall in love, even though their governments don't want them to live together. This story was produced by Chris Brookes and Michele Ernsting for the World Views series of first person narratives, from Homeland Productions.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who Deserves What
episode_acts.summary: The story of The Arabian Nights is actually 350 or 400 stories, depending on how you count them. Many of the stories are stories of impossible love, including the very last story in the whole epic tale—the story of Jasmine and Almond.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from the awkward, confusing, hormonally charged world of middle school.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Robert Lundin, who talks about a time in his life when he felt too alive, and how much more sane he feels now, though his life is less exciting.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How To Avoid The Everyday Irritations Of Everyday Life
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt tells the story of Charlene Riling, who nearly died, and who explains how life near to death can be better than everyday life.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How To Avoid The Difficulty Of Living With Someone
episode_acts.summary: When adults talk babytalk to each other, it is precisely to avoid having real conversations and experiencing real moments with each other. People almost never discuss babytalk in public. This American Life producer Nancy Updike and her boyfriend—Chicago journalist Adam Davidson—agreed to step forward and speak the truth on the subject.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How To Avoid Everything
episode_acts.summary: It's possible to turn off your emotions and go on autopilot for brief periods with the people you love, and it's possible to shut them down completely. Writer Dani Shapiro reads from her memoir Slow Motion: A True Story.

fields.episode_descript: Nancy Updike goes to Iraq to try to figure out what it's like to be a private citizen working in the middle of a war zone.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira goes to the courtroom of Abraham Lincoln Marovitz, who, at 93, presides over the ceremony to make people citizens. In this setting, it's hard to talk about America as it is.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What Do Arnold Schwarzenegger And Sigmund Freud Have In Common?
episode_acts.summary: Because of a shortage of math and science teachers, New York City decided to import instructors from Austria. Then the Austrians started to see things about this country that few Americans ever get to see.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Are Movies Stronger Than Communism?
episode_acts.summary: This is a story of a father and son—told by the son, Juan Zaldivar, who was born in Cuba. Juan has spent the past four years shooting a movie about his father, to try to reassure him that he did the right thing to leave Cuba with his family in the 1980s and come to America.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When the end of time comes, what videos will we watch? Under fundamentalist Christian doctrine, the first thing that will happen during the End Time is that all the good Christians will be whisked suddenly to heaven. We hear clips from Left Behind—a video designed to be played after all the Christians have vanished, by all the people left behind.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cowboys Of The Apocalypse
episode_acts.summary: How fundamentalist Christians and Orthodox Jews are combining forces to breed a perfect red cow that could bring about the end of the world. Ira talks with cattleman and minister Clyde Lott, and with New Yorker writer Lawrence Wright.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Cost Of Misunderstanding
episode_acts.summary: The story of how an understanding of Bible prophecy by the FBI could have prevented the tragedy at Waco at the Branch Davidians compound.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Again
episode_acts.summary: How believing in the end of the world can be the best thing that ever happens to you. Writer Sarah Vowell talks about three end-of-the-world groups she comes to know.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: None Shall Know The Exact Hour Or Time
episode_acts.summary: Both Bonnie Gaunt and Marilyn Agee have been counting the length of time of all the events in the Bible, and through their calculations, they believe they have individually discovered the exact day that good Christians will be raptured directly to heaven. Bonnie's date: September 11, 1999; Marilyn's date: May 21, 1999.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to do good: Why they often fail and why they occasionally succeed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Brigid starting going blind, she tried to hire someone to drive her around. Only problem was, the guy she hired wanted to carry her groceries, hold her arm as she walked to the curb...he tried to help her in too many ways.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You Can't Go Home Again
episode_acts.summary: Jackie and Kenny Wharton were kids in the tiny town of Canalou, Missouri, off of old Highway 61. They moved away for 40 years but always dreamed of moving back.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Humanitarians
episode_acts.summary: Modern-day fables of two different kinds of do-gooders during and after the 1994 genocide in the African country of Rwanda. Philip Gourevich, author of the book We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will be Killed With Our Families: Stories from Rwanda, tells first about international relief workers who served as "caterers" to some of the Hutu powers as they continued their policy of ethnic cleansing after fleeing to refugee camps.

fields.episode_descript: This entire show is devoted to just one story. A former pimp tells how he and three childhood friends became pimps in the 1970s in Oakland, California. He explains all the elaborate "rules of the game" among pimps and prostitutes of that era. He didn't have the stomach for the violence of pimping, and failed as a pimp because of that. Tamar Brott reports.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about the classic biography of an American pimp, Iceberg Slim's Pimp: The Story of My Life, and explains today's show. He warns listeners that although there's no sex in the show at all, there is a scene or two in which men hit women.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Rules Of The Game
episode_acts.summary: How Kevin and his friends got into the game of pimping, and the rules of the game at the time.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Price Of Ignoring The Rules
episode_acts.summary: Kevin's story continues. We hear about his own rise and fall as a pimp, and how he failed in his attempt to be a different kind of pimp—a less cruel kind.

fields.episode_descript: Sarah Vowell has a theory that you can tell the entire history of the United States by standing on one street corner—specifically at Michigan Avenue and Wacker Drive in Chicago—and describing all the events that happened within eyeshot of the corner. She covers three centuries of history, from Louis Joliet to Keanu Reeves. (21 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the Four Corners tourist monument where Arizona, Colorado, Utah and New Mexico meet. He proposes creating our own little monument to America: a four corners show depicting life on four street corners across this great nation.

episode_acts.name: Act One: History
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell has a theory that you can tell the entire history of the United States by standing on one street corner—specifically at Michigan Avenue and Wacker Drive in Chicago—and describing all the events that happened within eyeshot of the corner. She covers three centuries of history, from Louis Joliet to Keanu Reeves.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Love
episode_acts.summary: Scott Richer and Julie Riggs of Louisville, Kentucky, were supposed to have their first kiss at the corner where South Fourth Street meets the alley behind the West End Baptist Church. But it went wrong.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Neighbors
episode_acts.summary: Writer Mike Paterniti tells a story of dogs and a community of dogwalkers that formed on the grounds of an old cemetery at the corner of Vaughn and Clifford in Portland, Maine.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: How To Become An American
episode_acts.summary: Writer Achy Obejas reads a piece of short fiction from her book, We Came All the Way from Cuba So You Could Dress Like This? (11 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: A Guatemalan immigrant living near Boston gets a phone call with some very strange news about his past.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Adam and Jamie were kids, Jamie would always ask for Adam's advice, but he didn't want to hear what Adam would say himself. Instead, he wanted Adam to pretend to be an Israeli commando he once knew, named Yakov.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Sleepless In Seattle
episode_acts.summary: What if you asked people for advice and actually took all the advice that everyone gave you? As an experiment, writer Sarah Vowell tried exactly that, when she recently solicited advice from many different people about insomnia.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Advise And Consent
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with his mom—a clinical psychologist—about why people seem to rarely take the advice others give. Then advice columnist Dan Savage, author of the syndicated column and book Savage Love, gives the audience some advice that hopefully might save lives.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Guided Meditation
episode_acts.summary: Forget all the self-help seminars you've ever heard of or attended. Writer Cheryl Trykv leads the audience in Seattle in a guided meditation, to end our program with epiphany, epiphany, epiphany.

fields.episode_descript: How a stolen library book got one man into his dream school and changed his life forever. Or at least that's the story he tells himself.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Eddy Harris. The first time Eddie set foot in a black nation in Africa, a man at the border found out he was an American—a black American—and said "Welcome home." But Eddy Harris says the Motherland doesn't really feel much like home.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Exile
episode_acts.summary: Twenty-six-year-old Jose William Huezo Soriano—a.k.a. Weasel—grew up in Los Angeles.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Brothers Of Different Mothers
episode_acts.summary: In this act we hear two stories of people who stumbled upon a place where they instantly and instinctively felt more at home than in their real homes. Stephen Dubner, author of the memoir Turbulent Souls: A Catholic Son's Return to His Jewish Family, talks about an encounter with a Jewish man named Irving that changed his life.
episode_acts.byline: By Stephen Dubner, Ira Glass, Anna Lengyl

fields.episode_descript: What happens when of a group of public school students in the Bronx goes to visit an elite private school three miles away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: On the tenth anniversary of the crackdown at Tiananmen Square, we hear from Wen Huang, who was part of the student movement. He says that the students weren't fighting for democracy, at least not as it's been widely understood in the West.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Where The People Walk Around Upside Down
episode_acts.summary: More stories from Wen Huang that contradict what you think you know about the 1989 student uprising in China.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: When Czechs Bounce
episode_acts.summary: If part of the impulse behind the Tiananmen Square uprising was the pure desire to feel like life had possibility, that the future had potential...that impulse was behind another movement. This one among young people in Eastern Europe back before the Berlin Wall fell.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When We Were Animals
episode_acts.summary: Since the high school shootings in Littleton, Colorado, parents and teachers are looking for warning signs that the children in their lives might suddenly strike out. But the dividing line between normal childhood aggression and social pathology can be hard to spot.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: When We Were Angels
episode_acts.summary: The most innocent possible student uprising imaginable...documented by an actual student, Hillary Frank, using the crude tools of a telephone answering machine and a shiny red boom box.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when a dad tries too hard to protect his child from disappointment and instead enthrall the child. With the best of intentions, New Yorker writer Lawrence Weschler did all that, and in the process accidentally broke his daughter's heart. And then she took action and mended the problem. This story was first broadcast a year ago on Father's Day, when his daughter Sara was 11. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The story of the lengths a father will go to to retrieve a lost teddy bear, and why—after he's enlisted many other parents to help him wade through tens of thousands of bags of trash to find it—none of the parents involved think he's nuts.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Paddington's Day At The Dump
episode_acts.summary: The story begun in the Prologue continues.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Trip Down Memory Lane
episode_acts.summary: Photographer Joel Meyerowitz decided to go on a last big trip with his father Hy, who has Alzheimer's. Joel also brought his own son.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Age of Enchantment
episode_acts.summary: What happens when a dad tries too hard to protect his child from disappointment and instead enthrall the child. With the best of intentions, New Yorker writer Lawrence Weschler did all that, and in the process accidentally broke his daughter's heart.

fields.episode_descript: Conspiracy theories about the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin continue to shape Israel's politics and future.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass lays out the premise of this week's show.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How To Talk Your Way Into A Half Million Dollars ... In 45 Minutes.
episode_acts.summary: A story that takes place at the crossroads where art meets commerce—a place where we can ask the question: Is the art of commerce better than the art of art? Writer (and occasional screenwriter) Sandra Tsing Loh accompanies a Hollywood screenwriter as he tries to sell a movie idea—a comedy in the style of Liar Liar. (19 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Jail Sell
episode_acts.summary: Writer/performer Danny Hoch performs a monologue taken from his one man show, Jails, Hospitals and Hip-Hop. It's a story about a guy who's been locked up for doing the most American activity possible: Selling stuff on the street (in this case Bart Simpson/O.J. Simpson t-shirts).

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who's The Man?
episode_acts.summary: Becoming a salesman can make you more confident and happy, make you ignore it when someone tells you "no"...and why that might be a bad thing. The story of a man who sold radio advertising.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Secret To Being Rich And Happy
episode_acts.summary: What happens to you if you stay in sales all your life? 76-year-old salesman "Diamond" Jimmy Roy has sold everything from used cars to antiques to jewelery. Independent producer Dan Collison shadowed Jimmy Roy in his native Braddock, Pennsylvania, to talk to him about the philosophy that's kept him going as a salesman for over fifty years.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about what happens when we don't do something. It turns out that not falling in love, not doing our jobs, not spending time with our families is every bit as vivid and complicated an experience as doing something.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira reads a very brief excerpt from a short story from writer Stuart Dybek called "We Didn't." Dybek fills 11 pages, thousands of words, describing all the things two people do when they're not doing something.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You Come And Go, The Waiters Remain
episode_acts.summary: This story is part memoir, part philosophical inquiry into the nature of not doing things. Writer Geoff Dyer had always wanted to write a biography about D.H.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dance
episode_acts.summary: What do we do when we're not doing something? Not writing a book, not doing our jobs, not falling in love? Sometimes we just feel self-conscious. Sometimes we spend a lot of time explaining ourselves.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Same Time Next Year
episode_acts.summary: Writer/Comedian Amanda Marks shares the story of a couple that didn't fall in love, didn't get together, didn't form a future. Then coincidence and fate kick in...confusingly.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Saying No For 75 Years
episode_acts.summary: Journalist Steve Bogira tells the story of Vincent Bogan, who said "no" to something once—a decade ago, when he was 21—and now has to live with that one decisive act. Bogan was arrested and charged with 17 counts of armed robbery.

fields.episode_descript: We think of crime as a kind of monolithic, menacing presence. But there are many kinds of crimes and many kinds of criminals. Through our crimes, we express who we are. Today we hear of three different criminals and three different kinds of crimes.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A survey of local crime blotters from the Anacortes American (by John Bauer; thanks also to Gail Mann and Duncan Frazier) in Anacortes, Washington; the Pueblo Chieftain (by Juan Espinosa) in Pueblo, Colorado; and the Athens Daily News (by Ben Deck, Stephen Gurr and Joan Stroer; thanks also to Jim Thompson and Greg Martin) in Athens, Georgia. Actor Matt Malloy reads.
