episode_acts.name: Act One: Your Good Girl's Gonna Go Bad
episode_acts.summary: When she was 21, Julia Sweeney got a job as a bartender's assistant and stole between ten and fifteen thousand dollars in cash. She describes the thrill of stealing, and how she justified her thefts to herself, and—oddest of all—how she became a more religious Roman Catholic during her crime spree.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You'll Pay
episode_acts.summary: Some criminals do not see themselves as basically good people getting away with something bad. Some people do not believe God is on their side when they commit their crimes.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Grandma Takes A Fall
episode_acts.summary: No one knows how much theft is committed each year by senior citizens. One study found that seniors comprise 15 percent of people apprehended for shoplifting.

fields.episode_descript: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Amy McGuiness flies tourists to the North Pole who pay thousands of dollars for the privilege. When you get to the Pole, it looks exactly like all the other ice you've been staring at for hours.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Ishtar Days, Arabian Nights
episode_acts.summary: John Bowe decided to visit a friend of his who was in the peace corp in Mali, in West Africa. But he chose the most difficult possible route to get there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Game
episode_acts.summary: It can be frightening to get lost, but what if you could adapt the thrill of being lost, the pleasure of being lost, to safe parameters? Just get a little lost. Is it even possible? Or is that playing with fire, where you're sure to get burned? Writer David Sedaris has these thoughts.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Snatch The Pebble From My Hand, Grasshopper, And Then You Can Leave
episode_acts.summary: Nicole Graev, an assistant to the editor at a publishing house, needs to know if her job as an assistant is actually an educational career step or a waste of time. The things she's been doing as an assistant—answering phones, faxing—is entirely different than the skills she needs for the job she really wants: her boss's.

fields.episode_title: The Book That Changed Your Life
fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who believe a book changed their life. It's a romantic notion, and one reason we believe it is because we want to believe our lives can be changed by something so simple as an idea — or a set of ideas contained in a book.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Alexa was seven, she started going through her grandfather's books. Her grandfather was a playwright and teacher, and through the books—and especially through his notes in the margins—she entered the world of 1930's American theater.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: More of Alexa Junge and how Moss Hart's autobiography changed her life. She followed his path, learned specific lessons, and had a vision of him that was absolutely clear—until she met his widow.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Family That Reads Together
episode_acts.summary: The story of a book that changed a family's life, but only temporarily and not for the better. David Sedaris describes what happens when he finds a dirty book in the woods and shares it with his sisters.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Roger And Me, Lewis And Clark
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Jeremy Goldstein tells the story of a man who had many books change his life, even though he'd never read them.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Little Sod Houses For You And Me
episode_acts.summary: Writer Meghan Daum goes to DeSmet, South Dakota, where Laura Ingalls Wilder lived and where many of the books she wrote in the Little House on the Prairie series are set. It turns out to be remarkably similar to what Meghan had pictured before she went: The people seem like they are genuinely trying to hold on to the values Laura Ingalls Wilder writes about in her books.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people drawn to some idea, some picture, some "thing" that they just want to be. How some people imitate this "thing" innocently, some less innocently, and how easy it is to slip from one to the other.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The story of Jug Burkett, a businessman in Dallas and a Vietnam vet, who years ago routinely started checking the bona fides of anyone in the news who claimed to have served in the Vietnam war. He says he's found hundreds of fakers, and he says that one of the tricky things about the fakers is that they often seem more like The Real Thing than real vets do.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Life With The Thrill Kill Cult
episode_acts.summary: The story of someone trying and trying to get close to The Real Thing, and why it was so difficult. Kelly McEvers was a newspaper writer here in Chicago and started to get interested in stories she was hearing about girl gang members.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Black Like Me
episode_acts.summary: Professor Glenn Loury from Boston University and John Simpkins on basketball, hockey, and what makes a real black person.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Drawl
episode_acts.summary: What does it mean to talk like a real Southerner—and why a multimillion industry can't seem to figure it out. Southern expatriate Mark Schone dissects Southern accents as they're portrayed in movies and TV shows.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Real Love
episode_acts.summary: There's The Real Thing when it comes to your idea of what job you want, what house you want, what person you want to fall in love with. And until you find The Real Thing you seek, life is the same story over and over again: It's the story of not getting The Real Thing yet again.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when of a group of public school students in the Bronx goes to visit an elite private school three miles away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with an idealistic would-be politician in California. The puzzle of American politics is that our political system is filled with idealistic people, but few of our candidates for top office seem either idealistic or capable of inspiring passion.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Upside Down World
episode_acts.summary: A campaign diary from writer Michael Lewis from four years ago, about a politician you've heard a lot about: John McCain...and the story of a moment when the opposite of normal politics became normal politics.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kiss And Tell
episode_acts.summary: A Walter Mondale-voting, gay-rights-supporting unrepentant liberal signs up as a Republican party member—and ends up a party functionary—a delegate to the state Republican convention...where he wreaks havoc. Dan Savage tells the story.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Pete And Repeat
episode_acts.summary: How California Governor Pete Wilson's anti-immigrant policies found some supporters among immigrants themselves. We hear an explanation of the profoundly idealistic notion of "self-deportation" from its main proponent, Daniel D.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Throwing Money At The Problem
episode_acts.summary: A few years back Alex Kotlowitz wrote a book called There Are No Children Here, about two boys growing up in Chicago's Henry Horner public housing projects. Those projects were across the street from the site of the 1996 Democratic Convention in Chicago, and when the convention came to town, money poured in for a makeover.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of family businesses, and what happens when the tension of family dynamics collides with the pressure of capitalist market forces.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with Rory Evans, who describes the day her father fired his own mother from their family business, a machine shop called Evans Industries.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What's A Grecian Urn?
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff takes us inside the world of a Greek family-owned ice cream parlour, and what he learned about the husband and wife and son who owned it...and what he didn't figure out until later.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Silent Partner
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole visits Chad's Trading Post in Southampton, Massachussetts. One person who works there wears a shirt that says "Chad's Brother;" other shirts say "Chad's Best Friend," "Chad's Cousin," "Chad's Father." Pictures of Chad are everywhere.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Family Photo Opp
episode_acts.summary: Dave Eggers on what happens when politics suddenly becomes your family business. When his brother ran for office, he asked for Dave's help and support.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Every Unhappy Family Cleaning Supplies Business Is Unhappy In Its Own Way
episode_acts.summary: Hillary Frank explains how an invitation to a business meeting, sent through the mail in 1963, kept two sides of a family from speaking to each other for most of the second half of the 20th Century.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are trying to make invisible worlds visible, and what happens when you make them visible.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There are thousands of voices passing through your body right now on radio waves—signals from cellular phones and cordless phones, military transmissions and baby monitors. You're not supposed to listen in on these.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Faster Than A Speeding Bullet
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alex Blumberg with people who listen in on the invisible world on the nether reaches of the radio spectrum, mostly illegally...and what they find there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: More Powerful Than A Locomotive
episode_acts.summary: One of the most powerful forces in a room can be the thing that is unspoken between people. Five writers—Scott Carrier, David Sedaris, Sarah Vowell, Brady Udall and Lan Samantha Chang—give us case examples: stories when they felt the presence of something unspoken.
episode_acts.byline: By Scott Carrier, Lan Samantha Chang, David Sedaris, Brady Udall, Sarah Vowell

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Able To Leap Tall Buildings
episode_acts.summary: The publisher of the zine Infiltration talks about the pleasure and importance of going behind the scenes of everyday life.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: Producer Nancy Updike tells the story of scientists who simply made up an invisible, weightless subatomic particle called the neutrino. Then they set out on the task of finding it, using tools that sound positively crude: A mineshaft and 100,000 gallons of dry cleaning fluid.

fields.episode_descript: We hear the story of one African-American single mother. Barbara Clinkscales recorded her family's life over the course of seven months for This American Life. Her life defies—or makes irrelevant—most of our typical notions of inner-city, black single mothers.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass describes the moment when black single mothers became a national political issue—and a national symbol. It was 1965, when a young Assistant Secretary of Labor named Daniel Patrick Moynihan issued a report calling for action on the issue of African-American single mothers, and black leaders, including the Rev.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Barbara Clinkscales grew up in Chicago's public housing projects, had her first child when she was 15, and is now—over two decades later—struggling to get her teenage son to finish his senior year of high school. Barbara is a working mom, with a network of close friends who look out for her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Barbara's story continues, as she hears some terrible news about her son.

fields.episode_descript: We've all heard occasional news stories about how some of the drug laws enacted in the last 15 years may have gone too far. First time offenders get locked up for decades. Judges—even Republican appointees—say that mandatory minimum sentences prevent them from making fair rulings. But have sentences really gone too far? This hour examines the areas where a consensus is growing on the problems in federal drug laws, and it explains the areas where drug laws seem to be administered fairly.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with former Congressman Daniel Rostenkowski. When Rostenkowski began a term in federal prison, he met for the first time people who'd been locked up under harsh drug laws that he'd voted for himself. "The whole thing's a sham," he declares.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What's Wrong With This Picture?
episode_acts.summary: The story of how a person could be sentenced to 19 years for drug possession—even if police found no drugs, drug money, residue or paraphrenalia—even if it's a first offense. Dorothy Gaines was an Alabama nurse with no prior record and no physical evidence of any drugs who was sentenced to 19 years.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How We Got Here
episode_acts.summary: We hear the history of why these drug laws were enacted from a firsthand witness. Eric Sterling was the lawyer in charge of drug laws for the House Judiciary Committee during the 1980s, when mandatory minimums were put in place.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who Watches The Watchmen?
episode_acts.summary: Judges give their opinions of the drug sentencing laws. Terry Hatter is the Chief U.S.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Night In Drug Court
episode_acts.summary: Before this show ended we wanted to know—how typical are the horror stories? What happens in a typical drug case? To find out, reporter Nancy Updike spent nine hours in Night Narcotics Court in Chicago. What she discovers is that the system is working as fairly as one could hope or expect, with one caveat: Nearly all the defendants are African-American, even though the jurisdiction contains an equal number of white drug users.

fields.episode_descript: One reason we tell stories is to explain things to ourselves that cannot, in the end, always be explained. When someone we're close to dies, we struggle for a way to get our minds around the fact of their absence. And often—the stories we invent aren't quite up to the job. In this week's show, people struggle to invent words adequate to cope with death.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Mark Arax spent three years investigating the murder of his father and yet he's still not at peace when he thinks of his dad's death. (His book is called In My Father's Name: A Family, a Town, a Murder.) This is how it goes sometimes.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Disappearance
episode_acts.summary: Genevieve Jurgensen and her husband Laurent lost their two daughters, Elise and Mathilde, at the ages of 4 and 7. Actress Felicity Jones reads from Jurgensen's book, The Disappearance: A Memoir of Loss, in which Jurgensen tries to explain her children's lives and their deaths to a friend through a series of letters.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Look For The Union Label
episode_acts.summary: A father and daughter (Adrian LeBlank and his daughter Adrian Le Blank) decide to write his obituary—together—not really thinking very seriously at first about the real meaning of what they were doing.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Take My Wife, Please
episode_acts.summary: Some of us have tragedy thrust upon us. Some of us allow ourselves a few moments to contemplate the worst that could happen.

fields.episode_descript: For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it's our annual program about turkeys, chickens, fowl of all types, and their mysterious hold over our imaginations. This show includes favorite stories from previous Poultry Shows, and some new stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass introduces this episode about... fish?

episode_acts.name: Act One: Duki
episode_acts.summary: The story of a typical American family—imaginary poultry—and a handpuppet.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Still Life With Chicken
episode_acts.summary: What happens when a chicken crosses the thin yellow line that divides the animals we eat from the animals we keep as pets. Jonathan Gold, food writer for Gourmet magazine, tells how he accidentally came to adopt a chicken, and what happened to his opinion of chickens afterwards.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How To Do The Funky Chicken
episode_acts.summary: The true story of how a multinational chicken company turned a white man into a black man. The man they did it to? An old time Kentucky Colonel who liked to dress up as a Southern plantation owner in string tie and goatee, who happened to be their own spokesman.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Chicken Diva
episode_acts.summary: Yet another testimony to the power chickens have over our hearts and minds. Jack Hitt reports on an opera about Chicken Little.

fields.episode_descript: The surprisingly entertaining story of how the U.S. got itself into a housing crisis.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Stories about rats in the city, from Kate Aurthur (former rat columnist for New York magazine), and from a Mark Lewis documentary called Rat. When rats arrive in our homes, we remember why we as a species wanted to tame nature in the first place.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Interpretation Of Dreams
episode_acts.summary: Building everything that comprises modern life—constructing cities and suburbs both—means trampling nature. And that bothers some people.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: One Brave Man Stands Up For What's Right
episode_acts.summary: Unlike Reykjavik, some cities don't coddle citizens in their idiosyncratic beliefs about nature. We hear New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani react (with vehemence) to a man who believes New Yorkers should have the right to keep ferrets in their homes.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Church Of Latter Day Snakes
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier tells the story of trying to bring a part of the outside world inside the house when he was a boy. His brother wanted to capture a rattlesnake and bring it home and keep in the basement, as a secret.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: God Bless The Hamster Who Has His Own
episode_acts.summary: True stories of what happens when children are allowed to bring nature's own creatures into the house as pets. When it comes to rodents, fish and amphibians, it often works out badly...for the pets.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Waiting For The End Of The World
episode_acts.summary: We end our show with a story of city life and the natural world co-existing peacefully. Iggy Scam went on a mission seeking urban fisherman—guys who throw down fishing poles right down in the middle of the big city, often in the most polluted industrial environments possible.

fields.episode_descript: It's an odd fact of religious life in America that in this country founded by Christians, in which a majority of people say they believe in God and identify themselves as Christians, that so many religious Christians feel they're an oppressed minority. They say the media doesn't share their values. That secular institutions undermine their beliefs. And the job of raising Christian children, they'll tell you, is like trying to do God's work from behind enemy lines. This week we're devoting our whole show to the kids they're struggling to bring up.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: This American Life host Ira Glass and producer Susan Burton spent a week in August recording a suburban Chicago youth group at every stage of their very first mission trip. The teenagers were from Covenant Presbyterian Church in Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Exodus
episode_acts.summary: These teenagers are the children the Christian right has in mind when it holds conferences on what's at stake in America's culture war. On the fourteen-hour drive to West Virginia, we listen to the Backstreet Boys and talk about Dawson's Creek. One of the things that's so interesting about these teenagers is the odd mix of Christian and secular pop in their lives.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Unto The Uttermost Part Of The Earth
episode_acts.summary: The teenagers arrive in West Virginia and take a look around.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Wise As Serpents And Harmless As Doves
episode_acts.summary: Hardships begin. Their leader gets sick.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Your Name Is Ointment Poured Forth
episode_acts.summary: One great thing about staying in a camp of 130 other Christians is the much-better-than-in-school chance of meeting a nice, cute Christian boy.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Substance Of Things Hoped For
episode_acts.summary: The teenagers try to get to know the locals, without a lot of success.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: The Evidence Of Things Not Seen
episode_acts.summary: Some improvements in their missionary work.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Made To Stumble Because Of Me
episode_acts.summary: The limits of what one accomplishes on a mission trip like this.

fields.episode_title: The Angels Wanna Wear My Red Suit
fields.episode_descript: Students in a French language class in Paris try to explain holiday customs to a woman from Morocco, and somehow everything they describe sounds utterly improbable. A true story from writer David Sedaris, recorded before a live audience at a reading for City Arts and Lectures in San Francisco. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Stephen Nissenbaum, author of a history called The Battle for Christmas, which explains when people started believing in a Santa who arrives Christmas Eve carrying presents. It was in 1822, and incredibly, the poem that created our modern idea of Santa is still around, known by heart by tens of millions.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Red Velvet Underground
episode_acts.summary: We begin our show with the most idealistic notion of Santa. Mike Paterniti heads on a quest across the country, looking for something we've lost, when it comes to Santa.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: If This Sleigh Is A-rockin', Don't Come A-knockin'
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell explains why so many popular songs portray Santa as a ladies man.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It Takes A Nation Of Santas To Hold Us Back
episode_acts.summary: Riz Rollins tells a story about himself, his brother, his grandmother and a guy in a Chicago department store they hope has some pull with Santa.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Santa In Handcuffs, Prometheus In Chains
episode_acts.summary: What if do-gooders patrolled department stores, keeping tabs on the Santas? We hear this story, of The Most Fantastic Crimefighter The World Has Ever Known: Chickenman. Recorded for This American Life by Dick Orkin, Christine Coyle and Rod Roddy at the Radio Ranch in Los Angeles.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Santa Claus Vs. The Easter Bunny
episode_acts.summary: Students in a French language class in Paris try to explain holiday customs to a woman from Morocco, and somehow everything they describe sounds utterly improbable. A true story from writer David Sedaris, recorded before a live audience at a reading for City Arts and Lectures in San Francisco.

fields.episode_descript: In the hospital, we give up our normal schedule and sleep patterns; we give up our normal food and clothing; we're in a place that has its own rules and its own language and its own customs. And in the midst of all this, there's this complicated human interaction we have to negotiate: We have to deal with doctors and nurses to get the care we need. In this show we hear stories of those delicate and sometimes not-so-delicate negotiations.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Robert Lipsyte, author of In the Country of Illness, who tells a story of how one lady in New York won the hospital staff over to her side with one conversation.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Is That Your Final Answer?
episode_acts.summary: When Terry Shine's father was in the hospital, Terry and his brothers spent weeks trying to do whatever they could to help. But first they had to learn the language and customs of the average American hospital.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Other Nursing Staff
episode_acts.summary: No radio program about caregivers in a hospital would be complete without a few words about the caregiver that is the most omnipresent...in every room, in the waiting rooms, at the nurses' stations. It's television.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fire And Ice Cream
episode_acts.summary: When a nurse asks a 14-year-old burn victim out for ice cream, is it a date? Brent Runyon tells the story, which was produced by Jay Allison, part of his Life Stories series, with help from Christina Egloff and funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The story is part of Runyon's book The Burn Journals. Ira then speaks with an interested party.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Looking For Love In All The Wrong Places
episode_acts.summary: Wendy Dorr, an assistant producer at Radio Diaries, has this story of what happens to you if you break one of the cardinal rules of a hospital, over and over, for years.

fields.episode_descript: Mike Paterniti talks about working on a teen ambulance corps, growing up in Connecticut. (19 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The story of a teenagers' party among teenagers who thought of themselves as very grownup. In many ways they completely understand what a grownup party is like: Quiet conversation with lots of thoughtful nodding of heads, alcohol without excessive or loud consumption.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Was A Teenage Ambulance Driver
episode_acts.summary: Mike Paterniti talks about working on a teen ambulance corps, growing up in Connecticut.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Househusband At 12
episode_acts.summary: When Anh Tuan Hoang was 12 and living in Vietnam back in 1980, his cousin was scheming up a way to escape the country by boat. Anh Tuan was invited too.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Miseducation Of Josh Frank
episode_acts.summary: This is another story of a young person making a huge, life-changing decision about his own fate while still very young. Hillary Frank tells the story, about her own little brother—and his trumpet.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Angry Young Man, Times Two
episode_acts.summary: This is the story of two people—one in his late teens, one in his late fifties. Both have good reasons to be mad at the world, but what they did with their anger—and what society did with them—are very different.

fields.episode_descript: Usually it's difficult to get to know the front-runner in a Presidential race. With the most to lose, front-runners are the least spontaneous candidates. They stay on message. In debates, George W. Bush often gives the same few answers to all sorts of different questions. Sarah Koenig has been covering the Bush campaign for months for the Concord Monitor, a New Hampshire newspaper. She tells a story of trying to get to know the "real" George W. Bush. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Three days into the beginning of the new millenium, Kahari Mosley and Garcia Suzinko left home to do something they'd never done before: They took a twelve-hour bus ride to New Hampshire to volunteer for a Presidential campaign. What they saw...and what moved them to volunteer in the first place.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Eliminate The Middleman
episode_acts.summary: Here in America, here's how we interact with our political candidates: We dispatch middlemen to the scene, they listen to what the candidates say, they research the candidates' backgrounds, and they tell us what they think is most important. Those middlemen, of course, are journalists.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Mask Behind The Mask
episode_acts.summary: Usually it's difficult to get to know the front-runner in a Presidential race. With the most to lose, front-runners are the least spontaneous candidates.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Pay No Attention To The Man Behind The Mosh Pit
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg tells the story of citizens who feel perfectly connected to their candidate of choice. Citizens who feel inspired by him.

fields.episode_descript: Conspiracy theories about the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin continue to shape Israel's politics and future.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A high school student explains the intricacies of a four-year crush, and declares that having a crush can be better than having a boyfriend.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Kiss
episode_acts.summary: So what if you held onto a high-school crush? Under what conditions would it never go away? Tobias Wolff reads a short story called "Kiss." (38 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How A Bill Becomes — A President
episode_acts.summary: Bill Bradley press secretary Julia Rothwax explains how a political crush works. This is a crush that wants only for a candidate to get elected to office.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: On Seeing The 100% Perfect Girl One April Morning
episode_acts.summary: As pure of a depiction of unadulterated crush feeling as can be imagined—from writer Haruki Murakami's collection of short stories, The Elephant Vanishes. It's read for us by actor Matt Malloy.

fields.episode_descript: The story of a company trying an experiment at marketing dolls to little girls:A new kind of doll store near Chicago's Magnificent Mile called "American Girl Place." The company has figured out all the ways little girls love dolls and they're trying to sell to nearly every one of those desires. Susan Burton reports that it's as if they've settled into a perch inside little girl's dreams and are selling from there. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the human urge to turn something inanimate into something that's alive, about the moment Pinocchio stops being a concoction of wood and string and becomes a real boy. He chats with Ronn Lucas, a ventriloquist, about moments when his dummies have seemed alive enough to surprise him.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Thank Heaven For Little Girls — Made Of Plastic
episode_acts.summary: The story of a company trying an experiment at marketing dolls to little girls:A new kind of doll store near Chicago's Magnificent Mile called "American Girl Place." The company has figured out all the ways little girls love dolls and they're trying to sell to nearly every one of those desires. Susan Burton reports that it's as if they've settled into a perch inside little girl's dreams and are selling from there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Know What Mr Bear Would Say
episode_acts.summary: A truly remarkable children's book just came back in print: The Lonely Doll, by Dare Wright. Jean Nathan tells the story of the book and its author, and how the author's life came to resemble something from her book.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Boy Who Would Be A Helicopter
episode_acts.summary: Kindergarten teacher and "Genius Grant" recipient Vivian Paley is the author of many books about the stories children invent and the way they play, and what it's about. At a time when schools are cutting back on having a doll corner, she tells the story of a child in her class who was sort of saved by a doll, and the story he told about the doll.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of dogs and cats and other animals that live in our homes. Exactly how much are they caught up in everyday family dynamics? We answer this question and others.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Heather and her girlfriend lived with a cat named Sid. The girlfriend showed all sorts of affection toward Sid that she never showed toward Heather.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Youth In Asia
episode_acts.summary: When a pet dies, to what degree can it be replaced by another? And to what degree can pets replace people in our lives? David Sedaris tells this story of cats and dogs and other animals.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: If Cats Ran Hollywood
episode_acts.summary: What do cats want to see on television? Steve Malarky, creator of the world's best-selling home video for cats, tells all. And—in the interest of equal time—a cashier who works at a chain store that sells pet products rants about the absurdity of the items she's ringing up every day: St.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Resurrection
episode_acts.summary: Writer Brady Udall with another story about what animals can take the place of, in our lives and in our homes—this one involving an armadillo. This work of fiction originally appeared in the Autumn 1999 issue of Story magazine.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who tell a lie and then believe the lie more than anyone else does. In other words: Stories about people pulling hoaxes...on themselves.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole explains why he decided that he would speak with a British accent—morning, noon and night—from the age of sixteen until he was eighteen...and how he believed the lie that he was British must be true.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Sun Never Sets—On The Moosewood Restaurant
episode_acts.summary: The story of two young people who, in their search to figure out who they were, pretended to be people they weren't. Both were from small towns; both took on false identities.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Conning The Con Men
episode_acts.summary: The story of a con man, one of the most successful salesmen in a long-running multimillion-dollar telemarketing scam, who finally got caught when he was conned himself. Nancy Updike talks about the case with Dale Sekovich, Federal Trade Commission investigator.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Outperforming The Performers
episode_acts.summary: A story about the Broadway show Rent, the thrill of sitting close to the stage...and the evil it can lead to.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who've grown so accustomed to wartime that the lives they've left behind no longer make sense.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with people who've been hit by lightning. They describe what happened at the moment the bolt struck ... and how they came to view it later.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Used To Bank Here But That Was Long, Long Ago
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff goes in search of the only existing mementos of a year-and-a-half of his life when he nearly died from Hodgkins Disease. The missing relics are his own pre-chemotherapized sperm — which reside somewhere in a Toronto lab.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Exile On Main Street
episode_acts.summary: Keith Gessen, a young Russian emigre, revisits the heroes of his youth: the brave Soviet dissidents who risked their lives at the height of the Cold War. Many of them resettled into comfortable suburban lives in America.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Shopping for a Better Future
episode_acts.summary: Producer Julie Snyder looks at what happens in one poor Chicago neighborhood when the community begins to undergo a revitalization and a new store comes to town.

fields.episode_descript: At one grain elevator on the outskirts of Lincoln, Nebraska, during the slow months, the five burly men who load corn, soybeans, wheat and milo onto trains spend their work hours watching soap operas. Meghan Daum gets them to explain what they like about the Young and the Restless. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass stands at the corner of Diversey and Broadway in Chicago and describes all the people who are out at 3:00 on a weekday.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Why Aren't You At Work?
episode_acts.summary: All those people you see in the middle of the workday, in coffee shops and bookstores? Who are they? Why aren't they at work? Reporter George Gurley tackled these tough questions. On four separate days, he interviewed these loafers in New York.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: In A World Full Of Soybeans, The Men Turn To Love
episode_acts.summary: At one grain elevator on the outskirts of Lincoln, Nebraska, during the slow months, the five burly men who load corn, soybeans, wheat and milo onto trains spend their work hours watching soap operas.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Geography Of Childhood
episode_acts.summary: In the early 1970s, a geographer named Roger Hart did a study of exactly where it is that children go during the daytime. For two years, he followed 86 children—all the children in a small town in Vermont, during the hours when parents were away at work.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Invisible Man
episode_acts.summary: A postman explains how it is that he can be so much a part of the scenery that people commit crimes in front of him, on quiet daytime streets, as if he's not there. This American Life producer Alex Blumberg spent a day with postman on Chicago's west side, to find out what he sees...and who sees him...and who doesn't see him, even though he's right there.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: $82.50 A Day.
episode_acts.summary: Writer Mona Simpson reads from her forthcoming novel My Hollywood. This excerpt is about the daytime life of Filipino nannies, during the hours in which they run the lovely homes of certain Los Angeles neighborhoods.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when seventh graders become an angry mob? Karen Bernstein reports on her own seventh grade class from small-town Connecticut. In 1973, a teacher turned them into an angry mob, an event they all remember decades later. She tracks down her classmates...and the teacher. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There's a TV ad so popular in Canada right now that people chant it in bars, stand and cheer it in theaters and at hockey stadiums. The ad taps into our desire to be part of a mob...and provides a safe way to do it, without fear.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Among The Thugs
episode_acts.summary: Writer Bill Buford reads from his book Among the Thugs. In it he sets out to try and understand the soccer hooligans who were rioting in ways large and small on a regular basis after soccer matches. It's a remarkable book—in turns funny, and then horrifying.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: One Tin Soldier Rides Away
episode_acts.summary: What happens when seventh graders become an angry mob? Karen Bernstein reports on her own seventh grade class from small-town Connecticut. In 1973, a teacher turned them into an angry mob, an event they all remember decades later.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Hissing Of Winter Lawns
episode_acts.summary: What happens when a crowd converges over something they strongly believe in, for weeks, and months, in front of television cameras that never go away? To what degree does that change the character of being in a crowd? A few days before Elian Gonzalez was seized by Federal authorities, reporter Alix Spiegel went to the lawn of his home, where activists camped out 24 hours a day.

fields.episode_descript: Can the secular world and the religious world understand each other?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Tillie Olsen reads from her short story "I Stand Here Ironing," from her collection Tell Me A Riddle. In the story, a mother reviews all that's gone wrong in the raising of her oldest daughter...and makes a few conclusions about what she should think about her mistakes as a mother.

episode_acts.name: Act One: She Said, She Said
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alex Blumberg conducts an investigation, perhaps the first ever, into this American subspecies: People who compulsively imitate their mother's voices in everyday conversation, well into adulthood.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Are You My Mommy?
episode_acts.summary: When Jessica Robinson was sent to adult prison at the age of 14, the state did such a terrible job taking care of her that several women—an embezzler, a convicted murderer, and some thieves—stepped in to mother her. Alex Kotlowitz reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mom Music
episode_acts.summary: Beau O'Reilly and his mother Winifred, who had 14 children, discuss her secret feelings about Johnny Cash and other matters on Mother's Day.

fields.episode_descript: In context of the Presidential contest between George W. Bush and Al Gore, we hear stories of character assassination—political and non-political.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Jack E. Robinson, Republican candidate for Senate in Massachusetts.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Those Who Ignore History Are Condemned To Repeat It—But Those Who Pay Attention To History Are Also Condemned To Repeat It
episode_acts.summary: Dirty political attacks go back to the very beginning of the American Republic. What's different today, says historian Richard Norton Smith, is that television and the other electronic media have made our contact with the candidates so intimate.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sonny Takes A Fall
episode_acts.summary: David Foster Wallace reports on a turning point in past Presidential primaries: The moment when John McCain failed to respond well to an attack by George Bush...which arguably ended up costing him the election.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When Slime Is Good
episode_acts.summary: Former political consultant Ron Susskind says that when he began in politics, he thought there was nothing lower than negative campaigning. But then in 1980 he learned that sometimes when your opponent attacks you, it can actually help you.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Who You Gonna Call?
episode_acts.summary: There is an entire class of consultant who does nothing but help people and companies that are under public attack. Eric Dezenhall is one of them.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: When Attacks Really Count
episode_acts.summary: There's little in adult life that can hurt as much as a character assassination attack when it happens in junior high school. We hear the story of how one boy organizes the entire school against his former best friend, a guy named Bob Cucuzza.

fields.episode_descript: Linnel Peterson drives the Number 66 bus in Chicago, on Chicago Avenue. She grew up just blocks from the route, still lives near the route, and says it's strange whenever she drives her car on Chicago Avenue these days. She sees people waiting for the bus and momentarily heads over to pick them up. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains the premise of the show, and we hear what's actually going on inside five of these cars.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Number 66 Bus
episode_acts.summary: Linnel Peterson drives the Number 66 bus in Chicago, on Chicago Avenue. She grew up just blocks from the route, still lives near the route, and says it's strange whenever she drives her car on Chicago Avenue these days.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Emerald Green Peugeot
episode_acts.summary: Nick Hornby, author of High Fidelity and About a Boy, explains the travails of driving his autistic son to the park.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Leased Volvo Sedan
episode_acts.summary: Jay Allison and his 12-year-old daughter discuss what radio station to listen to. She wants music.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Three More Bubbles
episode_acts.summary: An '88 Grand Marquis that Senator Conrad Burns inherited from his mother; a New York taxicab whose driver, Jeff Perkins, tape-records his passengers to help pass the time; a 1980s-era BMW 5 series in which film producer Rob Levine had his first job as driver and assistant to movie producer Edgar Sherrick.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: 1991 Silver Toyota Camry
episode_acts.summary: Ernest Castle and his best friend Clarence tool around the neighborhood where they grew up—the Chicago suburb of Hazelcrest—drinking and running into friends on a Sunday morning.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Bubble Five
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris, author of Me Talk Pretty One Day, explains how the most important moments of your life can happen in a car...and you can miss them.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Yellow AAA Pickup Truck
episode_acts.summary: Kelly Keggers demonstrates how there are angels on the road in San Francisco.

fields.episode_descript: This is a story of people wanting to change and not wanting to change at all. A Minnesota family builds the same 1970s-era suburban house three times, and moves it once, just so they don't have to live in a house that's different than the house that contains all their memories. Susan Burton reports. (22 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ben Schrank describes what it's like to work as a professional mover. He says that people often go sort of nuts when they see all their worldly possessions—all the stuff that defines them as people—packed into a van.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Sleeping In Mommy And Daddy's Room
episode_acts.summary: This is a story of people wanting to change and not wanting to change at all. A Minnesota family builds the same 1970s-era suburban house three times, and moves it once, just so they don't have to live in a house that's different than the house that contains all their memories.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Deal Of A Lifetime
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Koenig tells the story of how her stepsister Rue bought a house and moved in—but the former owner did not move out. And won't move out, until he dies.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: To A De-luxe Apartment In The Sky
episode_acts.summary: Producer Blue Chevigny used to have a job that was all about Moving Day—and people who didn't want to move. She worked for an agency in New York called Project Reachout, part of Goddard Riverside Community Center, that moved homeless, mentally ill people into their own homes.

fields.episode_title: Can You Fight City Hall…If You Are City Hall?
fields.episode_descript: Stories of a typically American kind of hero: The person who decides to fight city hall, who stands up alone for what's right, and damn the consequences. We hear the story of two idealists who work in government, two centuries after another set of idealists created the American government. Both of the modern idealists suffer and sacrifice because of their ideals; both lose their jobs.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Monica Childs joined the Detroit police force because she hated cops, and wanted to change the system from the inside. She wanted to be an honest cop.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Take That, Copper
episode_acts.summary: Monica Childs's story continues. She tells the story of how she was asked by her boss to do something illegal...and how she refused...and the repercussions she suffered.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Money Versus Man
episode_acts.summary: A small-town mayor tries to keep a developer from building in his town...and it results in the kind of snowballing fiasco by the end of which the town literally doesn't exist anymore. Alix Spiegel tells that story, which she produced with funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

fields.episode_descript: Every crime scene hides a story. In this week's show, we hear about crime scenes and the stories they tell.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Medical Examiner L.J. Dragovic, in Pontiac, Michigan, explains how every crime scene is like a novel.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How Do We Know?
episode_acts.summary: Forensic Criminologist Enrico Togneri in Nevada explains exactly what can be learned from evidence on a crime scene: What can be learned from the shape of a blood stain or a piece of cheese.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Grime Scene
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Nancy Updike spends two days with Neal Smither, who cleans up crime scenes for a living, and comes away wanting to open his Los Angeles franchise, despite the gore—or maybe because of it.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Criminal Returns To The Scene Of The Crime
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes criminals return to the scene of their misdeeds—to try to make things right, to try to undo the past. Katie Davis reports on her neighbor Bobby, who returned to the scene where he robbed people and conned people...to coach Little League.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: What Police Cannot Do
episode_acts.summary: Actor Matt Malloy reads a short story by Aimee Bender, from her book The Girl in the Flammable Skirt: Stories.

fields.episode_descript: Many Americans have dreamy and romantic ideas about Paris, notions which probably trace back to the 1920s vision of Paris created by the expatriate Americans there. But what's it actually like in Paris if you're an American, without rose-colored glasses?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with writer David Sedaris at the Louvre in Paris. David's never set foot inside, though he lives just a few minutes away.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Him Talk Pretty Three Days
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris takes Ira on a tour of his favorite spots in Paris. He moved to France with no special feelings for the place.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Ca Vie Americaine
episode_acts.summary: We hear from two Americans who live in Paris about what it is that draws the people who love France so much.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Notes From A Native Daughter
episode_acts.summary: Is Paris still the racially tolerant place that Richard Wright and James Baldwin discovered in the 1940s? Janet McDonald talks about whether African-Americans are still welcomed in Paris so warmly, even after a half century of African migration to the city. Also: Why it's sometimes better for her to put on a bad American accent.

fields.episode_title: Nobody's Family Is Going to Change
fields.episode_descript: Three stories that consider the question: Does anyone's family ever change?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass describes a children's book from the 1970s called Nobody's Family Is Going to Change by Louise Fitzhugh, the author of Harriet the Spy. On the surface, it sounds like a rather menacing title for a kids' book. But in fact, the story is about how kids can finally find peace if they stop hoping that their parents will ever be any different.

episode_acts.name: Act One: So A Jew, A Christian, And A Recording Crew Walk Into This Bar
episode_acts.summary: Julia Pimsleur travels to Alaska to spend some time with her brother, hoping he might change a little—just as he hopes that she'll change a little.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Matching Outfits Not Included
episode_acts.summary: What can happen if a sibling relationship doesn't ever change. Hillary Frank brings us the story of two sisters, now in their seventies, who have preserved the same relationship they had as girls...for better or worse.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Artist Formerly Known As Dr. Sarkin
episode_acts.summary: What happens when you want your dad to change—and he wants to change, too—but there's literally nothing that can be done to change him. Jon Sarkin was a chiropractor with workaholic tendencies.

fields.episode_title: Memo to the People of the Future
fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are engaged in something that's both difficult and probably futile: Trying to control how they'll be seen by generations to come.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells the story of a time capsule project designed to document our lives so that people a thousand years from now can know what we were like. Ira explains that when a friend of his got involved in the time capsule, Ira realized that he hates the people of the future.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dewey Decimal Beats Truman
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell visits four Presidential libraries on a fact-finding tour for...President Clinton. Not that he asked her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: One And One Don't Make Two
episode_acts.summary: What if you're remembered in ways that you don't like? What if you're remembered for something someone else did? In this act, we consider the case of Marguerite Oswald, mother of Lee Harvey Oswald. In 1965 she spent three days with reporter Jean Stafford, who wrote about Mrs.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You Don't Have To Be An Einstein
episode_acts.summary: After he died, Albert Einstein became a figure of international kitsch: Appearing in computer and Pepsi ads, showing up a comic character in movies with Meg Ryan, and until very recently his brain was on the loose without his family's consent...in the unauthorized possession of the doctor who did the autopsy, a man named Thomas Harvey. Mike Paterniti took a cross-country roadtrip with Dr Harvey and the brain.

fields.episode_descript: There are all sorts of situations in which we suspect the fix is in, but we almost never find out for certain. On today's show, for once, we find out. The whole program is devoted to one story, in which we go inside the back rooms of one multinational corporation and hear the intricate workings—recorded on tape—of how they put the fix in.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass speaks with two people who believe they've uncovered behind-the-scenes conspiracies but can't be sure. Attorney Andy Hail has sued the two biggest supermarkets in Chicago (Dominick's and Jewel) because they charge a dollar more for milk than stores around the country, and because their prices seem to change simultaneously, as if orchestrated.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: We hear the first part of our story about Archer Daniels Midland and FBI informant Mark Whitacre. In this half, Whitacre inadvertently ends up a cooperating witness—and turns himself into one of the best cooperating witnesses in the history of U.S. law enforcement, gathering evidence with an adeptness few have matched.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Our story about ADM and Mark Whitacre continues. The FBI finds out that their star cooperating witness Mark Whitacre has been lying to them for three years about some rather serious matters.

fields.episode_descript: David Rakoff tells a story about an actual pursuit—a scavenger hunt—that takes hundreds of hours to create ... done for the sheer pleasure of it. (18 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with producer Blue Chevigny about how a prank caller taught her that when it comes to pursuing happiness, Carole King, the world of independent cinema and the New York City Police Department have a lot more in common than she ever imagined. He also talks with MIT Professor Pauline Maier, author of the book American Scripture: Making the Declaration of Independence.

episode_acts.name: Act One: One Man's Treasure Is Another Man's Trash
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff tells a story about an actual pursuit—a scavenger hunt—that takes hundreds of hours to create ... done for the sheer pleasure of it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: When Happiness Hurtles Downward Like Rain From Heaven
episode_acts.summary: Thomas Beller tells the story of how we go from innocently amusing ourselves, to less innocent activities—all in the pursuit of happiness.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When Irish Eyes Are Smiling
episode_acts.summary: Every year, the Emerald Society, an association of Irish Chicago police officers, flies in policemen from New York City for Chicago's two big St. Patrick's Day Parades.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: How To Be Happy, One Man's Guide
episode_acts.summary: Finding happiness is serious business. At least, for most us, it requires an act of will.

fields.episode_descript: We live in a big enough country that there are lots of laws too obscure for most of us to have heard of...but which actually affect tens of thousands of lives in huge ways. This show deals with one of them: A 1996 immigration law that the Immigration Service itself says is unfair. Most of the law's original sponsors in Congress now say they went too far, and that they were too harsh when they passed the law. And yet most of the law's key provisions still stand unchanged.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to jail in Bristol County, Massachussetts, where there's a large Portuguese community, and where even a law-and-order sheriff named Tom Hodgson opposes this particular immigration law. He also talks with inmate Jorge Aruda, who's being deported for a crime he already served his sentence for.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Where Goes The Neighborhood
episode_acts.summary: Producer Blue Chevigny tells more of the story from Bristol County, where the immigration law of 1996 has a community of non-political people reluctantly going to protests, attending meetings at night, talking to politicians, and doing all sorts of other things most of us would do anything to avoid.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Whose Idea Was This Anyway?
episode_acts.summary: Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman Bill Strassberger explains why INS opposes parts of the 1996 immigration law, even while it enforces it. Congressman Barney Frank—whose district includes Bristol County—argues that most of his colleagues in Congress had no idea what they were voting for when they voted for key portions of the law.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Man Without A Country
episode_acts.summary: What happens if the immigration service wants to deport you, but the country you came from won't take you back? Under current law, usually, you stay in jail...indefinitely. Writer Alex Kotlowitz tells the story of one legal alien from Vietnam, Trung Tran, and the unusually close and friendly relationships he and his fellow deportees have with their captors in a jail in Victoria, Texas.

fields.episode_descript: The 2000 election season was strange in that many of the issues that the candidates debated most heatedly were ones that most of us have no handle on—prescription drug policy, social security solvency...and educational accountability. Producer Alex Blumberg travels to North Carolina, a state where many of the promises both candidates make regarding education are already in place. He finds, not surprisingly, that they work better as soundbite than as policy, and that if the two candidates get their way with education, it'll push it in a direction most North Carolina teachers find alarming. (23 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Bennett Miller and Matt Futterman about a campaign for student government that changed the way student elections were done in Mamaroneck High School back in 1985. Futterman, in the waning days of his campaign, tried a radical tactic: A TV ad.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fools Rush In
episode_acts.summary: A Michigan millionaire tries to swing his swing state, using only his voice, his millions, and major market radio ad time. A report on Jeffrey Fieger, who helped swing his state to McCain during the primaries with several irreverant attack ads against Bush.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What We Talk About When We Talk About The Issues
episode_acts.summary: The 2000 election season was strange in that many of the issues that the candidates debated most heatedly were ones that most of us have no handle on—prescription drug policy, social security solvency...and educational accountability. Producer Alex Blumberg travels to North Carolina, a state where many of the promises both candidates make regarding education are already in place.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Nepotism: A Beginner's Guide
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Adam Davidson is related to George W. Bush.

fields.episode_descript: We document one day in a Chicago diner called the Golden Apple, starting at 5 a.m. and going until 5 a.m. the next morning. We hear from the waitress who has worked the graveyard shift for over two decades, the regular customers who come every day, the couples working out their problems, assorted drunks, and, of course, cops.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Day
episode_acts.byline: By Susan Burton, Ira Glass, Nancy Updike

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Night
episode_acts.summary: In this act, we hear from the rowdier, drunker late-night patrons of the Golden Apple. A guy walks in with two young women, hoping to go home with one of them.

fields.episode_descript: A story of self-deception, a story about deceiving others, and a story about accidental deception. And how one type of deception can easily turn into another.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads an excerpt from Nick Hornby's novel About a Boy. The narrator, Will, recalls a time when he was a child that he convinced a friend that a portal to another world existed at the back of his closet.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Self-Deception
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alex Blumberg tells the story of an ex-con-turned-actor named Richie Castellano. After a bit role in the movie Analyze This, he moved to a small town and got dozens of people to invest money and time in a movie that never premiered.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Deceiving Others
episode_acts.summary: Lawrence Otis Graham reads from an account of how he left his job as a $105,000-a-year Manhattan attorney to enter the exclusive Greenwich Country Club the only way they'd allow a black man like him: as a busboy. He discovers just how invisible he can become once he gives up his seat at the table and starts clearing the dishes instead—so invisible that people make racist remarks right in front of him.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Accidental Deception
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris tells the story of a subway ride he took in Paris. Two American tourists mistake him for a Frenchman and, thinking he can't speak English, begin to talk loudly about how he smells.

fields.episode_descript: They mean something, whether we want them to or not.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear the story of a disastrous birthday party and how it's hard not to see these kinds of moments as symbolic of something bad.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pilgrim's Progress
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell takes over the family Thanksgiving dinner by bringing everyone to New York. What results is a series of milestones and family firsts.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kodak Moments Of The Dead
episode_acts.summary: The story of Tyler Cassity and how he's trying to remake one of our oldest rituals of commemoration.Tyler is one of the owners of a cemetery called Hollywood Forever, and he's been introducing 20th century technology to American funerals, which haven't changed much since the Civil War. At Hollywood Forever, the cost of a burial includes a video of your life: to be shown at your funeral, to be viewable at kiosks on the cemetery grounds, and to be posted—for eternity—online.

episode_acts.name: Act 3: Happy Birthday to Us
episode_acts.summary: Fresh Air host Terry Gross offers her congratulations and some words of wisdom to This American Life to help commemorate the show's fifth anniversary.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Birthday Present
episode_acts.summary: On a commemorative day, it can be hard to feel a real sense of the past and of how time has moved forward. Russell Banks has a story demonstrating what it might take to do just that.

fields.episode_descript: What goes on while mom and dad are away, that mom and dad never find out about. Including the story of two teenagers who decide to invent children to babysit, as an excuse to get out of their own house.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We listen in on a ritual that happens in millions of families every week: kids getting dropped off at the babysitters. Six-year-old Dylan and nine-year-old Sarah explain what they can and can't get away with when they have a babysitter.After that, host Ira Glass has a few words about Mary Poppins, who is the Gold Standard of all fictional babysitters.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What Big Teeth You Have
episode_acts.summary: Lots of babysitting is done by family members. Hillary Frank reports on what can happen when a teenaged son is put in charge of his younger brothers.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: In The Event Of An Emergency, Put Your Sister In An Upright Position
episode_acts.summary: The story of several huge companies that accidentally got put into the babysitting business in a big, big way because of snow on December 26, 1988. Every year on the day after Christmas, divorced kids all over America fly from one parent to the other.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Yes There Is A Baby
episode_acts.summary: Myron Jones and his sister Carol Bove explain what happened when they were teenagers, and they ended up babysitting children who didn't exist.

fields.episode_descript: In the wake of the 2001 election debacle in Florida, the two political halves of this country seemed angrier at each other than they had in decades. This week we bring you tales of that widening rift. Democrats explain why they're having trouble getting over it, and Republicans explain why this is so infuriating.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We got a new President, but after the recount mess in Florida in the fall of 2001 and the Supreme Court decision that ended the election, some people were having a hard time moving on. Why? Why couldn't they just let it go? Host Ira Glass talks with people at the inauguration.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You're Not The President Of Me
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Chait of The New Republic and David Horowitz of Slate magazine each tell the story of the Florida recount. There is astonishingly little overlap in their accounts.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Brief History Of Republican Time
episode_acts.summary: Writer David Brock gives us the inside story of how we got to this point of bitterness. It is not a pretty story.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bedroom Politics
episode_acts.summary: When it comes to political fighting, there's no more intimate a space than a marriage, where you have to get along. Where you have to figure out how to move on and get over disagreement.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Let Us Reason Together
episode_acts.summary: We return to the Supreme Court case of Bush vs. Gore to try to better understand why the majority ruled the way it did...and whether the decision was in fact as outrageous as many critics said it was.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: What Would You-know-who Do?
episode_acts.summary: A chat with Reverend Richard Harris, an African-American minister in Florida who's trying not to be angry about the election...because it's against his religion.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people living completely outside the grid of American life. Americans in Paris. Chinese in America. West Virginians in treehouses. Mexican-Americans in Rochester.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Lee Qi, who came to America from China. He worked in Chinese restaurants in small towns, live in tiny apartments with other illegal immigrants who worked there as well—apartments that were sometimes in the back of the restaurants.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Family That Flees Together, Trees Together
episode_acts.summary: The Jarvis family, a group of eight, goes on the run from the law—for seven years. They live on a boat, in a treehouse in a swamp.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What's French For "Steeee-rike Three?"
episode_acts.summary: Adam Gopnik reads a story from his book Paris to the Moon, about living in Paris with his family and wanting his son to be a bit more American. He tells him a bedtime story about the most American thing he can think of: baseball.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It's Julie Andrews' World, Sylvia Just Lives In It
episode_acts.summary: Sylvia becomes the first person in her Mexican-American family to go away to college, at a predominantly white school in upstate New York.

fields.episode_descript: We answer the following questions about superpowers: Can superheroes be real people? (No.) Can real people become superheroes? (Maybe.) And which is better: flight or invisibility? (Depends who you ask.)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to comic artist Chris Ware, who thought about superheroes a lot of the time as a kid. In grade school, Chris drew superheroes, he invented his own character named The Hurricane (not to be confused with Reuben Carter), and he made a superhero costume.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Invisible Man Vs. Hawkman
episode_acts.summary: John Hodgman conducts an informal survey in which he asks the age-old question: Which is better: The power of flight or the power of invisibility? He finds that how you answer tells a lot about what kind of person you are. And also, no matter which power people choose, they never use it to fight crime.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Wonder Woman
episode_acts.summary: Kelly McEvers with the story of Zora, a self-made superhero. From the time she was five, Zora had recurring dreams in which she was a 6'5" warrior queen who could fly and shoot lightning from her hands.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Green Team Of Boy Millionaires, Beppo The Amazing Supermonkey From Planet Krypton, And The Man From Sram
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Jonathan Morris, the amazingly funny and charming editor of the website Gone and Forgotten, an Internet archive of failed comic book characters. Jonathan explains what makes a new superhero succeed, and what makes him tank.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Wonder Twins
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with journalist Jason Bleibtreu about Luther and Johnny Htoo, twelve-year-old twins, and the leaders of a rebel army of Burmese separatists called God's Army. Everyone around them, both their own forces and their enemies, believed they possessed superpowers, that they could not be harmed by bullets, that they had the power to command ghost armies.

fields.episode_descript: The story in a way of a town that time forgot, or more accurately, a town that tried to forget the times. A special broadcast co-hosted by award-winning journalist Alex Kotlowitz, author of the books There Are No Children Here and The Other Side of the River.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear from Father Jim Kastigar, who got on the wrong side of Town Hall and suffered the kinds of consequences people in Cicero suffer. His parish was denied a permit to hold an outdoor religious ceremony they'd held peacefully for seven years, the youth group's tamale fundraiser was shut down by city inspectors and the parking lot near the church was deemed unfit for Sunday parking.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Untouchables
episode_acts.summary: To understand how Cicero reacted when Hispanics started flooding into town, you have to understand how it dealt with conflict in the past. For a period the town was run by Al Capone, and the mob was connected to Town Hall for most of the twentieth century.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Inevitable
episode_acts.summary: In the 1970s and 1980s, a wave of non-white migration into Cicero begins, this one primarily Mexican-American. The head of the political machine is named Betty Loren-Maltese, whose husband, now deceased, was convicted for mob-related activity.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: War By Other Means
episode_acts.summary: Despite the town's resistance, Hispanics now make up three quarters of the population. And yet the incumbent Town President, Betty Loren-Maltese, seems likely to win the next election.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: They Say Our Love Is Here To Stay
episode_acts.summary: Two stories about daily life in Cicero. First the tale of Dave Boyle, who stumbled into Cicero politics accidentally in the 1980s, suffered the bruises, and left town.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who try to revisit their childhoods. What they find. And what they do not find.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Kayla Hernandez, a seventh-grader who likes to reminisce about when she was a child, back in fifth grade. She visits Room 211 in her school, where her fifth grade class met, and looks at her old books, thinks about what happened there.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Once More, With Feeling
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Katz listens to old tapes of his family; then travels back to the neighborhood in Brooklyn they lived in during the 1950s, looking for evidence of what his childhood was like. His sister is along for the trip, and they do not agree on the meaning of what they're seeing.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Punk In A Grey Flannel Suit
episode_acts.summary: A mortgage broker named David Philp discovers that his old punk band from the 1970s is hot in Japan. He decides to leave corporate life and revisit his teenage years by going back on tour, playing music for the first time in two decades.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ich... Bin... Ein... Mophead
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alex Blumberg sets out to find a woman named Susan Jordan, who babysat him and his sister for a year when he was nine. He discovers that each of them remembered something about the other that the other would just as soon forget.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Every Day I Forget Something Else
episode_acts.summary: An excerpt from Nicholson Baker's novel The Everlasting Story of Nory, which is narrated, more or less, by a ten-year-old. In this excerpt, we return to what Kayla Hernandez talked about in the prologue to the show: The narrator discusses the difficulty of remembering what happens on any given day.

fields.episode_descript: A special show, composed entirely of stories from just one This American Life contributor: Scott Carrier, whose strange and compelling stories sound like nothing else on the radio.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the story about how Scott first got into radio. He was listening to a story on the radio one day, thought "I can do that," and promptly hitchhiked across the country to Washington, to the headquarters of NPR.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Test
episode_acts.summary: At a fairly bleak time in his life, Scott took a job driving all over the state of Utah, interviewing people who were diagnosed with schizophrenia. His job was to administer a standard test, which measured mental health.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Friendly Man
episode_acts.summary: It's another not-so-great period in Scott's life. This time he takes a job inside his profession, as a producer for a national commercial radio program.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who Am I? What Am I Doing Here?
episode_acts.summary: Scott goes on a quest to discover if the amnesia in the movies—where someone gets bonked on the head and forgets everything—ever happens in real life.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Day Mom And Dad Fell In Love
episode_acts.summary: Scott interviews his 11-year-old daughter about his marriage. She sheds light on the previous three stories in the show.

fields.episode_descript: Adam Davidson reads from his high school diaries.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to two different people who have stories they just can't get over...stories that make them cringe...and stories from which we can glean what makes a cringe story different from other kinds of stories.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What We Cringe About When We Cringe About Love
episode_acts.summary: Cringing means literally "to shrink from something dangerous or painful." So what could be more potentially dangerous or painful—more cringe-worthy—than love? Nancy Updike reports on the characteristics and bylaws of cringe love.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: M*a*s*h Notes
episode_acts.summary: Ira reports on a week he spent on the set of the TV show M*A*S*H in 1979, supposedly to do a story about the program for National Public Radio. He was 20 years old.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ariel Sharon, Shimon Peres, David Ben-Gurion, and Me
episode_acts.summary: Adam Davidson reads from his high school diaries.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Cringe And Purge
episode_acts.summary: A lot of stories from your life, the more you tell them, the less power they have over you. But cringe stories often don't seem to lose their power over time.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the legacy of absent parents. We hear four cases from the files of the Missing Parents Bureau.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Cate, a white woman with a black, adopted, seven-year-old son, Glen. Sometimes Glen threatens that he's going to return to his real family—royalty, in Africa.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Better Left To The Imagination
episode_acts.summary: Most sperm banks provide all sorts of information about their donors: Education level, medical background. They even have videotaped interviews and recorded answers to essay questions.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Tell It To The Void
episode_acts.summary: We hear a series of letters that originally appeared on the brief-lived, little-known, but well-loved webzine Open Letters. They're written by a woman who signs her name as "X" and are addressed to the father of her adolescent son.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: I'm An Orphan; Don't Tell My Mom
episode_acts.summary: When Starlee Kine was a kid, she wanted to be a child star so badly that she signed up for an acting class with a famous acting teacher named Kevin McDermott. One of the class's exercises was to develop a character with a troubled past, and a real psychologist would come in for a session of character group therapy.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Runaway Mom
episode_acts.summary: In Seattle, Dan Savage and his boyfriend adopted a son, DJ. It was an open adoption, so the birth mother could keep in touch with her kid.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to love their neighbors, and failing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to the Arnold Abbott, the founder of "Love Thy Neighbor," a Florida charity that's being sued by "Love Your Neighbor," a Michigan ministry and business. "Love Your Neighbor" owns the trademark on the phrases "Love Your Neighbor" and "Love Thy Neighbor;" the attorney for the Michigan business Julie Greenberg, contemplates whether suing a neighbor can fall within the category of loving them as yourself.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mr. Rothbart's Neighborhood
episode_acts.summary: When he was just a kid, Davy Rothbart and his family visited the most famous neighbor in America—Mr. Rogers—at his summer cottage on Nantucket.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Girl Next Door
episode_acts.summary: What happens when the kid next door wants to be your new friend...and comes over, tries to talk to you, befriends your dog. Are you a bad person if you don't want to accept the tiny hand of friendship? Cheryl Wagner tells the story of her young, persistent next-door neighbor.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Ratman Cometh
episode_acts.summary: What happens when a good neighbor goes bad. Katie Davis lives on a block where everyone wants to get along, and they're trying, even though one of their favorite neighbors has dozens of rats infesting her yard and attacking other houses.

fields.episode_descript: One way to measure the faith—the good old-fashioned faith—that people put in celebrities is to examine what people ask of them. Ann Hepperman has a story that gives a rare and vivid glimpse of what people want from celebrities...or anyway, what they want from country legend Willie Nelson.
