Justin Kaufman reads surprisingly riveting excerpts. The book was self-published at xlibris.com.

fields.episode_descript: Sure, John Kerry got in trouble for using the phrase, but we have no fear. Because we know that regime change, like charity, begins at home. This week: Stories of regime change in everyday life—people switching jobs, people switching families, businesses dying and new ones starting in their place.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with This American Life producer Julie Snyder about a personal regime change that happened when she was a kid, after her parents got divorced and her stepdad came on the scene. She says that by the time her parents separated, literature on what to tell the children was everywhere, and the kids took it relatively well.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Unconquerable
episode_acts.summary: Katie Davis tells the story of one storefront in her bustling commercial neighborhood that resists all occupation. Over the decades, many businesses have tried to operate there, none have succeeded.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Or Give Me Death
episode_acts.summary: The story of a band of libertarians with a plan to take over a state. They call it the Free State Project and it goes like this: They pick a state with a low population, 20,000 of them move to it, establish a voting majority, and run it according to libertarian principles.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Heart Is A Lonely Junta
episode_acts.summary: Jeffrey Brown wrote a comic novel called Clumsy, a beautiful and intimate account of his relationship with his ex-girlfriend. He talks with Ira about the relationship and why he chose to draw cartoons about it after it ended.

fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass talks with producer Alex Blumberg about going on a date with a woman from Russia. Even though she spoke perfect English, the night was a misunderstanding, because they each had different ideas of what is meant by the words "good date." (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with producer Alex Blumberg about going on a date with a woman from Russia.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Chasm Between Comedy And Music
episode_acts.summary: Why is it that karaoke machines only have songs on them? If what they do is take a version of a public performance and allow the rest of us to give our own interpretations of the material, why aren't there other options, like the "you talkin to me?" scene from Taxi Driver, or Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech. Jonathan Goldstein and producer Starlee Kine find out why when they go to a karaoke club that has, along with all the songs, comedy routines for people to perform.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Star Of Bethlehem
episode_acts.summary: Very few Palestinians speak Hebrew, and very few Israelis speak Arabic, even though most Palestinians and Israelis live a short drive from one another. Nancy Updike has this story about Nasser Laham, a Palestinian TV journalist in Bethlehem who has a nightly show where he translates Israeli broadcasts into Arabic.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Translating For The Very, Very, Very, Very Tall
episode_acts.summary: The story of a not-very-tall, not-very-athletic man—Colin Pine—who becomes a minor celebrity in the NBA, as the translator for one of the most famous rookies in basketball history: The first Chinese player ever to go number one in the draft, Yao Ming. Reporter Jesse Hardman tells his story.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are lost, histories that are lost, and things that are lost. This show was recorded onstage in front of audiences on a five-city tour in May 2003. The cities: Boston, Washington DC, Portland Oregon, Denver and Chicago. Featuring house band OK Go.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells the story of Chris Sewell, who was living on the street and yet somehow managed to find $610,940 of lost money that belonged to the city of New York, hidden away on the Internet.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Losing It
episode_acts.summary: If you're going to do a show about people who are lost, you pretty much have to include a story about adolescents. Jonathan Goldstein tells a story from his teenage years.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Teacher Hit Me With A Ruler
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell tells the lost story behind a patriotic song, "The Battle Hymn of the Republic." An early version of the song celebrated an American terrorist. She's accompanied by Jon Langford and the band.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: I Found Your Letter
episode_acts.summary: Davy Rothbart reads from letters, notes, scraps of paper and school papers, which have been lost by their original owners. He collects and publishes things like this in his magazine, Found Magazine.

fields.episode_descript: David Sedaris tells a story about how, as a teenager, he was scared of certain people...until he made them scared of him, one fateful night. Sedaris is the author of Me Talk Pretty One Day and other books. (17 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Alex Meyer, high school sophomore in Seattle and host of the Alex Meyer Show, which he produces in his bedroom, on a castoff home stereo of his dad's. When it became clear that no radio station would ever give him a job, he simply took charge and created his own show to learn what he needed to learn.

episode_acts.name: Act One: It's Not Just The Aces That Are Wild
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris tells a story about how, as a teenager, he was scared of certain people...until he made them scared of him, one fateful night. Sedaris is the author of Me Talk Pretty One Day and other books.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Playing Clinton In The Bush Leagues
episode_acts.summary: Katy Vine reports on yet another promising young person, Tye Thomas, and how he went through the rise and fall of a full political career, in just one year, at the age of 21, in the Texas town of Gun Barrel City.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You Talkin' To Me?
episode_acts.summary: Adam Davidson reports from Baghdad on the charismatic, ambitious young Americans who want to bring freedom and hope to Iraq, if only the Iraqis would listen to them. There is a ominous information gap between the U.S. officials running the country and the Iraqi people being governed.

fields.episode_descript: Instead of the usual "each week we choose a theme, and bring you 3 or 4 stories on that theme" business, we throw all that away and bring you 20 stories—yes, 20—in 60 minutes.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass introduces the idea of doing 20 stories in one hour.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Don't I Know You
episode_acts.summary: Contributor Starlee Kine talks to actor Tate Donovan about the day he felt he was being exactly the kind of celebrity he'd wanted to be: when suddenly, he was approached by a kid with a camera.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: No, Of Course I Know You
episode_acts.summary: Writer and producer Scott Carrier recognizes a woman he sees in a restaurant.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It's Commerce That Brings Us Together
episode_acts.summary: Susan Drury talks about "Swap and Shop," a local radio classifieds show that has become a low-tech, personable sort of Ebay.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Sound of One Hand Waving
episode_acts.summary: From Patty Martin: a one minute, four second vacation on Nantucket Island, involving a lot of waving.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Sound of No Hands Clapping
episode_acts.summary: From Vicki Merrick, Eric Kipp, and Jay Allison at Transom: scallops on Martha's Vineyard.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Reaching Out With Radio
episode_acts.summary: From Blunt Youth Radio: a story of a possibly bad "food situation" at the cafeteria in juvenile detention.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Up Where the Air Is Clear
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein, host of Wiretap, brings us this story about The Penguin as a young man.

episode_acts.name: Act Eight: The Greatest Dog Name in the World
episode_acts.summary: Two brothers, ages 12 and 13, have very different ideas for their dog's name.

episode_acts.name: Act Nine: Of Dogs and Men
episode_acts.summary: Elaine Boehm overhears a couple in her pet shop, trying to choose a dog collar.

episode_acts.name: Act Ten: Act Ten
episode_acts.summary: A two minute play called “Title,” written and performed by Greg Allen and Heather Riordan of the Chicago group, The Neo-Futurists.

episode_acts.name: Act Eleven: Etiquette Lesson
episode_acts.summary: Author David Sedaris on cell phone usage in restrooms.

episode_acts.name: Act Twelve: To Tell the Truth
episode_acts.summary: Brent Runyon reports from the kids' section at the public library.

episode_acts.name: Act Thirteen: More Lies
episode_acts.summary: Catherine and John, two college undergrads, do a babysitting gig together.

episode_acts.name: Act Fourteen: Call in Colonel Mustard For Questioning
episode_acts.summary: Mystery and missing flavor at the hot dog plant.

episode_acts.name: Act Fifteen: Mister Prediction
episode_acts.summary: Author David Rakoff worked at an advertising agency, and could see exactly where its technology was going.

episode_acts.name: Act Sixteen: That One Guy at the Office
episode_acts.summary: Someone sits next to the printer. You see him forty times a day.

episode_acts.name: Act Seventeen: You Can't Choose Your Gift
episode_acts.summary: Richard Kerry has an impressive ability: he can recreate the sound of a whole swamp.

episode_acts.name: Act Eighteen: Party Talk
episode_acts.summary: Author Chuck Klosterman and his friends make a party game out of comparing television shows to rock bands.

episode_acts.name: Act Nineteen: The Hard Life at the Top
episode_acts.summary: Every year 1,200 new army cadets arrive at West Point. Once they say a single sentence correctly, they can go to their barracks.

episode_acts.name: Act Twenty: The Greatest Moment I Ever Saw On a Stage
episode_acts.summary: Teenage girls from a detention center perform a song for their parents.

fields.episode_descript: Living behind enemy lines among the enemy, it's sometimes hard to remember why you're fighting in the first place.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells the enemy camp story the way we like it to be told.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Confession
episode_acts.summary: Patrick Wall was a special kind of monk. He was a fixer.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Blood Agent
episode_acts.summary: You can divide all living creatures into two camps. We humans are in one camp, along with lots of other things like dogs and birds and trees and caterpillars.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: And I Love Her
episode_acts.summary: A short story, "Fatso," by Etgar Keret. A woman reveals to her boyfriend that she's not always what she seems.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Yet Another Ineffective Road Map For World Leadership
episode_acts.summary: Two women in a small town find themselves on opposite sides of a protest. One is for the war in Iraq, one is against it, but despite this, they cross enemy lines and become friends.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about what the passage of time can do to someone. When each story starts, the world's aligned one way. Years pass—or sometimes just months—and everything's different.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays parts of a speech by George Ryan, former Governor of Illinois. When he was a state senator in 1977, Ryan was part of a successful coalition that voted to reinstate the death penalty in Illinois.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Hiker And The Cowman Should Be Friends
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier tells the story of how the environmentalist that ranchers hated the most—whom they tried to run out of town and hanged in effigy—came to take the ranchers' side of things. Some funding for this story comes from Hearingvoices.com and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Scrapbook, The Verb
episode_acts.summary: A Houston woman tries to document every day of her four-year-old daughter's life...in preparation for a day far away. Produced by Julie Checkoway and Kimberly Meyer of Story Rodeo.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Slingshot
episode_acts.summary: A story by John Hodgman about returning to the beach after a very bad year.

fields.episode_descript: In real life, we usually never get to invent ingenious solutions, like the guy in the old TV series MacGyver. Today, four real stories in which real people invent amazingly clever solutions to their problems.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reminds the audience about the old TV series MacGyver, about the guy who stops bad guys without a gun. He uses science and sheer ingenuity to invent solutions.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Bolt Of Lightning, Pro And Con
episode_acts.summary: Chuck Klosterman talks about the time he MacGyvered his way out of one of the worst situations a boyfriend can find himself in.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Files In Cakes, Ha!
episode_acts.summary: There's a book called Prisoners' Inventions, by a California inmate who publishes under the pseudonym Angelo. He describes the ingenious devices prisoners build out of the rudimentary materials at hand.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: So Crazy It Just Might Work
episode_acts.summary: The story of an FBI sting that involves gangsters, G-men, and lots and lots of people who want to work in the movies. It's adapted from an article by Elizabeth Gilbert that first appeared in GQ magazine.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Girl's Guide To Mending The Unmendable
episode_acts.summary: Susan Burton tells the story of how she used a clever scheme to get over a broken heart.

fields.episode_descript: What is it about them, our mean friends? They treat us badly, they don't call us back, they cancel plans at the last minute, and yet we come back for more. Popular bullies exist in business, politics, everywhere. How do they stay so popular?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear kids recorded at Chicago's Navy Pier and at a public swimming pool, talking about their mean friends. Host Ira Glass interviews Lillie Allison, 15, about the pretty, popular girls who were her best friends—until they cast her out.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Return To The Scene Of The Crime
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein interrogates the girls, now grown up, who terrorized him and his classmates years ago in school—and finds they can be just as scary as ever. Jonathan Goldstein is the author of the novel Lenny Bruce is Dead.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Does Niceness Pay?
episode_acts.summary: In which we conduct a little scientific experiment—on tape, with hidden microphones—about whether niceness pays. We wire two waitresses with hidden microphones.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: And What's Going On With You?
episode_acts.summary: A case study in every word from a friend meaning its opposite. An excerpt from the short story "The Underminer." A book based on the story is forthcoming from Bloomsbury USA.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Keeping It In The Family
episode_acts.summary: An excerpt of Bernard Cooper's story about the bill he got from his own father, for the entire cost of his childhood. Actor Josh Hamilton reads.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of very unusual pen pals, including a ten-year-old girl from Michigan who befriends Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. A show from 2003 that we’re bringing back with news this week of Noriega’s death.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to historian Ted Widmer about two of the first pen pals in the New World. John Winthrop and Roger Williams were both Puritans in Massachusetts in the 1630s.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Who Put The "Pistol" In "Epistolary?"
episode_acts.summary: Andrea Morningstar tells the story of a ten-year-old girl from small town Michigan named Sarah York, and how she became pen pals with a man who was considered an enemy of the United States, a dictator, a drug trafficker, and a murderer: Manuel Noriega.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Pen Pal Husband
episode_acts.summary: When Janice Powell's husband went to prison, he wrote her a letter every day for eight years. When he was at home, he'd drink and get violent, but Janice said that the years in prison were the best of their relationship.

fields.episode_descript: What is this thing? This thing called love, that is. For answers, we explore the romance novel industry, a $1.5 billion empire run almost entirely by and for women. Plus, relearning the rules of romance from the other side of the gender line. And Sarah Vowell tells the story of the Greatest Romance of the 20th Century.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear Billie Holliday, Keely Smith and Leo Reisman (with Anita Boyer) asking the musical question, "What Is This Thing Called Love?" And, reporter Sean Cole talks about love with Joe and Helen Garland, who fell in love during World War II, but married other people. Thirty years later they met again, felt the same love they felt when they were young, divorced their respective spouses, and finally married each other.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Inside The Romance Industry
episode_acts.summary: Robin Epstein visits people who define this thing called love—for a living. She attends the annual convention of the Romance Writers of America.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: View From The Other Half
episode_acts.summary: An act named after two TV shows, one where women sit around and talk, the other where men sit around and talk. If men are from Mars and women are from Venus, when you switch from one planet to another, what do you need to know about love? We hear from several transsexual men who've done exactly that.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Love Story
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell tells "The Greatest Love Story of the 20th Century," Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash.

fields.episode_descript: Some stories we make happen, others happen to us. Extremes from the latter category, where people let things happen to them and don't act, even when maybe they should. David Rakoff guest hosts.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: David Rakoff tells a story from when he was a kid, about the day he realized the he would inevitably be viewed a certain way by his classmates, no matter what he did or said.

episode_acts.name: Act One: If It Drives, Go Live
episode_acts.summary: For four hours in August 2001, KCAL-9, an all-news channel in Los Angeles, broadcast a very unusual police pursuit. The suspect drove under the speed limit, obeyed all traffic laws, signaled every time he wanted to turn.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Don't Just Stand There
episode_acts.summary: When you get to know someone, really know them, you can almost predict their behavior. It's comforting, this intimacy.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Hello, Baby
episode_acts.summary: A lot of life's inevitability is hazy; it'll happen some time, but you're not sure when. But with pregnancy, it's on an invariable schedule: forty weeks.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: And On The Eighth Day, God Created Tartar Sauce
episode_acts.summary: A few times every summer, for complicated scientific reasons, thousands of live fish, crab and shrimp wash up onto the beaches of Mobile Bay, Alabama, on the Gulf Coast. It's a natural event—like a hurricane, but good.

fields.episode_descript: We make what's usually invisible, visible: the world of trash. We follow the trash from the sanitation men on the street, to the mob guys who controlled the hauling business, to the people who actually live in dumps.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Every day each American produces 4.8 pounds of garbage. Where does it all go? Ira talks with Robin Nagle, a anthropology professor at New York University who's been studying garbage,and says that most of us want garbage to be invisible.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Oh, Mr. San Man
episode_acts.summary: The people who pick up our trash don't call themselves garbagemen. They're san men ("san" being short for "sanitation").

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Except For The Smell, I Think I Have A Crush On You
episode_acts.summary: There are squatters who've built entire neighborhoods on top of rotting trash heaps in Mexico. They scavenge in the garbage piles for their living.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: "I'm A Legitimate Businessman...Waste Management."
episode_acts.summary: We hear the secret recordings that ended mob control of New York garbage collection, and talk to Rick Cowan, the NYPD detective who went undercover for three years to make them.

fields.episode_title: The Annoying Gap Between Theory...and Practice
fields.episode_descript: What happens if you're poor, and do everything right, all your budgeting, all your choices...are you actually any better off? Actor Liza Colón-Zayas reads a passage from Adrian Nicole LeBlanc's book Random Family. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to two people about their real-life stories of theory and practice. Subject 1: Michael.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Rock, Paper, Computer
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Jack Hitt explains the alarming difference between theory and practice when it comes to computerized voting machines—specifically, those made by a company called Diebold.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Detroit Is In The House
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg spends three days with Michigan state representative Steve Tobocman. He ran for office because he thought that would be the best way to change things for his neighborhood in Detroit.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Zero Divided By Zero Is Still Zero
episode_acts.summary: What happens if you're poor, and do everything right, all your budgeting, all your choices...are you actually any better off? Actor Liza Colón-Zayas reads a passage from Adrian Nicole LeBlanc's book Random Family.
episode_acts.byline: By Liza Colonzeas, Adrian Nicole LeBlanc

fields.episode_descript: Biblical fables ripped from today's headlines. In his ongoing effort to write his own version of the Bible, Jonathan Goldstein retells the story of Cain and Abel. Finally we hear Cain's side of the story. Plus: neighbors in a small town in Illinois wonder if they could have stepped in—as their neighbors' keepers—to prevent a brutal triple murder. And the story of a man who lives his life among his political enemies, feeling responsible for the problems he believes they're creating for everyone.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the story of Cain and Abel, and the question in the story, "Am I my brother's keeper?" It turns out that the story doesn't really answer that question very satisfyingly.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Whatever Happened To Baby Cain?
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein retells the story of Cain and Abel. Finally we get to hear Cain's side of things.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: This Land Is Your Land, This Land Is My Land. Or Maybe Not.
episode_acts.summary: We hear the story of someone trying to help all sorts of people who absolutely do not want his help. Nancy Updike reports on Dror Etkes, who has taken it as his personal mission to document the spread of Israeli settlements in the West Bank: Every shack, mobile home, housing cluster, bypass road and town.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Neighbor's Keeper
episode_acts.summary: Could anyone in a small farming town have done anything to prevent a brutal crime, committed by one of their neighbors? Robert Kurson first wrote about the March 2002 triple murder in Toulon, Illinois, for Chicago Magazine. His article has been reprinted in the anthology Best American Crime Writing 2003. (15 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: During the highest turkey consumption period of the year, we bring you a This American Life tradition: stories of turkeys, chickens, geese, ducks, fowl of all kinds—real and imagined—and their mysterious hold over us.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and his friend Danielle, whose family says they're eating fish when in fact it's turkey or chicken, for an unusual reason.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Duki
episode_acts.summary: The story of a typical American family, and how their family dynamic has reorganized itself around an imaginary duck, invented in childhood, who somehow stayed alive well into adulthood.  (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Winged Warrior
episode_acts.summary: In the 1960s, the adventures of "The Greatest Crimefighter the World Has Ever Known"—Chickenman—were heard on hundreds of radio stations. On today's show, the winged warrior flies again.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Chicken Diva
episode_acts.summary: Yet another testimony to the power chickens have over our hearts and minds.  Jack Hitt reports on an opera about Chicken Little.  It's performed with dressed-up styrofoam balls, it's sung in Italian and, no kidding, able to make grown men cry. (14 minutes)The official website for the opera "Love's Fowl" by Susan Vitucci and Henry Krieger is pulcina.org.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Trying To Respect The Chicken
episode_acts.summary: Ira accompanies photographer Tamara Staples as she attempts to photograph chickens in the style of high fashion photography. The chickens are not very cooperative. (15 minutes)Tamara's photos have been collected in a book, The Magnificent Chicken: Portraits of the Fairest Fowl.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from faraway, hard-to-get-to places, where all rules are off, nefarious things happen because no one's looking, and there's no one to appeal to.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with sailor and researcher Captain Charles Moore about a gigantic area in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, as far away from land as you can get, that is filling with plastic trash. There are five spots like this on the world's oceans.

episode_acts.name: Act One: No Island Is An Island
episode_acts.summary: Nauru is a tiny island, population 12,000, a third of the size of Manhattan and far from anywhere: Yet at the center of several of the decade's biggest global events. Contributing editor Jack Hitt tells the untold story of this dot in the middle of the Pacific and its involvement in the bankrupting of the Russian economy, global terrorism, North Korean defectors, the end of the world, and the late 1980s theatrical flop of a London musical based on the life of Leonardo da Vinci called Leonardo, A Portrait of Love.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: On Hold, No One Can Hear You Scream
episode_acts.summary: This American Life senior producer Julie Snyder found herself in a ten-month battle with her phone company, MCI Worldcom, which had overcharged her $946.36. She spent hours on hold in a bureaucratic nowhere.

fields.episode_descript: In early 2003, we brought you a special show about a California teenager, Hyder Akbar, who traveled to Afghanistan, his family's homeland, for the first time. His father had moved back to work for Afghan President Hamid Karzai. Hyder brought along a tape recorder, and his audio diary, produced by Susan Burton, won the Silver Award for Best Documentary at the 2003 Third Coast International Audio Festival.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Hyder was 17, he went to Afghanistan. This place that he'd been hearing about his whole life.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Part One
episode_acts.summary: Hyder notices changes in Kabul in the year since he visited Afghanistan. Then he heads to Kunar, near the Pakistan border, one of the remote regions where Al Qaeda, the Taliban and local warlords are still fighting the new Afghan government and the U.S. military.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Part Two
episode_acts.summary: Hyder's story continues. He and his convoy of American soldiers run into trouble on their way back home.

fields.episode_descript: The vexing difficulty of finding the perfect gift.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to a busy Target store one week before Christmas. Most shoppers he talks to don't think any of their gifts will be returned.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Make A Joyous Noise Unto Your Mom
episode_acts.summary: Ian Brown tries, after decades of failure, to give his mother the perfect Christmas gift. He and his brother attempt something they haven't done since they were kids: Rehearse and sing her a program of Christmas carols.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Christmas Memory
episode_acts.summary: We play a 1959 original recording of Truman Capote reading his holiday story A Christmas Memory—and sounding eerily similar to David Sedaris.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Secret Santa. Very Secret Santa.
episode_acts.summary: Caitlin Shetterly reports on a true-life holiday fable from rural Maine, complete with a misunderstood recluse with a heart of gold, a deserving family in need, and a very special Christmas tree farm with secrets of its own.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people living without. Nubar Alexanian explains what fish can do for him that his own ears cannot. Sarah Vowell explains the cheerful journalism of deprivation. And other stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: It's hard to give things up. Host Ira Glass tells the story of Walter, a three-year-old boy who had to give up his pacifier, and then, wanting comfort, asked all the adults around him to tell the stories of when they gave up their pacifiers.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Do You Hear What I Hear?
episode_acts.summary: Nubar Alexanian was forced to give up one thing—and then gave up another thing by choice. This story was put together by Nubar and his daughter Abby, with help from Jay Allison, for Transom.org, with funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Journalism Of Deprivation
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell introduces you to a magazine that—if you're lucky—you've never had to read. A magazine called Living Without. Her story is part of the Hearing Voices project, which gets funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Call Of The Great Indoors
episode_acts.summary: Every week, Chelsea Merz has lunch with a homeless man named Matthew, in the same restaurant. Matthew's been on the street for seven years, but once or twice a year, he housesits for a friend.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Tin Man
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes it's hard to figure out if you're doing something of your own choice or because someone wants you to do it.

fields.episode_descript: People return to the scene of the crime where they should have spoken clearly, plainly, forcefully...to review what the hell went wrong, and in a few cases, to fix it. Jonathan Goldstein tries to stop time. Charles Monroe tries to figure out how to teach a lesson to the President of the United States.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about trying to figure out what to say to his dying mom. He's sure that someday he'll wish he said something different than what he actually said.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Freeze Frame
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein, for once in his life, gets to suspend time itself. He gets to freeze the hands of time, and finally come up with the right thing to say in all sorts of situations.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: In The Bush Leagues
episode_acts.summary: The true story of a young activist, Charles Monroe-Kane (now a producer at WPR's To the Best of Our Knowledge), who, in his very first political action, heckled the leader of the free world...and failed horribly...leaving him mulling it over late at night, for years.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Can Of Worms
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris wishes he could take back a wish. He's the author of Me Talk Pretty One Day and other books.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Life Sentence
episode_acts.summary: The President of the Maryland State Senate, Mike Miller, a veteran political operator, talks about the off-the-cuff remark in 1989 that many people say changed his life forever.

fields.episode_descript: People leaving the situation they're used to and striking off for something less familiar.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with two Vietnam veterans about what it was like to leave the army and come back to civilian life. Both of them, to their surprise, missed the excitement of combat.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I've Got A Secret I've Been Hiding From You
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alex Blumberg tells the true story of Jerry Springer's life before he was a talk show host. It's the story of an idealistic and serious Jerry Springer, a progressive politician, and the most popular mayor ever of a certain American city.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: God And Hockey
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Shalom Auslander, who was raised as an Orthodox Jew and who made a pivotal break with his faith at a Rangers game. Shalom Auslander is the author of a book of short stories, called Beware of God.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Nuns Amok
episode_acts.summary: Susan Drury reports on a group of Glenmary Sisters who chose to leave the Catholic Church in the 1960s but still stay nuns, more or less. Several of the former sisters, Monica Appleby, Helen M.

fields.episode_descript: For millennia, people have tried to reach a spiritual promised land by fasting. Jesus did it. Buddha did it. Monks and saints and new age gurus have done it. And, for for this episode, the late David Rakoff tried it. He did a 20-day fast, to find out if it would bring him any form of enlightenment. Also, contributor Starlee Kine tells a story about getting as close to one promised land as you possibly can, without actually going in.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Fans of movie musicals might know about something called the "I Wish" number. In many movies and Broadway shows, it's the main character's first song, in which they express the hope that will set the story in motion.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Across the Street From Heaven
episode_acts.summary: Contributor Starlee Kine tells a story about getting as close to one promised land—Disneyland—as you possibly can, without actually going in.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Life In The Fast Lane
episode_acts.summary: For millennia, people have tried to reach a spiritual promised land by fasting. Jesus did it.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mystery Train
episode_acts.summary: Hillary Frank with a story of a train ride, an overheard conversation, and two people seeking two different promised lands.

fields.episode_descript: Chris Neary tells the story of how a bungled Nazi sabotage operation from the early days of World War II has become the legal foundation for the Bush administration's current push to try U.S. citizens in military tribunals. But when you return to the original facts of the case, it's not only unclear if they support current Administration policy, it's unclear if they support the Supreme Court's decision in the original case. The attempted sabotage operation was chronicled in Washington Post reporter Michael Dobbs's excellent book,  Saboteurs: The Nazi Raid on America. (36 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass discusses Howard Stern, who claims that current action by the FCC will take him off the air. We hear from Congressman Fred Upton of Michigan who heads the House committee passing new FCC fines, and from Brent Bozell who heads the Parents' Television Council.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Straight Eyes On The Quirin Guys
episode_acts.summary: Chris Neary tells the story of how a bungled Nazi sabotage operation from the early days of World War II has become the legal foundation for the Bush administration's current push to try U.S. citizens in military tribunals. But when you return to the original facts of the case, it's not only unclear if they support current Administration policy, it's unclear if they support the Supreme Court's decision in the original case.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mush Polling
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sarah Koenig talks to the people behind survey results—whose answers determine so much of political news.

fields.episode_descript: Stories trying to understand what actually happens in marriages during this time when the definition of marriage is up in the air. Music throughout the hour by a real wedding band, a good one: The Doug Lawrence Orchestra.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass visits Kassie Hannah's Adult Living class at Rock Island High School in Rock Island, Illinois, where they stage a mock wedding each year as part of the curriculum.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What Really Happens In Marriage
episode_acts.summary: Ira visits marital researcher John Gottman, who's part of a generation of researchers that have revolutionized the way we see marriage by observing successful and unsuccessful marriages and trying to figure out what the successful happy ones are doing that the ones who end up in divorce are not. Marriage research and links to marriage education programs for couples are online at www.smartmarriages.com.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Defense Of Marriage Act
episode_acts.summary: Adam Felber explains how legalized gay marriage are ruining his marriage with his wife. (His comments first appeared on his blog felbers.net.) And Ira talks about legal strategies with Matt Staver, the head of the group defending traditional marriage in the California lawsuits; and with David Cruz, a law professor at the University of Southern California.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: I Want To Be A Statistic
episode_acts.summary: Starlee Kine gets answers about her parents marriage from her dad...after a lifetime of mystery. She and her sister had wanted her parents to divorce since they were little.

fields.episode_descript: People looking for miracle cures, some from above, others from abroad. A son tries to help his mom in a faraway place defy the laws of medical science. A daughter tries to help her dad by going to a faraway place to defy the laws of the United States of America.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Dr. Stephen Rosenberg of the National Cancer Institute about a cancer patient of his who spontaneously healed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Changing The Channeler
episode_acts.summary: This American Life contributor Davy Rothbart goes to Brazil with his deaf mother to try and get her hearing back from a miracle healer called Joao de Deus, or John of God. They had trouble agreeing whether the things they witnessed down there were miracles or not.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Entities Known As The Food And Drug Administration
episode_acts.summary: Julia Whitty's father's cancer medication cost $47,000 a year if she bought it in the United States. It cost $1,200 a year if she bought it in a foreign country.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people stuck in unfixable situations who try desperate measures. Sometimes these are inventive, sometimes they're ingenious, sometimes they even work.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass visits the Richard E. Byrd Community Academy, a public elementary school in Chicago in need of repair.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hasta La Vista, Arnie
episode_acts.summary: Therapist Scott Miller tells the story of a patient who thought he was Arnold Schwarzenegger. Solving the problem required unusual treatment.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: We Built This City On Rock And Coal
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with a college freshman in Michigan about her governor's new Cool Cities Initiative. (4 minutes) Then Sarah Koenig reports on how the towns of Mauch Chunk and East Mauch Chunk went in for an unusual makeover to try to save their town fifty years ago.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Router Less Taken
episode_acts.summary: A man tries to unload a piece of junk he bought by selling it on eBay...not by concealing its many terrible properties...but by bragging about them. Which gets results.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Rocks At Rock Bottom
episode_acts.summary: Hillary Frank speaks with a man who figured out how to get over heartbreak, using only your throwing arm. She's the author of Better Than Running at Night and I Can't Tell You.

fields.episode_descript: Jonathan Goldstein with a story of the kind of preferential treatment we all dream of, where waiters routinely bring us extra appetizers on the house, delivery men throw a little something special into our take-out orders, and deli owners regularly comp us free pickles and chips. He talks with his friend Howard, who lives this dream, about all the work that went into making it a reality. (16 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with two sisters, one high-school age, the other younger, about who gets treated better in the family. They all agree the youngest does.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lunchtime With The King Of Ketchup
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein with a story of the kind of preferential treatment we all dream of, where waiters routinely bring us extra appetizers on the house, delivery men throw a little something special into our take-out orders, and deli owners regularly comp us free pickles and chips. He talks with his friend Howard, who lives this dream, about all the work that went into making it a reality.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Except For That One Problem, It's Perfect
episode_acts.summary: Gregory Warner reports on a program that solves a problem that's been plaguing prisons for years. But there's just one catch...prison guards hate it, because it gives inmates special treatment.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mommie's Psychic Helper
episode_acts.summary: When Aimee Phan and her brother were babies, her mother had horoscopes predicting their futures made and put on tape. The tapes were in Vietnamese, which Aimee and her brother didn't understand.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Way To A Boy's Heart Is Through His Stomach
episode_acts.summary: Lisa Carver's nine-year-old son, Wolfgang, was born with a rare illness that, among other things, makes it impossible for him to eat anything by mouth. He's fed through a g-tube, straight into his stomach.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to drag science where it doesn't belong.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass visits Arlington Racetrack on opening day with four regulars who explain their quasi-scientific systems for winning.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Spook Science
episode_acts.summary: Jake Warga heads out with AGHOST, a Seattle group that's using whatever scientific principles they can find to hunt for ghosts. Jake's story got support from Hearing Voices and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and editorial advice from Barrett Golding.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Government Science
episode_acts.summary: The Union of Concerned Scientists has issued a report condemning the Bush Administration for what it called "distorting and censoring scientific findings that contradict" Administration policies. One of the cases cited in the report involves something called the Advisory Committee on Childhood Lead Poisoning.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Beauty Science
episode_acts.summary: Adam Sternbergh, the co-editor and co-founder of Fametracker.com, dissects the issue of People magazine which is now on newsstands — an issue which chooses the most beautiful people in the world, allegedly through purely scientific methods, somehow ending up with a list of people who have movies coming out this summer. This story first appeared at Fametracker.com.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Radio Science
episode_acts.summary: Fake science can be fun. Fake science can make people happy.

fields.episode_title: I'm From the Private Sector and I'm Here to Help
fields.episode_descript: Today's show is devoted to just one story. Contributing editor Nancy Updike went to Iraq to try to figure out what it's like to be a private citizen working in the middle of a war zone. Private contractors are a part of this war in unprecedented numbers, but we don't know that much about the people doing these jobs — why they chose to come to Iraq, and what they're seeing that we can't.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: This American Life host Ira Glass talks about one thing you probably haven't heard about the occupational hazards of working in Iraq: Since you work every single day, you never know what day of the week it actually is.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Airport
episode_acts.summary: The private security guys (from a company called Custer Battles) who guard Baghdad International Airport usually get along fine with the U.S. military personnel stationed there—except when Nancy happened to be taping, and a huge fight broke out.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hank
episode_acts.summary: A former military man, Hank was hired by Custer Battles to clean up one of its other Iraq operations, guarding businessmen. He has a very clear idea of who he wants working for him: "flat-bellied, steely-eyed professionals." Instead, he's trying to tighten up a outfit whose workers once engaged in an extended firefight at a Baghdad hotel—against each other.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Green Zone
episode_acts.summary: The Green Zone is where the Coalition Provisional Authority has set up its headquarters, and the former seat of Saddam Hussein's government. Nancy ends up at a hidden restaurant by a helipad, with workers for Fluor Corporation, who have just arrived in Iraq to fix power plants.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Electricity
episode_acts.summary: On their way out to a power plant, Nancy and Lee, a supervisor for Fluor in Iraq, get shot at by men in a BMW. When they finally get to the plant, Nancy learns why it's been so difficult to get power plants running again in the country.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Karen
episode_acts.summary: Karen Hahn, who works for Custer Battles at the airport, started out there screening women passengers—and learned a lot from their handbags. Unlike most people Nancy met in Iraq, Karen is not a former military person, she doesn't work with guns or big machines, and she's never been happier in her life.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Cops
episode_acts.summary: Hundred of Iraqi police officers have been killed since the United States invaded Iraq. One Boston cop, Jerry Burke, is trying to keep them on the job, and train them in Western police practices.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Hank Redux
episode_acts.summary: Nancy finally gets Hank, the Custer Battles employee, to answer the question of whether he ever has any reservations about his mission—or the country's mission—in Iraq. (3 minutes)John Kimbrough composed original music for this week's show.

fields.episode_descript: Perhaps there was a time when the rules of polite society were clear. No longer. This week, we bring you stories of people forced to try to figure out how to maintain their dignity—and decency—in some very unsettling situations.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: It seems apples for the teacher is a bygone tradition. Host Ira Glass talks to Mindy, a first-grade teacher, about the rather racy gifts her students give these days at Christmas.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Government Says The Darnedest Things
episode_acts.summary: The FCC says it just wants a little civility on the nation's airwaves. And by tightening the rules on what swear words are allowed, government officials say they're protecting kids.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dems Gone Wild!
episode_acts.summary: Ken Kurson, a Republican, runs for New Jersey State Assembly in a very, very Democratic district. He expects disagreement and debate.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Swiss Near-miss
episode_acts.summary: Out with a man on a moonlit walk on Lake Geneva, an American woman does the proper thing. He does not.

fields.episode_descript: Three stories about people who decide to try out a new life—the kind of life their parents never wanted for them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: How does a person who's not gay convince herself that she is for two years? Host Ira Glass talks to one of the show's contributing editors, Nancy Updike, about her two-year stint believing she was a lesbian, even though she was not attracted to women.

episode_acts.name: Act One: That's Funny, You Don't Look Jewish
episode_acts.summary: Chaim and Billy both lived in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, just blocks away from each other, in worlds that almost never collided. Chaim was a Hasidic Jew—he'd never heard pop music or watched MTV.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Miami Vices
episode_acts.summary: A nice Florida girl changes high schools and takes the opportunity to try on a new personality...the slutty kind. Sascha Rothchild reads from her own teenage diary.

fields.episode_descript:
Aimee Bender reads her story "The Rememberer," about a woman whose lover is undergoing reverse evolution. One day he's a man, the next, a salamander. The story is in her her book The Girl in the Flammable Skirt. (8 minutes)

In the 75-year history of the song "Someone to Watch Over Me," there's only been one hard rock cover ... and you can download it here. The song was recorded right here at Chicago Public Radio by the band American Draft. Check out the music they write themselves at their website.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Susie and John Drury moved to their farm just two years ago. But when John got sick for awhile, people who were no more than friendly acquaintances started helping out in ways that completely surprised them.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Doctoring The Doctor
episode_acts.summary: Jo Giese's husband, a doctor named Douglas Forde, had spent his life caring for other people. But then he had some strokes and developed a kind of dementia.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Over-protective Kind
episode_acts.summary: Veronica Chater's mother wants to go to a resort in Mexico with a friend. Her father, a former cop with an extravagant sense of security, prepares as if she's headed for a war zone.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Are You A Man Or A Mouse?
episode_acts.summary: Aimee Bender reads her story "The Rememberer," about a woman whose lover is undergoing reverse evolution. One day he's a man, the next, a salamander.

fields.episode_descript: How, one might wonder, could a simple hunk of cheese drive a wedge between an aging aunt and her devoted niece? Sure, every family has its share of grudges, secrets and bad behavior. What's harder to understand is how those things end up changing family relationships in ways no one could have predicted. Three stories about family legends that have either been kicking around for years or been completely suppressed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Eddie Schmidt about his Aunt Mary, the source of the best stories in his family—including how she was so cheap she stole azalea bushes from the side of the highway.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Take My Cheese, Please
episode_acts.summary: We continue with the story of Eddie Schmidt and his parents, Josie and Bob, who tell the greatest Aunt Mary story of all time: the one about the provolone, the glance, and an aggrieved woman's attempt at revenge.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: We Don't Talk About That
episode_acts.summary: Some family legends are most notable for their absence. They're too disturbing or scandalous to tell.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Admissions
episode_acts.summary: The story of a prank that the family was building up to for years. But when the youngest sister executes it—perfectly—her mother can't forgive her.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about adults struggling to figure out what is in the best interest of some child. And in situations where, what is best is not so clear.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Colin Dunn had an A average as an eighth grader, and he was in a program for gifted kids. But he hated school.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I'd Rather Not
episode_acts.summary: The story of Colin's truancy continues. The whole thing was especially awkward for his dad, because he's a behavior specialist for 100 public schools in Oregon—including Colin's school.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Exodus Of One
episode_acts.summary: When she was three years old, Georgia was caught by immigration officials when a Milwaukee woman tried to bring her into the country illegally from Jamaica. She ended up at a residential detention center in Chicago.

fields.episode_descript: Lissa Yellow Bird searches for missing people. She's great at it. But then, her niece goes missing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Writer Thomas Frank went on the radio show On Point to talk about his book What's the Matter With Kansas? The book is about how people in his home state keep voting for Republicans even though Republican policies aren't helping them economically. But the people who called in to the radio show didn't exactly see it his way.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pink Elephant
episode_acts.summary: Patrick Howell, a gay Republican from Orlando, goes on what might seem like an ill-fated hearts-and-minds mission at the Republican Convention.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Right And Righter
episode_acts.summary: A visit to one of the many states where the GOP has been picking up strength, to see why and how. This American Life producer Alex Blumberg spends some time with the Alabama Republican Party.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Indecent Proposal
episode_acts.summary: Mike is a Democrat, the yellow dog kind. The guys he works with—rich guys, like him—are mostly Republican.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: It's My Party
episode_acts.summary: One of the most civil conversations you'll ever hear between GOP members on opposite sides of the party's culture war. Log Cabin Republican Patrick Howell from Act One sits down to talk with Christian Republican Steven King from Act Two, to hash out their differences.

fields.episode_descript: Hilary Hoffman wanted to give up his nine-to-five urban life. So he convinced his wife they could make it as organic farmers in rural Pennsylvania. It hasn't been going so well. The deer eat his vegetables. Weeds are strangling his strawberries. His muscles are constantly sore. Plus, he's just not a morning person. So This American Life arranges for him to get a makeover, agricultural style. George DeVault, a writer and editor at Rodale's New Farm magazine, who has his own organic farm, comes to the rescue. Shea Dean helped produce this story. (19 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When you're in school, you're supposed to be a Renaissance person — do art, literature, sports, music—and be enthusiastic about it all. You get graded for effort.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Farm Eye For The Farm Guy
episode_acts.summary: Hilary Hoffman wanted to give up his nine-to-five urban life. So he convinced his wife they could make it as organic farmers in rural Pennsylvania.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Diary Of A Longshot
episode_acts.summary: When a 24-year-old runs for city council in Washington, D.C., he has to answer one question over and over: What's a 24-year-old doing running for city council? Sam Brooks is the candidate. At one point his campaign looks so hopeless, even he doesn't believe he's the better man for the job.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Contrails Of My Tears
episode_acts.summary: Brett Martin documents a previously unnoticed human phenomenon, one that involves airplanes...crying...and Reese Witherspoon.

fields.episode_descript: Behind enemy lines, sometimes people get confused about whose side they're on and how to fight the enemy.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Behind enemy lines, sometimes people get confused about whose side they're on and how to fight the enemy.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Our Own Worst Enemy?
episode_acts.summary: In this election year, one question is rarely asked in a very direct way: Is the Bush Administration competent at conducting the war on terror? Every few weeks it seems like there's more news about how badly it's going: Senior Administration officials like Colin Powell now admit the insurgency in Iraq is growing; terror suspects like Yasir Hamdi (who supposedly were so dangerous that having a lawyer talk to them about their case would compromise national security) are released without trial because the evidence against them is so flimsy; there was the Abu Ghraib prison scandal; and just this week, the former head of the U.S. operation in Iraq, Paul Bremer, declared the problem from the start was that there were not enough troops there. Host Ira Glass discusses whether the Bush Administration is simply not very skilled at fighting terror with Richard Perle and James Fallows.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Confession
episode_acts.summary: Patrick Wall was a special kind of monk. He was a fixer.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Blood Agent
episode_acts.summary: You can divide all living creatures into two camps. We humans are in one camp, along with lots of other things like dogs and birds and trees and caterpillars.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: And I Love Her
episode_acts.summary: "Fatso," a short story by Etgar Keret from his collection The Bus Driver Who Wanted to Be God. A woman reveals to her boyfriend that she's not always what she seems, especially at night.

fields.episode_descript: Washington Irving Elementary School became a model of school reform in Chicago a decade ago. The school did it without adding a ton more money. It wasn't a magnet school or charter school. Their strategy: Get the kids to enjoy reading and writing, get them glasses if they need them, give teachers control of their classrooms. Scores climbed. Teachers like Cathy were happy. Students actually liked coming to school. We hear excerpts from Ira's 1994 All Things Considered series about the school. (21 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Ira heard that Cathy La Luz, the best public school teacher he'd met during all his years of education reporting, was considering leaving her job, he went to see her in her classroom.

episode_acts.name: Act One: 1994
episode_acts.summary: Washington Irving Elementary School became a model of school reform in Chicago a decade ago. The school did it without adding a ton more money.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 2004
episode_acts.summary: We continue with the story of Irving Elementary, and hear what's happened to make Cathy La Luz think about quitting. In just nine months, the reforms that had made the school a model began to unravel.

fields.episode_descript: Favorite stories by our longtime contributor and friend David Rakoff.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass asks how it's possible that some people still don't know what they think of President Bush just a few days before election day.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Buddy, Hackett
episode_acts.summary: Ira spends hours talking to James Hackett, known to his friends, and by the end of the story, to Ira, as Gig. He's a doctor in Cincinnati and a lifelong Republican.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Cold-cock The Vote
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt tells tales of voter sabotage so outrageous that we swear will get you yelling at your radio and calling for people's heads.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: One Son, One Vote
episode_acts.summary: Matthew Chasteen is 18 years old. He's joined the Navy, and he's voting for the first time.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: He's Got Legs
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Lisa Pollak goes canvassing with her friend Andy in Ohio. He's a first time door-knocker for MoveOn.

fields.episode_descript: It's rare that a successful apology happens. One where you apologize to someone, not for selfish reasons, but because you're really sorry and you want them to know that, and when the person you're apologizing to really hears what you're saying. Three stories of people groping toward that moment.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about the surprising way apologies tend to play out in couples when one person has cheated on the other, based on stories his mother, Dr. Shirley Glass, told in her book Not Just Friends. And contributing editor Sarah Vowell tells us about the time she couldn't stop apologizing.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Repeat After Me
episode_acts.summary: A story by regular contributor David Sedaris involving his sister Lisa, a secret, and her very understanding parrot. David read this story live, and it's on his CD Live at Carnegie Hall. The story is also published in his book Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dial "S" For Sorry
episode_acts.summary: Tapes from The Apology Line, a phone line connected to an answering machine where people leave anonymous apologies—but not to the people they actually hurt.		Also, an interview with "Mrs. Apology," a.k.a.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Two Words You Never Want To Hear From Your Doctor
episode_acts.summary: Until recently, most insurance companies didn't want doctors to apologize to patients they'd harmed, for fear it could be used against them in lawsuits. Now, though, there's a new movement encouraging doctors to 'fess up and say sorry.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about amateur spies—regular people who spy on other regular people, and the consequences of their spying.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to This American Life contributing editor Jack Hitt about the time he hacked into his employer's computer and found out what he didn't want to know.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Lobbyist
episode_acts.summary: When Burt Covit was programming his VCR one day, he accidentally tuned in to a channel showing the lobby of a building. He started to watch, and couldn't stop.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Life With The Haters
episode_acts.summary: Writer Beth Lisick decides to try a new strategy to get her infant to sleep better, and buys a baby monitor as part of the deal. Soon, she's hearing her neighbors make drug deals over the monitor's frequency.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mystery Shoppers
episode_acts.summary: They are ordinary people who go undercover in coffee shops and chain stores, spying for The Man. This American Life producer Lisa Pollak reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Stop Bugging Me
episode_acts.summary: What do you do when you think your apartment is being bugged? You call the apartment de-buggers. It's a weird job; still, someone's got to do it. This American Life producer Jane Feltes goes on a counterespionage mission.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people who love their cars, for better or for worse.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear the eerily calm answering machine message that Brita Bonechi leaves for her husband, Rob, after she's had an accident and is trapped upside down in her car.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Crunk In The Trunk
episode_acts.summary: David Segal of the Washington Post investigates the competitive world of db drag racing ("db" stands for "decibels"), where people customize their cars with stereos so loud that they can't actually be played—or listened to—at least not without risking a nose bleed.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Baby You Can't Drive My Car
episode_acts.summary: Jamie Kitman tells the story of the car that broke his heart. He's the New York Bureau Chief for Automobile Magazine and the automotive editor for Men's Journal.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Objects In The Rear View Mirror May Be Alarmingly Familiar
episode_acts.summary: When Darren's car was stolen in Washington, D.C., he did what everyone does: He called the police and figured he'd never see the car again. But within a week, as he was driving his rental he spotted his stolen Toyota, and chased it, with some help from the nice lady at 9-1-1.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Not Your Father's Chevrolet Salesman
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Sarah Koenig checks out competing sales techniques at a Chevy dealership on the south side of Chicago. It turns out the number two salesman thinks he's number one, and the number one salesman...is a grandmother, Yvonne Hawk.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: End Of The Road
episode_acts.summary: People don't want to stop driving, no matter how old they get. This American Life producer Lisa Pollak talked with Rosyna Salerno, a 91-year-old widow, who recently gave up her license after she had a stroke. And Dan Neil, automotive critic for the Los Angeles Times, tells the story of Stirling Moss, the race car driver who, at 75, still holds the world record for completing a 1,000-mile race called the Mille Miglia.

fields.episode_descript: What life is like for American soldiers in Iraq.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Tom Irwin, a stand-up comic who recently performed for American troops all around Iraq for over a month. It seems his best joke, about Iraqi sheep farmers, only makes sense if you're a soldier on deployment.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When Weekend Warriors Work On Weekdays
episode_acts.summary: When an Arkansas National Guard Unit is sent off to Iraq, they assume they're going to help rebuild the country, since they're trained as an engineering unit. But once they arrive, they find themselves in a combat zone, unprepared and ill-equipped.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Marine Life
episode_acts.summary: Rob Miller is a first lieutenant in the Marine Corps commanding a weapons platoon in "Charlie Company" of the First Battalion, Eighth Marines. He led his men recently in the battle of Fallujah, and in a recent satellite phone call, he told This American Life contributing editor Jack Hitt (who also happens to be his uncle) what we never seem to hear elsewhere: Details of what it's like to fight house-to-house in urban warfare.

fields.episode_descript: Sometimes, getting your big break isn't all it's cracked up to be. A comedy duo lands the gig that can make them famous—the Ed Sullivan Show at the height of Sullivan's popularity—and they bomb. A third-grader gets his big chance to please his mother and push his drunken father out of the picture. And other stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells the story of Marisela and Yadira, who were honors students in high school. They wanted to go to the best colleges, but they couldn't get federally-funded scholarships because they weren't U.S. citizens; they had come from Mexico when they were little.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Take My Break, Please
episode_acts.summary: Charlie Brill and Mitzi McCall were a comedy duo back in the mid-1960s, playing clubs around Los Angeles, when their agent called to tell them he'd landed them the gig of a lifetime: They were going to be on The Ed Sullivan Show. The only problem was that their performance was a total fiasco, for a bunch of reasons, including one they never saw coming.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What Happens In Baghdad, Stays In Baghdad
episode_acts.summary: Two young men, Jeff Neumann and Ray Lemoine, decide it'd be interesting to be part of the rebuilding of Iraq. So they take a bus to Baghdad during the war and the bombings and the kidnappings and try to make their mark.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Oedipus Hex
episode_acts.summary: Shalom Auslander reads his true story, "The Blessing Bee." It's about the time when, as a third-grader at an Orthodox Jewish school, Shalom saw his chance to both make his mom proud, and push his drunken father out of the picture. Part of his scheme involved winning the school's bee on the complicated Hebrew blessings you say before eating certain foods.

fields.episode_descript: After four lawyers fail to get an innocent man out of prison, his friend takes on the case himself. He becomes a do-it-yourself investigator. He learns to read court records, he tracks down hard-to-find witnesses, he gets the real murderer to come forward with his story. In the end, he's able to accomplish all sorts of things the police and the professionals can't.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Carl King, a self-taught investigator, talks about the murder case he's working on now—one the police think they've already solved. Carl got started in this business after freeing his close friend from prison.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Anya Bourg tells the story of Carl King's first case, where he's able to accomplish what experienced detectives and lawyers were not. He proves that his friend was innocent.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: The story of Collin Warner continues. His friend Carl manages to convince the real shooter and the victim's brother (who watched him die on the sidewalk) to testify on Collin's behalf.

fields.episode_descript:
David Wilcox tells the story of how his mother, who was dying of lung cancer, made a short videotape for his sister, who is severely developmentally disabled. She hoped the tape would become a daily part of her daughter's life, like the other music and movies she liked to play, that she would watch it and remember her mother. But she also knew her daughter might never even see it. (9 minutes)

And we hear two stories from people who recorded their own memories in a booth in Grand Central Station in New York, as part of the StoryCorps project. The first is Don "Moses" Lerman, a champion eater who's thought a lot about what he'll be remembered for. The second is Ronald Ruiz, a bus driver, who's never forgotten one of his passengers. StoryCorps funders include the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, National Public Radio, the Ford Foundation and the Open Society Institute. (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Laura Mayer, editor of the New Trier Township High School yearbook, about the renegade student who jumps into as many club photos as he can. And contributing editor Jack Hitt explains how this impulse—to be remembered as someone you're not—can be traced back to Benjamin Franklin.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Thinking Inside The Box
episode_acts.summary: David Wilcox tells the story of how his mother, who was dying of lung cancer, made a short videotape for his sister, who is severely developmentally disabled. She hoped the tape would become a daily part of her daughter's life, like the other music and movies she liked to play, that she would watch it and remember her mother.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Where's Walter?
episode_acts.summary: Starlee Kine rents a room at a Ramada hotel in Fond du Lac, Wisconsin, where a ghost supposedly plays pranks on the guests and staff. The ghost's name is Walter, for Walter Schroeder, the guy who originally built the hotel in the 1920s.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Giving Up The Ghosts
episode_acts.summary: Writer Shalom Auslander reads his short story about how he decided to start forgetting the dead, even though his job required him to remember. Shalom's most recent book is Hope: A Tragedy.

fields.episode_title: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
fields.episode_descript: Amy O'Leary tells the story of a software writer at Apple Computer whose job contract ends, but he refuses to go away. He continues to show up at work every day, sneaking in the front door, hiding out in empty offices, and putting in long hours on a project the company canceled. There were no meetings, no office politics, no managers interfering with his work. Soon, he had written a perfect piece of software. His final problem is figuring out how to secretly install it in Apple's new computers without anyone noticing. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Bobby Morris about his decision to quit baseball's minor leagues after nine years and pretty good stats all the way.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Karachi Kid
episode_acts.summary: When Muhammad Kamran's Pakistani parents sent him off to college in Philadelphia, it was understood that he'd come back to Karachi after four years. But now that graduation is almost here, Muhammad thinks he might want to stay in America.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Not Far From The Tree
episode_acts.summary: Amy O'Leary tells the story of a software writer at Apple Computer whose job contract ends, but he refuses to go away. He continues to show up at work every day, sneaking in the front door, hiding out in empty offices, and putting in long hours on a project the company canceled.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Because I'm The Mommy, That's Why
episode_acts.summary: One day Virginia Holman's mother announced she was taking Virginia and her little sister to their cottage at the beach. At the time, Virginia didn't realize they were being kidnapped—that they'd be held for months, hostage to her mother's mental illness.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about trying to understand who's on your side. The defense minister of Israel visits would-be suicide bombers in prison, only to find out that in at least one case, he feels sorry for the terrorist. A prosecutor tries to censor a punk rock star. He takes him to court, but never bothers to listen to his lyrics. During the trial, he begins to think twice about his mission. Plus other stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Stephen Dubner, co-author of Freakonomics, about one of the men in his book, a guy named Stetson Kennedy. In the 1940s, Kennedy, a Southerner, infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Minister Meets The Martyr
episode_acts.summary: In 2002, a Palestinian named Arin Ahmen was arrested for planning to become a suicide bomber in Israel. A month later, Israel's defense minister visited her in prison.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: I Am Curious, Jello
episode_acts.summary: About 20 years ago, a Los Angeles prosecutor named Michael Guarino thought he'd make a name for himself by taking the lead singer of the Dead Kennedys to court for obscenity. He was so sure of success, he didn't even bother to listen to the lyrics.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Eight Percent Of Nothing
episode_acts.summary: Our program ends with a story of knowing your enemy in a more domestic setting: In a marriage. Actor Matt Malloy reads the story by Etgar Keret. "Eight Percent of Nothing" is from a collection of stories called The Nimrod Flip-Out.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who try simple mind games on others, and then find themselves way in over their heads.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews Lori Gottlieb about the time she sent a letter to a writer in a magazine, a letter packed with white lies.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Continued
episode_acts.summary: Lori Gottlieb's story continues. One complication led to another and before long, the writer seemed to be lying to her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Spy Who Loved Everyone
episode_acts.summary: A group called Improv Everywhere decides that an unknown band, Ghosts of Pasha, playing their first ever tour in New York, ought to think they're a smash hit. So they study the band's music and then crowd the performance, pretending to be hard-core fans.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Invisible Girl
episode_acts.summary: Scott Carrier and his family live in the same Salt Lake City neighborhood as Elizabeth Smart, the fourteen-year-old whose kidnapping made international news in 2002. Though pictures of Smart were everywhere in Salt Lake City, and thousands of volunteers searched for her, her captors brought her back to the neighborhood she was taken from, and they walked freely through the streets with her.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people who end up making choices they'd rather not make, when their options begin to run out. Sometimes this works out great; sometimes not so great.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews Joe Amrine, who was falsely accused of murder. Rather than avoid the death penalty, Amrine said everything he could think of on the witness stand to get the jury to give him a death sentence.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Working Class Hero Sandwich
episode_acts.summary: Dawna Lentz was a new employee at Quiznos sub shop in Seattle when the franchise owners just gave up. They stopped buying supplies, stopped answering their phones.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Don't Drive Like My Brother
episode_acts.summary: Charles Johnson was living in St. Louis, married with a young daughter, and he had no job.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Confessions Of A Not-so-dangerous Mind
episode_acts.summary: How NOT to get a job in U.S. intelligence: Admit to being a pervert during your job interview. Somehow, though, that's exactly what happened to a perfectly normal, nice guy who we're calling "Matt" for the purposes of this story.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about how easy it is for communication to go awry, and what the consequences can be after it does.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to film critic Jonathan Rosenbaum of the Chicago Reader about an anonymous love letter that turned out to be very different than it seemed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Froggy Goes A-courtin'
episode_acts.summary: The story of a series of misunderstandings with very dire consequences. Shaheen was stopped by the police, who looked at what was in his car and before Shaheen knew it, he'd come to the attention of some of the highest ranking officials in the Defense Department.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Cat Got Your Tongue
episode_acts.summary: A fable about gossip and the service industry involving a cat and a baboon, by David Sedaris. David's story was recorded live at UCLA's Royce Hall, as part of UCLA's Performing Arts series.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Romance Languages
episode_acts.summary: Ben Karlin talks about how a foreign language can come in handy when it comes to smoothing over potentially ugly misunderstandings. When he was a student in Italy, he signed up to coach basketball in hopes of making friends with some Italians.

fields.episode_descript: Sons and daughters get to find out the one thing they've always wanted to know about their father. The answers aren't always what they hope for.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Aric Knuth was a little kid, his dad would leave for six months at a time. He was a merchant marine.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Make Him Say Uncle
episode_acts.summary: Lennard Davis grew up hearing from his parents that he should, at all costs, avoid being like his good-for-nothing Uncle Abie. Later, after his father died, that very same uncle told him that his father was not, in fact, his father.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: My Favorite Martian
episode_acts.summary: Paul Tough's father was a mild-mannered professor. And then one day he left his family and went on a quest.
