fields.episode_descript: We hear a quick rundown of all the ways that Christian conservatives are making headway in advancing their values as public policy, why they think total separation of church and state is not what the founding fathers intended. And why they're wrong. On the Christian side of this argument is Pastor Russell Johnson of the Ohio Restoration Project, which is trying to recruit "patriot pastors" to get involved in state politics; and Bill Carrico, a Virgina legislator who's trying to make sure people can express their Christianity in schools and other public places. And then there are the videos and speeches of David Barton, whose group, Wallbuilders, is trying to teach people that the founding fathers meant for America to be a Christian country. On the other side are Rob Boston, spokesman for Americans United for Separation of Church and State, and Cornell government professor Isaac Kramnick, co-author of The Godless Constitution. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Two stories about people who suddenly realize they're the only ones around who value the separation of church and state. Paul Williams, a city councilman in Janesville, Wisconsin, wants to make sure a Salvation Army built with public money doesn't proselytize.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Substance Of Things Hoped For...In Government.
episode_acts.summary: We hear a quick rundown of all the ways that Christian conservatives are making headway in advancing their values as public policy, why they think total separation of church and state is not what the founding fathers intended. And why they're wrong.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: God Said, Huh?
episode_acts.summary: Julia Sweeney, a Catholic, tells the story of how her faith began to crack after reading a most alarming book...called the Bible. Her story is excerpted from her play, "Letting Go of God," which ran in Los Angeles.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about getting back together with your parent, your spouse, your ... Brahman bull. And how it never goes the way you think it's going to.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about some truths contained in the 70's hit "Reunited," by Peaches and Herb. (2 1/2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Not Your Parents' Parent Trap
episode_acts.summary: The story of an Iranian couple who were unhappily married for 27 years. He had a temper.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: If By Chance We Meet Again
episode_acts.summary: Ralph and Sandra Fisher, who run a show-animal business in Texas, had a beloved Brahman bull named Chance. Chance was the gentlest bull they'd ever seen, more like a pet dog than a bull.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: French Kiss
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell tells the story of General Lafayette's triumphant reunion with America, after becoming really, really unpopular in his native France. Sarah's is the author of “Lafayette in the Somewhat United States” among other books.

fields.episode_descript: The U.S. government spent two years on a sting operation trapping an Indian man named Hemant Lakhani, whom they suspected of being an illegal arms dealer. It's one of the few cases that has gone to trial in the War on Terror, and one the Justice Department has pointed to as one of their big successes. In the end, they got Lakhani, red-handed, delivering a missile to a terrorist in New Jersey. The only problem was, nothing in the sting was what it appeared to be. Including the missile.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The government had an almost impossible task after the September 11th attacks: They had to try to stop terrorists before they did anything — in some cases, before they even committed a crime. Dr.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Hemant Lakhani, an Indian-born British citizen, had been a salesman all his life. Clothing, rice, oil...it didn't matter to him what the product was, as long as he could spin a deal.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Our story about Hemant Lakhani's case continues, through the sting and the trial.

fields.episode_descript: This American Life producer Alex Blumberg investigates a little-studied phenomenon: Children who get a mistaken idea in their heads about how something works or what something means, and then don't figure out until well into adulthood that they were wrong. Includes the tale of a girl who received a tissue box for Christmas, allegedly painted by trained monkeys. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass describes the thing that we all do at some point: Talk expertly about something we don't actually know anything about. It's so common, explains This American Life contributing editor Nancy Updike, that some friends of hers invented an imaginary magazine devoted to such blathering.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Small Thoughts In Big Brains
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Alex Blumberg investigates a little-studied phenomenon: Children who get a mistaken idea in their heads about how something works or what something means, and then don't figure out until well into adulthood that they were wrong. Includes the tale of a girl who received a tissue box for Christmas, allegedly painted by trained monkeys.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: And Daddy Makes Three
episode_acts.summary: Six-year-old DJ has two dads, Dan Savage and Terry Miller. DJ is being raised by two gay men, but he has a preschooler's understanding of what gay means.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Sucker Mc-squared
episode_acts.summary: Bob Berenz had a good job as an electrician. But he wanted to do something bigger.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Art Of Adult Conversation
episode_acts.summary: Writer Alexa Junge tells about the time when she was thirteen and she decided to have a "grown-up" conversation with her beloved grandmother.

fields.episode_descript: Kristy Kruger realized in college just how bad her high school education had been. She was always having to pretend she knew what the people around here were talking about when she didn't know. And so she devised a troll-based system for getting through those moments without people thinking she was dumb. (Kristy's a musician in Dallas.) (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Kristy Kruger realized in college just how bad her high school education had been. She was always having to pretend she knew what the people around here were talking about when she didn't know.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dewey Decibel System
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg tells the story of an audacious act of rebranding done by a group of people who aren't normally thought of as very audacious: public librarians. In Michigan, they've started staging rock concerts in libraries.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Goldstein On Goldstein
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein decides to find out—once and for all—if his dad Buzz thinks he's manly enough.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Heart Shaped Box
episode_acts.summary: Julie Hill explains how she's going to remake all the ideas her son has about his father, using a very simple tactic.

fields.episode_title: Not What I Signed Up For
fields.episode_descript: Marian Fontana's husband was a Brooklyn firefighter who was killed on September 11, 2001. Afterwards, she started an organization, fighting to keep her husband's fire station open, and to help victims' families. She talked to reporters about these things and made appearances on TV. So that's what she thought she was going to do when she agreed to go on a show she thought was called "E! Online." Marian Fontana's book is A Widow's Walk: A Memoir of 9/11. (26 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Todd Bachmann tells about the time he offered to help out a Catholic charity and ended up getting bamboozled by a nun.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Double Whammy
episode_acts.summary: Marian Fontana's husband was a Brooklyn firefighter who was killed on September 11, 2001. Afterwards, she started an organization, fighting to keep her husband's fire station open, and to help victims' families.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Small Fish, Smaller Pond
episode_acts.summary: Nick Hornby's new story about a country so tiny, it's just a field, a few houses, a shop, and a café. There, a boy whose mom happens to be president of this minuscule nation is called upon to show his patriotism by playing on the national soccer team.

fields.episode_descript: Surprising stories from survivors in New Orleans. We give people who were in the storm more time than daily news coverage can to tell their stories and talk about what they're thinking. This leads to a number of ideas that haven't made it into the regular news coverage.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about something he read that seemed to put an end to all debate over one of the key issues swirling around right now. He checks with William Nichelson, author of the books Emergency Response and Emergency Management Law and Homeland Security Law and Policy, to see if he's correctly understanding the issue.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Middle Of Somewhere
episode_acts.summary: In the days following Hurricane Katrina, Denise Moore was trapped in the New Orleans Convention Center with her mom, her niece, and her niece's two-year-old daughter. There, she witnessed acts of surprising humanity by armed vigilantes, taking charge and doing good.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Forgotten, But Not Lost
episode_acts.summary: To find out more about the bridge Denise talked about in act one and the armed police who prevented pedestrians from crossing, This American Life producer Alex Blumberg talks with Lorrie Beth Slonsky and her husband Larry Bradshaw. They're paramedics from San Francisco who were visiting New Orleans for a convention when Hurricane Katrina hit.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Social Studies Lesson
episode_acts.summary: We compare Fox TV talk show host Bill O'Reilly's ideas about the hurricane's aftermath with those of Ashley Nelson, an 18-year-old who lives in the Lafitte Housing projects in New Orleans, in one of the flooded neighborhoods. Among other things, she explains what it feels like to go without food and water for two days.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Diaspora
episode_acts.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Gulf residents evacuated before the storm and followed the whole thing from afar. Cheryl Wagner left for Gainesville, Florida, where her friends advised her to buy a gun and a mean dog before returning home to New Orleans.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Displaced Persons Camp
episode_acts.summary: In August 2004, Hurricane Charley devastated parts of Florida. Afterwards, FEMA built a trailer park to provide immediate temporary housing for those who'd lost their homes in the storm.

fields.episode_title: This Is Not My Beautiful House
fields.episode_descript: It's the largest mass resettlement that America has seen since the Civil War, as over 400,000 people—victims of Hurricane Katrina—try to find a new place to live. From the Houston Astrodome to an abandoned New Orleans street, stories of people looking for home...and finding something else.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: At the Astrodome complex in Houston, charities from Colorado and Florida and other states are competing to take in the hurricane's refugees. But Colorado, which offers the best package of any state, just can't get New Orleans residents to relocate there.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Let It Snow, Let It Snow, Let It Snow
episode_acts.summary: Producer Jane Feltes talks with the first people on line for the bus to Colorado: Two twin, six-year-old sisters.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: No Place Like Dome
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to evacuees about what it's like to live on a cot in the Astrodome and the Reliant convention center next door. The lights never go out, and the p.a. runs announcements all day.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Land Grab
episode_acts.summary: As a half-dozen families—including a pregnant woman having contractions and another with a four-week-old baby—are driven around Houston looking for housing, they confront potential neighbors who they believe don't want them...and neighbors they themselves don't want. This American Life producer Lisa Pollak reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Long Way Home
episode_acts.summary: Nick Spitzer, host of the Public Radio International music show American Routes, drives through deserted streets to return to his own house, and finds it doesn't feel at all like home.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Water Bed
episode_acts.summary: Louann Mims, a 78-year-old retiree, planned to leave her New Orleans house before the floodwaters rose, but then the water came rushing in and she was trapped in her house for eight days on the only thing that would float: her extra firm Sterns and Foster mattress. Ms.

fields.episode_descript: Five stories of people doing what they think they have to, in order to make ends meet. A suburban dad makes what seems like a rational choice (to him, at the time, anyway) to start robbing laundries and banks. A trader at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange describes how he got rich from the Chernobyl disaster. They all talked with Alex Kotlowitz. Amy Drozdowska-McGuire produced the stories. Versions of them first appeared on Chicago Public Radio's series Chicago Matters, which gets funding from the Chicago Community Trust. (29 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Marti Noxon used to work for a company that did "product placement" for the movie industry. When auditors came to check that clients were being correctly billed, the company's bosses took unusual steps.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mothers Of Invention
episode_acts.summary: Five stories of people doing what they think they have to, in order to make ends meet. A suburban dad makes what seems like a rational choice (to him, at the time, anyway) to start robbing laundries and banks.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: That Guy
episode_acts.summary: Producer Diane Cook investigates that moment when you realize you've become "that guy" you've always hated, and how the simple act of purchasing deodorant can lead to that moment.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mall Rat
episode_acts.summary: John Hodgman provides an occasionally true account of seven days spent at the Mall of America. After crossing mall officials, he goes rogue, drinking from the flume ride and exploring what he describes as a secret tunnel lined with human skulls.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people and places that have come back to life after everything seemed lost.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In the middle of the news coverage of Hurricane Rita, newscasts broke into their coverage to show JetBlue flight 292, with its landing gear stuck in the wrong direction. For hours, the plane circled over the exurbs of Los Angeles to burn off fuel before it attempted an emergency landing.

episode_acts.name: Act One: In the Event of An Emergency
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass continues talking to passengers, like Zach Mastoon and Dave Reinitz, about being on that JetBlue flight.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 'P' Is For Porta-potty
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Sarah Koenig visits Pearlington, Mississippi, a town in danger of not starting up again after Hurricane Katrina. It's in Hancock County, the Ground Zero of the hurricane's devastation.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Friday Night Floodlights
episode_acts.summary: About fifteen miles from Pearlington, Bay St. Louis and Waveland are other communities struggling to bring themselves back to life.

fields.episode_descript: About a year ago, a John Hopkins University study in the British medical journal The Lancet estimated the number of civilian casualties in Iraq. It came up with a number—100,000 dead—that was higher than any other estimate, and was mostly ignored. This week, Producer Alex Blumberg tells the remarkable story of what it took to find that number, why we should find it credible and why almost no one believed it. (The original Lancet study is online; free registration is required). (38 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We're a nation at war, but it hardly feels like it. That contrast is especially jarring for people like Hannah Allam, who just returned home to Oklahoma after two years in Baghdad running the Knight-Ridder Newspapers bureau there.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Truth, Damn Truth, And Statistics
episode_acts.summary: About a year ago, a John Hopkins University study in the British medical journal The Lancet estimated the number of civilian casualties in Iraq. It came up with a number—100,000 dead—that was higher than any other estimate, and was mostly ignored.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Not Just A Number
episode_acts.summary: Captain Ryan Gist was given a particularly tough assignment in Iraq: To build relationships with a town where U.S. bombs had killed twelve innocent people. But first he has to apologize to the families of those who were killed.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: What Do We Do With These Numbers Anyway?
episode_acts.summary: So if, in fact, 100,000 Iraqis died because of the war—and that number is a year old—what do we do with that number? It instantly brings you to all these imponderable questions about what's worth 100,000 dead. In a way, this doesn't seem like a helpful question to think about.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the lengths we go to make things right, and about what money can and cannot fix.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Erin Einhorn grew up begging her mother to tell her all about the remarkable story of how she survived World War Two, thanks to a Polish woman named Honorata Skowronski, who risked her life. But her mother didn't like to talk about it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: One Good Deed
episode_acts.summary: Erin Einhorn's story continues. She tells what happens once she arrives in Poland.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Things That Money Can Buy
episode_acts.summary: Beau O'Reilly gets a chance to settle a 17-year-old score with the help of the Chicago police.

fields.episode_descript:
It took almost a month for Eli Ramirez to make it to this country. A native of Guatemala, he was smuggled through Mexico in the transport tank of a fuel truck, he was stranded in the desert, and forced to drink his own urine to survive. But just 24 hours after he made it to Chicago, he found himself at Charlie Trotters—one of the most exclusive, expensive, and fanciest restaurants in the country—a place unlike anything he'd ever seen before (4 minutes).

If you'd like to read more about Eli, his story is featured in the new book An Immigrant Class: Oral Histories from Chicago's Newest Immigrants, by Jeff Libman.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: It took almost a month for Eli Ramirez to make it to this country. A native of Guatemala, he was smuggled through Mexico in the transport tank of a fuel truck, he was stranded in the desert, and forced to drink his own urine to survive.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Not Just Tourists, Tourists Who Care
episode_acts.summary: Chris Tenove had this idea he thought could really make a difference for people in the developing world. The thought was to bring well-meaning tourists where their money would do the most good, spend some time with the locals, and then leave behind a little money to help out.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Johnny Get Your Mouse
episode_acts.summary: Lots of soldiers in Iraq are writing about their experiences online. Producer Amy O'Leary has read through dozens of them and talks about what the soldiers are writing.

fields.episode_descript: Continuing from our prologue, host Ira Glass checks in with Lisa and her older daughter, Kennedy, to see how the experiment went. After a month, they've charted surprising results, learned that the girls aren't the only ones in the house who need to change, and found out just how much money it takes to get a twelve-year-old to play with a five-year-old. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Lisa LaBorde has two daughters, and having grown up an only child, she can't understand why they fight all the time. Her idea of sisterhood is more like a scene from The Sound of Music. Wanting to create that kind of bond for her girls, Lisa decides to enlist the aid of science to see if she can turn these enemies into friends—in just one month.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lab Rugrats
episode_acts.summary: Continuing from our prologue, host Ira Glass checks in with Lisa and her older daughter, Kennedy, to see how the experiment went. After a month, they've charted surprising results, learned that the girls aren't the only ones in the house who need to change, and found out just how much money it takes to get a twelve-year-old to play with a five-year-old.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dreams Of Distant Factories
episode_acts.summary: Rachel Louise Snyder reports on the struggle to save the Cambodian economy. Right now, Cambodia is competing with other nations for the business of big clothing companies all over the world—buyers like the Gap, Nike, Adidas.
episode_acts.byline: By Lisa Pollak, Rachel Louise Synder

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Adventures At Poo Corner
episode_acts.summary: Contributor David Sedaris uncovers a disturbing and hidden trend that's taking place where small-minded people collide with big retail stores.

fields.episode_descript: The story of Reverend Carlton Pearson, a rising star in the evangelical movement, who cast aside the idea of hell, and with it everything he'd worked for over his entire life.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Carlton Pearson's church, Higher Dimensions, was once one of the biggest in the city, drawing crowds of 5,000 people every Sunday. But several years ago, scandal engulfed the reverend.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Rise
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Russell Cobb takes us through the remarkable and meteoric rise of Carlton Pearson from a young man to a Pentecostal Bishop: From the moment he first cast the devil out of his 17-year-old girlfriend, to the days when he had a close, personal relationship with Oral Roberts and had appearances on TV and at the White House. Just as Reverend Pearson's career peaked, with more than 5,000 members of his congregation coming every week, he started to think about hell, wondering if a loving God would really condemn most of the human race to burn and writhe in the fire of hell for eternity.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fall
episode_acts.summary: Once he starts preaching his own revelation, Carlton Pearson's church falls apart. After all, when there's no hell (as the logic goes), you don't really need to believe in Jesus to be saved from it.

fields.episode_title: The This American Life Holiday Spectacular
fields.episode_descript: A Christmas poem from David Rakoff, about holidays in The Big City. Rakoff's the author of, most recently, Half Empty. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass hauls out Ye Olde Book of Christmas Stories, only to realize that everyone's favorite stories are—gasp—missing. Sounding the alarm, he sets off to save Christmas, the only way he knows how.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Twas The Morning After
episode_acts.summary: A Christmas poem from David Rakoff, about holidays in The Big City. Rakoff's the author of, most recently, Half Empty.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: No Tenenbaum, No Tenenbaum
episode_acts.summary: This American Life receives an emergency transmission from a rooftop somewhere in New York City, where John Hodgman reports on the true-life origins of Christmas traditions. John Hodgman is the author of More Information Than You Require.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: My So-called Jesus
episode_acts.summary: Yeah, Mary Magdalene knew Jesus. She knew him before anybody else had ever even heard of him.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: An Animal Farm Christmas
episode_acts.summary: The great Christmas classics are all like fables. David Sedaris contributes his own, about barnyard animals who decide to play "Secret Santa." David is the author of many books, including a collection of Christmas stories, Holidays on Ice.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Christmas At Valley Forge
episode_acts.summary: A brand new Christmas carol gets its world premiere: A song about both Christmas and American history. With lyrics by Sarah Vowell.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: What Would Joseph Do?
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein retells the classic Christmas story, trying to understand what exactly goes through the mind of a man about to become surrogate father to The Lord. Jonathan's the author of Ladies and Gentlemen, The Bible!.

fields.episode_title: Seemed Like A Good Idea at the Time
fields.episode_descript: A girl signs up for a class. A couple hires an accountant. A group of co-workers decides to pool their money and buy a couple of lottery tickets. In the beginning, they're full of hope and optimism...and then something turns. Stories of good ideas gone bad.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Paul was a cop. One night he was pulling second shift when he had a perfectly good idea: He'd stretch out in the back seat and take a little nap during his break.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Luck Of The Irish
episode_acts.summary: It was two months into the tour. Katie Else and the rest of the Riverdance cast had been performing eight shows a week. They decided to pool their money for the Mega-Millions lottery.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Taxation Without Inebriation
episode_acts.summary: After years of neglecting their personal finances, Joel and his wife finally decide to sort things out. They hire a tax accountant named Len, whose casual manner is a real comfort, at first.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bad Morning America
episode_acts.summary: Davy Rothbart was on a 136-city tour appearing on morning TV talk shows to promote his book Found: The Best Lost, Tossed, and Forgotten Items from Around the World. Just before one appearance he had what seemed like a great idea at the time.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Function Of The Heart
episode_acts.summary: When Elspeth was a girl, she wanted nothing more than her father's attention. He was busy, a doctor, and distant.

fields.episode_title: In the Shadow of the City (2006)
fields.episode_descript: Stories that take place on the edge of civilization, just out of sight.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Every city's got a place like this: that weird no man's land on the outskirts of town, with junk yards and landfills. Charlie Gregerson grew up near that stuff, on Chicago's far south side, and he remembers finding debris from famous Louis Sullivan masterpieces in the garbage dump after those buildings were demolished.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Brooklyn Archipelago
episode_acts.summary: Out for a simple pleasure cruise with two friends, Alex Zharov was planning to see Jamaica Bay in New York City. But this end-of-the-day excursion, which should have only lasted 40 minutes, turns into an out-of-control adventure that left him lost, stranded, and bleeding...all within sight of the Empire State Building.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Thin Gray Line
episode_acts.summary: In New Orleans, visitors can take a bus tour called "HURRICANE KATRINA: AMERICA'S GREATEST CATASTROPHE," put on by the Gray Line bus company. (The tour is also sometimes called "Hurricane Katrina: America's Worst Catastrophe.") It's designed for out-of-towners, but we asked a local to take the tour and give us their impressions.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Yes, In My Backyard
episode_acts.summary: The story of the government cracking down on smokestack emissions at a city factory...even though the residents LIKE the emissions. We hear from Jorge Just, who explains the one, magical, special secret about Chicago no one outside Chicago ever believes is true, from Brian Urbaszewski, Director of Environmental Health Programs for the American Lung Association in Chicago; and from Julie Armitage, Manager of Compliance and Enforcement for the Bureau of Air at the Illinois State EPA.

fields.episode_descript: Shant Kenderian reads from his memoir 1001 Nights In the Iraqi Army: The True Story of a Chicago Student Held as a POW By the Americans During Desert Storm. During the first Persian Gulf war, Shant (reluctantly) fought for Saddam Hussein. After he was captured by the Americans, he and a female soldier fell for each other. His book is an eBook. (25 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Chicago Tribune newspaper columnist Amy Dickinson ("Ask Amy"), the heir to Ann Landers, as she reads letters from those readers who don't yet know their love is doomed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Prisoner Of Love
episode_acts.summary: Shant Kenderian reads from his memoir 1001 Nights In the Iraqi Army: The True Story of a Chicago Student Held as a POW By the Americans During Desert Storm. During the first Persian Gulf war, Shant (reluctantly) fought for Saddam Hussein.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Diary Of Mrs. Sam Horrigan.
episode_acts.summary: Sixteen-year-old Catalina Puente, one of WNYC's Radio Rookies, gets caught up in a complete and total obsession when a student shows up at her high school looking just like Sam Horrigan, a little-known TV actor she likes. This story was produced by Czerina Patel at Radio Rookies.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: So A Squirrel And A Chipmunk Walk Into A Bar
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads his new fable about a squirrel, a chipmunk, and a love that could never be. He's the author of many books, including Dress Your Family in Cordoroy and Denim.

fields.episode_descript: A story by David Sedaris about what happens when natural enemies meet, in an Alcoholics Anonymous program, in prison. This story appears in David's collection of animal fables Squirrel Seeks Chipmunk. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Adam Stein about the very real cat-and-mouse game between his friends and the vice principal of his high school that preoccupied them throughout their high school careers.

episode_acts.name: Act One: El Gato Y El Ratoncito
episode_acts.summary: Just near the US-Mexico border, a group of self described "pissed off patriots" called the Minutemen stake out illegal immigrants trying to cross the border. They've got call-signs and walkie-talkies and guns.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hello Kitty
episode_acts.summary: A story by David Sedaris about what happens when natural enemies meet, in an Alcoholics Anonymous program, in prison. This story appears in David's collection of animal fables Squirrel Seeks Chipmunk.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Looking For Loveseats In All The Wrong Places
episode_acts.summary: It's been well over a decade, so why can't Eric, who is in many other respects a measured and reasonable person, select a simple piece of furniture? David Segal attempts to explain why the man can't just buy himself a couch, already. David works at The New York Times.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Spray My Name, Spray My Name
episode_acts.summary: In a way, it's the most classic cat-and-mouse game of all: A nimble graffiti writer dashes out into the night to leave his mark. Watching and waiting for him are the stronger—if less agile—NYPD Vandal Squad, whose sole mission is their arrest.

fields.episode_descript: The right of habeas corpus has been a part of our country's legal tradition longer than we've actually been a country. It means that our government has to explain why it's holding a person in custody. But now, the War on Terror has nixed many of the rules we used to think of as fundamental. At Guantanamo Bay, our government initially claimed that prisoners should not be covered by habeas—or even by the Geneva Conventions—because they're the most fearsome enemies we have. But is that true? Is it a camp full of terrorists, or a camp full of our mistakes?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Joseph Margulies, a lawyer for one of the detainees at Guantanamo, explains how the detention facility there was created to be an ideal interrogation facility. Any possible comfort, such as water or natural light, is controlled entirely by the interrogators.

episode_acts.name: Act One: There's No U.s. In Habeas.
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt explains how President Bush's War on Terror changed the rules for prisoners of war and how it is that under those rules, it'd be possible that someone whose classified file declares that they pose no threat to the United States could still be locked up indefinitely—potentially forever!—at Guantanamo. (26 minutes).Clarification: When Seton Hall professor Baher Azmy discusses the classified file of his client, Murat Kurnaz, he is referring to information that had previously been made public and published in the Washington Post.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: September 11th, 1660
episode_acts.summary: Habeas corpus began in England. And recently, 175 members of the British parliament filed a "friend of the court" brief in one of the U.S.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: We Interrogate The Detainees
episode_acts.summary: Although more than 200 prisoners from the U.S. facility at Guantanamo Bay have been released, few of them have ever been interviewed on radio or on television in America. Jack Hitt conducts rare and surprising interviews with two former Guantanamo detainees about life in Guantanamo.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people trying to find new solutions to age-old problems—solutions that sometimes cause problems of their own.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Andy Woolworth, an executive vice president in charge of new product development at the world's largest manufacturer of mousetraps, Woodstrean Corporation, in Lititz, Pennsylvania. About once a month, Andy is contacted by someone who thinks he's invented a better mousetrap.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mother Of Invention
episode_acts.summary: Karen Sosnoski's one-year-old son, Anton, was born with what's known as Mosaic Down Syndrome, a rare condition where some of his cells have the extra chromosome that causes Down syndrome and other cells don't. So as he grows, he could end up having all the health risks and challenges of Downs syndrome...or just a few of them. Through a website, Karen found a kid with the same diagnosis, named Tim Colvin, who was doing really well...perhaps because his mother, Kristy, invented a surprising and unusual way to raise her son.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Everything Must Go
episode_acts.summary: Nellie Thomas sold ammunition illegally on the South side of Chicago. He made a good living—in cash.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: What Would Fill-in-the-blank Do?
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Brett Martin tries to use the tools of modern marketing to invent a new religion...one that would serve all the Americans who don't associate with any particular organized religion. It's a lot of people: Forty-three percent of the country says they don't consider themselves religious (according to a 2002 USA Today/Gallup poll).

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Squashing The Creative Spirit
episode_acts.summary: In San Francisco, Andy Raskin tells a story about the spirit of invention, and the forces that want to stop it...at the dinner table.

fields.episode_descript: In this show we return to two radio programs originally broadcast in 1996 and 1997. In one show, listeners came onstage with their letters, which they read aloud. In another, listeners from around the country talked about all the brand new sorts of experiences they were having with this new technology that had entered everyone's lives, the Internet. Each show, in its way, is a kind of time capsule.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about two live shows that This American Life put on in the early days, both co-hosted by David Hauptschein.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Letters
episode_acts.summary: Ira and playwright David Hauptschein took out advertisements in Chicago inviting people to come to a small theater with letters they've received, sent or found. People came for two nights, and read their letters onstage.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Internet
episode_acts.summary: In this show, at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Ira and David Hauptschein explored this now utterly quaint question: Are people having experiences on the Internet they wouldn't have anywhere else? Several hundred listeners sent in samples of what they were finding on the Internet. A guy offers a girl a late-night tour of Microsoft...and this actually makes him seem hot.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about kids who actually want their parents looking out for them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We play excerpts from the documentary film Troop 1500. In the film, girl scouts from an Austin, Texas, troop visit their mothers, all of whom are in prison.
episode_acts.byline: By Karen Bernstein, Ira Glass, Ellen Spiro

episode_acts.name: Act One: Two Possibilities, Both Bad
episode_acts.summary: When Gene Cheek was ten years old, his mother began dating a black man. It was 1961, in North Carolina.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Grandma Letters
episode_acts.summary: Will Seymour reads letters he and his grandmother exchanged when he was in high school. He was miserable at the time—his parents had just gotten divorced and he had no friends—and so was his grandma.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: My Angel's In The Centerfolds
episode_acts.summary: When Emily Helfgot was ten, her dad was a sex therapist on a call-in radio show, which thoroughly embarrassed her. He also kept a stack of Playboy magazines in their house, in plain sight.

fields.episode_descript: A grown man tries to get to the bottom of why his schoolmates threw him in a lake 20 years earlier. And a woman buys a house on the cheap, with the understanding that the seller will soon vacate. Ten years later, she's still waiting.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Jonathan Gold about the bully in high school who knocked Jonathan and his cello down the stairs one day as he was walking to history class—and why Jonathan felt a sudden surge of satisfaction about this almost three decades later.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Who Takes The Class Out Of Class Reunion
episode_acts.summary: Jon Ronson goes to his high school reunion to try to figure out why his schoolmates—his friends!—threw him in a lake when he was sixteen. The only trouble is, no one at the reunion seems to remember it quite the way he does.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Life Without Leanne
episode_acts.summary: Writer Larry Doyle on a love that will not die, no matter how dead it is.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Deal Of A Lifetime
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Sarah Koenig tells the story of how her stepsister Rue bought a house on the cheap, with the understanding that the previous owner would soon move out. More than ten years later, she's still waiting.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: One Word: Timing
episode_acts.summary: Television comedy writer Tami Sagher describes what can happen when you sit on a joke for years, as she did, before the perfect opportunity to tell it comes along.

fields.episode_title: The Parrot and the Potbellied Pig
fields.episode_descript: Original stories from David Sedaris, Jonathan Goldstein, and others, on two animals who don't even seem like they should know each other, much less appear on the same radio show.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Rosie Schaap about an unlikely love affair between a dog and a parrot, and how the dog betrayed the bird's trust, never to regain it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Parrot
episode_acts.summary: This parrot story began as a journalism school assignment. Then, for reporters Alex Lane and Eric Holm, it became something much bigger.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Pig
episode_acts.summary: A friend tells Jonathan Goldstein how a trip with a pot-bellied pig ended up revealing his character and making his girlfriend leave. Jonathan Goldstein is the host of the radio show Wiretap on the CBC, where a version of this story originally aired.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Combo Platter
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris reads a new story that explores the age-old question: Can a parrot and a pot-bellied pig find happiness in a world that only wants to pigeon-hole them? David's most recent book is Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim.

fields.episode_descript: Dan Savage made a pledge over a decade ago that he hoped would just vanish. But it somehow returns from oblivion. Dan's latest book is The Commitment. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with producer Alex Blumberg and his parents about a bad dog they once had, and how nothing—not getting hit by cars, attacked by bigger dogs, or being shipped off to live on a farm—could stop this dog from coming home. "The Cat Came Back" is sung by Nedelle Torrisi.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Promise Keeper Cat
episode_acts.summary: Dan Savage made a pledge over a decade ago that he hoped would just vanish. But it somehow returns from oblivion.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Political Cat
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about a specter who haunts the floor of the United States Senate and won't go away, who keeps showing up on TV and making speeches. That ghostly figure? John Kerry.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Baby Cat
episode_acts.summary: Michael Beaumier tells a story about a family member who keeps vanishing and returning. This is an excerpt from Michael's book I Know You're Out There.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Refugee Cat
episode_acts.summary: We end this show about people and animals who return against all odds with a story about some people who fear they may not be able to return: New Orleans public housing residents whose homes were damaged by Hurricane Katrina and now are slated for demolition by HUD. New Orleans resident Cheryl Wagner asks who should be more ashamed of themselves: The people who think that the public housing complexes in New Orleans should be torn down, or the ones who think they should stay.

fields.episode_descript: Can love be taught? A family uses a controversial therapy to train their son to love them. And other stories about the hard and sometimes painful work of loving other people.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Psychologist Harry Harlow sets out to prove, through a series of experiments with monkeys, that love is a key to normal development in children.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Love Is A Battlefield
episode_acts.summary: A couple uses a controversial therapy to train their son to love them.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hit Me With Your Best Shot
episode_acts.summary: A husband and wife face a decision about their autistic son's future, and whether he should continue to live with their family.

fields.episode_descript: Ira tells the story of two friends of his who were like superheroes. They had this incredible power to save someone. And with that great power came great responsibility. His friends are with Mission USA, working with gang kids in Chicago's prisons. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the story of two friends of his who were like superheroes. They had this incredible power to save someone.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Objects In Side View Mirror Are Truer Than They Appear
episode_acts.summary: Alex Kotlowitz reports on a woman with the power to change two people's lives...and at the height of her power, she doesn't even know she has it. Alex is the author of Never a City So Real and other books.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Unwelcome Wagon
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews the mother and daughter in a family who wished for years they could do something to stop their neighbor from all kinds of shocking behavior. Suddenly they get the power to decisively change things forever...and they have to decide whether they will.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Waiting For Joe
episode_acts.summary: When you're powerless, you think a lot about the powerful figures above you. Especially when their actions just make no sense.

fields.episode_title: And the Call Was Coming from the Basement
fields.episode_descript: For the lead up to Halloween, scary stories that are all true. Zombie raccoons, haunted houses—real haunted houses!—and things that go "EEEEK!!!" in the night. Plus, a story by David Sedaris in which he walks among the dead.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and Albert Donnay read a true ghost story that appeared in a medical journal in 1921. A "Mrs.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Hills Have Eyes
episode_acts.summary: Some of the scariest stories happen when fluffy, innocent creatures turn murderously evil. Producer Alex Blumberg tells one such story, about a raccoon gone bad.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Hitcher
episode_acts.summary: Writer Bill Eville and his brother are picked up on the side of the road late at night, and not taken to their destination. (10 minutes)Bill Eville is the author of a collection of essays called Washed Ashore: Family, Fatherhood, and Finding Home on Martha’s Vineyard.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: And The Call Was Coming From...the Listeners!
episode_acts.summary: We set up a special 800-number for listeners to call with their true-life scary stories. More than 500 people called.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Graveyard Shift
episode_acts.summary: One Halloween, David Sedaris decides to skip all the fake monsters and ghosts and zombies and visit the real thing: dead people, in a morgue. (14 minutes)David’s latest book is Happy-Go-Lucky.

fields.episode_descript: Recently, the British medical journal The Lancet published an study which updated their estimate of the number of Iraqis who've died since the U.S. invasion. With that in mind, we revisit a show we did in 2005 about the earlier study published in Lancet estimating the number of Iraqi deaths. That study was mostly ignored in the U.S. Alex Blumberg revisits the original study and looks at the new one.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to ordinary Iraqis about life in their country since the U.S. invasion. Every one of them has friends and relatives—civilians—who've been killed in the violence there.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Truth, Damn Truth And Statistics
episode_acts.summary: Two years ago, a Johns Hopkins University study published in The Lancet estimated the number of civilian casualties in Iraq. It came up with a number—100,000 dead—that was higher than any other estimate at the time and was mostly ignored.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Not Just A Number
episode_acts.summary: Captain Ryan Gist was given a particularly tough assignment in Iraq: To build relationships with a town where U.S. bombs had killed twelve innocent people. But first he has to apologize to the families of those who were killed.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The War This Time
episode_acts.summary: The Lancet's new study of deaths in Iraq, by the same research team that did the earlier study, yielded an astounding number—650,000 civilian deaths. Producer Alex Blumberg talks to Ira about the debate over this new study.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are in over their heads and trying to stay afloat.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Scott Shrake, who got hired for a job he was utterly unqualified for – as a German interpreter for visitors to Detroit. On his first assignment, Scott realized that not only couldn't he understand what the German tourists were saying, he didn't understand the English words he was supposed to translate.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mr. Central High
episode_acts.summary: Susan Drury tells the story of Chauncey Julius, who ended up in over his head completely by accident. As a high school student, Chauncey decided to turn his life around, only to be overwhelmed by all the attention he got for his achievements.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: I'm Not A Doctor But I Play One At The Holiday Inn
episode_acts.summary: A former heroin addict realizes that he wants to help other addicts kick their habits. The problem is, he wants to do this using a hallucinogenic drug – ibogaine – that is completely illegal, and which requires medical expertise he doesn't have.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: If This Ark Is A Rockin', Don't Come A Knockin'
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein retells the original sink-or-swim story, the one about Noah and the flood. Jonathan is host of the CBC radio show WireTap.

fields.episode_descript: A Muslim woman persuades her husband that their family would be happier if they left the West Bank and moved to America. They do, and things are good...until September 11. After that, the elementary school their daughter goes to begins using a textbook that says Muslims want to kill Christians.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In the 1930s, the designer of the U.S. Supreme Court made a frieze to adorn the courtroom walls.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Which One of These Is Not Like the Others?
episode_acts.summary: Serry and her husband's love story began in a place not usually associated with romance: The West Bank. That was where the couple met, fell in love and decided to get married.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: America, The Ad Campaign
episode_acts.summary: The New York advertising agency where Shalom Auslander works got an assignment from the State Department back in 2001: Sell American values to the Muslim world. Now they just have to figure out exactly what to say to millions of people they know absolutely nothing about.

fields.episode_descript: The mysterious hold supers have on their buildings, or that their buildings have on them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass visits the Upper East Side building in Manhattan where Peter Roach has been the super for about ten years. Peter has a lot of keys.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Super Always Rings Twice
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Jack Hitt tells the story of how he helped organize tenants and threaten a rent strike in a New York City building back in the 1980s. Before long, Bob, the building super became his enemy. The situation got pretty ugly.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Super Duper
episode_acts.summary: The super in Josh Bearman's Los Angeles building was kind of a needy character. He would sometimes ask Josh to come into his apartment and help him out -- check whether his garbage was being moved by a ghost, for example.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Please Re-lease Me
episode_acts.summary: A man who we're calling "Dennis" inherits his father's job as a landlord of a big apartment building. His dad had warned him that bad tenants could drive even a good man to become heartless, but Dennis vowed that would never happen to him. He's tested on this point when he tries to help a couple that falls behind in their rent.

fields.episode_descript: An American reporter in Iraq decides to rent a house in a residential Baghdad neighborhood rather than live in a hotel and be an easy target for insurgents. And an eleven-year-old boy figures out an ingenious way to see his dead father again. Big ideas gone amok.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to an expert stone cutter who makes headstones. One day he got a call from a guy who wanted him to make his headstone in advance, which is not all that uncommon.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Mr. Adam's Neighborhood
episode_acts.summary: Radio reporter Adam Davidson went to Iraq to report on the war. He decided that rather than living in some journalist compound in the Green Zone or in a big hotel—places insurgents were more likely to attack—he'd fly under the radar, and keep safe...by renting a house in a residential Baghdad neighborhood.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Tragedy Minus Time Equals Happily Ever After
episode_acts.summary: Ron Mallett was ten years old when his father died unexpectedly of a heart attack. A year later, after picking up a comic book based on H.G.

fields.episode_descript: When David Wilcox was eighteen, he set about looking for an apartment in Houston. He had no credit and very little money, but he was determined to move away from home. He finally found a place in the only apartment complex he could afford. After a few disturbing encounters with neighbors—plus a tornado—he realized maybe he needed to think again. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Randall Bell, who specializes in assessing how tragedy affects real estate. He's found that the market is much quicker to forgive and forget a scandal than the neighbors are.

episode_acts.name: Act One: It's Not A Crack House, It's A Crack Home
episode_acts.summary: Joe had lived alone in his big house in Brooklyn for decades. Then one night he saw a few people—prostitutes, actually—shivering outside in the cold, and he opened up his home to them.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Crisco Kid
episode_acts.summary: When David Wilcox was eighteen, he set about looking for an apartment in Houston. He had no credit and very little money, but he was determined to move away from home.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bully's Pulpit
episode_acts.summary: There's probably no house more famous for the bad behavior of its denizens than the U.S. House of Representatives.

fields.episode_descript: Ira talks with Bob Harris, a former Jeopardy champion, about how he prepared to go on the program. He turned his living room into a replica of the real-life Jeopardy studio, taped a poster of Alex Trebek, the host of Jeopardy, in the exact spot where the real Alex Trebek stands, and even made a fake buzzer out of a ball point pen and masking tape. He wrote a book about his experiences called Prisoner of Trebekistan. Ira also mentions that there's something special about the act names in this episode. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Bob Harris, a former Jeopardy champion, about how he prepared to go on the program. He turned his living room into a replica of the real-life Jeopardy studio, taped a poster of Alex Trebek, the host of Jeopardy, in the exact spot where the real Alex Trebek stands, and even made a fake buzzer out of a ball point pen and masking tape.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Gamester Of Ireland Is Fine
episode_acts.summary: Roger Dowds won several hundred thousand pounds on the Irish version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire, which is why Ronan Kelly, the host an Irish public radio program, first went to interview him. During their talk together, it became clear that Roger was a very unlikely game show champion.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dire Enigmas For Elite Fans
episode_acts.summary: Every winter, some of the world's best puzzle solvers gather in Boston for the MIT mystery hunt, a competition in which teams of puzzle enthusiasts spend between 24 and 72 straight hours trying to solve what just may be the hardest recreational puzzles in the world. This American Life producer Lisa Pollak hung out with one team (named Dr. Awkward...a palindrome) as they worked towards the ultimate answer, the location of a coin, buried somewhere on the MIT campus. Check out the puzzles from that year's hunt.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Girls In Need Of A Safer Time
episode_acts.summary: Robin Epstein talks about her old job, as producer and chief question writer on a game show for teen-age girls called Plugged In. It was one of the first shows to air on the Oxygen network, the TV channel for women created by Oprah Winfrey. Robin had hoped that the show could serve as a role model for young women, showing smart teen girls answering tough questions.
episode_acts.byline: By David Ellis Dickerson, Robin Epstein

fields.episode_descript: This American Life regular contributor Davy Rothbart talks about the time a friend asked him to make a decision for her that she really had to make for herself: Whether she should have an abortion. Davy is the founder and publisher of Found Magazine and author of a book of short stories, The Lone Surfer of Montana, Kansas. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Nancy Updike talks with a man, Eric Molinsky, about a weirdly heated argument he got into with a good friend, over corporate tax loopholes. Midway through, they both stopped to think: Why were they getting so upset over an issue they didn't really care about that much? And then they realized: Eric's ex-girlfriend was a political activist, and Eric's friend's ex-boyfriend was a hedge fund manager.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I'm The Decider
episode_acts.summary: This American Life regular contributor Davy Rothbart talks about the time a friend asked him to make a decision for her that she really had to make for herself: Whether she should have an abortion. Davy is the founder and publisher of Found Magazine and author of a book of short stories, The Lone Surfer of Montana, Kansas.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kill The Messengers
episode_acts.summary: Basim, an Iraqi national, worked as an interpreter for the U.S. Army.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Redemption By Proxy
episode_acts.summary: Robert (pictured) had a bad reputation as a kid who didn't do his schoolwork and had little respect for adults. But his best friend, Lilly (holding picture), thought he was misunderstood.

fields.episode_descript: Stories recorded during our 2007 live tour. Sarah Vowell, David Rakoff, Dan Savage, and other favorite contributors went on the road with us to New York, Boston, Minneapolis, Chicago, Seattle, and Los Angeles; and performed brand-new stories in front of sold-out audiences.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Jane Espenson—who's written for the TV shows Battlestar Galactica and Gilmore Girls—and with J.J. Abrams—one of the creators of the hit shows Lost, Alias, and Felicity—about how we might be in the midst of another Golden Age of television.
episode_acts.byline: By J. J. Abrams, Jane Espenson, Ira Glass

episode_acts.name: Act One: 29
episode_acts.summary: This American Life contributor David Rakoff, who swore off TV in college, returns to it in dramatic fashion: He attempts to watch the same amount of television as the average American—29 hours in one week. David is author, most recently, of the book Don't Get Too Comfortable.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Turkeys In Pilgrim Clothing
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell examines what happens when TV takes on a subject it really has no business exploring at all, but seems fairly obsessed with nonetheless: The Pilgrims. Sarah's most recent book is Assassination Vacation.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Radio On The Tv
episode_acts.summary: Ira says a few words about what he learned from working on a television show himself and about what it's like to hear your name mentioned casually by a fictional character on a prime time drama.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: My Other Dog's A German Shepherd
episode_acts.summary: Regular This American Life contributor Dan Savage, a syndicated sex columnist with possibly the filthiest mouth of anyone you could ever meet, finds a TV program so dirty, so weird, and so perverted that he won't let his son watch it—even though it's a kids' show, made for kids, and broadcast on a network for kids.

fields.episode_title: Nice Work If You Can Get It
fields.episode_descript: Host Ira Glass talks with some real-live NASA astronauts: Cady Coleman, Chris Cassidy, and Marsha Ivins. On average, NASA schedules just a couple of space missions a year. But it employs 95 astronauts. This means that only a tiny percentage of an astronaut's career is actually spent in space, and some never get there. Ira talks with these three astronauts about how they spend the vast majority of their time: on the ground, in an office, doing paperwork. (8 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with some real-live NASA astronauts: Cady Coleman, Chris Cassidy, and Marsha Ivins. On average, NASA schedules just a couple of space missions a year.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I'm Not A Tv Star, But I Play One On Tv
episode_acts.summary: This American Life contributor John Hodgman was unexpectedly chosen to be in a series of high-profile Apple Computer commercials (he plays a PC). He tells the story of what happens when celebrity hunts you down and finds you...on your living room couch, pushing 40, and a couple sizes larger than you want to be.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Show Me The Annuity
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Alex Blumberg talks with Ed Ugel, who had a very unusual dream job: He bought jackpots from lottery winners. When you win the lottery, your prize is often paid out in yearly installments.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Homesick Explorer
episode_acts.summary: This American Life contributor Sarah Vowell tells the story of a mapmaker named Charles Preuss who charted the Western Territories with two of American history's legendary explorers—John Charles Fremont and Kit Carson. The maps Preuss made were best sellers and helped open the Western frontier to settlement.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Just One Thing Missing
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Douglas McGray interviews a college student in California with good grades, an excellent work ethic, but no possible way to get a legal job. She's lived in the U.S. since she was little, but her parents are undocumented; and she is, too.

fields.episode_descript: This American Life producer Sarah Koenig tells a story of the rise and fall of a politician's reputation. Raymond Buckley, a Democratic operative from New Hampshire, was instrumental in his party's success in last fall's midterm elections. He set his sights on becoming the chair of the state Democratic Party. But three months before the election for party chair, one of Buckley's political rivals accused him of one of the worst things that anyone can be accused of. It threatened to destroy not only his career, but his life. Unlike most politicians at the center of a scandal, Buckley was willing to talk about what he went through and how it changed him. (35 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Robyn Forest thought she'd gotten her big break when a magazine assigned her to write about a famous Japanese pop singer. Instead, Robyn ended up on Japanese television denying that she and the singer were having an affair.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Not Everybody Loves Raymond
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Sarah Koenig tells a story of the rise and fall of a politician's reputation. Raymond Buckley, a Democratic operative from New Hampshire, was instrumental in his party's success in last fall's midterm elections.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Hole Truth
episode_acts.summary: It's one thing to wonder what other people really think of you. It's quite another to go out and ask them.

fields.episode_descript: An updated version of our episode "Habeas Schmabeas," which won a 2006 Peabody Award. Listen to a special, uncut version.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Joseph Margulies, a lawyer for one of the detainees at Guantanamo, explains how the detention facility there was created to be an ideal interrogation facility. Any possible comfort, such as water or natural light, is controlled entirely by the interrogators.

episode_acts.name: Act One: There's No U.s. In Habeas.
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt explains how President Bush's War on Terror changed the rules for prisoners of war and how it is that under those rules, it'd be possible that someone whose classified file declares that they pose no threat to the United States could still be locked up indefinitely—potentially forever!—at Guantanamo.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: September 11th, 1660
episode_acts.summary: Habeas corpus began in England. And recently, 175 members of the British parliament filed a "friend of the court" brief in one of the U.S.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: We Interrogate The Detainees
episode_acts.summary: Although more than 200 prisoners from the U.S. facility at Guantanamo Bay have been released, few of them have ever been interviewed on radio or on television in America. Jack Hitt conducts rare and surprising interviews with two former Guantanamo detainees about life in Guantanamo.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people struggling to follow the Ten Commandments from the book of Exodus.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reads from the Ten Commandments. Not the original Ten Commandments, but some of the newer, lesser-known ones.

episode_acts.name: Commandments One, Two and Three: Honor God
episode_acts.summary: As a boy in religious school, Shalom Auslander is informed that his name, Shalom, is one of the names of God, and so he must be very careful not to take his own name in vain.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Four: Keep The Sabbath Holy
episode_acts.summary: Six houses of worship in six different cities, each with its own way of honoring the Sabbath.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Five: Honor Your Father And Your Mother
episode_acts.summary: When Jack Hitt was 11, he did the worst thing his father could have imagined. Neither Jack nor his four siblings will ever forget the punishment.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Six: You Shall Not Murder
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg talks to Lt. Col.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Seven: You Shall Not Commit Adultery
episode_acts.summary: In the book of Matthew, Jesus says that looking lustfully at a woman is like committing adultery in your heart. Contributor David Dickerson was raised as an evangelical Christian, and for many years tried not  to have a single lustful thought.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Eight: You Shall Not Steal
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to a waiter named Hassan at Liebman's Deli in the Bronx about some audacious thefts he's witnessed in his years in the restaurant business.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Nine: You Shall Not Bear False Witness
episode_acts.summary: Chaya Lipschutz wanted to donate one of her kidneys to a stranger. But to save a stranger's life, she had to break the commandment against lying.

episode_acts.name: Commandment Ten: You Shall Not Covet
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to seventh-graders about the things they covet most.

fields.episode_descript: Four years into the Iraq War, what have we learned? Soldiers, civilians, Iraqis, and Americans talk—and sometimes yell—about what they've learned in the last few years...including how to stay alive and why the aftermath of a war can be the trickiest time of all.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There's a 200-person operation based out of Fort Leavenworth, Kansas called the Center for Army Lessons Learned. Host Ira Glass speaks with Colonel Steve Mains, who runs the Center, and with Craig Hayes and Lynn Rolf, two men who answer soldiers' requests for information.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cassandra
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Nancy Updike tells the story of Conrad Crane, the head of the U.S. Army Military History Institute.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: Second Half Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira speaks with Milt Hileman of the Center for Army Lessons Learned about the single most-requested publication they put out, Soldiers' Handbook: The First 100 Days: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures. It explains how to avoid getting killed in your first hundred days in Iraq, which is when a disproportionate number of U.S. casualties occur.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Am Not. Are Too. Am Not. Are Too.
episode_acts.summary: What lessons are civilians taking from the War? One journalist has said that Americans seem condemned "to relive the prewar debates over and over because they were never thrashed out in the sunlight." In Salt Lake City on May 4, the prewar arguments—and some other arguments as well—were re-argued, on stage, by Salt Lake's liberal mayor Rocky Anderson and conservative radio and TV host Sean Hannity. Scott Carrier attended the event.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Lessons Of Tomorrow, Today
episode_acts.summary: For all the discussion in Congress about withdrawing troops, there seems to be very little serious discussion about why, about what'll happen to Iraq once we leave, about responsible ways to withdraw. To understand better these and other rarely-discussed questions about the war, we turned to Washington Post reporter Thomas Ricks in Baghdad.

fields.episode_descript:
Josh's mother and younger brother were a mess. His mother drank too much. His brother got arrested a lot. Josh hadn't lived with them since he was nine, and they didn't play much of a role in his daily life—until duty called, and they took over his life.

Josh told the sequel to this story at our live show in 2014.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Vincent Homenick and Norman Goodman, the court officials who hear all the excuses from New York City residents trying to get out of jury duty.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Josh Bearman grew up in California with his dad, stepmom, and brother. But they're not his whole family.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Josh Bearman continues his story by looking at how things got so bad for his mother and David in the first place.

fields.episode_descript: When he was a teenager, Haider worked in the Iraqi Ministry of Information. He was specially trained to talk to visiting dignitaries and foreign reporters, and he loved his job. It was exciting, and he was treated like a celebrity.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells a story about how, when he was in seventh grade, he was over at his best friend's house and saw beer in the fridge. He'd only ever seen beer in fridges on TV; he didn't think it existed in real life.
episode_acts.byline: By Valentina Filimonova, Ira Glass, Starlee Kine

episode_acts.name: Act One: Teen Wolf...blitzer
episode_acts.summary: When he was a teenager, Haider Hamza worked in the Iraqi Ministry of Information. He was specially trained to talk to visiting dignitaries and foreign reporters, and he loved his job.

episode_acts.name: Act One, Continued: Act One, Continued
episode_acts.summary: Haider's story continues.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Sense Of Place
episode_acts.summary: Filmmaker Tony Hill took his friend Sally Goode, who was born blind, to a place she'd never been before, then taped her trying to figure out where she was. We first heard Hill's story care of our colleagues at the Third Coast International Audio Festival.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the pitfalls of trying to do the right thing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Tim Jaccard, who used to be a police medic. The calls he hated most were all the same: "Baby not breathing." So in 1998, he helped write the first "safe haven" law, which allows mothers to safely abandon their babies without getting into trouble.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Kill One, Save Five
episode_acts.summary: Say there's a group of five people standing on a train track, and you're on a train coming toward them. You can save the whole group by pulling a lever and switching to another track, but the catch is that you'll kill another person who's standing on that other track.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Rescue You, Rescue Me
episode_acts.summary: When the U.S. government sent out a call for volunteers—regular, non-military people—to go to Iraq and help rebuild the country, Randy Frescoln signed up. He believed in the cause of the war and in the promise of its mission.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Brady Udall tells the story of the time he helped a stranger get his car out of a ditch. In exchange, the man promises to help him any time, for any reason—legal or not.

fields.episode_descript:
Dal LaMagna made a fortune selling high-quality grooming products. And after retiring, he wanted to do some good in the world. His plan: Curb the violence in Iraq. He thought he could get the Sunni resistance to sit down with Coalition forces to negotiate a cease-fire. So he hooked up with a member of the Iraqi parliament named Mohammed Al-Dynee and headed to Baghdad and Amman, where, remarkably, doors opened to him.

This American Life gave Dal an audio recorder to carry into his meetings, and he recorded 25 hours of his remarkable journey through the Middle East as a would-be citizen-diplomat. Producer Sarah Koenig sifted through the 25 hours, talked to Dal about what happened, and put together this story. (22 minutes)

Dal also ran for President.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Dal LaMagna, millionaire and creator of the Tweezerman tweezer, prepares to go to Iraq on a diplomatic mission he invented for himself—despite concern (and mocking) from his own sister.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Man Of Lamagna
episode_acts.summary: Dal LaMagna made a fortune selling high-quality grooming products. And after retiring, he wanted to do some good in the world.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Wenceslas Square
episode_acts.summary: Arthur Phillips reads an abridged version of his short story "Wenceslas Square," which takes place in Czechoslovakia at the end of the Cold War. (31 minutes) This story was first published in a collection of essays and fiction called Wild East: Stories from the Last Frontier.

fields.episode_descript: David Iserson tried to lay low in junior high, staying out of sight to keep from getting teased and bullied. But then he starred in a local TV commercial for his father's furniture store, and all of a sudden everyone knew about him...in a bad way. Classmates would quote his lines back to him and snicker. Random people would see him on the street and start laughing. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: David Iserson tried to lay low in junior high, staying out of sight to keep from getting teased and bullied. But then he starred in a local TV commercial for his father's furniture store, and all of a sudden everyone knew about him...in a bad way.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What Part Of "Bomb" Don't You Understand?
episode_acts.summary: Rachel North was on a train that got blown up during the London subway bombings. After writing a very popular blog about her experience and her recovery afterward, Rachel became a spokeswoman for a survivors' group.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mr. Successful.
episode_acts.summary: Anthony Pico was a foster kid for most of his life. His mother was a crack addict who abandoned him, and he bounced around from house to house, relative to relative.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Impeachment Day
episode_acts.summary: Joe Lockhart was press secretary for President Bill Clinton. He recently told stories from his time on the job—live onstage at a performance space in New York City called The Moth, where regular people share stories about their lives—in front of a boisterous crowd.

fields.episode_descript: Writer Starlee Kine on what makes the perfect break-up song and whether really sad music can actually make you feel better. Plus, an eight-year-old author of a book about divorce, and other stories from the heart of heartbreak.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Lauren Waterman, who's in the middle of a break-up right now and grappling with totally contradictory feelings. She wants her boyfriend to call, but also—maybe a little bit—doesn't want him to call.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dr. Phil
episode_acts.summary: In the wake of a break-up, writer Starlee Kine finds so much comfort in break-up songs that she decides to try and write one herself—even though she has no musical ability whatsoever. For some help, she goes to a rather surprising expert on the subject: Phil Collins.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: But Why?
episode_acts.summary: Eight-year-old Betsy Walter goes on a campaign to understand her parents' divorce.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Let No Court Put Asunder
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with divorce mediator Barry Berkman about why it's bad when the justice system gets involved in a break-up. Barry specializes in matrimonial law and is a member of The New York Association of Collaborative Professionals, which he helped found.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Divorce Is Rrruuffff!
episode_acts.summary: What divorce looks like from the dog's point of view. This monologue was performed by Merrill Markoe and recorded at Un-Cabaret in Los Angeles.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to exorcize their inner demons.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about not being able to admit when he's wrong, as well as other traits he's not proud of, but can't seem to change.

episode_acts.name: Act One: And So We Meet Again
episode_acts.summary: Sam Slaven is an Iraq War veteran who came home from the War plagued by feelings of hate and anger toward Muslims. TAL producer Lisa Pollak tells the story of the unusual action Sam took to change himself, and the Muslim students who helped him do it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Vox Diaboli
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes the inner voice telling us to do the wrong thing actually sounds like a voice. TAL producer Nancy Updike talks to people about the voices in their heads that persuade them to go astray.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Devil Wears Birkenstocks
episode_acts.summary: Some people battle inner demons, but contributor David Ellis Dickerson went one step further. David tells the story of the time he took on an actual demon in his college classroom.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of adults taking very different approaches to communicating with children.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass asks fifth-grade kids to explain what adults do wrong when talking to children.

episode_acts.name: Act One: So, Kids: A Priest, A Rabbi, And A Hooker Walk Into A Bar...
episode_acts.summary: Sean O'Connor and Nick Maritato are professional comedians, and their job usually involves saying things that kids aren't supposed to hear. But last summer they got booked on a tour of kids' summer camps.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Age Of Consent
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to the teen editors of Sex, Etc., a national magazine for teenagers, about the mistakes parents make when talking—or not talking—to their kids about sex. Then, the story of what happened when one anonymous mother learned that her daughter was having sex. All the names in this essay have been changed, and it's read on the air by producer Julie Snyder.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Use Your Words
episode_acts.summary: Dan Savage makes the case for yelling at children. He also reflects on how his views on how to talk to kids have changed over the years.
