episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with a guy in Chicago named Josh who likes to spend time going bird watching. But one day, Josh was out in a park with his binoculars and he discovered something he definitely did not want to know about.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Full Disclosure
episode_acts.summary: Michael Leviton was raised in a family who encouraged him and his siblings to tell the truth all the time. They believed it was better to be honest and work things out.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Total Eclipse of the Son
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace tells the story of a community college student named Demetrius who seemed like he was doing exceptionally well in school. But as Zoe followed Demetrius over a semester, she discovered that there were things about his academic past that he had kept a secret.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Favorite
episode_acts.summary: Growing up, producer Stephanie Foo was the favorite child of her family in Malaysia. Particularly of the matriarch of the family who everyone called "Auntie." But as an adult, Stephanie found out the complicated truth about why she was the family favorite.

fields.episode_descript: People caught in limbo, using ingenuity and guile to try to get themselves out.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Rachel has two kids. Elias, age seven, is a vegetarian.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Do You Hear What I Hear?
episode_acts.summary: Sara Corbett's father-in-law Dick is 81. And he's become obsessed with a limbo most of us hate – the music he hears whenever he's on hold. Sara is co-author of the book A House in the Sky.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sunrise, Sun-Get
episode_acts.summary: Mark Oppenheimer reports on agunah in the Orthodox Jewish community. An agunah is a woman whose husband refuses to give her a divorce – in Hebrew it means "chained wife." If you're an Orthodox Jew, strictly following Jewish law, the only real way to get divorced is if your husband agrees to hand you a piece of paper called a get.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Contrails of My Tears
episode_acts.summary: Brett Martin documents a previously unnoticed human phenomenon, one that involves airplanes, crying, and Reese Witherspoon. Brett is the author of the book Difficult Men. (11 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people, cities, and commonwealths touching their noses and proclaiming "not it!" Including the story of how one city used a rocking chair to take retribution against a late night TV show host, and an island that takes people it doesn't want to deal with and ships them away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Adriana Cardona-Maguigad started talking to homeless men in the Chicago neighborhood she works in, she discovered that many of them had the same, very strange backstory. Adriana tellsIra how she stumbled upon this.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Como Se Dice "Not It"?
episode_acts.summary: Adriana's story continues, as she ventures deep into a mysterious world of heroin addiction treatment centers where no one seems to be taking responsibility for the people they're treating. Adriana is the editor of the bilingual newspaper The Gate.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Last But Not Least
episode_acts.summary: Producer Brian Reed tells the story of a city that years ago was given a title and is now saying, "not it!" They want to shed that title once and for all.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Big Crapple
episode_acts.summary: A story about a substance we've played "not it" with for generations, and why maybe we shouldn't anymore. Producer Zoe Chace explains.

fields.episode_title: The Incredible Rarity of Changing Your Mind
fields.episode_descript: It’s rare for people to change what they believe, and if they do it, it’s usually a long process. This week, stories of those very infrequent instances where people’s opinions flip on fundamental things that they believe. Why does it happen in these particular and unusual circumstances? We explain. NOTE: One of the authors of a study covered in this episode has asked that the study be retracted.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira introduces “the backfire effect,” a phenomenon stating that when confronted with evidence disproving what we believe, most of us ignore that evidence, dig in and become more entrenched in our beliefs. Which just makes the recordings he plays more surprising—recordings of canvassers going door to door and effectively convincing people to completely flip their positions.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Do Ask, Do Tell
episode_acts.summary: Ira continues to explain how these canvassers learned how to change people’s minds, and talks about the mistakes they made along the way.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Crime Pays
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Joe Richman visits a program in Richmond, CA that is trying a controversial method of reducing gun violence in their city: paying criminals to not commit crimes. Sounds crazy, but the even crazier part is…it works.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Glacial Change
episode_acts.summary: Zalena (pictured, right) lived in paradise. She grew up in American Samoa, hanging out on the beach, doing normal teenage things with her friends—until senior year, when her dad decided he was going to move the family to the exact opposite of everything she’d known—a tiny, isolated town in Alaska.

fields.episode_descript: People who are tied together, but imagine radically different futures.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In order to maintain their status as the friendliest, calmest people on the plane, flight attendants bicker mercilessly behind our backs.  Then they cuddle up and sleep right next to each other in the same bed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dream Weevil
episode_acts.summary: Kim Jong-Il loved movies – but hated all the movies made in North Korea.  So he kidnapped a famous South Korean director and his ex-wife, a South Korean film star, locked them up in a villa in North Korea, and forced them to make movies for him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Smell You Later
episode_acts.summary: Lots of people in America share actual beds – but almost never see each other. Flight attendants have crash pads near airports, oil rig workers carry their own sheets and sleep in shifts in an RV – and Stephanie Foo has a profile of Mexican immigrants who share a few beds in a tiny trailer in upstate New York.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The  Haunted Becomes the Haunter
episode_acts.summary: When someone stole Jessamyn Lovell’s ID, she became obsessed with the thief. Miki Meek tells what happened.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Overnight Flight
episode_acts.summary: Several people who just woke up on red-eye flights talk about their dreams.

fields.episode_descript: Some information is so big and so complicated that it seems impossible to talk to kids about. This week, stories about the vague and not-so-vague ways we teach children about race, death, and sex.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: This American Life producer Chana Joffe-Walt sits in for Ira Glass, because Chana has kids, two young sons. And her oldest, Jacob, has some complicated ideas about people, that Chana wants to straighten out, but doesn’t know exactly how.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Some Like it Not (On the Neck)
episode_acts.summary: Workshops on sexual assault and consent are hugely popular on college campuses around the country. Chana visits one of these workshops to find out what’s being taught, and more importantly, what college boys in particular have already learned about sex, back when they were kids.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: If You See Racism Say Racism
episode_acts.summary: Comedian W. Kamau Bell has two daughters, and tries to figure out just how much about the violent history of racism and oppression his four-year-old can handle.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: About that Farm Upstate
episode_acts.summary: While it’s hard to explain to kids how babies come into the world, it might be harder to explain that people leave the world too — especially to a kid whose mom or dad or brother or sister has died. There are grief counseling centers all over the U.S. that cater specifically to children.

fields.episode_descript: Blair Braverman was a dog musher on an Alaskan glacier. One day the weather turned rough, and she and a pack of tourists were stuck. The worst part? They had to pretend like nothing was wrong. This and other stories of people facing very difficult situations who put their game face on and muscle through. And, we hear from people whose faces betray them and prominently display all their anxiety.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira explores the news this week alleging bribery and corruption among officials for international soccer's governing board, FIFA. There have been 14 people arrested, and law enforcement officials have made clear that their investigation is not finished.

episode_acts.name: Act One: 200 Dog Night
episode_acts.summary: For two summers when she was 18 and 19, Blair Braverman worked as a dogsled guide on an Alaskan glacier. 8 times a day, helicopters full of tourists would arrive on the glacier for their experience of Real Alaska. Then one day, the weather turned bad and things got a little too real.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Funny Face
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Tig Notaro tells the story about the time she played a string of dates night after night after night in Las Vegas – and bombed every single time. Getting up on stage and pretending like everything was going great was not easy.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Who Put the Face in Game Face?
episode_acts.summary: Ira speaks with Mike Pesca, host of the sports podcast Hang Up and Listen and Slate's daily podcast The Gist about the whole concept of the game face in sports. What is it exactly? And who might be the best examples of athletes with incredible game faces? Then Ira speaks with writer David Dupuis about the athlete who may have the game face-iest game face in sports history – hockey goalie Terry Sawchuk.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Frankly Miss Scarlet
episode_acts.summary: It turns out that one of the members of the This American Life staff, Elna Baker, has a kind of anti-game face. She's what's called a chronic blusher.

fields.episode_descript: A captain’s log is a simple thing: the date, the time, maybe the weather — and the current status of a long journey. You wouldn’t know from the cryptic notations what weird worlds lurk beneath. On this week's show, stories behind those cryptic notations — including a concentration camp in China that housed groups of Girl Scouts. Also, Aziz Ansari explains the significance of a Thanksgiving text message, and Etgar Keret destroys a marriage piece by piece.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Erik Larson has read lots of captain’s logs while researching big historical events.  When he found the log of Captain Walther Schwieger, the guy who headed the U-boat that sank the Lusitania, he knew something didn’t sound right.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cookies and Monsters
episode_acts.summary: PJ Vogt’s friend plays a trick on some girl scouts. The trick doesn’t work.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Romancing the Phone
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Aziz Ansari has been touring the country collecting people’s text messages from when they first say hi, and ask each other out. Sociologist Eric Klinenberg wanted to study this raw data of the initial approach a man makes to a woman over text.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: On A Quiet Street in Richmond
episode_acts.summary: We bring you this very matter-of-fact article from 1853, about something profoundly troubling: a slave auction in Virginia.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Brief History of Us
episode_acts.summary: Actress Sue Scott reads a short story by Etgar Keret. Etgar's newest book is a memoir called The Seven Good Years.

fields.episode_descript: A story about someone who's desperately trying – against long odds – to make it to the United States and become an American. Abdi is a Somali refugee living in Kenya and gets the luckiest break of his life: he wins a lottery that puts him on a short list for a U.S. visa. This is his ticket out. But before he can cash in his golden ticket, the police start raiding his neighborhood, targeting refugees.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to cyber cafe workers around the world about something that lots of Americans have never heard of, but that people in other countries know all about: a lottery run by the U.S. government where the prize is a visa to come to America. Each year people flock to cyber cafes to enter it, hoping for a lucky break that will change their life.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: It turns out winning the lottery is only the first step in trying to come to America. More than half of the people who win each year never make it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Leo Hornak's story about Abdi continues. Abdi encounters one obstacle after another on the streets of Nairobi.

fields.episode_descript: A car plant in Fremont California that might have saved the U.S. car industry. In 1984, General Motors and Toyota opened NUMMI as a joint venture. Toyota showed GM the secrets of its production system: How it made cars of much higher quality and much lower cost than GM achieved. Frank Langfitt explains why GM didn't learn the lessons—until it was too late.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass introduces the story of the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., aka NUMMI. In 1984, General Motors and Toyota opened NUMMI as a joint venture.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: The rise of NUMMI, or how one of the worst auto plants in America started producing some of its best cars, thanks to lessons learned from the Toyota production system.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Why did it take so many years for GM to begin implementing the lessons of NUMMI across the company? NPR Automotive Correspondent Frank Langfitt continues his story.

fields.episode_title: The Problem We All Live With - Part One
fields.episode_descript: Right now, all sorts of people are trying to rethink and reinvent education, to get poor minority kids performing as well as white kids. But there's one thing nobody tries anymore, despite lots of evidence that it works: desegregation. Nikole Hannah-Jones looks at a district that, not long ago, accidentally launched a desegregation program.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira speaks with New York Times Magazine Reporter Nikole Hannah-Jones about her years reporting on education and the various kinds of school reforms administrators have tried to close the achievementgap that never seem to work. Nikole says there's one reform that people have pretty much given upon, despite a lot of evidence that it works – school integration.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Problem We All Live With PART ONE
episode_acts.summary: Nikole Hannah-Jones reports on a school district that accidentally stumbled on an integration programin recent years. It's the Normandy School District in Normandy, Missouri.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Problem We All Live With PART TWO
episode_acts.summary: Nikole Hannah-Jones' story on the Normandy school district from the first part of the show continues.

fields.episode_title: The Problem We All Live With - Part Two
fields.episode_descript: Last week we looked at a school district integrating by accident. This week: a city going all out to integrate its schools. Plus, a girl who comes up with her own one-woman integration plan.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Chana Joffe-Walt talks to Kiana, who went to a school that was overwhelmingly black and Latino, but when some white students showed up one day on an exchange program, she went up to them eagerly.  And since then, has embarked on a one-woman school integration program.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Secret Public Plan
episode_acts.summary: Chana Joffe-Walt reports on the Hartford, CT school system, which actively seeks to integrate.  The results have been impressive.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What’s It All About, Arne?
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Nikole Hannah-Jones, who has investigated integration in schools for years, joins ChanaJoffe-Walt to interview the Secretary of Education, Arne Duncan. The Obama Administration saysit’s in favor of integrating the schools, but doesn’t seem to do so much to promote it.

fields.episode_descript: When is too soon for that celebrity comeback; that joke that is either brilliant or full-on repugnant; that parent-child conversation? This week: stories about a fallen man trying to kickstart his career with a reality show, and an awkward moment between a mom and a daughter.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Jordan was going into his senior year of high school in small town Utah, he and his buddies all lived together in a house, daring each other into Jackass-style pranks and stunts. There's one particular thing Jordan did that he did not want to talk to Ira about.

episode_acts.name: Act One: But Wait, There's More!
episode_acts.summary: Harmon Leon is a writer and comedian whose cocktail party story about “the-weirdest-gig-I-ever-did” is more weird—by a lot—than anyone else’s we’ve heard. He answered an ad several years ago that called for a hilarious sidekick to a celebrity on a hidden camera show.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Pink Slip
episode_acts.summary: One of the show's producers, Zoe Chace, tells Ira about a joke she made pretty soon after something terrible had happened.And then Ira talks to Amy Silverman about something else being too soon, and how she finally figured out the right moment for it. Amy's blog about her daughter is at girlinapartyhat.com.

fields.episode_descript: Katrina bus tours go all over New Orleans, but it’s illegal for them to go into the Lower 9th Ward, the area that's been the slowest to rebuild. This week we go around talking to residents there about what matters the most to them (and what doesn't) ten years after the hurricane. The episode we did in 2005 the week of the storm is here.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Residents of the Lower 9th Ward in New Orleans felt so strongly against hurricane tours after the storm, that legislation made the bus tours illegal there. Ira Glass talks to residents about the problem with bus tours, and takes us on a walking tour of the area, to meet people who are there now, 10 years after the storm.

episode_acts.name: Act 1: First Stop
episode_acts.summary: Robyn Semien talks to St. Claude Internet Café owner Kirk Washington about what’s changed the most in his life, post-Katrina.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: Second Stop
episode_acts.summary: Zoe Chace goes to a favorite bar of the Lower 9th Ward: Mercede’s Place. She finds people who want so badly to go back to their lives before the storm, but know they can’t.

episode_acts.name: Act 3: Third Stop
episode_acts.summary: Lots of people in the lower 9th ward believe that the levees were exploded by the US government, and that’s why their neighborhood ended up under water. This makes a lot of sense when you learn about what happened in that same place in 1927.

episode_acts.name: Act 4: Fourth Stop
episode_acts.summary: A lot of people lost their homes during Katrina, but a lot of people lost their homes afterward, too—in ten years of post-storm debt, foreclosures, and hard loans. Zoe Chace talked with Roy Bradley, a Saints fan who’s facing losing his house right after he rebuilt it.

episode_acts.name: Act 5: Fifth Stop
episode_acts.summary: Someone has moved into Kirk Washington’s friend’s house—the guy from the first stop, whose friend died during Katrina. Her name is Sarah.

episode_acts.name: Act 6: Sixth Stop
episode_acts.summary: Lots of people don’t remember the storm: like people who are just becoming adolescents today.   But they think about it a lot.

fields.episode_descript: A father constructs an elaborate fantasy to occupy his 12 children, and a woman finds herself sucked into a world of make believe that we almost never get to see inside.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: As we were putting together this week's show, we came across a talk that changed the way we seeall the stories in it. Ira explains.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Overboard
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek tells the story of a father and the incredible, decades-long fantasy he created for his 12 children.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Lyin' Kings
episode_acts.summary: A woman befriends her neighbor, only to find herself dragged into a world of make-believe we almost never get to see inside. Producer Jonathan Menjivar tells what happened.

fields.episode_descript: Often we see someone’s situation from the outside and think we know exactly what’s going on. This week, we get inside and find out just how much more interesting the reality of it is.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A mysterious tunnel is found in a forest in Toronto. Public speculation is all over the place and totally wrong.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Can Explain
episode_acts.summary: A teenager reports what it is like to be inside an abusive relationship with an older man. (29 minutes)This piece was created by WNYC’s Radio Rookies program.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: RSV-Pa
episode_acts.summary: Larry speaks English. His dad speaks Chinese.

fields.episode_descript:
Gladiators in the Colosseum. Sideshow performers. Reality television. We've always loved to gawk at the misery or majesty of others. But this week, we ask the question: What's it like when the tables are turned and all eyes are on you?

An episode from last year, with one story swapped.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Joel Gold, a psychologist and author, about a strangely common delusion known as the "Truman Show Delusion," in which patients believe that they are being filmed, 24/7, for a national reality television program.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Am the Eggplant
episode_acts.summary: Producer Stephanie Foo speaks to Nasubi, a Japanese comedian who, in the 90s, just wanted a little bit of fame. So he was thrilled when he won an opportunity to have his own segment on a Japanese reality TV show.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: I Always Feel Like Somebody's Watching Me
episode_acts.summary: Writer Ariel Sabar tells the story of Roger Barker, a psychologist who believed that humans should be studied outside the lab. So Barker dispatched an army of graduate students to follow the children of Oskaloosa, Kansas, and write down every single thing they did.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Take My Break, Please
episode_acts.summary: Charlie Brill and Mitzi McCall were a comedy duo back in the mid-1960s, playing clubs around Los Angeles, when their agent called to tell them he'd landed them the gig of a lifetime: They were going to be on The Ed Sullivan Show. The only problem was that their performance was a total fiasco, for a bunch of reasons, including one they never saw coming.

fields.episode_descript: This week we go into the room at the headquarters of fast food chain Hardee's with the people who decided that this burger with beef, hot dogs, and chips is what America should be eating. We'll hear the story of how they sold that burger and other instances where how you tell the story is more important than the literal facts.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about the phenomenon of weird food mashups that fast food companies started selling in the last five years – things like the pizza with hot dogs on the crust that Pizza Hut made or the Hardee's burger with a cheesesteak as the topping on the burger. Ira explains that there is something about these foods that he's been wondering about.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Room Where It Happens
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace gets into the room that Ira has been wondering about. Specifically, the headquarters of fast food chain Hardee's.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Wedding Crasher
episode_acts.summary: Writer and musician Ahamefule Oluo has been puzzling out one story for a lot of his life. It's the story of a stranger, who also, is his dad.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Drivers Wanted. Really Really Wanted.
episode_acts.summary: As we were putting together this week's show, we thought back to the guy in Act One who was in charge of marketing when Jack in the Box went through an E. Coli crisis.

fields.episode_descript: Twenty years ago, the prime minister of Israel was assassinated. The killer was a lone gunman, Israeli and Jewish, just like the prime minister. Lots of witnesses saw it happen; the assassin confessed immediately, that night, and has never recanted. But today, oddly, lots of people don’t believe it happened that way. And a question hangs over the country: did this act change the fate of the nation?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Nancy Updike and reporter Dan Ephron, about their interview with the accomplice, Hagai Amir, who showed them the house where he and his brother plotted the murder and the shed where he machined special bullets.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Night
episode_acts.summary: Updike and Ephron reconstruct the night of the murder, with Ephron describing what he recalls (he reported from Israel at the time and covered the rally where Rabin was assassinated). A police investigator talks about interrogating Amir in the hours after the assassination.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Morning
episode_acts.summary: Ephron takes the shirt Rabin was wearing on the night of the assassination from Israel to the U.S. to have it examined by a gunshot expert. A right-wing activist describes what the assassination meant to her and her settler movement -- a political victory.

fields.episode_title: The Heart Wants What It Wants
fields.episode_descript: Emily Dickinson said “The heart wants what it wants.” This week stories from people who take that notion to extremes, and are unapologetic about it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to a man in his 70s who’s about to travel across the country to tell a woman he loves how he really feels, despite some very real signs that doing so might be a bad idea.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Jesse’s Girl
episode_acts.summary: Jesse had been waiting his whole life to fall in love—and then he started getting these letters from the perfect woman, Pamala. She seemed vulnerable.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: My Love Is Blue
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Elsa Waithe tells about going to Time’s Square to take part in the Black Lives Matter protests, and winding up with a huge crush on her arresting officer.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Unbreak My Heart
episode_acts.summary: Julia Lillis talks to Ira about the huge, romantic move she made after a break up, and how it was both crazy and worth doing.

fields.episode_descript: People deciding to make very big changes.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Bob Carlson and his 10-year-old daughter, Tess, were driving by Six Flags Magic Mountain when she told him about one of her biggest fears: roller coasters. So they decided to try and take one on.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Optimus ... Way Past Her Prime.
episode_acts.summary: Anthony DeVito recently observed his grandmother go through a metamorphosis no one in the family ever imagined they'd see.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Streetwise
episode_acts.summary: Most big grand transformations we go through really come down to a hundred little things that we change about ourselves. This recently happened for a refugee from Afghanistan, now living in Detroit.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Afterburner
episode_acts.summary: There are things lots of us think we might fix about ourselves, you know, someday. When we get around to it.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Trailbreaker
episode_acts.summary: It's not just that deciding to change your life completely can be momentous. Telling people about the decision can be a big deal too.

fields.episode_descript: Most of the time, the updates we share about our lives are small and inconsequential. This week, status updates that interrupt daily life. We hear two friends talk about how one of them has become rich and famous. And an entire town gets a status update on itself.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Three teenage girls explain why they are constantly telling their friends they are beautiful on Instagram.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Finding the Self in Selfie
episode_acts.summary: Jane, Julia and Ella continue describing the complex social map that is constantly changing in their phones.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mon Ami Ta-Nehisi
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming talks with his friend Ta-Nehisi Coates about Ta-Nehisi’s newfound fame and their friendship.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: There Owes the Neighborhood
episode_acts.summary: The story of an entire town that gets a status update. Producer Chana Joffe-Walt talked to Paul Kiel of Pro Publica, the man who gave the town its status update.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: 76-Year-Old Quarterback Throws Hail Mary Pass
episode_acts.summary: We have an update on a man in his 70s who planned to propose to a woman. We first spoke with him for time in our episode The Heart Wants What the Heart Wants.

fields.episode_descript: Gay Talese reads from his classic 1966 Esquire article, in which he followed around Sinatra at the height of Sinatra's power. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass, with a recording of a 1962 Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr., appearance at the Villa Venice, a club outside Chicago. What's fascinating about Sinatra is how he is so many different people at once, and they're all on display in this recording: sentimental crooner, cruel woman-baiter, bully, goofball.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Frank Sinatra Has a Cold
episode_acts.summary: Gay Talese reads from his classic 1966 Esquire article, in which he followed around Sinatra at the height of Sinatra's power.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: One Sinatra Fan ... Versus All Of Network TV.
episode_acts.summary: Before Sinatra died, Sarah Vowell appeared on this radio program and made a prediction about how network news would cover Sinatra's death ... and she made a simple plea. We hear whether her prediction came true.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: History Lesson
episode_acts.summary: Ira and music contributor John Conners on Sinatra's worst songs. And a brief history of what makes that 1950s Sinatra sound so great, with Will Friedwald, author of the definitive book on Sinatra's music, Sinatra! The Song Is You: A Singer's Art.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Death of Frank Sinatra
episode_acts.summary: Michael Ventura, who grew up Sicilian in New York, says that as a kid he thought Sinatra was in his family. His book The Death of Frank Sinatra is not really about Sinatra.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Chairman of the Block
episode_acts.summary: An odd occurrence at 124 East Fourth Street in Manhattan's East Village. For the last five weeks, a singer named Nick Drakides has stood on the stoop singing Sinatra songs late at night to the delight of his neighbors.

fields.episode_descript: Sure, there's a crude message that propaganda is trying to get across. But like poetry, when you know how to read it, propaganda contains lots of more subtle messages that you might not see at first glance. This week: examples, big and small, from around the world.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to New York Times reporter Damien Cave, about a strange phenomenon he noticed in the pages of in-flight magazines.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Guerrilla Marketing
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sean Cole tells the story of a brand of war propaganda developed in Colombia that was so ambitious and ornate, it's almost hard to believe. You can watch Jose Miguel Sokoloff's TED talk, which is featured in the story, here.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Not Our Town
episode_acts.summary: When Jon Mooallem went to see his six-year-old daughter in a musical at her after-school program, he didn't know what to expect. But it certainly was not the performance saw.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Spy Who Didn't Know She Was A Spy
episode_acts.summary: On September 29th a medical researcher in Philadelphia fired off a simple, well-meaning tweet, and then barely thought twice about it. Little did she know that by doing that, she was perpetrating covert propaganda on behalf of the U.S. government.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Party On!
episode_acts.summary: Evan Osnos, a staff writer for the New Yorker who for years reported on China, tells producer Nancy Updike about an incredibly shrewd and successful propaganda campaign that hinged on two words. Evan's book about China, Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China, won the national book award in 2014.

fields.episode_descript: No Christmas can ever be as good as the ones you had as a kid. But this week we go all in and bring the joy, the spontaneity, the sense that anything can happen back to Christmas.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about “The Twelve Days Of Christmas,” the one Christmas song he’s always hated. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Christmas On A High Wire
episode_acts.summary: Some of the best improv actors in the country join us for a special Christmas themed performance recorded live at the Bellhouse in Brooklyn. Scott Adsit, Mike Birbiglia, Aidy Bryant, Chris Gethard, Tami Sagher, and Sasheer Zamata dream up a magical world on stage that’s only possible at Christmas.
episode_acts.byline: By Mike Birbiglia, Chris Gethard, Tami Sagher, Sasheer Zamata

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Oily Potter and The Gobble of Fire
episode_acts.summary: Producer Stephanie Foo fell hard for a new holiday tradition this year – Turkey Fryer PSAs created by fire departments across the country.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The First Noel
episode_acts.summary: Andre, 6, and his 4 year old brother Luc are experiencing Christmas for the very first time. They’re adopted and have recently moved to the U.S. from the Democratic Republic of Congo.

fields.episode_descript: When you’re the only one who can see something, sometimes it feels like you’re in on a special secret. The hard part is getting anyone to believe your secret is real. This week, people trying to show others what they see—including a woman with muscular dystrophy who believes she has the same condition as an Olympic athlete.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira asks Jefrey Emtman do to the impossible—describe the indescribable color he sees in his left eye. Jefrey Emtman is the host of the podcast Here Be Monsters.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Do These Genes Make Me Look Fatless?
episode_acts.summary: Journalist David Epstein tells the story of Jill Viles, who has muscular dystrophy and can’t walk. But she believes that she somehow has same condition as one of the best hurdlers in the world, Priscilla Lopes-Schliep.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mom Jokes
episode_acts.summary: Producer Nancy Updike speaks with comedian Tig Notaro about her mother-in-law, Carol. Carol came up with a joke that is only funny to one person—herself.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Earth Angel
episode_acts.summary: Actor Alex Karpovsky reads a short story by Etgar Keret, from his book, “The Bus Driver Who Wanted To Be God." (4 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: This week, stories of people who are feeling the ground shift underneath them when people they are close to change. Including conservative radio host Tony Beam in South Carolina who is completely baffled by the candidate his audience has decided to get behind this election season.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Adam Mansbach about what happened when he went looking for an apartment and was mistaken for someone else. Adam is the author of the book Go The F*** To Sleep.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Who's Really On Line 1?
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace goes to Greenville, South Carolina to talk with Tony Beam – host of the radio show Christian Worldview Today. Tony and his listeners are evangelical Christians, and usually, Tony backs a candidate for office and his listeners tend to agree with him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: My Little Bruce Dupe
episode_acts.summary: One day comic Jay Larson's phone rang. And the people on the other end of the line thought they knew who they were talking to.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Light From the Other Side
episode_acts.summary: Robert had a bad reputation as a kid who didn't do his schoolwork and had little respect for adults. But his best friend, Lilly thought he was misunderstood.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: I Thought I Knew U2
episode_acts.summary: Scott Aukerman and Adam Scott have a podcast called "U Talkin' U2 To Me" that is all about the band U2. Scott and Adam love U2.

fields.episode_descript: The brain! It's powerful! Two stories of the brain working for and against its owners.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A staffer at St Joseph Medical Center in Houston finds a patient shot on the floor of his room. He is unarmed, and has been shot by the cops in the hospital.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When Your Hospital-Borne Infection Is a Bullet
episode_acts.summary: We tell the story of that patient, Alan Pean, and how his delusions lead him to a situation that's just as strange as the worst thoughts his mind is cooking up. This story is a collaboration with the New York Times.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Don’t Need to Know Basis
episode_acts.summary: In this act, writer Michael Kinsley describes harnessing the power of his own mind to deal with his Parkinson's diagnosis. Michael Kinsley is a contributing columnist for Vanity Fair and the Washington Post.

fields.episode_title: That's One Way to Do It
fields.episode_descript: Forget the easy way. This week, stories about people who come up with very innovative…and unusual...solutions to their problems. Including the story of a young voter who defies political categorization.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: As a California game warden Terry Grosz went to great lengths — and some depths — to stop illegal fishing. Terry also tells this story in his book Wildlife Wars.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Sex, Boyhood and Politics in South Carolina
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace hangs out with an unlikely Trump supporter in order to get to the bottom of his unusual motivation.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Here's Looking at You, Kidney
episode_acts.summary: Sigrid Fry-Revere was fed up with the kidney donation system in this country. So, she went somewhere that seemed to be doing a better job with its transplant patients— possibly one of the last places you’d expect.

fields.episode_descript: This week, a story about doubt: how it germinated, spread, and eventually took hold of an entire community, with terrible consequences.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira hears from a woman named Shannon about a phone call she got in 2008 that cast doubt on whether an 18 year old named Marie was telling the truth about being sexually assaulted. This idea leads to one of two investigations—one small and bad, and the other stunningly big and good.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: We go to Lynnwood, Washington to retrace the steps of a rape investigation gone undeniably wrong. Producer Robyn Semien and investigative reporter Ken Armstrong of the Marshall Project tell the story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Our story continues two years later in Colorado where detectives in four neighboring towns combine resources to run down a serial rapist.

fields.episode_title: When the Beasts Come Marching In
fields.episode_descript: We human beings think we run the world, that we’ve got things under control. Then an animal shows up, and things don’t go as planned. This week, seals, wolves, and a moose drop in and show us who isn't boss.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira visits an 83-year-old man named Dick Paterniti who’s been waging a long and lonely war against a woodpecker.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Beaching and Moaning
episode_acts.summary: Even when an animal is not a pest, not chewing up homes or spreading disease or biting average citizens, even when it is universally loved, it can still wreak havoc when it arrives in our world. James Spring has this example from a community of harbor seals in La Jolla, California, near San Diego.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hungry like a USDA Contract Employee
episode_acts.summary: Back in the day, generally when a wild animal showed up, we’d just kill it. Take this press release the federal government put out nearly a hundred years ago.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Weeknight at Bernie's
episode_acts.summary: In Anchorage, many people take pride in being able to co-exist side-by-side with wild animals. Jon Mooallem has the story of one animal that became a resident of the city in a way that few non-humans ever do.

fields.episode_title: It’ll Make Sense When You’re Older
fields.episode_descript: Kids do not like being told it’ll make sense when they’re older. They’re pretty sure the grown-ups are wrong.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Kids do not like getting told it’ll make sense when they’re older. They’re pretty sure the grown-ups are wrong, and whatever the conversation is, they’re up for it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Adolescence
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Hillary Frank finds out there is this tradition going on in her town, where big kids take over younger kids’ parties—and she investigates how one kid goes from freaked out to an instigator.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Grown
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Sasheer Zamata does this joke about her mom in her standup act. About how her mom hates white people.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Middle Age
episode_acts.summary: Host Chana Joffe-Walt worries she’ll have regrets in 20 years. So she finds someone 20 years older than she is to gauge how bad it gets.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Old Age
episode_acts.summary: For those in the early stages of dementia, some simple tasks become very complex. Chana sits down with one guy determined to figure out why something that used to be so easy has become so hard.

fields.episode_descript: The older and wiser we get, the more bewildering our past decisions can seem. This week, people revisit those decisions — and we revisit a story we aired a year ago with new, fascinating updates about a groundbreaking study that turned out to be false.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A year ago, we did a story about a study that found that a simple 20-minute conversation could change someone’s mind about controversial issues like gay marriage and abortion. But a few weeks after we aired the story, the study was discredited.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Knock Knock. Who’s There? The Truth.
episode_acts.summary: The story from the prologue continues, with the researchers re-doing the canvassing experiment. And the results are even more surprising this time around.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hotline Bleak
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Chris Gethard has a new podcast called Beautiful Stories from Anonymous People, where people can call in to talk to him about anything for an hour. Our editor, Joel Lovell, tells us about his favorite episode thus far — featuring a man who calls in desperately seeking Chris’ guidance.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Kids Look Back
episode_acts.summary: Senior Producer Brian Reed tells Ira about a book entitled “Now I Know Better,” where children write cautionary tales recounting horrific accidents they’ve endured. He also interviews one of the book’s contributors about his childhood mishap.

fields.episode_descript: Exactly how incompetent you are. What your ex’s best friend really thinks of you. The approximate time that you will die. Some things in life are better not to know about. And sometimes there can be a benefit to not knowing. In this episode — examples of ignorance truly being bliss, or even being an asset.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira relays advice from a staffer’s family on what to do if you’re thinking about something you don’t want to think about.

episode_acts.name: Act One: What You Don't Know
episode_acts.summary: Lulu Wang tells the story of an elaborate attempt to keep someone ignorant — her grandmother — and how her family pulled it off.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Ignorance for Dummies
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sean Cole tells the story of a psychological experiment that proved ignorance is, in fact, bliss.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Forget Me? Not!
episode_acts.summary: Producer Stephanie Foo describes a subset of the population who will never enjoy the benefits of ignorance — because they’re destined never to experience it in the first place.

fields.episode_title: Who Do We Think We Are?
fields.episode_descript: It’s nice to belong, to feel connected to others. But what happens when you realize that your fundamental beliefs don’t line up with the people you want to be close to? Do you bring it up? And, what does that conversation sound like? Including a story by Mariya Karimjee, pictured. Guest host Sean Cole sits in for Ira.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace checks in on Tony, a diehard, conservative Republican and Ted Cruz supporter, to see how he’s holding up this week. Not great.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Whose Great Idea Was This?
episode_acts.summary: When Mariya Karimjee was little, members of her family made a decision that would affect her entire life. Years later, she wants to know why.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Who Wants To Know?
episode_acts.summary: Nema and Neda Semnani have extraordinarily similar first names – and completely opposite ways of dealing with what happened to their dad when they were little.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about mysteries that exist in relationships we thought couldn't possibly surprise us, the strangeness of putting our wants on the line with someone who may not share them at all, and how much we're willing to risk for someone we may never see again.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Rachel Rosenthal, who spent years trying to figure out who had stolen her identity. She was closing bank account after bank account, getting more and more paranoid, until she realized she knew exactly who the thief was.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Rachel’s Getting Harried
episode_acts.summary: Ira’s conversation with Rachel Rosenthal continues. She tells the story of why it took her so long to break up with her boyfriend, even after she figured out that he had stolen from her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Why Can’t We Be Friends?
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming conducts an experiment to find out: can two adults, both new in town, become friends, with the right help? (16 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Hero Today, Gone Tomorrow
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Kyle Mizono, in a live performance, tells about the time she met her hero, spent a week working with him every day, and it went really well. And then, she emailed him.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Break It Down
episode_acts.summary: A short story by Lydia Davis about trying to calculate the cost of a love affair. The story is read by actor Matt Malloy.

fields.episode_descript: People who try simple mind games on others and find themselves in way over their heads.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews Lori Gottlieb about the time she sent a letter to a writer in a magazine, a letter packed with white lies.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Lori Gottlieb's story from the prologue continues. One complication led to another and before long, the writer seemed to be lying to her.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Spy Who Loved Everyone
episode_acts.summary: A group called Improv Everywhere decides that an unknown band, Ghosts of Pasha, playing their first ever tour in New York, ought to think they're a smash hit. So they study the band's music and then crowd the performance, pretending to be hard-core fans.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lonely Hearts Club Band...Of One
episode_acts.summary: Musician David Berkeley has gotten a lot of requests in his life, but none quite like the offer his agent got last year. A fan wanted Berkeley to come to his house and help save his relationship by serenading the troubled couple with a personal concert.

fields.episode_descript: The way people talk about being fat is shifting. With one-third of Americans classified as overweight, and another third as obese, and almost none of us losing weight and keeping it off, maybe it’s time to rethink the way we see being fat. A show inspired by Lindy West’s book Shrill.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews Lindy West about her experience “coming out” as fat.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Day the Scales Fell from Her Eyes
episode_acts.summary: Lindy West tells us how she went from being ashamed of her fatness to embracing it, and reads from her book, Shrill. The book has been adapted into a TV show on Hulu, starring Aidy Bryant.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: It’s a Small World After All
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker lost a lot of weight, 110 pounds. When she was fat, she wasn’t able to get a job or a boyfriend and sometimes thought, “I wonder if it’s my weight.” She figured no, that’s a bad attitude, paranoia.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How Are You Doing with Sizes?
episode_acts.summary: Obesity in America affects a higher percentage of black people than white people. Roxane Gay talks about being black and being fat with host Ira Glass.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Cross Trainers
episode_acts.summary: Fat is seen by so many people as a kind of moral issue. They think you’re fat because you’re weak and can’t get control of your own life.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: An Immodest Proposal
episode_acts.summary: We close the show with one more excerpt from Lindy West’s book, Shrill.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people making the wrong choice, even though the right one is staring them squarely in the eye. Basketball players making a conscious decision to not do the thing that makes them better, pollsters refusing to see the truth of Donald Trump, and more.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews author Alain de Botton about why so many of us choose the wrong spouses. Botton is the author of the new novel The Course of Love.
episode_acts.byline: By Alain De Botton, Ira Glass

episode_acts.name: Act One: Swish Miss
episode_acts.summary: Wilt Chamberlain - easily one of the best basketball players of all time - was a terrible free throw shooter. Except for one season when he changed technique and scored more free throws in one game than anyone ever has.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Poll Dance
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Tom, who regrets his vote on Brexit this week. And Zoe Chace talks to Harry Enten, a senior analyst at the website FiveThirtyEight, about Donald Trump.
episode_acts.byline: By Zoe Chace, Harry Enten, Ira Glass

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Post-It Not
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Kurt Braunohler makes a wrong choice, for his own amusement.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people trying to make sure they get what they paid for, from political change to bedroom slippers. We follow a donor as he vets presidential candidates, and go inside a company wrestling with the consequences of its "no questions asked,” lifetime return policy.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace takes a trip to the grocery store with Planet Money co-host – and ultimate bargain shopper – Jacob Goldstein.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Final Countdown
episode_acts.summary: Doug Deason is a political donor trying to make the biggest decision people like him make every four years – which presidential candidate to back. Producer Zoe Chace follows Deason through the unpredictable primaries of the 2016 election.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Bean Counter
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Sara Corbett looks into what happens when a company makes this promise: if you’re not 100% satisfied by our product, bring it back. Any time, for any reason; no questions asked.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Make It Count
episode_acts.summary: Most stories of customer satisfaction are told by the customers. In this act, we ask: is the product satisfied by life with you? We get answers, from a product itself. Simon Rich reads his short story, “Unprotected.” Please note: this story does vaguely acknowledge the existence of sex.

fields.episode_descript: A bunch of us from our show went to refugee camps all over Greece. We found people falling in love, kids mad at their parents for dragging them to Europe, women doing their laundry in a baseball stadium locker room, and hundreds of people living at a gas station—sitting next to the pumps, smoking. Also: wild pigs. 57,000 refugees are stuck in Greece, making homes in some surprising locations. We hear what that’s really like. (Part Two)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We were interested in how the Greek government was dealing with the refugees, but we also wanted to know what it was like for all these people who thought they were heading elsewhere in Europe who are now stuck in these camps, where they’re just waiting for some country to let them in and restart their lives.  Ira goes on a quick tour of camps around Greece.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Field of Interrupted Dreams
episode_acts.summary: One good place to see how this ad hoc response is working is at an abandoned baseball stadium in Athens. About a thousand Afghans are now living here.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Parents, Trapped
episode_acts.summary: Kids are everywhere in the camps, they’re a third of the refugees. You see them around, improvising stuff to play with.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: All Our Representatives Are Currently Busy
episode_acts.summary: The first step for refugees trying to get out of limbo in Greece has been calling (and calling) the asylum office… on Skype.

fields.episode_title: Don’t Have to Live Like a Refugee
fields.episode_descript: We return to Greece with stories of people trying to move on with their lives in whatever way they can. We meet a couple who fell in love even though they weren't expecting anything like that to happen, and even though her family didn't approve. We also meet a shopkeeper in a camp who's running what amounts to a cigarette charity. (Part One)

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A couple guys show off a pretty creative invention.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You Just Keep on Pushing My Love Over the Borderline
episode_acts.summary: There are young single men and women at the camps, and there’s some flirting for sure. But usually it doesn’t seem to go very far.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Thank You for Smoking
episode_acts.summary: People don’t have a lot of money in the refugee camps, and our producer Miki Meek went to see what that’s like at a camp that’s been built on the grounds of an abandoned psychiatric hospital. About 1,300 people are living there.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Last Resort
episode_acts.summary: There’s a camp trying to set the gold standard for what refugee camps are to be. It’s in an actual beach vacation resort. Joanna Kakissis went there.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Take Another Little Piece of My Heart
episode_acts.summary: One night at L-M Village, a panic-struck man walked up to Robyn Semien from our staff. He said his wife had a medical problem.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Smile, You’re on Handmade Camera
episode_acts.summary: Sean hit up this one piece of coverage that wasn’t like any of the others. He got a little obsessed with it.

fields.episode_descript: Summer is a time when change seems more possible than ever. But is that really how it happens? Can people actually reinvent themselves in the warmer months? This week we present stories — and some comedy — about people and their summer selves.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells a story about how he doesn’t enjoy the summer.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Grapes of Wrath
episode_acts.summary: Producer Dana Chivvis explores the case of a 66-year-old working lifeguard who is suing New York State for age discrimination after refusing to wear a Speedo on the job.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Say Yes to Summer
episode_acts.summary: A troupe of comedians tell personal stories about summer experiences and improvise scenes based on them. Featuring Mike Birbiglia, John Lutz, Kate Micucci, Shannon O'Neill, Connor Ratliff, Gary Richardson and Tami Sagher - Several of whom appear in Mike's new movie "Don't Think Twice," produced by Ira.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It Takes A Villa
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming tells the story of his dad and his family’s timeshare in Orlando, Florida.

fields.episode_descript: What do you do when you're thrown into a situation you’re not prepared for? And while you’re flailing around—what happens to the people who depend on you? This week we present stories of people who find themselves in over their heads, including an attorney who knows little about criminal law assigned to defend a young man facing twenty years in prison.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Aaryn Zhou. When she was nine, her father threw her into the deep end of pool to teach her to swim.

episode_acts.name: Act One: If You Cannot Afford an Attorney, Some Random Dude Will Be Appointed to You
episode_acts.summary: A lawyer with almost no experience in criminal law is assigned to a criminal case with a sentence of 20 years to life. This happened because, in Louisiana, like in a few states, public defenders’ offices are so short-staffed that courts are ordering private attorneys to take pro bono clients.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mein Camp
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes an entire government has to dive into the deep end of the pool and do something it’s never done before. One of our producers Karen Duffin has the story of the US government doing just that… in a high stakes sink or swim situation.

fields.episode_descript: This week, stories about people trying their best to turn themselves into something else—like a badger. Or a professional comedian, in a language they didn’t grow up speaking.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Charles Foster has always been obsessed with trying to figure out how animals see the world. So he decides to find out—by living life as a badger.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Je Suis Ici Toute La Semaine
episode_acts.summary: French comedian Gad Elmaleh is known as the Jerry Seinfeld of France. He sells out arenas.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nighttime
episode_acts.summary: Terriers have been bred for hundreds of years to kill rats. Ray Ray is a terrier, but he lives in a comfy apartment in New York City.

fields.episode_title: One Last Thing Before I Go (2016)
fields.episode_descript: Words can seem so puny and ineffective sometimes. On this show, we have stories in which ordinary people make last ditch efforts to get through to their loved ones, using a combination of small talk and not-so-small talk.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira explains how at the height of the Cuban Missile Crisis, the men with their finger to the button called their loved ones for what was potentially the last time.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Really Long Distance
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek tells the story of a phone booth in Japan that attracts thousands of people who lost loved ones in the 2011 tsunami and earthquake. A Japanese TV crew from NHK Sendai filmed people inside the phone booth, whose phone is not connected to anything at all.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Uncle's Keeper
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein tries to convince his uncle and his father to get into the same room and have a conversation for the first time in decades, before it’s too late and one of them dies. This story comes from Jonathan’s podcast Heavyweight, from Gimlet Media.

fields.episode_descript: San Francisco’s Spider-Man burglar was remarkable. He dropped into buildings from skylights, leapt 10 feet from one roof to another. But mostly, his talent got him into trouble. This week, his story, and stories of other undesirable talents.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Biba Struja – a Serbian man who says that when he was in high school, he discovered that he seemed to have a high resistance to electricity. It’s a power that he’s utilized, but is mostly a curse.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Climb Spree
episode_acts.summary: Awhile back, San Francisco experienced a rash of burglaries that all fit a pattern. The suspect got into businesses at night through skylights, or the attic, and then lowered himself in with ropes where he would rob safes.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Uganda Be Kidding Me
episode_acts.summary: Zora Bikangaga grew up in a mostly white California suburb, the son of Ugandan immigrants. But when he went to college, someone thought he himself was Ugandan.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Disbarred
episode_acts.summary: Wendy Whelan was a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet until 2014. She explains an undesirable side of having an incredible talent.

fields.episode_descript: Watching lies become the truth in this year's election. And a few people who try to bridge the gap between the way the two sides see the facts.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about what’s alarming him about this year’s election: facts seem less meaningful than they ever have, and the gap between the mainstream media and right-wing media’s versions of the world have never seemed further apart. CNN’s Jake Tapper explains what it was like to be on the air live when Donald Trump tried to take a huge, obvious lie and pass it off as the truth.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lies Become the Truth
episode_acts.summary: Ira's quest continues. He calls his Uncle Lenny, who gets his news from Fox and the Wall Street Journal, and lives with an entirely different set of facts, and Alex Nowrasteh, an immigration expert at the CATO Institute, who explains that the central issue in Donald Trump’s candidacy is based on something that isn’t true.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Judges with Grudges
episode_acts.summary: In this election year we look at the story of one small ballot initiative, in one state. We heard this referendum would gut Georgia's Judicial Qualifications Commission (JQC), an independent organization that investigates ethics complaints about judges.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Aw, Do We NAFTA?
episode_acts.summary: Ira explains that when Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton all seemed to be against free trade agreements, he got genuinely confused. Is free trade good or bad?  Was NAFTA good or evil? Are we down with TPP? He asked Jacob Goldstein of NPR’s Planet Money podcast to explain, once and for all, the pros and cons of free trade.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Seriously?
episode_acts.summary: We’ve been wondering about some of the things President Obama thinks about the current election, but can’t say publicly. But since he hasn’t told us his thoughts explicitly, we asked singer/songwriter Sara Bareilles – who did the Broadway musical “Waitress” – to imagine those thoughts for us.

fields.episode_title: Will I Know Anyone at This Party?
fields.episode_descript: Right now lots of Republicans feel like they don’t recognize their own party. Like a Minnesota congressman who’s confused when the residents in his district, people he’s known for years, start calling for a ban on Muslims moving to their town.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There’s a seismic, historic change going on in the Republican party this year. Producer Zoe Chace tells Ira about a place you can eavesdrop on a group of Republican friends as they fret and argue about that change week after week: a podcast called Ricochet.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Party in the U.S.A.
episode_acts.summary: One way to understand the split inside the Republican party is to look at immigration. It’s this urgent, emotional issue for so much of the party these days.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Party Guy
episode_acts.summary: (Podcast and Internet Only)		Another tragic figure this year is the head of the Republican National Comittee Reince Priebus, who has the job of holding the whole party together. A grueling and thankless job, this year.

fields.episode_descript: A story about Hillary Clinton that offers a different picture than what we’ve been hearing from both sides during this campaign. And some funny stuff, because everyone’s tired of the election.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There’s a political parable about Hillary Clinton that’s made the rounds this year. Host Ira Glass interviews contributor Jack Hitt, who says that in this parable you can see almost every version of Hillary that exists in the popular imagination: the A student, the opportunist, the mastermind, the rat fink, the pragmatist, the truth-twister.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Server Be Served
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole talks to reporter Garrett Graff, who read the 247 pages of interview summaries of the FBI investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails. Graff concludes that it’s not the scandal most people thought it was.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Knowing What We Know
episode_acts.summary: After Huma Abedin’s emails were discovered on her husband’s computer by the FBI, and after FBI Director James Comey publicly declared the agency would be investigating those emails, Hillary Clinton’s poll numbers dropped. What was the conversation Huma Abedin then had with her boss, Hillary Clinton? Actors Tami Sagher and Cady Huffman tried to imagine it.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Of Mice and Men
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Mike Birbiglia, his wife and his cat take a trip together and meet some parasitic zombie mice.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Squirrel Cop
episode_acts.summary: The first day on the job inevitably means mistakes, mishaps, and, sometimes, fiascos. A true story, about a rookie cop, told by the cop.

fields.episode_descript: People around the country talking about the coming four years. Some of them exultant, some of them, as President Obama said Wednesday, "less so."

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains that this hour we will hear from people from all over the country, with different points of view, explain what they’re feeling and thinking about Donald Trump’s election.

episode_acts.name: Act One: South Florida
episode_acts.summary: Two police officers who voted for Obama in 2008 explain to Producer Miki Meek why they went for Trump this time around.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Metro-North Train
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming talks to someone who was not happy with the results of Tuesday’s election. Janelle, who’s black, is bracing herself for the coming days.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Trump Tower
episode_acts.summary: Producer Karen Duffin visits someone who actually knows the man who’s going to be President: Donald Trump’s neighbor.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Los Angeles
episode_acts.summary: Producer Jonathan Menjivar listens in on parent-teacher conferences the day after the election at a bilingual school in Los Angeles.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Long Island
episode_acts.summary: For some people, this election wasn’t just about choosing a politician. It was about choosing their new boss.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Times Square
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to a Muslim woman who tweeted on election night that she was worried she would no longer feel safe wearing a hijab.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Nicholasville, Kentucky
episode_acts.summary: Donald Trump has promised to get rid of Obamacare. Producer David Kestenbaum talks with someone who’d lose their insurance.

episode_acts.name: Act Eight: Greenville South Carolina
episode_acts.summary: We’ve been talking to Trump voters all year—a time during which they’ve watched their candidate’s chances evolve from laughable, to likely, to striking distance, to victory. Producer Zoe Chace checks in with a father and son who’ve been Trump supporters since February, when their guy was an underdog.

episode_acts.name: Act Nine: Salt Lake City
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker talks to a Republican woman who voted for Hillary Clinton this year, and has suffered consequences in the Mormon community she lives in.

episode_acts.name: Act Ten: New York City
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace hung out with some immigration lawyers who are getting calls from their nervous clients.

episode_acts.name: Act Eleven: Toledo
episode_acts.summary: On election night, producer Emmanuel Dzotsi was the last person at our office. Just before midnight, he got on the phone to his mom in Ohio, and recorded their conversation.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who decide to rethink the way they’ve been doing things, or try to get others to do that. Including a woman who decides to confront the men who catcall her, and get them to give it up forever.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Eleanor Gordon-Smith, a writer/reporter in Australia who decides to confront her catcallers and figure out why they do it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hollaback Girl
episode_acts.summary: The story from the prologue continues. Eleanor tries to persuade Zack and Mike not to catcall or accost women in the streets of King’s Cross.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Real Decoy
episode_acts.summary: Producer Stephanie Foo talks to veteran Michael Pitre, who had to change the way he talked about his experiences in the military after he realized the effect it was having on people.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You Had One Job
episode_acts.summary: A bomb disposal robot is assigned a new and even more complicated task. Fiction by Scott Brown, read by actor Jeremy Shamos.

fields.episode_descript: Samantha Broun talks to cops, politicians, inmates, and family closest to the crime that changed policy 20 years ago for inmates serving life sentences in Pennsylvania. It's a crime Samantha knows well, because it happened to her mom.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira re-listens to an interview he did with his mom 16 years ago, three years before she died.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Samantha Broun interviews her mom about surviving a brutal attack by Reginald McFadden 20 years ago, and sets out to interview friends, family and policymakers about how that attack changed Pennsylvania law regarding life sentences at the time.		Additional information and outtakes are available on the Transom website.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Samantha continues toward McFadden, and talks to an inmate who knows something about the case that she never knew before.

fields.episode_descript: Kids using perfectly logical arguments, and arriving at perfectly wrong conclusions.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Rebecca who, using perfectly valid evidence, arrived at the perfectly incorrect conclusion that her neighbor, Ronnie Loeberfeld, was the tooth fairy. Ira also talks with Dr.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Baby Scientists with Faulty Data
episode_acts.summary: More stories like the one in the prologue, where kids look at something going on around them, observe it carefully, think about it logically, and come to conclusions that are completely incorrect.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Werewolves in Their Youth
episode_acts.summary: Michael Chabon reads an excerpt from his short story "Werewolves in Their Youth," from his collection of the same name, about an act of kid logic that succeeds where adult logic fails.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Game Ain't Over til the Fatso Man Sings
episode_acts.summary: Howie Chackowicz tried a risky combination when he was little, kid logic with puppy love. He used to think that girls would fall in love with him if they could just see him sleeping, or if they could hear him read aloud.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: When Small Thoughts Meet Big Brains
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg investigates a little-studied phenomenon: Children who get a mistaken idea in their heads about how something works or what something means, and then don't figure out until well into adulthood that they were wrong. Including the tale of a girl who received a tissue box for Christmas, allegedly painted by trained monkeys.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from people who want something desperately—for Christmas or otherwise—and then have their wishes fulfilled. Or do they?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Luke Huisenga, a Marine sniper who became a fan of Gilmore Girls while on deployment in Iraq.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lopsided Tannenbaum
episode_acts.summary: A fictional story written and read by Maile Meloy about a family that encounters two peculiar strangers in the snow on Christmas Day.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: He’s Making A List, Checking It Nice, Gonna Find Out Who Voted Twice
episode_acts.summary: After this year’s election, Republicans in North Carolina went out looking for cases of voter fraud - all over the state. It was hard to find, hard to prove—until they stumbled across what could have been the best present ever: a seemingly clear-cut case of Democrats out to rig the election.

fields.episode_descript: We’ve fought two wars since 9/11. We got help from tens of thousands of Iraqis and Afghans—some were targeted or killed because they helped us. We owe these people. We’ve passed laws that say so. So why has it been so hard for us to get many of them to safety?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass interviews Congressman Seth Moulton (D., Mass.), who served four tours as a Marine in Iraq. Moulton talks about an Iraqi translator he grew close to, and about a special visa program that allows Iraqi and Afghan translators to come to the U.S.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Good Things Come to Those Who Wait. But Not Always.
episode_acts.summary: An Iraqi translator named Sarah has been trying to get to the U.S. for eight years. Finally, this fall, she got a call to come in for an interview for her visa.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: He’s Making a List
episode_acts.summary: Nancy returns with a story that explains the origins of the special visa program for interpreters. A decade ago, a young guy named Kirk Johnson inadvertently became the point person for American policy about the Iraqis and Afghans endangered by their work for us.

fields.episode_descript: Some people are super-stoked for the political changes that are coming. We hear from them. And others.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to a man driving to Washington, D.C.—with his brother, father and a whole lot of neckties—for his first job on Capitol Hill.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Meme Come True
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace attends the DeploraBall, a party for trolls and others who say they memed Trump into the presidency.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dreamers Get Real
episode_acts.summary: Kenia and her brother Henrri make a trip back to El Salvador, for the first time in 12 years, since they immigrated to the US. For the last few years they've been protected from deportation, but are worried things might change under President Trump. Seth Freed Wessler reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Law and Border
episode_acts.summary: Border Patrol agents were stoked when immigration became a centerpiece of Trump’s campaign. Producer Stephanie Foo went to find out how they hope their jobs will change.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Sam Black visited factory workers in Indiana to see how they are feeling. Trump saved some of their colleagues’ jobs.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
episode_acts.summary: Democrats don’t run the White House. Or the House.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
episode_acts.summary: Two civil servants who do not like our new President weigh their options. Quit? Stay? Stay and fight? Producer David Kestenbaum reports.

fields.episode_descript: This week we document what happened when the President’s executive order went into effect temporarily banning travel from seven countries, and we talk about the way it was implemented. A major policy change thrown into the world like a fastball with no warning. It’s hard not to ask: “What just happened? What was that all about?”

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: This week we document what happened when the President’s executive order went into effect, and talk about the way it was implemented. A major policy change thrown into the world like a fastball with no warning.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Basket of Deportables
episode_acts.summary: The news of the executive order broke while immigrants and refugees were mid-flight. That meant they were stranded in airports around the country.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Heavy Vetting
episode_acts.summary: One of the justifications for the executive order from the administration was that we needed to temporarily stop admitting immigrants and refugees from these seven countries in order to scrutinize and improve the vetting process. Ira speaks with the vetters about how they vet and what they make of the new order.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Statement of Purpose
episode_acts.summary: There is one line in the executive order that justifies its existence. It’s the second sentence in section 1.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: How Do You Solve A Problem Like Sharia?
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with a very skeptical national security expert about whether this order actually secures the nation.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: It’s Not Easy Being Green
episode_acts.summary: We revisit a refugee who’s been resettled in America, and on our show in the past—Abdi Nor—to see what he thinks.

fields.episode_descript: People going to very extreme measures to demonstrate their feelings.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek takes Ira back to her old high school in a town called Payson, Utah. They meet up with students who go above and beyond when asking dates out to school dances.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dr. Strangelove.
