episode_acts.summary: A guy in Key West makes a series of grand gestures, each one more outrageous than the last. He goes so far that we need to say that this story, from Miki Meek, is not for kids.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Say It Out Cloud
episode_acts.summary: Our producer David Kestenbaum spoke with some people who are in the grand gesture business: skywriters.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It’s Gesture Imagination
episode_acts.summary: Among friends, Elna Baker is famous for her romantic advice: go big! She talks to Ira about successes and failures.

fields.episode_descript: A show about rules and what happens when they’re vague and randomly enforced.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The Department of Homeland Security’s new policies on deportation have sown fear and confusion among undocumented immigrants. Ira Glass and Lilly Sullivan go to Chicago and meet a family trying to navigate the situation.

episode_acts.name: Act One: That’s Just How I Rule
episode_acts.summary: A family that owns a private island in Hawaii sets rules for the people who live there. But when the rules are administered in an unpredictable way, the islanders get upset.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Dave in Court
episode_acts.summary: A judge in a suburban New Jersey courtroom wants the people who come before him to see the rules as fair. Including our reporter, David Kestenbaum.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from people who need a grown-up. Featuring teenage girls asking for advice about their love lives and Ira's tribute to his very grown-up friend Mary.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Sean Cole about a video he found of the rap duo Run the Jewels—giving advice to teenage girls.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Are You There, Ad-Rock? It's Me, Margaret
episode_acts.summary: Sean continues his story about Rookie Magazine's Ask A Grown, and goes through some particularly interesting moments of advice from famous people to regular teen girls. Watch more videos from Ask A Grown. (14 1/2 minutes) Ira's Ask A Grown Video

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Enemy of The People vs. The People.
episode_acts.summary: Mike Wilson, the editor of the Dallas Morning News, recently got some hate mail from conservative readers. They think that the media—and his paper—are biased.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ask My Grown-Up Kid
episode_acts.summary: We searched for a parent who had a question for their kid...that they could only ask them after their kid was an adult. Then we found Ken Gethard, comedian Chris Gethard's dad, who had some really meaningful questions he wanted to ask his son.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Ask A Very Grown Woman
episode_acts.summary: Ira's good friend Mary Ahearn died this week. She was thirty years older than him...so, decidedly more grown-up than he.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who decide that they are the best person for the job, no matter how dangerous. Including a story about a stay-at-home mom with a history of gun running for a guerilla organization, and a surgeon who does surgery...on himself.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells the story of what might be one of the most daring surgeries ever performed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Line in the Sand
episode_acts.summary: A Border Patrol agent takes us deep inside his experience patrolling the U.S.-Mexico border.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Da-Do-Run-Guns-Mum-Da-Do-Run-Guns
episode_acts.summary: Journalist Reya El-Salahi tells the story of learning something very surprising about her mother’s past, involving a fake marriage, guns and guerrillas.

fields.episode_descript: What it's actually like to live in the confusing information landscape that is Putin's Russia.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Russian reporter Anna Nemtsova in Moscow about the recent subway bombing in St. Petersburg and the conspiracy theories she heard from Russians as soon as news about the bombing started to spread. Anna Nemtsova is a correspondent for The Daily Beast and Newsweek.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Going In With A Bang
episode_acts.summary: Back in 1999 there was a series of bombings of apartment buildings in Moscow and across Russia. 300 people died. It happened just as Vladimir Putin was coming to power.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mr. Popular
episode_acts.summary: Vladmir Putin’s approval rating is a seemingly unreal 84%. Ira talks to reporter Charles Maynes to find out if that number is real and how it could be that high.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Maybe Pay Attention To The Man Behind The Curtain
episode_acts.summary: Disinformation and propaganda works differently in Putin’s Russia than it did during the Soviet Union. Instead of tamping down the opposition, the Russian government works to control the opposition.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Matter of Principal
episode_acts.summary: The anti-government protests last month in Russia were surprising for a few reasons – including the fact that they included tons of young people. After the protests, teenagers started posting videos to the internet of their teachers lecturing them about the protests and the kids arguing back.

fields.episode_descript: Before Donald Trump started his presidential campaign in 2015, there was a congressional race that redefined what was possible in American politics. Steve Bannon and Breitbart News got involved in that race early, just like they later got deeply involved in Donald Trump's race. On this week’s show: What happened in that campaign, what it made it work, and how we got to now.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Vice News producer Reid Cherlin tells Ira about a party he attended in Washington in 2014. At the time he thought everyone there was on the fringe of the right wing, largely irrelevant.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Brat Pack
episode_acts.summary: In 2014, in the wake of losing the previous presidential election, the Republican Party had committed itself to immigration reform as its only path to winning elections in the future. Within two years, Donald Trump would be elected on the exact opposite platform, railing against immigration.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Who Tells Your Story?
episode_acts.summary: For years Pat Buchanan ran on many of the same ideas that Donald Trump would later run on. Buchanan lost — three times.

fields.episode_descript: To be, or not to be a pirate? This week, that is the question. Hold fast, mateys! We have stories about both historical and modern-day swashbucklers who loot, pillage, and question their choices.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Elna Baker about Stede Bonnet, a nobleman who woke up one day and decided that his new life goal was to become a pirate. You can read the trials of Stede Bonnet online.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pirate Change Denier
episode_acts.summary: Mohammed Aden was just a regular Minnesotan dad who unwittingly became governor of a region in Somalia. As governor, one of his main goals was to eliminate piracy… so why is he now sitting in prison for colluding with pirates? Producer Dana Chivvis investigates.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: C.E.Yo-Ho-Ho.
episode_acts.summary: Producer Stephanie Foo talks to author and pirate historian Laura Sook Duncombe about the most successful pirate of all time, Cheng I Sao.

fields.episode_descript: Three people grapple with the question, “Are we alone?”

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: If there is intelligent life elsewhere in the universe, why haven’t we heard from the extraterrestrials yet? Producer David Kestenbaum explains The Fermi Paradox to host Ira Glass. The possibility that we are alone in the universe makes David sad.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Think We’re Alone Now
episode_acts.summary: David’s story continues. He visits his old physics professor, who helps him figure out what to think.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Two Can Be as Sad as One
episode_acts.summary: We turn now to one of the loneliest experiences a person can have: marriage. Ira listens to two people trying to break through what’s going wrong in their marriage, an excerpt from a new podcast in which real couples have a real therapy session with a real therapist, Esther Perel.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Rosie’s Paradox
episode_acts.summary: One night Rosie’s father, busy working, told Rosie, then 9, to stop distracting him with her questions. She should write them all down, he said.

fields.episode_descript: A polygraph operator and his strange journey. And other stories.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Relevant Questions
episode_acts.summary: A story about polygraph operator Doug Williams, created by the podcast Love + Radio, that’ll be part of their upcoming season. Produced by Jacob McClelland, Ana Adlerstein, Steven Jackson and Nick van der Kolk.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Where the Rubber Meets the Road
episode_acts.summary: Ira discusses James Comey’s Senate testimony this week, testimony that called the president a liar. And producer Sean Cole talks with Theo Greenly about a lie that bothered him for a while, a lie involving his cousin, an artist named Kenny Scharf.

fields.episode_descript: Just a few years before he got the internship at NPR that started him in radio, our host Ira Glass had another career. He performed magic at children's birthday parties. A powerful sense of embarrassment has prevented him from ever doing an episode on the subject, but when he learned that producer David Kestenbaum was also a kid conjurer, they decided to dive in together.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to producer David Kestenbaum about what it was like to be a kid magician.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Oldest Trick in the Book
episode_acts.summary: Magicians say it can take years to create and polish a new magic trick. Teller (of Penn and Teller) shows host Ira Glass how he invented one of his most beautiful and puzzling routines.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Lady Vanishes
episode_acts.summary: Producer David Kestenbaum became obsessed with one trick he loved as a kid—when David Copperfield made the statue of liberty disappear.

fields.episode_descript: Most of the time, we show the world a pretty superficial version of ourselves. "How about that weather?" But this week—people who try to go deeper, to get to something real, in some unexpected places: war, magic and porn.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt tells Ira about a man who decided to do a drag act at his child's elementary school talent show.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How I Learned To Start Worrying and Fear the Bomb
episode_acts.summary: Earlier this month, North Korea fired an intercontinental ballistic missile… one powerful enough, news reports said, to reach Alaska. People were shocked.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Lie Becomes the Truth
episode_acts.summary: Ira with two magicians who take the premise of magic – that it’s all about deception – and try to stand that on its head to get to something utterly real, unfaked and emotional. (16 minutes)		David Blaine is on tour for the summer.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fly Girl
episode_acts.summary: Jon Ronson has been working on a podcast for over a year that traces how one man changed the porn business, when he applied modern internet technology — keywords, search-term optimization — to porn. One big obvious consequence of this is that so much pornography is given away for free, people who make porn videos have a much harder time making a living.

fields.episode_title: Fear and Loathing in Homer and Rockville
fields.episode_descript: Two towns where people got really upset about undocumented immigrants, even though in both places, that did not seem to be the most important thing happening at all. One of the towns, a small town in Alaska, has no undocumented immigrants at all, but the possibility of them arriving put the whole town at each other’s throats.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to our Senior Producer Brian Reed about a fight that’s been brewing in the remote town of Homer, Alaska over a resolution that states that Homer welcomes immigrants. Which is odd.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fear
episode_acts.summary: Brian Reed continues his story about the town of Homer, Alaska. He talked to all sorts of people involved in the debate over whether the town should welcome immigrants.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Loathing
episode_acts.summary: In the first half of the show, we documented a community that was worried about what might happen, theoretically, if undocumented immigrants arrived. In this act, Producer Zoe Chace looks at a community where the immigrants have already arrived – Rockville, Maryland.

fields.episode_descript: When everything goes wrong, one of the first things we think is, "Who do I call?" This week, stories of lucky people who have found the exact right person to ring up for help.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Sean Cole tells a story about how he found the very perfect person to call for things large and small, and how Sean might be his guru's perfect person, too.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fass Talker
episode_acts.summary: Bob Fass has been a radio host on WBAI since 1963, often taking calls from strangers late at night. One night at 3 a.m. in 1971, a man called into his show facing a literally life-or-death dilemma.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Road By Any Other Name
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Aaron Reiss found a woman that an entire community calls, in order to find out the names of the very streets they're walking on. She's the gatekeeper for a series of secret underground maps of New York City.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ode to Joy
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass' friend Lucy used to love listening to the radio psychologist Joy Browne, who she thought always had the best advice. But is it possible for someone's advice to just be too good? Ira Glass talks to Lucy to find out.

fields.episode_descript: One of our producers, Neil Drumming, has recently become fascinated with Afrofuturism. It's more than sci-fi. It’s a way of looking at black culture that’s fantastic, creative, and oddly hopeful—which feels especially urgent during a time without a lot of optimism.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and producer Neil Drumming visit a comic book store in Philadelphia to try and help Ira understand Afrofuturism.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Metropolis Now
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming spends a couple days exploring Detroit, first with a quirky mayoral candidate running an Afrofuturist campaign, and then with a couple of locals.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Past Imperfect
episode_acts.summary: Comedian and actor Azie Dungey recounts her time playing a slave for visiting tourists at George Washington’s estate in Mount Vernon.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Black Sea
episode_acts.summary: This American Life commissioned an original song, “The Deep,” from the hip-hop group clppng., featuring actor and Hamilton performer Daveed Diggs. The song is based on the underwater mythology of the 90s Detroit electro band Drexciya.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Childhood’s End
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming looks into two videos he found on YouTube—one that takes place in Atlantic City, another in Brooklyn—that deal with the trouble kids face walking home from school.

fields.episode_descript: Everyone walks around on their own private map of the world. The places we’re from and how they made us, whether we like it or not.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to Australian novelist Gerald Murnane. He’s never left Australia.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Vouching Towards Bethlehem
episode_acts.summary: Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos is from Grand Rapids, Michigan. So is This American Life producer Susan Burton.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kids in the Hall
episode_acts.summary: Will McMillan found a home in the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah’s Witnesses when he was a teenager. Ultimately he was kicked out of the church.

fields.episode_descript: In 1967, the first two Black students were enrolled at an all-white private boarding school in Virginia. The main reason they were there? To benefit the white kids.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Mariya Karimjee about a college application essay question. Essay B asks students to imagine a person they might meet in college—someone from a very different background.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How to Win Friends and Influence White People
episode_acts.summary: Back in the late 1960s, a wealthy tobacco heiress saw that integration was happening all around the country—except at prep schools in the South. So she set out to find the best Black students in neighborhood public schools—in hopes of teaching the white prep-school students to be less bigoted. Mosi Secret tells the story of how the first two Black students to integrate Virginia Episcopal School succeeded beyond anyone’s expectations.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Mosi Secret’s story continues. We find out about a Black student who struggled at VES.

fields.episode_descript: Right-wing groups like the Proud Boys say they have no tolerance for racism or white supremacist groups. Their leader Gavin McInnes disavowed the white nationalist rally in Charlottesville. But the Proud Boys believe “the West is the best,” which, one of them points out, is not such a big jump from “whites are best.” And one of the Proud Boys organized the Charlottesville rally. (The group now claims he was a spy.) What should we make of groups like this?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Last month, after white nationalists and members of the alt-right and offshoot groups descended on Charlottesville, Virginia, and marched with torches, the staff of our show realized something: The guy who organized the rally was a member of a right wing men's group that our producer Zoe Chace had been following for months, long before the rally was planned. And she’d learned that the group had an unlikely spiritual advisor: a liberal, black relationship consultant and comedian named Dante Nero.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Lost in the Proud
episode_acts.summary: Dante Nero has been involved in this group for years, since before it even had a name. He’s seen its evolution.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Phone Calls to an Undisclosed Location
episode_acts.summary: The man who organized the rally in Charlottesville is named Jason Kessler. He says he’s not to blame for the violence that happened there, including the death of a counter protester.

fields.episode_descript: Who thought that would be good for a kid?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira remembers the time when his older sister, Randi, asked his mother where babies come from.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Stars & Bars & Bars
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming talks with the rapper Breeze Brewin about a toy car they both loved playing with as kids: The General Lee from the hit TV show The Dukes of Hazzard. Breeze went on to record a song called “Generally” about The General Lee with his group the Juggaknots.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: History is Not a Toy
episode_acts.summary: There’s a museum in Baltimore that was created to memorialize the Black experience in America. It’s called The National Great Blacks in Wax Museum.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Questionnaire
episode_acts.summary: Over the last few years, there’s been a flood of kids from Central America who’ve arrived in the United States by themselves. With no adults.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Rocket Boy
episode_acts.summary: Paul Zimmer is eighty-three years old now, and he’s still haunted by something he saw in his teens. Something very few Americans have ever seen: The explosion of an atomic bomb.

fields.episode_title: In the Shadow of the City
fields.episode_descript: Stories that take place on the edge of civilization, just out of sight.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Every city's got a place like this: that weird no man's land on the outskirts of town, with junk yards and landfills. Charlie Gregerson grew up near that stuff, on Chicago's far south side, and he remembers finding debris from famous Louis Sullivan masterpieces in the garbage dump after those buildings were demolished.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Brooklyn Archipelago
episode_acts.summary: Out for a simple pleasure cruise with two friends, Alex Zharov was planning to see Jamaica Bay in New York City. But this end-of-the-day excursion, which should have only lasted 40 minutes, turns into an out-of-control adventure that left him lost, stranded, and bleeding—all within sight of the Empire State Building. Brett Martin reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Troubled Bridge Over Water
episode_acts.summary: There is a four mile long bridge in Naan-jing China, famous for how many people jump off to die by suicide. In 2003, a man named Chen Sah began spending all of his weekends on the bridge, trying to single handedly stop the jumpers.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Yes, In My Backyard
episode_acts.summary: The story of the government cracking down on smokestack emissions at a city factory—even though the residents like the emissions. We hear from Jorge Just, who explains the one, magical secret about Chicago that no one outside Chicago ever believes is true.

fields.episode_descript: We all love to travel to different places, but not many of us like the stressful, banal process of the journey. This week, stories about delays—including a town known entirely for its speed trap, and a woman who comes up against bureaucratic nightmares every time she wants to go just a few blocks away.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to JetBlue pilot Anne Aldrich about the unusual speech she gives before take-off.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Most Expected Delay in Northern Ohio
episode_acts.summary: Linndale, Ohio, is a town known almost entirely for its speed trap. Producer Sean Cole explains.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Asleep at the Wheel
episode_acts.summary: Traffic jams that last days are not uncommon in China. Producer Stephanie Foo talks to two people about how they pass the time.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Longest Distance Between Two Points
episode_acts.summary: New York City has a paratransit service called Access-a-Ride for passengers who are disabled and elderly. But people who rely on the system refer to it as Stress-a-Ride.

fields.episode_descript: There are so many facts about the world that we take for granted—without ever questioning how we know them. Of course the earth revolves around the sun. Of course my dog loves me. But how exactly do we know things like that are true? This week, stories of people trying to unspool some of life’s certainties, and what they find.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host David Kestenbaum talks to producer Diane Wu about a list she keeps of things she means to know. Sweet potatoes vs. yams.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fraud Complex
episode_acts.summary: We’ve all heard reports that voter fraud isn’t real. But how do we know that’s true? David Kestenbaum went on a quest to find out if someone had actually put in the work—and run the numbers—to know for certain.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Flake News
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace has been following Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake for the last few months, reporting on the run-up to his re-election bid in 2018.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Sun Also Rises...Over There
episode_acts.summary: Among the things we tend to take for granted: The sun comes up and goes down like clockwork. Except when it doesn’t.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Period Drama
episode_acts.summary: Remember learning that women’s menstrual cycles tend to sync up when they spend a lot of time together? Producer Diane Wu was skeptical. So she went looking for evidence.

fields.episode_title: So a Monkey and a Horse Walk Into a Bar
fields.episode_descript: This week, blurring the line between animal and human.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells a favorite joke—about a popcorn-eating horse and a hat-wearing cow.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Monkey in the Middle
episode_acts.summary: Nature photographer David Slater went to Indonesia. While he was there, he got some stunning photos of monkeys.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: If Wishes Were Horses
episode_acts.summary: Two women attempt very different transformations. One wants to become a mother.

fields.episode_descript: We spent eight months and did over a hundred interviews to try to bypass the usual rhetoric and get to the bottom of what really happened when undocumented workers showed up in one Alabama town.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Today's show came out of something we heard politicians saying.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: We’ve visited Albertville, Alabama many times now, to figure out exactly what happened when the population shifted from 98% white in 1990, to a fourth Latino twenty years later.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: We hear the companies’ side—they have a totally different story to tell than the workers.		We also go to one of the leading researchers on the economic effects of immigrants, Giovanni Peri, who chairs the economics department at UC Davis. He and researcher Justin Wiltshire did a study for us on what happened to wages and jobs in Albertville.

fields.episode_descript: So many people in Albertville, AL wondered what it cost them in taxes when thousands of undocumented immigrants moved to their town. One woman drove our host Ira Glass to the grocery store to watch a random Latina mom buy some milk with government assistance, to try to prove her point. So what’d all the newcomers really cost? And what was their effect on crime, schools, and politics?

episode_acts.name: Act One: Christmas Lights and Fender Benders
episode_acts.summary: In the early years, when immigrants first arrived in Albertville, the things that bothered the locals weren’t the things you usually hear about when people talk about immigration. Not jobs or wages or crime.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The March
episode_acts.summary: Latino residents decided to organize a peaceful march in support of a path to legal status, and their white neighbors were shocked when 5,000 people poured into the streets.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Backlash
episode_acts.summary: Suddenly realizing just how many Latinos had moved to town, longtime residents jumped into action, fueled by a wave of national and statewide anti-immigration fever. Then in 2011, Alabama adopted the most extreme anti-immigrant law in the country.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Let’s Do the Numbers
episode_acts.summary: One of the things we were excited to investigate when we went to Alabama was to answer the question at the heart of the immigration debate: what does it cost taxpayers when we let in millions of immigrants, documented and undocumented? In Albertville, how much was it? We asked economist Kim Rueben and her colleague Erin Huffer to run the numbers.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Today
episode_acts.summary: In 2012, the fever broke, and the Albertville city council stopped targeting Latino residents. The mayor says he and the council are taking a cue from the public schools.

fields.episode_descript: Even the best laid plans can go catastrophically wrong when humans get involved. This week, people bungle simple operations on some of the most dangerous weapons in the world.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the little known story about one of the times we almost began a nuclear war with the Soviet Union—by accident.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: In 1980, deep in a nuclear missile silo in Arkansas, a simple human error nearly caused the destruction of a giant portion of the Midwest. Joe Richman, founder of Radio Diaries tells the story. 		Eric Molinsky helped report this story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Erring Like a Sailor
episode_acts.summary: The Navy’s Seventh Fleet has seen a string of collisions and accidents, killing 17 sailors this year. Producer Stephanie Foo learned about a part of Navy life that investigators say played a role in these accidents.

fields.episode_descript: A boy who can’t dribble gets a coach, a new best friend, and something to believe in.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira introduces David Kestenbaum's story with some thoughts about the challenges of parenting.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Believing
episode_acts.summary: A private basketball coach teaches a young student some things his parents don't agree with. David Kestenbaum has the story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Unbelieving
episode_acts.summary: Cody's parents try to get him to unlearn some of what AJ taught him—and it's difficult.

fields.episode_title: I Thought It Would Be Easier
fields.episode_descript: A year into Trump’s presidency, stories of politicians—of both parties—unable to accomplish tasks that seem pretty straightforward.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira wonders aloud, when it comes to DACA, with broad support from most Americans, including the majority of Trump voters, leaders of both parties and the president himself: Why is a permanent solution so hard? Why are politics so hard? (2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Send in the Gowns
episode_acts.summary: Marshall Project reporter Julia Preston and producer Jonathan Menjivar visit an immigration court in Laredo, Texas to find out how one of Trump’s mandates—to quickly expel immigrants from the US—is going.This story was produced in collaboration with The Marshall Project where Julia is a contributing writer. Julia’s print version of the story, “Lost in Court,” is on the The Marshall Project website.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fighting Amongst Demselves
episode_acts.summary: Ben Calhoun spent months following some key leaders in the Democratic Party, to find out the party’s best strategy for the future. He got some answers.

fields.episode_descript: In this politically charged climate, it feels like you have to be super careful with your language, no matter who you are or what side you're on. Stories about people who say the “wrong” thing and suffer the consequences, including a very conservative Republican from Louisiana who's lambasted for being too liberal.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass and producer B.A. Parker talk about a disagreement they’ve been having about a particular word.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Video Killed the Video Star
episode_acts.summary: A famous YouTuber gets harassed on the internet—no surprise there. What is surprising is who winds up harassing her, and what she does about it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Trigger Warning
episode_acts.summary: A glock-toting Republican is accused by her own party of trying to take away their Second Amendment rights.

fields.episode_descript: The one thing you know for sure when you're watching a romantic comedy is that it's going to turn out okay in the end. When you're living one? Not so much. This week, stories that unfold like rom-coms.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Romantic comedies usually don’t get much respect.  Producer Neil Drumming explains what’s so great about them. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Meet Cute
episode_acts.summary: Actor Daniel Radcliffe reads a short piece of fiction, “The Present,” from Simon Rich’s book of short stories “The Last Girlfriend on Earth.” (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Obstacle
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker interviews comedian Michelle Buteau about one of her first big romantic challenges.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Run
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum retraces the steps of Steve Snyder, a man who found himself running for love.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: You Had Me at Hello
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Jillian Welsh tells Diane Wu about one of the most romantic—and stressful—nights of her life, a night that paralleled the plot of a rom-com in several ways. A version of this story first appeared on the Risk! podcast.

fields.episode_descript: Exactly how much are the animals that live in our homes caught up in our everyday family dynamics?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Heather and her girlfriend lived with a cat named Sid. The girlfriend showed all sorts of affection toward Sid that she never showed toward Heather.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Youth In Asia
episode_acts.summary: When a pet dies, to what degree can it be replaced by another? And to what degree can pets replace people in our lives? David Sedaris tells this story of cats and dogs and other animals.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Polly Wants More Than A Cracker
episode_acts.summary: Veronica Chater explains the conflict in her house between her love for her pet macaw—a kind of parrot—and her love for her husband and three kids. The macaw wreaks a sort of low-level chaos in the house, because it wants Veronica all to itself.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Resurrection
episode_acts.summary: Writer Brady Udall with another story about what animals can take the place of, in our lives and in our homes—this one involving an armadillo.

fields.episode_descript: As Harvey Weinstein goes to trial, we have a different kind of #MeToo story about several women who worked for the same man. They tell us not only about their troubling encounters with him, but also about their lives beforehand. Who were they when they entered the workplace, and how did their personal histories shape the way they dealt with his harassment?

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt fills in for Ira Glass this week. We hear from a person you don’t normally hear from in these kinds of stories — the partner of a man who has been accused of sexual harassment.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Deanna
episode_acts.summary: Growing up, Deanna is told that relationships with men won’t be easy: that men are dumb and she’ll have to make sense of things for them. Throughout her twenties, this proves true.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Dinner
episode_acts.summary: Alternet editors try to figure out what to make of Deanna’s odd behavior at an all-staff dinner. (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Onnesha
episode_acts.summary: When Onnesha asks Don for a raise, he asks her a weird question.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Cliff
episode_acts.summary: Don’s behavior grows increasingly troubling to Deanna.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Tana
episode_acts.summary: Tana is clear on how to deal with Don.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Kristen
episode_acts.summary: Kristen has no trouble naming what’s going on with Don: sexual harassment. She’s the first Alternet employee angry enough to try to do something about it.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Vivian
episode_acts.summary: We return to Vivian, Don’s partner, who reflects on how to incorporate some new information into the story of her own relationship with him.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from border walls around the world, where one place ends and another begins. And the strange ecosystems that arise.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass takes a tour to walls all around the world. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Just Another Kind of Outdoor Game
episode_acts.summary: There are two tiny Spanish towns on the African continent protected by multiple layers of razor wire, cameras and guards.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: No One Has Seen Them Made or Heard Them Made
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks with Robert Costa of The Washington Post about President Trump's promise that Mexico would build the wall.Then Brian Reed investigates a wall that may or may not exist. Brian is our senior producer and host of our podcast series S-Town.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: He Is All Pine and I Am Apple Orchard
episode_acts.summary: When writer Mariya Karimjee was a kid in Pakistan she heard about this elaborate ceremony at the border with India where soldiers on both sides performed perfectly synchronized sky-high kicks and steps. But she went to visit and it was not what she expected.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: We Keep the Wall Between Us As We Go
episode_acts.summary: Where do parents go when they’re deported? For some, the answer is: as close as possible to their kids. That often means Nogales, Mexico.

fields.episode_descript: Before he leaves the Senate for good, Republican Jeff Flake is trying to get a bill passed. He has his work cut out for him, with a Senate that barely brings anything to the floor, a party he feels estranged from, and a president who seems to hate his guts. Producer Zoe Chace hung out with him for four months.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace talks with host Ira Glass about following Senator Jeff Flake, and how when he announced his retirement she thought her reporting had ended.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Bluff
episode_acts.summary: Senator Jeff Flake tries use his newfound leverage to get a commitment to bring DACA to the Senate floor in exchange for his vote for the Republican tax bill. Things change at the last minute.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Flakes Second At Bat — Now With the President
episode_acts.summary: Senator Jeff Flake goes to the White House and discovers a president who seems to be very open to doing whatever immigration deal the senate brings him. He spends an optimistic 24 hours writing a bill with his bipartisan partners.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: When the Cat’s Away, the Mouse, He Can Run Around
episode_acts.summary: Senator Jeff Flake breaks from the plan and speaks openly about the bipartisan DACA proposal to the media before the president has a chance to sell the deal himself. Turns out, that’s not what actually kills the deal.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: It’s Our Prerogative
episode_acts.summary: The government shuts down, and Flake tries to get the senate to ignore what the White House wants. Unsuccessfully.

fields.episode_descript: It’s one thing to weigh pros and cons. But sometimes all you have is con and con. This week, stories of people having to make a choice, when no good options exist.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with two women who went to see the rodeo – the Professional Bull Riders tour – and came away wondering if they were witnessing a #MeToo moment in a very surprising place.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Borrowers
episode_acts.summary: A group of refugees who are stuck in debt, see a way out. But there’s a catch.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: We Must Destroy This Family in Order to Save It
episode_acts.summary: Eileen was desperate to help her son, and the only way to do it involved a perverse legal loophole. But should she dare try it? Shannon Heffernan tells the story. She’s a reporter at WBEZ Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Amricani
episode_acts.summary: What’s worse than being the new kid in school? Being the new kid in the country. Especially when the whole country’s tougher than you are. Sharif Youssef tells this story, which was first published on Yale Herald Audio.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people who accidentally bump into unsettling facts of history in settings meant to teach them history. What they end up learning is very different from what they’re supposed to.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks to Brian Reed about encountering an intriguing plaque in Alabama.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Miseducation of Castlemont High
episode_acts.summary: A bunch of high school students gets taken to see a movie that’s supposed to teach them about history. But they end up learning about a lot of other stuff instead.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Exit Through The Gift Shop
episode_acts.summary: The bizarre experience of being a guest in museum dedicated to the worst day of your life.

fields.episode_descript: Conservative students don't feel like their ideas are welcome on campus. So they're fighting back. We go to Nebraska, where one skirmish spins out of control.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Zoe Chace goes to a conference hosted by Turning Point USA, where college students get trained to fight political battles.

episode_acts.name: Round One: The Brawl on the Mall
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Steve Kolowich goes to the University of Nebraska where one new recruit to Turning Point goes out on campus to sign people up for her club. And that one act immediately devolves into a political battle of epic proportions.

episode_acts.name: Round Two: The Fiasca in Nebraska
episode_acts.summary: The brawl on the mall of the University of Nebraska turns into a fiasco at the state capitol, as legislators try to step in and dictate what should happen at the university. (16 1/2 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Cryptic messages on a cell phone and a teeter totter at a construction site: these are clues people found, trying to make sense of a death.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to a guy about a crazy experiment he devised when he was a kid. It almost killed him.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dear Dealer
episode_acts.summary: We begin with a woman whose sister has died. She has questions.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Commento Mori
episode_acts.summary: There’s a problem with having a Facebook account after you’re dead that you’ve never, ever, ever thought about. Producer Stephanie Foo tells this story, about Dave Maher.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Funeral for a Stranger
episode_acts.summary: A guy goes to a funeral for someone he doesn’t know at all, and has to piece together everything about him.

fields.episode_descript: A security guard at the airport notices something going wrong on the tarmac, and takes it upon herself to fix it. It’s way harder than she expects.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: LaDonna Powell starts her new job out on the tarmac at the airport.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Old Guard
episode_acts.summary: LaDonna sets out to understand how this place is run.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The New Guard
episode_acts.summary: LaDonna sets out to transform the way this place is run.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about people trying to learn something when no one is clear what the lesson is supposed to be.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass and Kelefa Sanneh talk about Starbucks’ racial bias training program, which Kalefa recently discussed with Howard Schultz.

episode_acts.name: Act One: All the Caffeine in the World Doesn’t Make You Woke
episode_acts.summary: Kelefa Sanneh sits in on one of Starbucks’ anti-racial bias classes. There’s one thing that no one seems to want to talk about.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Throw the Book at Them
episode_acts.summary: A group of kids is told that “education is the door to their futures.” But these kids are in jail, facing adult sentences. Why learn algebra when you’re facing 25 years? Eli Hager reports.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Those Who Can’t Play
episode_acts.summary: Daniel Alarcón’s dad was obsessed with soccer when he was growing up, but he was only average at soccer. But those who can’t do...find something else to do.

fields.episode_title: It's My Party and I'll Try If I Want To
fields.episode_descript: Democrats are desperate to retake part of Congress. Their best shot is the House. This fall, they’ll be slugging it out with Republicans—but in the meantime, they’re slugging it out with each other. The progressive and moderate wings of the Democratic party are going head-to-head in Democratic primaries all over the country right now, wrestling over what the party should be and stand for. This week, we have the story of a candidate in one primary like that.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Ben Calhoun about how Democrats are furiously trying to retake New York’s 19th congressional district. The sitting Republican is considered very vulnerable, and has been the subject of weekly protests that even have a house band.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: When Jeff Beals learned who was going to run in the Democratic primary for NY-19, he was disappointed. Beals, a progressive, thought the Democrats jumping in were conventional candidates, ones who embodied what he thinks is a failed strategy for his party: raising lots of money from big donors and lobbyists, and buying TV ads.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Beals is running against six other candidates, many of whom say they, too, are progressive. Beals disagrees.

fields.episode_title: Change You Can Maybe Believe In
fields.episode_descript: An innocent man forgives the cop who framed him. An Argentinian talk show that usually treats women as objects suddenly gets really interested in feminism. This week, stories about changes that seem too tidy to be true.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A lawyer tries to help a father separated from his 12-year-old daughter at the border.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The All-Too-Real Housewives of Argentina
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Jasmine Garsd grew up in Argentina watching talk shows, which were kind of extreme even for Latin American television. The women on screen were pumped with silicone and Botox, and sometimes showed up wearing almost nothing.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Have the Right to Remain Angry
episode_acts.summary: The TV news stories told it as heartwarming tale of reconciliation from small-town America: a black man who was framed by a white cop decides to forgive him. But those stories left out a few things. Producer Lilly Sullivan looked into it.

fields.episode_title: If You Build It, Will They Come?
fields.episode_descript: A young preacher opens a new church. A new restaurant reopens old wounds. This week, stories of people trying to build something that will last.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Eric Mennel introduces Host Ira Glass to church planters, a group of evangelical Christians who apply the lessons of Silicon Valley to their goals of building new churches and growing their flock. (9 ½ minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Come All Ye Faithless
episode_acts.summary: Eric Mennel tells the story of one church planter, Watson Jones, who sets out on his mission to build a new church in a very challenging setting.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Hole in the Wall
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming has steadfastly avoided one bar in his neighborhood because of the controversy that surrounds it—until recently, when he noticed that lots of people he didn’t expect to go there were becoming regulars.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: An Awful Place That You’re Lucky To Get To
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass reads a favorite passage from the writing of the recently deceased poet Donald Hall.

fields.episode_descript: Dispatches from a government agency in its tumultuous teenage years.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Congressman Mark Pocan and Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal about a bold bill they sponsored last week.

episode_acts.name: Act One: We'll Talk About It in the Car
episode_acts.summary: Anita was separated from her son at the border a month ago. Jeremy Raff and Nadia Reiman follow her as she tries to get him back.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Iceman Cometh
episode_acts.summary: Miki Meek tells the story of an unlikely alliance between an ICE agent and a group of undocumented immigrants. (34 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Every crime scene hides a story. In this week's show, we hear about crime scenes and the stories they tell.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Medical Examiner D.J. Drakovic, in Pontiac Michigan, explains how every crime scene is like a novel.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Grime Scene
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Nancy Updike spends two days with Neal Smither, who cleans up crime scenes for a living, and comes away wanting to open his Los Angeles franchise, despite the gore — or maybe because of it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: What Police Cannot Do
episode_acts.summary: Actor Matt Malloy reads a short story by Aimee Bender, from her book “The Girl in the Flammable Skirt," about what can be and cannot be recovered from a crime scene, or from anywhere.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Criminal Returns to the Scene of the Crime
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes criminals return to the scene of their misdeeds — to try to make things right, to try to undo the past. Katie Davis reports on her neighbor Bobby, who returned to the scene where he robbed people and conned people. This time, he came to coach little league.

fields.episode_descript: A flute player breaks into a British museum and makes off with a million dollars worth of dead birds.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: After hearing about the heist, Kirk Wallace Johnson gets sucked into the feather underground. He ends up discovering things that the people in charge of the theft investigation didn’t.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Specimens
episode_acts.summary: The birds Edwin Rist stole were valuable and collected in the mid-1800s by one of the greatest scientific explorers of his time: a man named Alfred Russel Wallace.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Flautist
episode_acts.summary: Edwin's life in a rarified world of flutes and feathers.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Museum
episode_acts.summary: Edwin visits a branch of Britain's Natural History Museum in a little town called Tring.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Heist
episode_acts.summary: The detective on the case takes Kirk to the crime scene.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Investigation
episode_acts.summary: The police track Edwin down after a fly-tier turns in a tip.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: The Suspect
episode_acts.summary: Kirk wonders if Edwin has a sidekick who helped him the night of the Tring heist.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Oslo
episode_acts.summary: In Norway, Kirk tracks down fugitive feathers.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when unadventurous people end up in adventurous situations. Like an astronaut who goes to places no one has gone before, even though he’s not really into outer space.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Diane Wu tells Ira the story of a woman and her quest to find out who sent her a mysterious gift.

episode_acts.name: Act One: So Over The Moon
episode_acts.summary: Producer David Kestenbaum tells the story of an astronaut who returns with a very unexpected view of the great beyond.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Traveling Violation
episode_acts.summary: One of Jared’s oldest friends is about to embark on a trip he may not be able to return home from.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Fly On the Call
episode_acts.summary: A man tries something he’s never done before and discovers a new passion. A work of short fiction written by Neil Drumming and read by actor Dorian Missick.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: We end our show with a true story in the form of a song — “Rabies," by the rapper Aesop Rock. A few years ago he moved into the country, into an actual barn, to make music.

fields.episode_descript: Yes, youʼve heard about the family separations. Youʼve heard about the travel ban. But there are dozens of ways the Trump administration is cracking down on immigration across many agencies, sometimes in ways so small and technical it doesnʼt make headlines. This week, the quiet bureaucratic war that’s even targeting legal immigrants.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to Tijuana, Mexico where people trying to come to the U.S. asking for asylum have devised a new way to keep track of their place in line.  (11 minutes)Cindy Carcamo first wrote about this story for the Los Angeles Times.

episode_acts.name: Act One: All Together Now
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Julia Preston goes to a mass hearing in McAllen, Texas where 74 immigrants are being charged in a federal courtroom as a result of zero tolerance. Julia is a contributing writer for The Marshall Project, which published a print version of this story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Kitchen Sink
episode_acts.summary: All the little and not-so-little ways the Trump administration is tightening its scrutiny of immigrants.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Terminators
episode_acts.summary: A bunch of government emails recently came out as part of a class-action lawsuit. The emails show new appointees trying to roll back one particular part of immigration policy that could result in half a million people having to leave the United States.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Now IRC Me, Now You Don’t
episode_acts.summary: The President has cut the number of refugees officially allowed into the U.S. So a bunch of refugee resettlement offices are shutting down.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Why So Few

fields.episode_descript: A bunch of teenagers go missing from a town in Long Island. For months, the police treat them as runaways, ignoring the kids' parents, who keep trying to tell them otherwise. They keep trying to tell them that something much worse might have happened.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira takes us through a couple of occasions in which President Trump has evoked the brutal street gang MS-13. The President has lauded local law enforcement on Long Island on its efforts to stop the gang.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Hannah Dreier with ProPublica spent a year reporting in Brentwood, Long Island where three teenagers mysteriously disappeared. All three were considered runaways by the Suffolk County Police.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Hannah Dreier’s story continues. She confronts former Suffolk County Police Commissioner Timothy Sini with her findings.

fields.episode_descript: Making big decisions about other people's lives can feel pretty awful. Zoe Chace followed Senator Jeff Flake as he decided to force the Senate to delay its vote on Judge Kavanaugh. Among her discoveries: Those protestors in the elevator? They aren’t the reason he did what he did.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass on the weird news vortex of the past week. (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Judge
episode_acts.summary: Zoe Chace gives us a peek at what Senator Jeff Flake was up to in the days before and after deciding to delay Judge Kavanaugh's confirmation vote.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Jury
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein talks to Sven Berger, a juror still hung up over an assignment he served ten years ago. Jonathan is the host of Heavyweight from Gimlet Media, which just began its third season.

fields.episode_descript: There’s no rulebook on how to handle a school shooting. And no real way to prepare for one. This week, people take what they’ve learned from these tragedies and try to use that knowledge to save others.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A school in rural Ohio has decided to arm some of its staff, and is practicing how to use the school's new guns in case of an emergency. Reporter Lisa Pollak talks to Ira about how they came to the decision, and what they learned at that training.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Ready As You’ll Never Be
episode_acts.summary: Marjory Stoneman Douglas had just completed a schoolwide upgrade on their emergency plans, just a month before the mass shooting at their school. Producer Robyn Semien talks to two teachers at the school about how that training both benefited them, and didn’t.

episode_acts.name: Act Two:  Keep Breathing
episode_acts.summary: Since losing their daughter in the Aurora, Colorado shooting, Sandy and Lonnie Phillips have gone to the locations of many mass shootings. They know lots about the challenges grieving families face, and have information only people who have lost someone to a shooting can know.

fields.episode_descript: People who tell a lie and then believe the lie more than anyone else.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole explains why he decided that he would speak with a British accent—morning, noon and night—from the age of fourteen until he was sixteen, and how he believed the lie that he was British must be true.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Sun Never Sets—On The Moosewood Restaurant
episode_acts.summary: The story of two young people who, in their search to figure out who they were, pretended to be people they weren't. Both were from small towns; both took on false identities.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Conning The Con Men
episode_acts.summary: The story of a con man, one of the most successful salesmen in a long-running multimillion-dollar telemarketing scam, who finally got caught when he was conned himself. Producer Nancy Updike talks about the case with Dale Sekovich, Federal Trade Commission investigator.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Oedipus Hex
episode_acts.summary: Shalom Auslander reads his true story, "The Blessing Bee." It's about the time when, as a third-grader at an Orthodox Jewish school, Shalom saw his chance to both make his mom proud, and push his drunken father out of the picture. Part of his scheme involved winning the school's bee on the complicated Hebrew blessings you say before eating certain foods.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of women in unsettling situations. When they try to explain what’s wrong, they’re told that they don’t understand—that there’s nothing unsettling about it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks with producer Lilly Sullivan about a story she heard growing up about men messing with a girl’s mind. Lilly can relate. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Old Man on My Shoulder
episode_acts.summary: From the ages of 12 to 27, our producer Elna Baker was supposed to confess to male clergy anytime she did anything sexual. It was so routine for her that she barely thought to talk about it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: While You Were Out
episode_acts.summary: A doctor tries to investigate something that horrifies her, but people tell her it’s not worth thinking about. It’s the way it’s done.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who believe there is always a way. And also those who don’t.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Etgar Keret tells the story of how his mother convinced an army general to send her son home for a day in the middle of a war.

episode_acts.name: Act One: When Cooperation Doesn’t Get You What You Want
episode_acts.summary: As a teenager he saw himself as an historical figure, then that ended up becoming true. Producer Zoe Chace tells the story of Newt Gingrich, the man who either reinvented politics or broke it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Life Is a Coin With One Side
episode_acts.summary: Producer David Kestenbaum took issue with the entire premise of today’s show, and explains why.

fields.episode_descript: Documents you don't normally think of, showing you things you didn't expect.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass finds the men behind a bot, whose job was to generate random inspirational quotes and images. But the bot ended up making something more surprising.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Veritas Is Out There
episode_acts.summary: There’s a lawsuit going on between Harvard and some Asian American students who say the admissions process discriminates against them.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Know That You Are Unprecedentedly Negative
episode_acts.summary: When health care premiums went up in New York State, a bunch of people got mad and wrote letters to the state.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bladen Runner
episode_acts.summary: What one professor saw in voter registrations that others didn’t.

fields.episode_descript: Libraries aren't just for books. They're often spaces that transform into what you need them to be: a classroom, a cyber café, a place to find answers, a quiet spot to be alone. It's actually kind of magical. This week, we have stories of people who roam the stacks and find unexpected things that just happen to be exactly what they required.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: One Monday earlier this month, we sent five producers to record what happened at library reference desks around the country.

episode_acts.name: Act One: In Praise of Limbo
episode_acts.summary: There is a library that's on the border of Canada and the United States — literally on the border, with part of the library in each country. Producer Zoe Chace interviews journalist Yeganeh Torbati about how lately, it's become a critical space for a surprising set of visitors.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Book Fishing In America
episode_acts.summary: In Richard Brautigan's novel "The Abortion," he imagines a library where regular people can come and drop off their own unpublished books. Nothing is turned away.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Growing Shelf-Awareness
episode_acts.summary: Lydia Sigwarth spent a lot of time in her public library growing up – all day, almost every day, for six months straight. Producer Stephanie Foo returned to that library with her, after years away.

fields.episode_descript: We revisit those moments of calm before the storm, when things could have gone very differently, but instead, they went to hell.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass gets his grandmother Frieda’s college files, which reveal a whole other side of this person he thought he knew so well.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Where Have You Gone, Barbara Jordan? Our Nation Turns Its Lonely Eyes to You
episode_acts.summary: Back in the 1990s, a bipartisan team led by the charismatic Barbara Jordan came up with a solution to the immigration debate that would have fixed a lot the things we’re arguing about today.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Director’s Cut
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Will Weldon’s ex-wife made a movie loosely based on their marriage.  Producer Elna Baker watches the film with Will as he revisits his break-up.

fields.episode_title: The Theme That Shall Not Be Named
fields.episode_descript: Satan! In his many surprising manifestations, all around us.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays recordings from the Satanic Prayer Line, and speaks to the line’s creator, Chris Allert.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Record Deal with the Devil
episode_acts.summary: New Yorker staff writer Kelefa Sanneh tells the story of exorcist Bob Larson’s trip into the world of heavy metal.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Details of the Devil
episode_acts.summary: Religion professor Elaine Pagels explains the roots and evolution of Satan in religious texts.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Devil You Know
episode_acts.summary: Writer Gary Shteyngart presents a fictional diary of two Russian men — and a story of the special malevolence that can grow from an intimate situation. A portion of the story is read by actor Josh Gad.

fields.episode_descript: Intimate and personal dispatches from two very different battlefields: A small town in the Syrian war. And the U.S. opioid epidemic. Each came from a DIY radio outfit. (Okay, one’s a podcast.)

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the story of Dave, a former heroin addict who, with his friend Chris, launches a podcast inspired by the Howard Stern Show. Except it’s all about heavy drug use.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Two Dope Kings
episode_acts.summary: Producer Dana Chivvis picks up the story of Dave and Chris and their show “Dopey.” (27 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Good Morning, Kafranbel
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Dana Ballout tells the story of Radio Fresh, a community station in Syria that the local listeners depend on, and local militant factions try to shut down.

fields.episode_descript: People tossing words out into the world impulsively, to ignite and burn over decades.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays a strange voicemail left by a 96-year-old surgeon about a letter that was written five decades ago. (6 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Humor Is Not The Best Medicine
episode_acts.summary: Producer Lilly Sullivan reports out that voicemail. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Babies Got Bank
episode_acts.summary: On his deathbed, a wealthy man in Toronto decides to make some trouble. Hundreds of babies are involved. Stephanie Foo tells the story.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Meatball and Chain
episode_acts.summary: Cyclist Mike Friedman said something to cyclist Ian Dille in the middle of a race that ate at both of them for years. Jared Marcelle tells the story.

fields.episode_title: Scrambling to Get Off the Ice
fields.episode_descript: The Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee may have to fight to protect Mueller's investigation and make his report public. Now that they’re in the majority, they have new tools they can use. Our producer Zoe Chace spent weeks behind the scenes with them as they tried out their new powers for the first time. This and other stories of people scrambling to get their footing on some challenging terrain.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Mike Wise tells Ira about a run he went on one winter night with his dog, years ago along the C&O Canal in DC. It was late.

episode_acts.name: Act One: New Sheriffs in Town
episode_acts.summary: Jerry Nadler and other democrats in the House Judiciary Committee were anticipating their first major public appearance – and show of power – since winning back the house in November. As Nadler and his staff prepared to get some answers from then-acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker about his role and conduct as interim AG, producer Zoe Chace follows them behind the scenes for weeks in the run-up to the hearing, to see if their strategies work, or don’t.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Going Under
episode_acts.summary: When Jessica Hopper was inappropriately groped by an anesthesiologist, during labor, she tries to out him that same day, to a roomful of hospital staff who don’t believe her. That sets her on a many year mission to get someone to take up her cause.

fields.episode_descript: Stories from the upside-down world where conspiracy theorists dwell.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells the story of a guy, Lenny Pozner, who strikes up a conversation with a stranger in a bar, only to learn the guy already knows who Lenny is. And the stranger is furious with him.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Down the Rabbit Hole
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek picks up the story of Lenny Pozner, whose son, Noah, was killed at Sandy Hook. In the years after Noah's death, Lenny and his family were harassed by people who believed the shooting at Sandy Hook never happened – that it was all a conspiracy.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Alex in Wonderland
episode_acts.summary: Alex Jones spread the idea that Sandy Hook was a hoax, on his radio show and website for years after the shooting. He's probably the country's most famous conspiracy theorist. He's even had Donald Trump on his show.

fields.episode_descript: People connecting the dots that maybe should not be connected.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to producer Zoe Chace about what she learned about the President and conspiracy theories at a Trump rally.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Show Me State of Mind
episode_acts.summary: Writer Jelani Cobb travels to Missouri to talk to people in Ferguson about the troubling deaths of six activists there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Red Menace Hits the Crimson Tide
episode_acts.summary: A Democrat in Alabama watches helplessly as Russian internet bots play dirty with the 2016 election. But a year later, those same tactics inspire him to organize an election conspiracy of his own. Producer Ben Calhoun has the story.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of very small injustices and also one very big one.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer David Kestenbaum explains how teachers at his sons’ preschool installed a “tattle phone” where kids could register their complaints about each other. David rigged it up to record those complaints and document the unfairnesses of preschool.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hoop Reams
episode_acts.summary: Writer Michael Lewis takes us inside the world of NBA refereeing. He explains how protests about unfair calls have increased in recent years.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Fairer Sex
episode_acts.summary: When Heidi Schreck was 15 years old she loved the United States Constitution — in part, because she believed it enshrined the idea of fairness. She traveled to American Legion posts across the country, where she competed in speaking competitions about the Constitution.

fields.episode_descript: People figuring out how to move through a world in which something important has disappeared.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Eleven adult siblings need to divide their dead parents' stuff. But they don’t all get along.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Sudden Departure
episode_acts.summary: When a small town loses 100 people in just a few hours, kids come home to find their parents missing. Producer Lilly Sullivan talks to people trying to make sense of where they went and if they’ll come back.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Passed Over
episode_acts.summary: With flames moving in from all sides during the Northern California fire, an entire town flees—except for four friends who’ve lived there since childhood. Producer Nancy Updike on what they do next.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Book of Death Is Long and Boring
episode_acts.summary: Where do we go when we die? Producer David Kestenbaum learns that the answer's pretty bureaucratic.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people standing up for themselves, shaking off their fear, bracing themselves, and doing what they’ve been scared to do.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira goes to a crowded singles bar where it wasn’t hard to find serial ghosters — people who kiss and disappear.  (8 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Finally
episode_acts.summary: We start with someone getting up the nerve to do something that really, it would be nice to see more often — an apology. And not just any apology.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: A Brief Catalogue of Spines Recently Grown
episode_acts.summary: We put out a call looking for people having to face something that freaked them out. Over two hundred people wrote in, facing big, life-changing moments, and some smaller ones.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Because You’re Spine, I Walk the Line
episode_acts.summary: We turn to those who are truly spineless, and I mean literally, they are creatures that have no spines. Also featured in this story: the people who study them who, like us all, could sometimes use a little more spine.

fields.episode_descript: What it's like to be momentarily big on the small screen.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira follows Yankee Stadium cameraman Eric Capstick as he puts fans on the Jumbotron. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Anything You Say Can And Will Be Used...on Television
episode_acts.summary: Dan Taberski takes us into the world of the TV shows Cops and Live PD. And talks to people about what it’s like to be caught by the police and caught on camera at the same time.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Born to Play the Part
episode_acts.summary: One of our producers Bim Adewunmi explains her obsession with a certain baby on television.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lina with an N
episode_acts.summary: Producer Lina Misitzis revisits a moment in a TV special that’s stuck with her for over twenty years.

fields.episode_descript: Adults telling kids who they are, and kids wondering — are they right?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira talks with comedian Gary Gulman about his transformation from high school nobody to football star.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Jersey? Sure.
episode_acts.summary: Gary puts on a tough guy costume, but will it turn him into a tough guy? Ira continues Gary Gulman’s story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Grownups Know Things
episode_acts.summary: Eleanor Gordon-Smith tells the story of a woman who wants to know why she was taken away from her mom as a kid. A version of this story is in Eleanor’s book Stop Being Reasonable: How We Really Change Our Minds.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of those unexpected moments when we see who we really are.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole guest hosts. He was attacked in the street and happens to have a recording of the moment right afterwards.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You Don’t Have to Be a Star to Be in My Show
episode_acts.summary: Zack McDermott was a lawyer who moonlighted as a comedian.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Distant Replay
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emanuele Berry and her dad only talked about basketball. But they never talked about a game that her dad had botched.

fields.episode_descript: This country is crawling in presidential candidates right now and they're bumping into each other in Des Moines and yelling over each other in Miami. We hang out with them, in this weird early period of the election when they're easy to walk right up to.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace drives around with Washington Post political reporter extraordinaire Dave Weigel. He delights in this special period in the race where it’s easy to trip over people running for president.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Wannabes One
episode_acts.summary: Weigel and Zoe drop in on two candidates desperately trying to break out of the one percent.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Wannabes Two
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass follows presidential hopeful Julián Castro as he prepares for the first debate of the Democratic primary. His goal is just to let people know he’s in the race! By, possibly, interrupting somebody onstage.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Wannabes Three
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emanuele Berry plays Ira Glass some weird inside his head tape of presidential hopeful Cory Booker trying to walk two blocks.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Wannabes Four
episode_acts.summary: Producer Ben Calhoun gets on the road with presidential hopeful Andrew Yang as he bestows free money on an Iowa family to make a point.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Wannabes Five
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace and Washington Post reporter Dave Weigel spin through some greatest hits of their weekend in Iowa once more, and Weigel reflects on what’s about to come next in the presidential race.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Wannabes Six
episode_acts.summary: Producer David Kestenbaum drops in on some Republicans who are still trying to field a candidate to challenge this president.

fields.episode_descript: People go on missions to save young girls from danger. But sometimes they get so caught up in the mission that it overshadows the girl herself.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Lina Misitzis tells Ira Glass about this one video game character from the 90s who consistently brings men to tears.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Very Unhappy Birthday
episode_acts.summary: Nadia Reiman looks into the case of a girl the U.S. government is determined to save, even though she doesn’t want them to.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Frida Be You and Me
episode_acts.summary: A whole country gets obsessed with rescuing a missing girl. Aviva DeKornfeld tells what happens.

fields.episode_descript: Words mean things, but some words are especially meaningful — whether in a survival manual, a song lyric, or a slur.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: What does God get out of us praising him? Or is it actually for us? (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Go To The Mattresses
episode_acts.summary: Shamyla always loved books. Like lots of other eleven-year-olds back in 1989, she loved The Babysitters Club.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Daddy Lessons
episode_acts.summary: Parents try to shape who we are in their own image. Producer Neil Drumming spoke to Adam Mansbach, who tried to make his daughter fall in love with hip-hop.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Where I Came From
episode_acts.summary: Producer Ben Calhoun recalls a weighty moment from childhood and thinks about how the words from that encounter have come up again.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when our most ingenious creations actually make it out into the world.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira questions the motives of overly ambitious scientists and inventors. (2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Breakout Star
episode_acts.summary: A reality show contestant tries to game the system. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Two Times a Lady
episode_acts.summary: An inventor designs a robotic device that creates a dilemma for the administrators and judges of a major electronics trade show.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Fraught Couture
episode_acts.summary: A government agent steals a suit that’s supposed to make her invisible. It does more than that.

fields.episode_descript: What if someone told you about a type of therapy that could help you work through unhealed trauma in just ten sessions? Some people knock through it in two weeks. Jaime Lowe tried the therapy—and recorded it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells us about a short-term therapy for trauma called CPT. Cognitive processing therapy was designed for survivors of sexual assault and is also used for veterans with PTSD symptoms.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Week One
episode_acts.summary: Jaime Lowe begins CPT.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Week Two
episode_acts.summary: After a difficult first week in therapy, Jaime starts to see progress. (21 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Two people, sitting down over a beer, hashing out their differences and understanding where the other guy is coming from. Hard to imagine these days, right? It's so rare right now that someone is curious enough to actually see the other person's point of view. This week on the show, beer summits. Including going behind the scenes of the most famous one ever.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and producer Robyn Semien go behind the scenes with some of the Obama staffers to hear what it felt like in the days leading up to the infamous Beer Summit of 2009.

episode_acts.name: Act One: One More For My Baby and One More For the Road
