episode_acts.summary: Maybe the most radical national experiment to avoid tribalism ever done, anywhere in the world. Of course the key moment two sides come together happens in a bar.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Lagerheads
episode_acts.summary: A Democratic club at a bar in South Bend, Indiana, melts down over President Trump, and producer Ben Calhoun is there to see who’s still left in the club at the end of the night.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who decide the only way forward — for real change — is to burn everything to the ground.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: The Amsterdam Fire Department has a very surprising sensitivity training video called “The Incident with the Helmet." (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Policeman Burns Down the Firehouse
episode_acts.summary: A strongman gets hired to take over the Amsterdam Fire Department. He’s a career police officer named Leen Schaap who has zero firefighting experience.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mom. Hey Mom. MOM. Hey Mom. Mom. Mom
episode_acts.summary: A teenage girl decides the only way forward is to tear something down and rebuild from the ground up. Elna Baker explains.

fields.episode_descript: The staff goes to one of the biggest parties in New York City, the Labor Day Carnival and the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Neil Drumming wonders what it would be like to know exactly where he’s from.

episode_acts.name: Act 1: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Writer and poet Imani Brown takes us through her experience at the parade that takes place in the early hours before the parade.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Producers Marlon Bishop and Nadia Reiman go inside a heated steel pan competition and meet a mother and daughter who could be competing together for the last time.

episode_acts.name: Act 3: Act Three
episode_acts.summary: Our regular host Ira Glass talks to some Hasidic Jews who also live in the neighborhood to get a different take on the parade.  (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 4: Act Four
episode_acts.summary: One of New York’s biggest and most successful masquerade bands goes down the parade route for the last time.

fields.episode_descript: For over 100 days now, protestors in Hong Kong have taken to the streets every weekend. What it’s like to live through that.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A 22-year-old woman has been going to protest in Hong Kong for more than four months. She’s got packing her bag for a protest down to a science.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Cursed Generation
episode_acts.summary: A bunch of 22-year-olds from Hong Kong explain why they are cursed and what that means for their and Hong Kong’s future. (17 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Fight
episode_acts.summary: Ira and Emanuele go to a protest and get tear gassed in front of a Ruth's Chris Steakhouse. (6 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Uncivil Disobedience
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emanuele Berry has a day at the mall unlike any other. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Good Cop, Dad Cop
episode_acts.summary: A protestor who thinks the Hong Kong police are terrible has a chat with his dad — a police officer.  Alan Yu reports. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Five: A Slow Boat to China
episode_acts.summary: Producer Diane Wu goes to a party.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Two Weeks Later
episode_acts.summary: The 22-year-old woman from the beginning of the show catches up with producer Diane Wu. Things are different.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about being little. Secret writings in tiny letters. The power of a very small number. And a medication that's supposed to cure shortness.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about our fascination with small things.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Coming Up Short
episode_acts.summary: An endocrinologist wrote the show about a wave of parents coming to her to treat their short (but otherwise healthy) children with human growth hormone. Contributor Scott Brown investigates.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Let’s Give ‘Em Nothing to Talk About
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum talks about his love of the number zero and its power to destroy. Among zero's victims: one of the most controversial laws in recent memory.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: What the Eye Can’t See
episode_acts.summary: Lilly Sullivan tells the story of the writer Robert Walser, who moved into a mental hospital and then seemed to disappear from the world. Until people looked more closely.

fields.episode_descript: Reports from the frontlines of the Trump administration's "Remain in Mexico" asylum policy. We hear from asylum seekers waiting across the border in Mexico, in a makeshift refugee camp,  and from the officers who sent them there to wait in the first place.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass and Aviva DeKornfeld visits refugee camps we don’t call refugee camps—right on our country’s doorstep.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Goodbye, Stranger
episode_acts.summary: Los Angeles Times reporter Molly O’Toole talks to U.S. asylum officers—the people who end up sending migrants back to Mexico. And they don’t feel good about it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Take the Long Way Home
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Emily Green happens to meet a man being sent back to Mexico who tells her he’s afraid of being kidnapped—and then, he gets kidnapped.

fields.episode_descript: There's a lot that can be gained from unearthing the past -- learning about oneself, learning about others. But, it doesn't always go how you'd expect.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira talks with producer Emanuele Berry about the man who tried to find one of history’s — and literature’s — most storied cities.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Family Plot
episode_acts.summary: Producer Lina Misitzis travels to Greece with her family to exhume the bones of her dead grandmother. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Next of Kindle
episode_acts.summary: After his mother passes, a man unearths her book collection… and is surprised. (6 1/2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: A Curious Bone
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum tells the story of a man on the verge of one of the greatest scientific discoveries of all time … right on the verge. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Revision Quest
episode_acts.summary: In her forties, Jill Ciment wrote about the love of her life.

fields.episode_descript: For the holidays, stories of families finally addressing the thorny thing they’ve never really talked about.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira remembers the contentious family gatherings of holidays past - and how things have changed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How Do I Say This?
episode_acts.summary: Scaachi Koul is trying to learn a language native to her parents, and heads back to Calgary to ask why they never taught it to her in the first place.  (21 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Probably Think This Song is About You
episode_acts.summary: Singer-songwriter Loudon Wainwright III asked his ex-partner Suzzy Roche and their daughter Lucy to perform at his wedding party.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Pigeons on a Plane
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Kevin Sieff travels from Mexico to Chicago with a group of seniors reuiniting with their undocumented kids in the U.S., some for the first time in decades. (18 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Other universes that are just like our own, but with one small difference.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with David Kestenbaum about a phone app that can create alternate universes with the press of a button.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dreams From My Father
episode_acts.summary: Writer Etgar Keret tells a story about his father, who was constantly imagining parallel universes. In a way, they saved him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sorry/Not Sorry
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum finds out about a speech that, in another world, President Clinton gave on August 17, 1998.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Sklar-Crossed Brothers
episode_acts.summary: Being an identical twin is kind of like having a parallel world right on top of ours, one in which there is another version of you running around. Dana Chivvis has the story of the Sklar twins, and a 48-year-old mystery.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: If I Lived Here, I’d Be Home Now
episode_acts.summary: Diane Wu has the story of a woman who goes to South Korea to meet her birth mother, a trip that lets her visit one of the other worlds in which she almost lived.

fields.episode_descript: In these dark, combative times, we attempt the most radical counterprogramming we could imagine: a show made up entirely of stories about delight.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks to Bim Adewunmi about her understanding of delight through American pop culture and the summer she spent in the US as a 19-year-old.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Job Of Delight
episode_acts.summary: Bim talks to poet Ross Gay, whose book inspired today’s show, about the discipline and rigor of seeking and holding onto delight.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Squeals On The Bus
episode_acts.summary: Producer Robyn Semien captures a special morning for her five-year-old son, Cole, who is doing something delightful for the very first time: he’s getting to ride the school bus.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mrs. Meek Shall Inherit The Earth
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek speaks to Noriko Meek, her 72-year-old mother, about discovering delight late in life.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Elephant In The Bedroom
episode_acts.summary: Producer Dana Chivvis follows the night zookeeper at the Denver Zoo as she doles out snacks and tucks the animals in.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Delight At The End Of The Tunnel
episode_acts.summary: What happens when a dealer of delight gets depressed? Podcast host Tracy Clayton talks to Bim Adewunmi about the road back. (17 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: We return to our story about Abdi Nor from 2015, with some big news about his life today. When we first broadcast the story, Abdi was a Somali refugee living in Kenya desperately trying – against long odds – to get to the United States. Then he got the luckiest break of his life: he won a lottery that puts him on a short list for a U.S. visa. But before he could cash in his golden ticket, the police started raiding his neighborhood, targeting refugees.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Three weeks ago, Abdi Nor became a U.S. citizen, in a ceremony in Maine. We go to the ceremony, and then head back in time to 2013, when he won a visa under the Diversity Visa Lottery.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: It turns out winning the lottery is only the first step in trying to come to America. More than half of the people who win each year never make it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Leo Hornak's story about Abdi continues. Abdi encounters one obstacle after another on the streets of Nairobi.

fields.episode_title: Get Back to Where You Once Belonged
fields.episode_descript: People looking everywhere to find a place—any place—where, for once, they don't have to be the odd man out.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Emanuele Berry and Ira Glass watch a Soviet film from 1936. A bizarre cameo of an African American baby in an all-white crowd makes Emanuele wonder about what it’s like to be Black in a country with so few Black people.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Black in the USSR
episode_acts.summary: Yelena Khanga grew up in Russia knowing almost no other Black people. Emanuele Berry asks Yelena what that was like.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Nowhere Man
episode_acts.summary: Raul felt like he had found his spot in the world: a job he was good at, a group of people he liked and admired. And then he got kicked out.

fields.episode_descript: People squirming in a world where everything is rated and reviewed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with writer Michael Schulman about a book he wrote.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Their Eyes Weren’t Watching God
episode_acts.summary: On a friend’s recommendation, B.A. Parker decides to try attending First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mr. Chen Goes to Wuhan
episode_acts.summary: An average Chinese citizen decides to go to Wuhan, the heart of the coronavirus epidemic, to see for himself what’s happening there.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Must Love Cats
episode_acts.summary: Lina Misitzis talks to the one person in America who loves the movie everyone else in America loves to hate. (11 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Things do not seem fine at all, but it’s hard to say why.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to people as they prepare for the coronavirus but don’t know exactly what to expect yet.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Do You Hear What I Hear?
episode_acts.summary: Khristen, a single mom, decides to secretly record her home inspector to catch him sexually harassing her. Eight years later, reporter Jessica Lussenhop checks in with Khristen to talk about what the recording meant back then versus now.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Reality Show
episode_acts.summary: FBI agents question NSA contractor Reality Winner, who was later charged with leaking evidence of Russian interference in U.S. elections. Even the most casual small talk takes on an air of menace. (18 minutes)This is an excerpt from Is This A Room, a play based on the real FBI interrogation transcript.

fields.episode_descript: This week, as the staff creates the episode from their apartments and houses, with our host in quarantine, in this moment when everyone’s reaching out to the people they love, we put together a collection of family stories, with some timely stuff at the top.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass gives an update on his health status after going into quarantine last week, and David Kestenbaum interviews a 71 year old trying to avoid the virus.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hey Dad. Dad!
episode_acts.summary: Stephanie Foo talks to a father trying to go about his day while his daughter comes to him over and over, with some things on her mind.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Call Me Maybe
episode_acts.summary: A mom checking in on her son. A son figuring out who he can talk to about his mom.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Mom
episode_acts.summary: Ira calls up his mother Shirley Glass after unexpectedly finding her quoted as a “sexpert” in Marie Claire magazine, back in 1996. One of the first stories we did on our show.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: It Takes a Villa
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming tells the story of his dad and his family’s timeshare in Orlando, Florida.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Let’s Talk Radio
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to his dad about a job he had before Ira was born.

fields.episode_descript: The coronavirus has now fully arrived in the United States. This week, stories of people trying to rise to that challenge, in some pretty extreme situations.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: People want to do the right thing, but it’s not always possible.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Inside Game
episode_acts.summary: What it’s like inside a small New York apartment with a toddler and two parents who are very sick with COVID-19. Producer Ben Calhoun talks to his brother-in-law, Elia Einhorn.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A View from the Park
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emanuele Berry talks to Jiayang Fan about how Jiayang’s trying to protect her mother, who she worries about as the virus spreads across New York City.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Outbreak Breakout
episode_acts.summary: Across the country this week, thousands of incarcerated people have been ordered released early from prisons and jails to try to protect them from the coronavirus. Producer Sean Cole talks to Terry Smith, who got out of the San Francisco County jail last week.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Hello From the Other Side
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emanuele Berry gets a text message from the other side of the crisis.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong. When you leave the normal realm of human error, fumble, mishap, and mistake and enter the territory of really huge breakdowns. Fiascos. Things go so awry that normal social order collapses.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt tells the story of a small town production of Peter Pan in which the flying apparatus smacks the actors into the furniture, and Captain Hook's hook flies off his arm and hits an old woman in the stomach. By the end of the evening, firemen have arrived and all the normal boundaries between audience and actors have completely dissolved.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Opening Night
episode_acts.summary: Jack Hitt's Peter Pan story continues.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Squirrel Cop
episode_acts.summary: The first day on the job inevitably means mistakes, mishaps, and sometimes, fiascos. A true story, told by a former rookie cop.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Tragedy Minus Comedy Equals Time
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Mike Birbiglia talks about the time he ruined a cancer charity event, by giving the worst performance of his life. Here's a hint: He improvised.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Fiascos As A Force For Good
episode_acts.summary: Journalist Margy Rochlin on her first big assignment to do a celebrity interview. It was 1982.

fields.episode_descript: Sometimes a sketch of a thing needs filling in for its true significance to be known.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A nurse giving instructions to her partner in case she dies from COVID-19; a brother and sister talking every day, all of a sudden. (9 minutes)We first heard about nurse Elise Barrett in a story by Eric Boodman for STAT.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Can’t Be Your Hero, Baby
episode_acts.summary: The stories of undocumented people so often sound cliche. Writer Karla Cornejo Villavicencio has heard all of them, and thought she could do better.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Popular Vote
episode_acts.summary: The discovery of new information casts a new light on a high school competition. Producer Sean Cole talks to some of the people involved, more than a decade later.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Tunnel Vision
episode_acts.summary: A mysterious tunnel in Toronto leads to wild public speculation. Nick Kohler tells Ira the story behind the tunnel, which he wrote about for MacLean’s.

fields.episode_descript: Desperate to know what happened to his family, a man obsessively decodes the only information about them he can get. That, and other stories of people looking into the void for answers.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Couples therapist Esther Perel talks to Ira about the very particular ways she’s seeing lockdown impact couples around the world.  Listen to season three of her podcast, “Where Should We Begin: Couples Under Lockdown.” (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Phone Flickers in the Dark
episode_acts.summary: Abdurahman Tohti left his home country, China, behind 7 years ago to move to Turkey, safe from the Chinese regime that discriminates and arbitrarily detains Uyghurs, specifically, which Abdurahman is. Reporter Durrie Bouscaren talks to him about what happened to his wife and children and extended family in China, and the endless challenges he faces trying to be sure they are safe.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: State of Emergency
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek talks to two emergency medical service workers in New York about the sheer number of 911 calls they are responding to, and how they are coping under the stress of being on constant high alert.

fields.episode_title: One Last Thing Before I Go
fields.episode_descript: Words can seem so puny and ineffective sometimes. On this show, we have stories in which ordinary people make last ditch efforts to get through to their loved ones, using a combination of small talk and not-so-small talk.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to a New York City ICU doctor about the little observations nurses are recording about their COVID patients to save for their families.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Really Long Distance
episode_acts.summary: Producer Miki Meek tells the story of a phone booth in Japan that attracts thousands of people who lost loved ones in the 2011 tsunami and earthquake.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Uncle's Keeper
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein tries to convince his uncle and his father to get into the same room and have a conversation for the first time in decades, before it’s too late and one of them dies.

fields.episode_descript: During a time when a lot of us feel like we are living in a holding pattern, stories of people feeling stuck.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to an Oregon ICU doctor about his desire to help fight COVID in the country’s biggest hot spots, and his frustration over the surprising reason why he can’t.

episode_acts.name: Act One: You Can Check Out Any Time You Like, But You Can Never Leave
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Elna Baker about the time she and her siblings found themselves trapped in a hotel room with an unexpected visitor.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Can’t Go Your Own Way
episode_acts.summary: Carmen Maria Machado tells the story of being stuck in an abusive relationship as a “Choose Your Own Adventure” tale. This chapter of Carmen’s memoir, “In The Dream House,” was read for us by actor Zoë Winters.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Cold Case
episode_acts.summary: Nadia’s family has been isolating and disinfecting everything for weeks, and yet a cold still managed to creep in. How?

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Unhappy Accident
episode_acts.summary: The story of someone stuck in a difficult situation, from Etgar Keret. (8 minutes)This was read for us in English translation by actor Michael Chernus.

fields.episode_descript: Last week, our episode "The Out Crowd" won the very first Pulitzer Prize ever awarded to a radio show. This is the episode that won, with some updates on the stories. Hear what the Trump administration’s "Remain in Mexico" policy actually means, on the ground, at the Mexican border.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass visits refugee camps we don’t call refugee camps—right on our country’s doorstep. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Goodbye, Stranger
episode_acts.summary: Los Angeles Times reporter Molly O’Toole talks to U.S. asylum officers—the people who end up sending migrants back to Mexico.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Take the Long Way Home
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Emily Green happens to meet a man being sent back to Mexico who tells her he’s afraid of being kidnapped—and then, he gets kidnapped. (18 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: While sports of all kinds have been put on pause, we bring you favorite stories from back when people were still on football fields, boxing rings, and basketball courts.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to sportswriters Jason Kirk and Spencer Hall about life in a sportsless world. Read Jason and Spencer’s essay about this.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Friday Night Floodlights
episode_acts.summary: Lisa Pollak tells the story of a high school football team in Mississippi getting ready to play its first game just a month after Hurricane Katrina upended everything.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dunk and Go Nuts
episode_acts.summary: Producer Nancy Updike talks to her friend Mary Conway about the strangest-looking trophy she got in her years playing basketball.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Those Who Can’t Play
episode_acts.summary: Daniel Alarcón’s dad was obsessed with soccer when he was growing up, but he was only average at soccer. But those who can’t do...find something else to do.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Girl With the Golden Gloves
episode_acts.summary: A story about someone with a complicated relationship with the sport she loves, from Meema Spadola.

fields.episode_title: A Mess to Be Reckoned With
fields.episode_descript: Lissa Yellow Bird searches for missing people. Cold cases, mostly. People no one else is looking for. It’s not her job, but a lot of Native Americans go missing and their cases remain unsolved, so families often ask Lissa for help. But then, Lissa’s own niece goes missing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Lissa Yellow Bird started searching for missing people after an oil worker disappeared from the reservation Lissa’s from. Since then, many Native American families have asked for Lissa’s help looking for their loved ones, too.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: When Lissa’s niece, Carla Yellow Bird, went missing in 2016, Lissa threw everything she had into figuring out what happened to her—including talking for hours on the phone with someone she suspected was involved.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Lissa knows how to read people, how to pull information out of them that others can’t. Because of this, she’s able to find out what happened to her niece in just five days.

fields.episode_descript: In this moment of sorrow, protest, and rage in the wake of George Floyd’s death, we offer this as a break from the dreadful present: our show about Afrofuturism. It’s a way of looking at Black culture that’s fantastic and hopeful, which feels especially urgent during a time without a lot of optimism. Featuring the song "The Deep" by clppng.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira and producer Neil Drumming visit a comic book store in Philadelphia to try and help Ira understand Afrofuturism.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Metropolis Now
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming spends a couple days exploring Detroit, first with a quirky mayoral candidate running an Afrofuturist campaign, and then with a couple of locals.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Past Imperfect
episode_acts.summary: Comedian and actor Azie Dungey recounts her time playing a slave for visiting tourists at George Washington’s estate in Mount Vernon.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Black Sea
episode_acts.summary: This American Life commissioned an original song, “The Deep,” from the hip-hop group clppng., featuring actor and Hamilton performer Daveed Diggs. The song is based on the underwater mythology of the 90s Detroit electro band Drexciya.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Childhood’s End
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming looks into two videos he found on YouTube—one that takes place in Atlantic City, another in Brooklyn—that deal with the trouble kids face walking home from school.

fields.episode_descript: An exhaustingly familiar story. Maybe it’ll have a different ending this time, but maybe not. We hear what different people said and did one weekend in reaction to the killing of George Floyd.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass introduces the show and goes straight to Act One.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Letter From America
episode_acts.summary: Bim Adewunmi talks about the feeling of now.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Before Sunrise
episode_acts.summary: Producers Diane Wu and Lina Misitzis spend the night at a corner grocery store in Brooklyn, New York and talk to some of the people that pass by. (25 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Grand Army
episode_acts.summary: Ira watches videos of police behavior at protests. The videos were pulled from a Twitter thread (and corresponding spreadsheet) created by T.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Do Not Pass Go, Do Not Collect $200
episode_acts.summary: Writer Kimberly Jones provides context with a brief history of the American economy, told through a popular board game.

fields.episode_descript: Michigan has passed its Covid-19 peak, and the state has started opening up. But it’s still been intensely difficult for the staff in the ICU at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. We've embedded with them over the past few months, and tracked how this pandemic has changed them and their city.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We meet the doctors. Rana Awdish spends hours of each day walking the floors of the ICU checking in on her co-workers, which means that maybe more than any single person in the hospital she knows best what the staff has been going through at each stage of this pandemic. One doctor that has deep ties to Detroit is Geneva Tatem.
episode_acts.byline: By Miki Meek, Robyn Semien, Ira Glass

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pod Bless America
episode_acts.summary: When it comes to caring for Covid-19 patients, it’s the nurses who are carrying the heaviest burden. Ben Calhoun spent weeks talking to the nurses in the first Covid-19 unit to open in the ICU – Pod 4.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Stan’s Good Day
episode_acts.summary: We found out about a patient from a recording made by young doctor named Stan Linder. Producer Emanuele Berry put this together.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Granger in a Strange Land
episode_acts.summary: Robert Granger was a patient in Pod 4 for several weeks. During that time, his daughter learns something about him she'd never realized before.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Mr. Eastside
episode_acts.summary: Some of the first Covid-19 patients to arrive at Henry Ford Hospital were police and others who’d attended a community breakfast in early March called "Police and Pancakes." Aaron K. Foley has this story of this breakfast and of one man — Marlowe Stoudamire — who ended up at Henry Ford.

fields.episode_descript: As China's new national security law tightens its control over Hong Kong, we return to our episode about last fall's anti-government protests and check in to see how people are responding.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains how things have changed in Hong Kong this month, and wonders how things are going for a protester we’re calling Jennifer, who he went to protests with back in the fall.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cursed Generation
episode_acts.summary: A bunch of 22-year-olds from Hong Kong explain why they are cursed and what that means for their and Hong Kong’s future. (17 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Fight
episode_acts.summary: Jennifer, Ira, and producer Emanuele Berry go to a protest and get tear gassed in front of a Ruth's Chris Steakhouse. (6 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Good Cop, Dad Cop
episode_acts.summary: A protestor who thinks the Hong Kong police are terrible has a chat with his dad — a police officer.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Slow Boat to China
episode_acts.summary: Producer Diane Wu goes to a party. A Chinese flag party.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Nine Months Later
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass calls Jennifer to talk about the new security law. (12 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: In space, in the ocean, by ourselves, or with others—we’re all just figuring out how to be apart.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Bim Adewunmi sits in for Ira Glass and talks to retired NASA astronaut Leroy Chiao about how a space mission compares with living alone in a one-bed apartment on earth.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Unbearable Part
episode_acts.summary: Writer Danielle Evans has been almost completely alone all quarantine — and she’s had time to think about grief, and loneliness and what might come after this pandemic is over. (17 minutes)A version of this essay first appeared in the Corona Correspondences series at The Sewanee Review.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Notion Apart
episode_acts.summary: Producer Lilly Sullivan used to feel such a strong kinship with “the loneliest creature on earth” that one of her first radio pieces seven years ago was about him. (9 minutes) You can read Lilly's 2013 report about this whale.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Parent Trap
episode_acts.summary: Producer Nadia Reiman tells the story of one mom and her son stuck someplace with no choice.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Applied Bob Studies
episode_acts.summary: When Sandy Allen fled the people-heavy city back in 2017, they were looking for green space and a chance to learn how to cope with being alone. They had a sort of guide book, though — their Uncle Bob, who’d made a radical decision decades before.

fields.episode_descript: Years ago, producer Chana Joffe-Walt started reporting on one school in New York. She thought the story was about segregation and inequality in public schools. But the more she looked into it, the more she realized she was witnessing something else. She was seeing the inordinate power of white parents at this school. This is the first episode of Chana’s new mini-series: Nice White Parents.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When the trailer was released for Chana Joffe-Walt’s new show, it prompted a kind of online war. Within a week, people left thousands of ratings and comments: some saying it was divisive and racist; others saying the opposite.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: In just one year, everything in one ordinary public middle school changed. It went from an incoming class of thirty sixth graders—most of them Black, Latino, and Middle Eastern—to a class of 103 sixth graders.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: As the school year moved forward, the fundraising committee planned a gala at the French Embassy. And the PTA planned a separate, Spring Carnival.

fields.episode_descript: From the moment we wake up in the morning there are a trillion rules — big and little — governing our lives. But sometimes, we encounter one we just can't abide by. In a pitched moment of rule-questioning, a show about rules and the people who break them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Benjamen Walker of the podcast Theory of Everything tells guest host Sean Cole about an Uber drivers strike he came across in Kenya. The guys who didn’t join the strike and kept driving for Uber made extra money since there were fewer cars on the road.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Time Bandit
episode_acts.summary: Jerome Ellis is a composer and musician. But this year, at an annual New Year's Day performance event, he got on stage with no instrument, or anything else, and broke a small rule in a monumental way.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: It’s All About the Jeffersons
episode_acts.summary: As a kid, comedian Tone Bell was a rule follower. But there was one time he got into big trouble when he broke the rules in a serious way. There’s a Polaroid commemorating the event that’s become part of family lore. Tone tells producer Elna Baker what happened.

fields.episode_descript: It’s the last few weeks of summer, so we’re going to the beach! This week, stories from the surf and sand.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reflects on his feelings about going to the beach.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Grapes of Wrath
episode_acts.summary: Producer Dana Chivvis explores the case of a 66-year-old working lifeguard who is suing New York State for age discrimination after refusing to wear a Speedo on the job.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Beach Doctor
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg talks to Shane Dubow about a time decades ago, when Shane went sea kayaking and camping with his friends on the beach in Baja California, Mexico. When Shane’s neck stiffens up on him, he finds himself looking for an unlikely chiropractor, in the middle of nowhere.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Beachcomber
episode_acts.summary: This clip is from what Ira calls “the beachiest show” public radio ever made.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Now We Are Five
episode_acts.summary: David Sedaris comes from a big family, who for many years growing up, took annual vacations to the same beach house. In this story, David tells us about losing a sister, and how her death prompted a family reunion back at the beach.

fields.episode_descript: Teachers, students and parents around the country have been bracing themselves all spring and summer long for the start of this unprecedented school year. This week, it's here.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira talks with a teacher in South Carolina who is just trying to figure out what the first day of school will look like.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Masked Crusaders
episode_acts.summary: Two teachers find themselves thrown into a heated and ugly fight with parents right before school opens back up. Producer Miki Meek has this story from Utah.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Screen Times at Ridgemont High
episode_acts.summary: Aviva DeKornfeld talks with a high schooler about how he’s prepped for remote learning with a bunch of kids he doesn’t know. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Future Imperfect
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum talks to one teacher there who’s already gone through a month of in-person learning to see what the  future might hold for other schools.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Case of the Well-Prepared Elementary School
episode_acts.summary: A school that has prepared for every Covid scenario faces a problem they never saw coming. Stephanie Wang tells the story of one Indiana school's first day in person.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Leftovers
episode_acts.summary: A week after starting classes, a Covid outbreak forces a university to send students back home. Producer Robyn Semien takes a tour of the emptying campus.

fields.episode_descript: Sarah Vowell and her twin sister Amy headed out on the road to retrace the Trail of Tears – the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land – and reflected on the question, what are we supposed to do with the mix of good and bad that is this country?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to a direct descendent of Thomas Jefferson about treating Monticello as his personal playground and about whether monuments to Jefferson should come down.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell and her twin sister, Amy, retrace the Trail of Tears. They visit the town in Georgia that was the capital of the Cherokee Nation before the Cherokee were expelled. They enjoy a tourist trap hotel in Chattanooga. They go to Ross's Landing, the embarkment point for the water route of the Trail of Tears. (27 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Sarah Vowell's story continues. She and Amy visit the home of President Andrew Jackson, the villain in the Trail of Tears drama. They drive west to Cherokee graves in Kentucky and a commemorative marker that's been placed, oddly, at an Arkansas high school. They head into Oklahoma, where the Cherokee settled and where they were born. Sarah talks with her oldest living relative about the Trail. And she and Amy end their trip at the place where they first heard about the Trail of Tears: an amphitheater where every summer, they saw a dramatic two hour recreation of the Trail. (23 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: At a time when going to the movies is mostly out of the question, we bring the movies to you.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass revisits the one movie he’s seen more than any other, about an ocean liner that gets hit by a tsunami and flips over. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Putting the Ease in Disease
episode_acts.summary: To cope with this pandemic, producer Sean Cole finds himself turning to a movie about a pandemic, What's So Bad About Feeling Good? But the virus in this movie isn’t like any you’ve ever heard of. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Late Registration
episode_acts.summary: Political documentaries aren’t for everyone. Especially when they’re over five hours long.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Many a Thing She Ought to Understand
episode_acts.summary: Our producer Diane Wu spent most of her life thinking she doesn’t have a unique and personal take on The Sound of Music.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Kid Namastays in the Picture
episode_acts.summary: Jaime Amor does yoga storytelling for kids. We ask her to try taking on a film for grownups.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people who are tied together, but imagine radically different futures. In one case, a movie star and her ex-husband plot against Kim Jong-Il. In another, a woman stalks her doppelgänger. And sometimes, one bed is the basis for an entire relationship, even for a man who almost never sees the person who shares his bed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass discusses what it means to peacefully transfer power from one president to the next. He points out one of the weirdest things about it, that the new president has to go and sleep in the same bedroom as the previous president.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dream Weevil
episode_acts.summary: Kim Jong-Il loved movies, but hated all the movies made in North Korea. So he kidnapped a famous South Korean director and his ex-wife—a South Korean film star—locked them up in a villa in North Korea, and forced them to make movies for him. Nancy Updike tells the story.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Smell You Later
episode_acts.summary: Lots of people in America share actual beds, but almost never see each other; flight attendants have crash pads near airports, oil rig workers carry their own sheets and sleep in shifts in an RV. Producer Stephanie Foo has a profile of Mexican immigrants who share a few beds in a tiny trailer in upstate New York.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Haunter Becomes the Haunted
episode_acts.summary: When someone stole Jessamyn Lovell’s ID, she became obsessed with the thief. Miki Meek tells what happened.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Overnight Flight
episode_acts.summary: Several people who just woke up on red-eye flights talk about their dreams.

fields.episode_descript: A doctor who breaks the law might go to jail like anybody else. But who decides if that doctor gets to keep their medical license? On today’s show, the not-often-talked-about realm of licensing boards, and the disturbing decisions they sometimes make.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: For the past couple-two-three weeks, producer Ben Calhoun has been calling around to small town municipal clerks in his home state of Wisconsin, asking them how mail-in balloting really works. It can be chaotic, they say, but not in the way the president would have you believe.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Clinical Trial
episode_acts.summary: Law professor Rebecca Allensworth has been studying another realm of civic-minded individuals charged with helping society function: medical licensing boards. They’re mostly doctors deciding whether other doctors should be allowed to keep practicing medicine.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Dana Chivvis’s story on the Tennessee Board of Medical Examiners continues with Dr. Michael LaPaglia’s contested case hearing.

fields.episode_descript: People who are worried — or not worried enough! — about what's hurtling unstoppably towards them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass speaks to Kevin Sheekey, the man tasked with spending $100m of Mike Bloomberg’s billions on securing a Democrat win in the constant battleground state of Florida. He also speaks to producer Lina Misitzis about what’s going on down on the ground with Democrats in the state.

episode_acts.name: Act One: School of Hard Knocks
episode_acts.summary: Broward County is  one of the bluest counties in Florida, and some of the Democrats who live and vote there are worried their party isn’t doing enough to keep it that way. Lina Misitzis spent some time talking to them about their fears.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Words Vs Fear
episode_acts.summary: Michael Bernard Loggins tried to battle his fears by listing them — at last count he had a list of 138 fears. Actor Tom Wright reads excerpts.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Best Laid Plans
episode_acts.summary: Kurt Braunohler and his girlfriend had been together for thirteen years, and they were still only 30. They wondered why they had never considered marriage, and realized that they needed to sleep with other people before they tied the knot.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Potus Operandi
episode_acts.summary: Ten years ago Jonathan Menjivar was on the cusp of something big: the birth of his daughter.

fields.episode_descript: People finding themselves stuck in small spaces—an elevator, an attic, an orchestra pit—trying to make sense of their new surroundings.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Jay Van Bavel, who recently found himself trapped in an elevator (in a very 2020 predicament).

episode_acts.name: Act One: The People Up the Stairs
episode_acts.summary: A few weeks ago, Jessica and Moisés found themselves hiding in an attic. Reporter Kevin Sieff talks to them about how they got there.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Music of the Night after Night after Night
episode_acts.summary: The musicians in the orchestra for Phantom of the Opera tell reporter Jay Caspian Kang about what it’s like to play the exact same music every single night—for decades—and how they’ve learned to make their peace with it. (22 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Ahead of the election, we have stories about people trying to live in the unreality that defines this moment. Election officials combat a contagion among their very own workers; people who've never owned guns suddenly go buy them; and two women who allege they were sexually assaulted by the president compare notes.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira gives us a recent shortlist of things that feel almost too unreal to believe as we head into the national election.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Would You Like to Come Up to First Class?
episode_acts.summary: The journalist E. Jean Carroll is one of dozens of women who’ve accused the president of sexual assault or harassment.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Gun Reality of Now
episode_acts.summary: The statistics on first time gun ownership are higher than ever in America.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Second Time’s the Charm
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Johnny Kauffman embeds with the election staff in Georgia’s most populated county to find out if the staff—who had a horrible go of it during the primary election—can possibly do better this time.

fields.episode_descript: People grappling with an endless presidential election.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks with Georgia Democrats who went out to “cure” ballots in a state with some of the closest results in the country.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Virginia
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Mike Giglio follows a group of militia members as they prepare to heed President Trump’s call and watch polling locations for signs of trouble on Election Day.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: New York and Germany
episode_acts.summary: Stephanie Foo talks with two Army officers with very different political views about the week’s results.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Louisiana
episode_acts.summary: Ben Calhoun talks to a man in ICE detention in Louisiana about how he and people around him are following the election. But right as the results are coming in, the man’s case takes a serious turn.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Detroit
episode_acts.summary: Emanuele Berry talks to Khalilah, who got involved as a poll watcher this year and ended up inside a national news story. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Miami
episode_acts.summary: Nadia Reiman talks to Ninotchka and Marco in Florida. The mother and son immigrated from Venezuela, and while they live and work together, they feel very differently about American politics.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Massachusetts
episode_acts.summary: During an election in which it feels like the very existence of our democracy hangs in the balance, producer Sean Cole and someone very close to him have been dealing with their own immediate existential questions.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people changing their minds.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There is a lot of disinformation surrounding the 2020 presidential election. A few conspiracy theories in particular have gained traction.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Signs, They are a Changin’
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Lizzie Johnson calls her grandpa after he unexpectedly changes his mind about something. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Puppy Love Triangle
episode_acts.summary: Writer Emily Flake’s young daughter tries to make up her mind about whether or not she has a crush on a boy in her class.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The All-Too-Real Housewives of Argentina
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Jasmine Garsd grew up in Argentina watching talk shows which were kind of extreme even for Latin American television. The women on screen were pumped with silicone and Botox, and sometimes showed up wearing almost nothing.

fields.episode_descript: For Thanksgiving weekend, stories about food, and people who set out on very particular missions with food.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Vertamae Grosvenor, shows Ira how to tell a chicken is done simply by listening to the sound of the grease.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Dead Ringer
episode_acts.summary: A while ago, a farmer walked through a pork processing plant in Oklahoma with a friend who managed it. He came across boxes stacked on the floor with labels that said "artificial calamari." Ben investigates the physical resemblance between two very different types of food.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Still Life With Chicken
episode_acts.summary: Food writer Jonathan Gold tells what it's like to pan-fry a chicken—with a live chicken watching you the entire time.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lunchtime With The King Of Ketchup
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein talks about his friend Howard who gets amazing treatment from people in the service industry.

fields.episode_descript: To commemorate our show’s 25th year, we have a program about people who were born the year our show went on the air.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays a recording of a rookie, try-hard, 25-year-old radio reporter.

episode_acts.name: Act One: 25 vs. 19
episode_acts.summary: We send one of the youngest people on our staff, 26-year-old Noor Gill, to report on a 25-year-old whose job took over her life earlier this year.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Buy Like a Butterfly
episode_acts.summary: An incredibly accomplished 25-year-old, two-time Olympic boxing gold medalist Claressa Shields, achieved a big dream of hers this year. A dream that had nothing to do with her sport.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Rest of His Life
episode_acts.summary: Mitchell S Jackson profiles Ahmaud Arbery, who was 25 years old when he was shot to death by three white men in Georgia earlier this year.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Bachelorette in Arlington
episode_acts.summary: Turning 25 has always been a very specific deadline for Linah Mohammad: a deadline to get married.

fields.episode_descript: What the day-to-day business of saving the world looks like. We visit with one group of people who are trying to rescue us from something very large, and another group trying to rescue us from something very small.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: To fight those massive fires out west, there are these camps hidden from view. If you were driving by, you might not even know they’re there.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Extinguishers
episode_acts.summary: We heard about these fire camps from Lizzie Johnson. She’s a reporter at The San Francisco Chronicle and spends most of the year chasing fires around California.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Other Extinguishers
episode_acts.summary: For years one group of people has been trying to push a giant boulder to the top of a hill, like Sisyphus. But in this case, it looks like they’ve actually succeeded! David Kestenbaum spoke with four scientists who have been working on a coronavirus vaccine, one that was just shown to work.

fields.episode_descript: People going to great lengths to throw a special Christmas for their families.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Linda Lutton and her eleven year old daughter Pirecua explain what happened the year Pirecua begged for a gift that she turned out to be allergic to. Linda is a reporter at our home station, WBEZ Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Christmas in 3-D
episode_acts.summary: Maya Gurantz tells the story of Glenn and Laurie Mutchler, who go further than most parents to create a magical Christmas for their kids, Colin, Erica and Adam. Theirs included a family mythology of Santas that had its own logic, with many Santas and a family elf named Jeko, who were never jolly and often thrillingly scary.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Deer in the Footlights
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Connie Rex about the deer she and her sisters kidnapped and ended up putting into their school’s Christmas pageant in Woodruff, Utah, in a starring role.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Replacement Claus
episode_acts.summary: Jonathan Goldstein tells the story of Santa Claus, who, after losing his wife, Martha Claus, sets out to find love once again.  Jonathan is the host of the podcast, Heavyweight.

fields.episode_descript: There's always someone whose job it is to decide if you measure up.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Dr.

episode_acts.name: Act One: God Committee
episode_acts.summary: People given the difficult task of deciding who lives and who dies.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Winter’s Bone
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker notices a change in how people in New York City are dating during the pandemic. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Reluctant Bureaucrats
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Katie Mingle wonders why the 211 hotline in the San Francisco Bay Area for people experiencing homelessness so often turns out to be a dead end for them.

fields.episode_descript: Things we’ve lost in the past year — since the first American coronavirus case — that we haven’t talked about so much. Gossip. The chance to make new friends. And much larger stuff.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A woman’s dog has an unexpected reaction to the pandemic, and a mother has to re-think how to teach her son to drive.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cops and Mobbers
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Emmanuel Felton called up several Black Capitol Police officers in the days after the attack on the Capitol on January 6th to find out what it was like for them to face off with this mostly white mob. (13 minutes)You can find more of Emmanuel's reporting on race and inequality at BuzzFeed. The video of Eugene Goodman was filmed by Igor Bobic of HuffPost.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 50 Shades of Shade
episode_acts.summary: Producer Lilly Sullivan talks trash with writer Rachel Connolly about people neither of them know.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: There’s a German Word for That
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks to journalist Jochen Bittner about a political lie from 1920s Germany and the lessons it holds for 2020s America. His op-ed about this ran in the New York Times. Bittner’s one of the people who runs the Opinion section of the German newspaper Die Zeit.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Quarantweening
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt talks to a seventh grader who doesn’t have a seventh grade, or an eighth grade. (11 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A beloved drawing goes missing from Mr. Ablao’s third grade classroom.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Through The Eye Of A Needle
episode_acts.summary: Fewer than 40 million Americans have gotten the vaccine so far, which leaves a lot of people jealous and wondering what happens inside those little rooms.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Penny for Your Non-Thoughts?
episode_acts.summary: For years, producer Lilly Sullivan has wondered what goes on beneath the surface in the mind of one of her good friends and co-workers, Diane. This week, she tries to get to the bottom of it. (11 minutes)This was the story director Greta Gerwig gave to Margot Robbie, while Robbie was trying to figure out how to play Barbie.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: One if By Land, Three if By Sea
episode_acts.summary: Firefighter and paramedic Sam Gebler gets a glimpse of what lurks beneath the surface of a sunny California afternoon.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Boiling Under
episode_acts.summary: Lots of things go unspoken between family members, sometimes for years. We searched for a parent who had a question for their kid that they’d never been able to ask before.

fields.episode_descript: Why we tell them, and what happens after we do.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Susan Burton watches videos of female legislators sharing very private stories.

episode_acts.name: Act One: My Own Very Serious Comedy About Women and Food
episode_acts.summary: Susan Burton talks to women about why it’s so hard to talk about eating disorders.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mommy’s Busy Right Now
episode_acts.summary: Lana has a problem lots of mothers have right now during the pandemic—but a more extreme version of it.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bad Cell Service
episode_acts.summary: Pavan Bivigou writes about having sickle-cell anemia.

fields.episode_descript: This week, three men who came together to protest the murder of George Floyd. They were unified, loud, and impressive, but over time these three friends end up in three very different places.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When Executive Editor Emanuele Berry’s friend pitched her a show about Black Lives Matter activists, she was not sure. He made it anyway and it’s really good. Today we are featuring some of Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr.’s reporting from the podcast Resistance. He’s captured a story about Black Lives Matter that has always been there but nobody ever tells. (4 minutes)You can hear Resistance from Gimlet, a Spotify company.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: When Saidu’s friend Marcus-David Peters was killed by police, he wanted to figure out what to do with the weight of that loss. He began following three men who began protesting after the murder of George Floyd. They seemed to know what to do when faced with police violence. Saidu tells the story of their lives after they began protesting with the Warriors in the Garden.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: We continue our story about three members of Warriors in the Garden. After a summer of protest, the Warriors have to figure out what to do when their activism draws the attention of the police. (25 minutes)

fields.episode_title: The Campus Tour Has Been Cancelled
fields.episode_descript: How the pandemic has thrown college admissions process into a kind of slow-motion chaos. One of the biggest changes: most colleges have stopped requiring the SAT. For decades, there’s been a debate over whether schools should drop the test. What’s it mean that it finally happened?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass takes us on a tour of the various ways the pandemic has affected going to college this year.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Paul Tough and Host Ira Glass look at the biggest change in admissions this year: colleges no longer requiring the SATs. Paul speaks to a student whose SAT score determined her future.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A World Without The Need For Number Two Pencils
episode_acts.summary: Paul Tough turns to UT Austin to see what happens if you admit students with great grades, who didn’t perform well on the SAT, into your college.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about the power of blood.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to writer Mitchell S.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Started From Phle-Bottom, Now We’re Here
episode_acts.summary: When Adele wrote into our show last summer, she described herself as “the worst phlebotomist in the whole hospital.” Producer Diane Wu couldn’t resist calling her up to find out exactly what she meant by that.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Blood Ties
episode_acts.summary: The discovery of 30 century-old postcards written in old Yiddish by a distant family member challenges David Kestenbaum’s ideas about the unimportance of blood ties.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Stage Fright
episode_acts.summary: Fifteen years after a bloody Shakespeare production that, at its height, had people fainting night after night, producer Bim Adewunmi talks to its director, Lucy Bailey.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: There’s No ‘Us’ in Uterus. Oh, Wait...
episode_acts.summary: When Neena Pathak found out she had a fibroid, it didn’t seem so bad. But then it got bigger, more uncomfortable, bloodier… and she had to decide if she was going to have to get surgery to get it removed.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Un-Break My Heart
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sean Cole scrubs in to observe heart surgeon Dr. John Elefteriades, or Dr.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when your own community suddenly turns on you?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: You can’t get herd immunity until you deal with the herd, and get enough of them moving together in the same direction. That’s been difficult this past year, in a way it’s never been during any other epidemic in our history.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Hazardous to Your Health Official
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Anna Maria Barry-Jester tells the story of two public health officials in Santa Cruz County, California, whose lives have been completely upended by threats and harassment over the past year. (20 minutes)This story is a collaboration with Kaiser Health News. You can read their version here.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Elephant in the Zoom
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum follows one person as they try to find something—a set of words, some facts, a story—to convince Trump Republicans to get themselves vaccinated.

fields.episode_descript: An ode to life's daily practices, and what you learn from doing a thing every single day.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass goes to a block in New York City where, over a year into the pandemic, neighbors are still clapping for health care workers every night at 7 p.m. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: How Do You Get To Carnegie Hall?
episode_acts.summary: Producer Ben Calhoun investigates a daily mystery—a daily musical mystery. (15 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: So Nice to Hear Your Voice
episode_acts.summary: Dee Brown’s routine is thrown totally out of whack when Covid hits.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: It Had to Be YouTube
episode_acts.summary: For the last five years or so, Johnny Dark has kept up a very specific, unusual, and labor intensive daily practice.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Here’s What Else You Need To Know Today
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass with the last piece in today’s show, inspired by the New York Times podcast, The Daily. (3 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: So many of us, we don’t want to think about death. We avoid grieving when we lose someone, distract ourselves, look away. In this episode, at a moment when so many families are mourning, we have stories of people figuring out how they’ll grieve, and doing a pretty good job of it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with comedian Rob Delany, who suffered the worst kind of loss a parent can endure — the death of his two-year-old son, Henry. Rob describes what his grief has been like and what he’s learned from it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Goodbye Mr. Facey
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt wondered what it was like for surviving MTA employees coping with the loss of their co-workers due to Covid-19. She met one in particular who’s had a hard time saying goodbye.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: When It Rains
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sean Cole has, unfortunately, experienced something known as “cumulative grief” this year. He writes about the multiple upheavals he’s been dealing  with.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Caretaker
episode_acts.summary: Producer Bim Adewunmi travels to the site in Minneapolis where George Floyd was murdered by a police officer. It’s become a huge, make-shift memorial, big enough to absorb the grief of all-comers who wish to pay homage.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: All My Love
episode_acts.summary: One of the 590,000 casualties of U.S. Covid-19 this year was Leiah Danielle Jones.

fields.episode_descript: The bonds between sisters and how they get broken and fixed—or not.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In families with sisters, every sister has their role to play. And whatever your role is, it sort of becomes your identity: the sweet one, the diva, the rebel.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cindy and Dayana
episode_acts.summary: Cindy and Dayana Carcamo are close. But recently, they’ve been struggling with this thing that happened when they were very young.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Megan and Sybil
episode_acts.summary: The first act of our show was about someone who has spent decades trying to close the gap with her sister because they were apart until she was eight years old. This next story is the reverse.

fields.episode_descript: Solving problems using very extreme measures.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks to Sam Ashner, whose debilitating fear of spiders was ruining his life. So he opted for an extraordinary treatment — the nuclear option — to deal with it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Catching Deer When You Wanted Lions
episode_acts.summary: When the United States Congress saw a problem — sex trafficking — it acted to eliminate it.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Lonely Island
episode_acts.summary: For the last year, writer Karen Cheung has been watching her hometown of Hong Kong change in big and small ways under a new law, and wondering when and if leaving will be her last resort.

fields.episode_descript: Words mean things, but some words are especially meaningful.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: What does God get out of us praising him? Or is it actually for us? (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Go To The Mattresses
episode_acts.summary: Shamyla always loved books. Like lots of other eleven-year-olds back in 1989, she loved The Babysitters Club.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Daddy Lessons
episode_acts.summary: Parents try to shape who we are in their own image. Producer Neil Drumming spoke to Adam Mansbach, who tried to make his daughter fall in love with hip-hop.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Rundown
episode_acts.summary: The story of one woman’s mission to bring people together everywhere by eliminating small talk forever. Starlee Kine has been going around lecturing audiences on the subject.

fields.episode_descript: What’s recovery mean, anyway?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Chase Friedman was in an accident that left him paralyzed from the shoulders down. Ira Glass talks to him about the unusual goal he set for his recovery.

episode_acts.name: Act 1: Naked Lunch
episode_acts.summary: Susan Burton is a couple years into recovery from the eating disorder she’s had for decades.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: Shot Girl, Summer in the City
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker investigates the “Shot Girl Summer” phenomenon.

fields.episode_descript: Bad neighbors. What can you do about them?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to Eyal Levin, who says his neighbor has been propagating a lie for years about one of the most contentious issues in New York: street parking.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Home, Home Near the Range
episode_acts.summary: A stranger moves to Pawlet, Vermont. At first, his neighbors aren’t sure exactly what to make of him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fear Thy Neighbor
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Mike Giglio tries to answer the question: Just how much should the residents of Pawlet fear their new neighbor? (21 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: The pandemic forced jobs to change, but then the workers changed, too.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Chana Joffe-Walt talks to a carpenter whose job output went from fixing doors to something more urgent in the last year. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Three Bottles of Joy
episode_acts.summary: Station agent Moneta Lewis worked underground to shepherd disappearing commuters during the darkest days of the pandemic.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The $25 Tip
episode_acts.summary: The pandemic forced restaurant server Shelly Ortiz to put on her “Covid Goggles.” What she saw through them made her reevaluate her ideas of what’s important.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Teacher Number Four
episode_acts.summary: In Maine, early childhood educator Miss Jordyn Rossignol had several members of her workforce quit. But none hit her quite as hard as Shania.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: 12 Million Thank You Meals
episode_acts.summary: What does “thank you” actually look like? And who gets one? For Flato Alexander and other essential workers, all sorts of symbols that hadn’t bothered them much before suddenly became unbearable.

fields.episode_descript: People trying to escape all kinds of seemingly impossible situations.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We hear a phone call from this week between Kirk Johnson in California, and Ajmal, a man standing in a canal outside the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Nancy Updike tells the story of the phone call from the prologue.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Can Check Out Anytime You Like, But You Can Never Leave
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to producer Elna Baker about the time she and her siblings found themselves trapped in a hotel room with an unexpected visitor. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You Can’t Go Your Own Way
episode_acts.summary: Carmen Maria Machado tells the story of being stuck in an abusive relationship as a “Choose Your Own Adventure” tale.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Blue Kid on the Block
episode_acts.summary: Leo’s family moved away from Rochester, NY, leaving behind all of Leo's friends and stranding him in a new — and in his opinion, much worse — middle school. (10 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: We made you a mixtape. Don't make a big deal out of it or anything.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole guest hosts.

episode_acts.name: Track One: Just Be Good to Me
episode_acts.summary: As a kid, Nichole Perkins always liked a very specific type of song.

episode_acts.name: Track Two: Music is Easy
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole plays a minute of a tune he’s had stuck in his head. Happily.

episode_acts.name: Track Three: The End of the Road
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt really loves the slideshows that schools display at end-of-the-year parent assemblies. A lot.

episode_acts.name: Track Four: What’s the Frequency, Kenneth?
episode_acts.summary: A lot of music discovery happens when we are kids.

episode_acts.name: Track Five: I Talk in Tunes
episode_acts.summary: We had a song made just for you.

fields.episode_descript: Who thought that would be good for a kid?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira remembers the time when his older sister, Randi, asked his mother where babies come from.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Stars & Bars & Bars
episode_acts.summary: Producer Neil Drumming talks with the rapper Breeze Brewin about a toy car they both loved playing with as kids: The General Lee from the hit TV show The Dukes of Hazzard. Breeze went on to record a song called “Generally” about The General Lee with his group the Juggaknots.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: History is Not a Toy
episode_acts.summary: There’s a museum in Baltimore that was created to memorialize the Black experience in America. It’s called The National Great Blacks in Wax Museum.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Take Your Kid to Work Day
episode_acts.summary: A boy rides shotgun in a memorable car ride with his mother, and in the process learns how his father earns money for their family. This story appears in Domingo Martinez’s memoir, The Boy Kings of Texas, which was a finalist for the National Book Award.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Rocket Boy
episode_acts.summary: Paul Zimmer at 83 years old is still haunted by something he saw in his teens. Something very few Americans have ever seen: The explosion of an atomic bomb.

fields.episode_title: The End of the World as We Know It
fields.episode_descript: What happens when one family goes all in on fighting climate change.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: So yes, climate change is real and most Americans believe that’s what we’re seeing around us right now. But there are people out there who look at the same evidence the rest of us do and take it to heart in a way most of us don’t.

episode_acts.name: Act One: 1.5 Degrees of Separation
episode_acts.summary: Producer Aviva DeKornfeld was interested in the toll that having a wakeup-moment could have on a family, and she heard about someone who had a moment like that over a decade ago. He tried to pull his family into activism too, and what unfolded was the most extreme example of things going badly in a family that Aviva heard of.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Out of the Crying Pan and into the Fire
episode_acts.summary: Alexi Horowitz-Ghazi takes Ira to an annual tradition in his hometown of Santa Fe, where people have figured out a surprisingly effective way to deal with the problems of the world, large and small.

fields.episode_descript: An hour devoted to embarrassing stories. They’re not always just little moments – funny, daily stuff that we laugh about later. Some can change you for the rest of your life.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Elna Baker hears of a story from Jane Marie, about an embarrassing moment that haunts her. (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Belle of the Gall
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker picks up with Jane Marie’s story. Jane Marie is the host of the podcast The Dream.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Judgment Day
episode_acts.summary: Writer Kiese Laymon tells Elna Baker his most embarrassing story, involving one of the most important people in his life. Kiese Laymon is the author of Heavy and Long Division.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Traumarama
episode_acts.summary: We put out a call for embarrassing stories and got back more than 1000.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Putting the Bare Ass in Embarrassment
episode_acts.summary: Cariad Harmon tells Elna Baker about what it was like to live through a literal embarrassment nightmare. (15 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Getting from Point A to Point B—with expert assistance.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Amy D'Addario had ferried her mother to the hospital dozens of times before.

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Was A Teenage Smuggler
episode_acts.summary: Because the U.S. doesn’t usually prosecute anyone under 18 for the crime of smuggling people illegally across the border from Mexico, tons of teenagers do it, for money. Reporter Kevin Sieff spent months talking to some of them.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Last Ride
episode_acts.summary: What’s it like, being on that boat with the immortal ferryman, heading into the underworld? Writer Marie Phillips imagines one such trip. Actor Noma Dumezweni reads.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Better Call Dave
episode_acts.summary: When you need to retrieve all manner of treasures secured behind steel doors and complex locks, there’s one man you can count on: safecracker Dave McOmie.

fields.episode_descript: We bring the movies to you.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass revisits the one movie he’s seen more than any other, about an ocean liner that gets hit by a tsunami and flips over. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Many a Thing She Ought to Understand
episode_acts.summary: Our producer, Diane Wu, spent most of her life thinking she doesn’t have a unique and personal take on The Sound of Music. She is wrong.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Putting the Ease in Disease
episode_acts.summary: To cope with the COVID pandemic, producer Sean Cole finds himself turning to a movie about a pandemic. But the virus in this movie isn’t like any you’ve ever heard of.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Director’s Cut
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Will Weldon’s ex-wife made a movie loosely based on their marriage. Producer Elna Baker watches the film with Will as he revisits his break-up.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Kid Namastays in the Picture
episode_acts.summary: Jaime Amor does yoga storytelling for kids at Cosmic Kids Yoga and on YouTube. We ask her to try taking on a film for grownups.

fields.episode_descript: A man who was imprisoned for 14 years in Guantanamo Bay, without charges, gets out and issues an invitation to all the people who kept him there. Amazingly, three of them agree to talk.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Scott, who had worked as a guard at Guantanamo Bay, sees that the detainee he had been in charge of all those years ago, Mohamedou Ould Slahi, had finally been released. The two of them talk.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Sydney
episode_acts.summary: Mohamedou talks with Sydney, who still thinks he was a major player in Al Qaeda. She was an intelligence analyst, who spent weeks at Guantanamo, questioning him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mr. X
episode_acts.summary: Mohamedou talks to a man he only knew as Mr. X and who still gives him nightmares.

fields.episode_title: What We’ve Got Here is Failure to Communicate
fields.episode_descript: Getting the point across — or trying to, anyway.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
