episode_acts.summary: At Sullivan High School in Chicago, being able to communicate is key. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Until The Cows Come Home
episode_acts.summary: A state senator tries persuading his own constituents, from his own party, that the 2020 election was not stolen. (17 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How I Met My Mother
episode_acts.summary: Producer Elna Baker’s mom doles out some very harsh feedback for her daughter, which goes unnoticed for ten years. (14 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Amelia Bedelia Works From Home
episode_acts.summary: Literally, Amelia Bedelia works from home. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The Importance of Meeting Earnest
episode_acts.summary: For more than fifty years, Jeanne Darst’s dad neglected to tell his entire family about their entire family. (13 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Stories about birds and the hearts they sway, the havoc they wreak, the lives they change.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira goes out birding with birder extraordinaire Noah Strycker, who tells the dramatic story of the bird that changed his life: the turkey vulture.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Don’t Chicken Out
episode_acts.summary: Carmen Milito tells Ira the story of a date she went on as a teenager, and the bird her mom brought to the occasion.

episode_acts.name: Act 2: More with Noah
episode_acts.summary: Ira tromps around the woods some more with Noah Strycker, who explains, among other things, his problem with the movie Spencer.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Scrub Is a Bird That Can’t Get No Love From Me
episode_acts.summary: Producer Bim Adewunmi on a decades-long political battle in Florida — between the incumbent state bird and the challenger that threatens to knock it off its perch.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: We Need to Talk About Birdly
episode_acts.summary: There are the birds who exist, and then there are the birds who may as well exist. Producer Sean Cole explains.

fields.episode_descript: In 2006, a new convert showed up at a mosque in Orange County, California. Known as Farouk al-Aziz, the convert was actually an FBI informant named Craig Monteilh. That informant’s infiltration of the mosque is at the heart of FBI v Fazaga, a case heard at the Supreme Court last month. We return to our episode from 2012, which tells the story behind it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: At a Muslim community center in New York, two lawyers teach a workshop on how to react when an FBI agent shows up at the door asking questions. The workshop is a project of CLEAR — Creating Law Enforcement Accountability and Responsibility — at the City University of New York School of Law.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Gym Rat
episode_acts.summary: In the summer of 2006, an FBI official visited a mosque in Orange County, California. His intention was to reassure the community that they weren't being spied on.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: The story of Craig Monteilh continues: What happens when you turn someone into the FBI who, it turns out, is working for the FBI? Trevor Aaronson, whom Sam Black interviewed for this story, has a book called The Terror Factory: Inside the FBI’s Manufactured War on Terrorism.

fields.episode_descript: People earnestly doing what they're told, and absolutely not getting what they were promised.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A teenage girl finds a wallet and has to decide whether to return it. That, and other stories of people trying to do the right thing, and it not working out the way they thought.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Damned If You Don't
episode_acts.summary: Rebecca Shrader thought she knew what was right when it came to abortion. Then she got pregnant.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Brian and Peg
episode_acts.summary: Brian and Peg disagree over a very important thing. Host Ira Glass tries to figure out who’s right.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Bought the Farm
episode_acts.summary: Senior editor David Kestenbaum helps his kids set up an ant farm. They follow all the instructions, to the letter! But he ends up learning a lesson he’s pretty sure the manufacturer did not intend.

fields.episode_descript: People use machines to find people they lost.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira tells three stories about the ghosts captured whenever you record sound. (10 minutes)Michèle Dawson Haber wrote about hearing her father’s voice on tape as a Modern Love column "Hearing His Voice Changed Everything," in The New York Times.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Ghostwriter
episode_acts.summary: Vauhini Vara lost her sister when she was in college. Even though Vauhini’s a writer now, she’d never really been able to write about her sister.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Father of Invention
episode_acts.summary: There’s a machine lots of us encounter as a big impersonal, mechanical apparatus, that has a ghost in it. But it’s a ghost that appears to just a small handful of people. Jean Hannah Edelstein tells the story to Ira.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: This Must Be the Place
episode_acts.summary: For more than a decade, Boris Furman has meticulously tracked the whereabouts of his family members, averaging the latitude and longitudes to arrive at “The Family Average Location.” But nobody really knows why.

fields.episode_descript: Think back to two summers ago, the summer of 2020, when a series of violent, highly-publicized killings of Black Americans sparked outrage and a national movement to eradicate racism and its evils. That movement gave way to a newer, reactionary one, a backlash that is playing out in schools and school board meetings across America. Host Emanuele Berry shares stories about Black people who got tangled up in this current backlash in both extreme and very personal ways.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: As a new high school principal, Dr. Whitfield felt moved by the national renouncement of racism he saw all around him in the wake of George Floyd’s murder.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Incident
episode_acts.summary: During her sophomore year in high school, Nevaeh was targeted in a secret text message chain by a handful of her peers. She’d come to learn the text chat was a mock slave trade where her photo and photos of other Black classmates were uploaded, talked about as property and bid on.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Farce Awakens
episode_acts.summary: After the murder of George Floyd, sales of books by Black authors skyrocketed. Now, there are efforts to ban many of the same books.

fields.episode_title: A Couple Walks Into a House
fields.episode_descript: Rob and Reyna Mathis make an unsettling discovery in the home of a local police officer. Soon, their whole city is asking questions about who the officer really is and what he's been doing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Rob and Reyna Mathis go house hunting with their family in Muskegon, Michigan. What they find in a police officer’s home prompts an upsetting debate.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Decision
episode_acts.summary: Rob and Reyna weigh whether or not they should go public with what they’ve seen.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: It Begins
episode_acts.summary: The response to Rob and Reyna’s Facebook post is loud and immediate. This officer has a past and people have thoughts about him in the town he works, Muskegon, Michigan.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The People in Charge
episode_acts.summary: Muskegon’s City Manager and Chief of Police have to figure out what to do about their employee who’s now in the spotlight.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: We Know That Guy
episode_acts.summary: People in Muskegon show up at a community meeting to talk about their run-ins with this particular police officer. The reviews are not good.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: Officer Anderson On the Job
episode_acts.summary: An example of how this officer could be on the job.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Things Get Ugly
episode_acts.summary: Rob and Reyna Mathis deal with the scary fallout of their choice to name the officer.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: The Investigation
episode_acts.summary: The official investigation by the city of Muskegon into the officer’s past gets underway– and we have a transcript of what went down! Finally we hear the officer – and his wife – explain themselves.

fields.episode_title: A City Walks Into an Investigation
fields.episode_descript: Last week's story continues, about a Michigan couple who walked into a police officer's house and made a disturbing discovery. This week: the police officer suffers the consequences and so does the couple.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira summarizes part one of our story.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Chief Lewis Adds It Up
episode_acts.summary: The police chief in Muskegon conducts his own personal investigation into Officer Anderson’s interactions with Black people on the job. He doesn’t like what he discovers.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Way It Actually Happened
episode_acts.summary: Officer Anderson is fired based on the chief’s findings. But that’s not what’s said publicly.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: How To Fire a Police Officer
episode_acts.summary: Muskegon’s chief of police explains why he decided he couldn’t mention any of the stuff he found troubling about Officer Anderson’s treatment of Black people on the job.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: People Who Got the Short End of Anderson’s Deal
episode_acts.summary: Duke Stalling, whose mother’s birthday party was pepper sprayed by Officer Anderson when he showed up on a noise complaint, reacts to the city’s deal with Anderson.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: No Good Deed Goes Unpunished
episode_acts.summary: Turns out, the couple who originally brought Officer Anderson into the spotlight with their Facebook post had encountered Anderson before in Muskegon. Specifically, at a traffic stop where things got ugly.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: Was It Worth It?
episode_acts.summary: The Mathises consider if going public with what they found in Officer Anderson’s house was worth it, given what their personal lives have been like since.

episode_acts.name: Coda: Coda
episode_acts.summary: Ira and Ben consider how officers could be flagged for bad policing in a more systematic way, rather than the freak occurrence of a couple walking into an officer’s home and finding a KKK application up on his wall.

fields.episode_descript: A while back, one of our producers Brian Reed was in England giving a speech about the podcast he'd hosted, S-Town. A journalism student approached him, asking for advice about a story he wanted to look into – something that’d been big news in Britain, something he’d thought about for years. Brian and the student, Hamza Syed, decided to team up to try and solve the mystery at the heart of that story. The original idea was to put this on our show, but it got too big. Too many twists and turns! This week, it rolls out as a spectacularly great podcast called The Trojan Horse Affair. We’re excited to bring you their first episode today.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira introduces the first part of the latest podcast from Brian Reed (S-Town) and Hamza Syed — which all started when Hamza was a student with a burning question.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Hamza and Brian visit Tahir Alam, the alleged mastermind of a plot to ‘Islamize’ Birmingham’s schools.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: As Tahir’s revamp of Park View School continues to grow and deliver stunning results, his reputation grows — as does resentment at his blunt, unvarnished style. And then came the letter, and hoax or no, the consequences of its contents began to unravel Tahir’s life’s work almost immediately.

fields.episode_descript: A woman wakes up and discovers her backyard has disappeared, and other stories from places slowly coming apart.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with a radio announcer in Truckee, California, about the increasingly alarming content of his fishing reports.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Apocalypse Now-ish
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alix Spiegel reports on the city of Pacifica, California. A huge fight erupted there after it was asked to start planning for sea level rise.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Resilience is Futile
episode_acts.summary: Miami writer Mario Alejandro Ariza on how his city is trying to beat back the impacts of climate change.

fields.episode_descript: Stories about Vladimir Putin. Did he come to power in 1999 by killing hundreds of innocent Russians? How’s he really seen in his home country? This show is a mix of old and new stories we’ve done about him.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Late at night on the evening Russia invaded Ukraine, Ira talks to two people who escaped to Lviv, near the Polish border: a woman we call Natalie, and the Ukraine Correspondent for The Economist, Richard Ensor. Natalie’s harrowing story about escaping Kyiv is not the sort of war story that makes you think, "I can't imagine what it'd be like to go through that.” In fact it’s just the opposite.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Going In with a Bang
episode_acts.summary: Back in 1999 there was series of bombings of apartment buildings in Moscow and across Russia. 300 people died. It happened just as Vladimir Putin was coming to power.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Mr. Popular
episode_acts.summary: Vladmir Putin’s approval rating among Russians is always stunningly high. Ira talks to reporter Charles Maynes to find out if that number is real and how it could be that high.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Maybe Pay a Little Attention to the Man behind the Curtain
episode_acts.summary: Disinformation and propaganda works differently in Putin’s Russia than it did during the Soviet Union. Instead of tamping down the opposition, the Russian government works to control the opposition.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Matter of Principal
episode_acts.summary: Protestors came out across Russia after the Ukraine invasion. In this act, that we first broadcast in 2017, we hear from young people who attended anti-government protests that swept through Russia.

fields.episode_descript: The pandemic broke school. Can we ever go back?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Chana Joffe-Walt talks to teachers and principals about the unique challenges the pandemic has created in their daily working lives. (7  minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Big Mother Is Watching
episode_acts.summary: When school closed and threw routines into disarray, one mom and daughter figured out a new way to make it work.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Case of The Vanishing Sixth Grader
episode_acts.summary: The pandemic moved lots of families around, and many children simply vanished from school, in person, and online.

fields.episode_descript: Three people, and one animal, who know the path their lives will take until, suddenly, they don’t.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Like a lot of parents, Yibin Li’s dad dedicated himself to making sure his daughter stayed on a path that would lead her to a better life than his. But the obstacles her dad had to surmount to achieve this are unlike those any parent anywhere has faced.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Audition
episode_acts.summary: Ira’s story of Yibin Li continues.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Synchronized Swimmers
episode_acts.summary: At the age of 17, competitive swimmer Lynne Cox had already accomplished a lot in the open ocean. She’d set two world records crossing the English Channel.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Year of Manic-al Thinking
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Casey Wilson’s mom was a stabilizing force in her family. So after her unexpected death, both Casey and her father felt devastated and unmoored.

fields.episode_title: Well Someone Had to Do SOMETHING!
fields.episode_descript: People trying to jump in and solve other people's problems, putting themselves directly in the gap between the problem and the solution.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Sean Cole tells us the story of Seattle residents who’ve had their bikes stolen, only to get them back in a way they really are not expecting.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Cold Call to Action
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alix Spiegel tells the story of a Lithuanian man who devises a plan to solve a problem related to the war in Ukraine.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Zoo Unto Others
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole speaks to Washington Post reporter Siobhan O’Grady about her visit to the zoo in Kyiv.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: One Last Thing After I Go
episode_acts.summary: Producer Aviva DeKornfeld tells the story of Bill Edgar, who accidentally ended up helping people have a say at a moment when most people don’t get to say anything at all.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: A Funny Thing Happened When We Were Already AT the Theater
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt tells the story of a woman who took it upon herself to do something in an effort to help, and was not well received. (8 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: In this moment when autocrats and almost-autocrats are getting bolder and more powerful, we bring you two stories of resistance, from Hungary and Russia.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass zooms in on five surreal minutes of Hungary’s opposition campaign. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Brothers Harangazo
episode_acts.summary: Producer Zoe Chace spends time with two brothers in Hungary, trying to win an election that’s basically impossible for them to win.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Putin’s On Our Side
episode_acts.summary: One of the last independent newspapers in Russia finds new ways to cover a war that the government doesn’t want them to cover.

fields.episode_descript: Four personal stories from the war in Ukraine.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass plays recordings of a woman named Katia in Kyiv, dealing with the quotidian challenges of life — like taking the dog out to pee — in the middle of the war. (7 minutes)We found out about Katia from the podcast Vice News Reports, a show with a lot of great reporting on the war in Ukraine, plus stories that are unfolding all over the world.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Yevgenia and Her Neighbors
episode_acts.summary: As Kyiv empties out, Ukrainian photographer Yevgenia Belorusets documents her interactions with those who stayed behind. (15 minutes)Her diaries were published by ISOLARII.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Munachi and The Escape
episode_acts.summary: There’s a group chat for Nigerian students living in Ukraine that got totally upended by the war.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Alyona and Oleg
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Ashley Cleek talks to one Russian protestor in the middle of re-evaluating one of her oldest friendships. (15 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: A man finds himself thrust into a new world he didn’t necessarily ask to visit. He takes a look around.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ken had created a website and abandoned it. Years later, a stranger reaches out to him and tells him he can make money off it.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Planet of the Apes
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass follows Ken as he tries to figure out whether or not the man who reached out to him actually scammed him. Ken learns about a mysterious bot that may have been involved and worries his life may be in danger.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: In the Time of Chimpanzees I Was a Monkey
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks to one of the suspects. Ken learns who is behind the bot and who isn’t.

fields.episode_descript: People staring squarely at the truth, and still finding it hard to believe what they’re seeing.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Two co-workers notice something off about the new guy at work.

episode_acts.name: Act One: She Blinded Us With Science
episode_acts.summary: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt talks to researcher Mary Koss about how she came to see a thing that others couldn’t, and about what she did with that knowledge. (15 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How the Other Side Leaves
episode_acts.summary: Reporter James Spring visits a refugee camp in Tijuana, Mexico filled with Ukranians fleeing the war.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: We Did Start the Fire
episode_acts.summary: Sometimes even when you live through something, it can be hard to see it for what it is. Reporter Katie Worth has a story about a 7th-grader in that position.

fields.episode_descript: Government isn’t doing much to prevent school shootings. So parents are jumping in: parents whose kids have died in mass shootings, in the wake of each shooting. They take practical, effective action — and they get results.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: There's a whole infrastructure that springs into action when a mass shooting occurs. There's the police and SWAT teams, the Red Cross, the Billy Graham prayer truck, therapy dogs.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Keep Breathing
episode_acts.summary: Sandy and Lonnie’s daughter, Jessi, died back in 2012, when a gunman opened fire in a movie theater in Aurora, Colo. Since then, they’ve organized their whole lives to be able to reach out to other parents like themselves.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Down the Rabbit Hole
episode_acts.summary: Lenny Pozner’s son, Noah, was killed at Sandy Hook. In the years after his death, Lenny and his family were harassed by people who believed the shooting at Sandy Hook never happened – that it was all a conspiracy.

fields.episode_descript: Kids navigating hairy situations all on their own, with no help from grown-ups.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Elna Baker tells Ira about two detectives who solved a murder remarkably quickly, especially considering that they were still in middle school.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Magically Malicious
episode_acts.summary: Lilly Sullivan tells the story of an elementary school “movie day” that went horribly wrong for many of the kids. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Classified Dad
episode_acts.summary: Chris Benderev speaks with writer Georgie Codd, who went searching for someone to be the father she never had.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Stations of the Double Cross
episode_acts.summary: Michelle Navarro attended a Catholic youth group retreat when she was thirteen.

fields.episode_title: The Longest Distance Between Two Points
fields.episode_descript: Getting from A to B via Z.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Cassidy, a 10-year-old who has to take a very long route when he encounters an unfamiliar word in a book.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Voter...Reformed
episode_acts.summary: A man in Mississippi tries to get his right to vote back. The state constitution provides a way to do that.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Ill Communication
episode_acts.summary: Yang Yi, in China, tells the story of a strange journey he took that started at home and ended at home.  But somehow took a very long path. Yang Yi’s podcast is called Go LIVE.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Roe Less Traveled
episode_acts.summary: For most of their history, salmon were born upstream and swam to the ocean before coming back as adults to spawn. But humans have disrupted the route the salmon take to the ocean.

fields.episode_title: The Pink House at the Center of the World
fields.episode_descript: The Supreme Court case that overturned Roe v. Wade began with a lawsuit filed by a Mississippi abortion clinic. On the day Roe was overturned, we were there. Stories from the center of this moment of history, the day it happened.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass reminds us that, before they change the country, all major Supreme Court cases start with just a person, in a place. (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Pink House
episode_acts.summary: Documentarian Maisie Crow has been following the fight to stay open by the Jackson Women’s Health Clinic, for ten years. Now the Supreme Court decision is forcing their doors shut for good.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Welcome to Illinois—Abortion Oasis
episode_acts.summary: Our producer Zoe Chace goes to Fairview Heights, Illinois, where Planned Parenthood has opened a massive new abortion clinic just across the river from Missouri. Abortion is banned in Missouri and lots of the surrounding states now that Roe has been overturned.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Abortion Desert Across the River
episode_acts.summary: Zoe Chace spends time with a lawmaker in Missouri on the day Roe fell who’d worked her whole life for this moment and can’t believe it’s really here.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Next
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass walks through possible next steps with a pro-life activist who worked on the Texas SB8 bill, that set a precedent for enforcement of abortion bans throughout the country.

episode_acts.name: Act Five: The Pill Smuggler
episode_acts.summary: Rebecca Grant introduces us to an abortion pill smuggler, who walks us through her undercover operation to mail pills to people who want medication abortions in places where it's hard to get them.

episode_acts.name: Act Six: The Babies
episode_acts.summary: Emma Green spends time with Anja Baker, who’s working on preparing Mississippi for the influx of babies it will have to absorb now that abortion is illegal in that state.

episode_acts.name: Act Seven: Back to Jackson
episode_acts.summary: Maisie Crow is back to take us inside the Jackson clinic once again, as they rally themselves to see all the patients they’d scheduled for the next month to come in in the next ten days, before the ban goes into effect.

fields.episode_descript: An investigation into a very basic question about people: Are most of us bad or good?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: As a joke, Jessica Williamson posts a fake “CAT FOUND” poster with pictures of a possum instead of a cat. To her surprise, she gets hundreds of phone calls that ultimately shift her view on humanity.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Now You See Me
episode_acts.summary: Writer Kiese Laymon talks to comedian Darryl Lenox about how his trust in strangers dramatically shifted after he lost his sight. (17 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Spring Awakening
episode_acts.summary: Clay Elder grew up Mormon, with a fear of outsiders. That changed on a visit to New York City.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Never Hear the End of It
episode_acts.summary: Producer Sean Cole tells one of his favorite stories — about the ending of the book A Clockwork Orange.

fields.episode_descript: Stories of people racing against time to solve a problem. Will they make it?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Mike McFarland tells Ira about trying to get a message to someone under the most critical deadline imaginable—emphasis on the “imagine.” (8  minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Quorum
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Sarah Gibson tells the story of a huge political divide in the tiny town of Croydon, NH –  population 800. She follows local activists as they try to rally everyone to their side in time for a crucial town meeting.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Snail in the Coffin
episode_acts.summary: Senior Editor David Kestenbaum talks with a different kind of advocacy group: animal scientists doing their best to save a particular species before it winks out of existence. (16 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Ten people were killed at a grocery store in Buffalo, NY. Their stories, as you’ve never heard them.

episode_acts.name: Pearl Young and Aaron Salter Jr.
episode_acts.summary: A person cannot be summarized in a sentence.

episode_acts.name: Act 1: Celestine Chaney
episode_acts.summary: Kayla Jones was extremely close with her grandmother, Celestine Chaney. For Colored Nerds host Brittany Luse talks with Kayla about her grandmother and their shared love of beauty. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 2: Andre Mackniel
episode_acts.summary: Bim Adewunmi finds a window into Andre Mackneil’s world through TikTok. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 3: Katherine Massey
episode_acts.summary: The fact that was repeated about Katherine Massey was that she had written an letter to the newspaper calling for gun control the year before she was murdered. Katherine Massey made things happen. Eve L.

episode_acts.name: Act 4: Margus Morrison
episode_acts.summary: Margus Morrison was a school bus aide, father of six.

episode_acts.name: Act 5: Geraldine Chapman Talley
episode_acts.summary: Writer Kiese Laymon wanted to talk through one fact in particular about Geraldine Chapman Talley’s life: her move from Alabama to Buffalo.

episode_acts.name: Act 6: Ruth Whitfield
episode_acts.summary: Ruth Whitfield. 86 years old. There was a detail repeated often came to Ruth Whitfield, the oldest victim.

episode_acts.name: Act 7: Roberta Drury
episode_acts.summary: She was the first person and the youngest person killed. She’s described in a lot of stories as vibrant, funny, joyful. Damon Young was struck by another particular detail.

episode_acts.name: Act 8: Deacon Heyward Patterson
episode_acts.summary: Heyward Patterson was a deacon at the State Tabernacle Church of God in Christ. He was at Tops often where he worked as a jitney driver.

fields.episode_descript: When a fundamental part of yourself changes dramatically, are you still who you thought you were?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Bim Adewunmi talks to Mona Chalabi about why she sometimes feels like an imposter in her own home.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Voice Over
episode_acts.summary: Sandy Allen tells the story of learning to play an instrument that suddenly sounds very different — his own voice.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Me Minus You
episode_acts.summary: Writer Marie Phillips has a short story about a strange man in a parking lot, offering to grant one wish.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: One Pill Made Me Small
episode_acts.summary: When Karla Cornejo Villavicencio decided to make a change that had the potential to alter who she’s known herself to be for many years, she didn’t know who would emerge. (17  minutes)

fields.episode_descript: An exploration of the very upper limits of what you do for someone you love.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass explains what we’re doing on today’s show. (2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Exit Strategy
episode_acts.summary: Amy Bloom tells the story of her husband, Brian, getting Alzheimer's and wanting assisted suicide. Her search to find a way to do that led her to Dignitas, in Switzerland.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Comedy Duo
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Zarna Garg tells jokes onstage about the extreme ways she tries to control her daughter Zoya’s life.

fields.episode_descript: Getting to the facts can be difficult, but it’s always the right thing to do. Except when it isn’t.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Tobin Low tells Ira about Paul, who intended to have an anonymous, romantic rendezvous but instead wound up having to decide whether or not to clear up a big misunderstanding.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Home Test
episode_acts.summary: Valerie Kipnis tells the story of 12-year-old Ilya, a Ukrainian refugee eager to figure out whether his hometown can still feel like home. He and his family return to Mariupol, a city badly damaged in the war, and now under Russian control.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Oh What A Hangled Web We Weave
episode_acts.summary: Lilly Sullivan talks with former science reporter, Kelsey Padget, who’s on a mission to disabuse the world of its incorrect assumptions about an allegedly murderous creature: the black widow spider. (10 minutes)Kelsey Padgett will be hosting an upcoming weekly podcast about big history rivalries and gossipy petty feuds. Dr.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: U-F-No!
episode_acts.summary: David Kestenbaum desperately wants to set the record straight for everybody about whether aliens regularly visit earth. They don’t, he says.

fields.episode_descript: People taking it upon themselves to keep an eye on those in charge.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass looks into what’s going on behind the scenes of this year’s midterm election.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Magazona
episode_acts.summary: Washington Post reporter, Isaac Arnsdorf, and producer, Zoe Chace, continue the story about the takeover of the Republican party. Together, they hit the road to document how the presence of the MAGA newbies are changing things on the ground in Arizona. Isaac is writing a book all about the MAGA plot to take over America.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: I’ll Be Watching You
episode_acts.summary: A group of 6th grade boys are bothered by their teacher’s behavior. They complain, but no one listens.

fields.episode_descript: Two people go on excavations of their families’ pasts. Including the first episode of the new podcast, “We Were Three,” hosted by our longtime producer, Nancy Updike, and from Serial Productions and The New York Times.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass introduces Nancy Updike, one of This American Life's founding producers.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Black Box
episode_acts.summary: One evening last fall, Rachel McKibbens got a text from her younger brother, Peter. It read: “I’ve been too distraught to tell you, but Dad passed away today at 2:42 p.m.” She had no idea her father had even been sick, and no idea that her brother was also dying.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Great Lie-Gration
episode_acts.summary: Jahmal Williams stumbles on a clue about his grandmother’s history that answers a question he’s always had. (11 minutes) Video: The Williams family gets on the bus for their trip north in 1962. WJAR-TV Collection © Rhode Island Historical Society. Archival audio in the story: WPRI-TV Collection ©1962 WPRI-12, Nexstar Media Inc. Courtesy of the Rhode Island Historical Society.More from Gabrielle Emanuel on the Reverse Freedom Rides: The Cruel Story Behind the Reverse Freedom Rides The Long Journey North

fields.episode_descript: We hear from kids who are dealing with some of the country’s most contentious debates. Debates that are supposedly about them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Chana Joffe-Walt talks to students stuck in a fight between their parents and their principal. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: This Is Not a Drill
episode_acts.summary: After every school shooting a political debate reemerges about guns. Meanwhile, kids keep going to school.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Finn Raises His Hand
episode_acts.summary: A super-heated adult debate about trans kids lands in the life of an Alabama teenager named Finn.

episode_acts.name: Act 3: One More Thing
episode_acts.summary: Chana talks about a recent news story that unexpectedly connects the two stories in today’s show. (3 minutes)

fields.episode_title: Mapmaker, Mapmaker, Make Me a Map
fields.episode_descript: Not long ago, Republicans in Ohio passed a constitutional amendment to end gerrymandering in the state. And then a funny thing happened. The same Ohio Republicans drew electoral maps that violated their own constitutional amendment. They’ll be using them in this week’s midterm elections. We try to understand how that could happen.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass brings us back to the moment of celebration when the anti-gerrymandering constitutional amendment was passed in Ohio.

episode_acts.name: Act One: They made each other a pledge. Unheard of. Absurd.
episode_acts.summary: Anti-gerrymandering activists in Ohio worked for decades to pass a constitutional amendment to curb gerrymandering. Then Republican lawmaker Matt Huffman came along and finally made it happen.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Sunrise Sunset
episode_acts.summary: In 2021, Ohio got a chance to take its new constitutional amendments out for a spin for the first time, and draw non-gerrymandered maps. Ira Glass tells the story of what went wrong, including an eleventh-hour Hail Mary vote.

fields.episode_descript: People trying to coax each other across the line, from one side to the other.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Valerie Kipnis tells Ira about how Russian soldiers in the war in Ukraine are making a huge decision in an unusual way: over a hotline.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Flies, Meet Honey
episode_acts.summary: An elections administrator in Texas, Heider Garcia, uses a radical approach to try to win over election skeptics: tactical patience.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Who Is Ryan Long?
episode_acts.summary: A guy tries to coax himself from one reality into another, while on national television.

fields.episode_descript: Something we’ve never done before: true stories told in the form of a game show.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Jiayang Fan has this theory that because she's spent so much time thinking about her own accent when she speaks English, she believes that when she hears other Chinese-Americans speak, she can tell how old they were when they immigrated to the U.S. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: With Great Power Comes Great Pronounceability
episode_acts.summary: We test Jiayang Fan’s self-proclaimed special skill by having her listen to three Chinese-Americans speak, and then guss when they came to the U.S. (20 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: You Bet Your Planet’s Life!
episode_acts.summary: Is it possible for the U.S. to reach the goals set by the Paris Agreement? What steps would we have to take to cut emissions by 50% by 2030? We challenge climate researcher Melissa Lott to get us to that number. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: You Didn’t Hear It From Me. No, Really. You Didn’t.
episode_acts.summary: A game of telephone played on the podcast Normal Gossip reveals how gossip spreads, and why stories change from person to person.

fields.episode_descript: People experiencing Christmas in brand new ways, giving the holiday even more meaning.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira introduces us to Santa Allen. A man who is NOT the real Santa Claus but who will – for the first time ever – be sitting in a chair, dressed as Santa, asking little children what they want for Christmas this year.  He’s nervous.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Does Santa Believe in Himself?
episode_acts.summary: Producer Aviva DeKornfeld accompanies Santa Allen to his first “chair gig” to see whether all of his hopes, or all of his fears, or a little of both, will be realized. (16 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Jews for Jesus, for Just One Day
episode_acts.summary: Alex Edelman grew up in an Orthodox Jewish household in Boston. But one year, unexpectedly, his family decided to celebrate Christmas – for what he says are very Jewish reasons.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Buffalo Girls Can’tcha Come Out Tonight
episode_acts.summary: Our former colleague Neil Drumming has never seen “It’s a Wonderful Life” – which makes no sense given that he’s seen almost every other movie there is.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Single Bells
episode_acts.summary: Scaachi Koul is commemorating a Christmas first of her own – and ON her own – this year.

fields.episode_title: Half-Baked Stories About My Dead Mom
fields.episode_descript: Writer Etgar Keret tries to come up with the stories that capture his late mother, Orna Keret—but it’s hard, he says, because she’s like Maria in West Side Story and she’s also like Thanos from the Avengers. He ends up with a series of very short stories — most just a few paragraphs long — that give glimpses of different sides of her.

episode_acts.name: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to author Etgar Keret about his mom, and the stories she used to tell him when she put him to sleep.  He explains why it's always been so hard to write about her.

episode_acts.name: Story #1: Bedtime Story
episode_acts.summary: The story Etgar's mother told him, to explain what her father was like.

episode_acts.name: Story #2: Razor
episode_acts.summary: Etgar asks his mother why she only ever strokes his face with the back of her hand.

episode_acts.name: Act 3: Conversation
episode_acts.summary: Etgar tells Ira about his mother’s experience in the Holocaust and why she didn’t like people seeing her as a "survivor" or being defined by those terrible years. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Story #3: Fabric
episode_acts.summary: Etgar's mom invents a business for herself where other women look to her like a queen.

episode_acts.name: Story #4: Rain Day
episode_acts.summary: It rains one morning before Etgar's son goes to school, and he and his wife don't agree on how to handle the situation.

episode_acts.name: Story #5: Never Forget a Smell
episode_acts.summary: Etgar’s mother and a school bully. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 7: Conversation
episode_acts.summary: Ira asks Etgar if he has any memories where his mom is not the hero of the story.  (3 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 8: Conversation
episode_acts.summary: How Etgar's parents met.

episode_acts.name: Story #6: The Stuff
episode_acts.summary: Etgar becomes a vegetarian and his mother jumps into action.

episode_acts.name: Act 10: Conversation
episode_acts.summary: Etgar mom asks for a disturbing favor.

episode_acts.name: Story #7: The First Angel You See
episode_acts.summary: A story Etgar's mom only told him one time, while very drunk.

episode_acts.name: Story #8: Good Day
episode_acts.summary: Etgar remembers throwing a fit at a restaurant as a little boy, and what his mother said to him. (3 minutes)Most of these stories about Etgar's mom were written for an exhibition about her called "Inside Out" at the Jewish Museum in Berlin.

fields.episode_descript: People being dodged, delayed, and evaded—and what they do to put an end to it.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Sean Cole about a nightmarish runaround he’s been caught in. It all started when Sean thought: I'd like a new bed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Like The Show “48 Hours", Except A Lot More Hours
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Brenna Smith tells the story of Renee, a mom who is determined to get back nearly $3000 worth of food stamps stolen from her. She soon finds herself caught in a bureaucratic runaround.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Strange Loop
episode_acts.summary: Our senior editor David Kestenbaum introduces us to someone who is literally running around the block as a way to solve one of his problems. David tries to figure out why it works.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Americans Most Wanted
episode_acts.summary: American criminals who flee to Mexico to evade law enforcement discover it's not so simple as crossing the border.

fields.episode_descript: Sometimes you raise your hand. Other times you’re just the only one left.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: What happens when an emergency room nurse has an emergency? Kelsay Irby did something that landed her in the headlines. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Every Day is Father's Day
episode_acts.summary: Megan Tan never felt close to her father. For years they’ve been distant.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Game of Phones
episode_acts.summary: Over the last few years, producer Chana Joffe-Walt has been checking in with someone who wears the mantle of being “it” well. She’s a school principal named Teresa Hill.

fields.episode_descript: When it comes to finding love, there seems to be two schools of thought on the best way to go about it. One says, wait for that lightning-strike magic. The other says, make a calculation and choose the best option available. Who has it right?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: When guest host Tobin Low was looking for a husband, he got opposing advice from two of the most important people in his life, his mom and his best friend.

episode_acts.name: Act One: 10 Things I Require About You
episode_acts.summary: Zarna Garg had a clear plan for how she was going to find a husband.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Crazy Stupid Love
episode_acts.summary: People who fall in love at first sight often describe it as a kind of magic. One of our producers, Aviva DeKornfeld, is skeptical of these sorts of claims.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: He’s All That
episode_acts.summary: Calvin is an 11 year old who is learning what love is all about, the hard way. (7 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: How To Leave a Guy in 10 Days
episode_acts.summary: Writer Marie Phillips believes that magic is not just reserved for the beginning of a relationship.

episode_acts.name: Coda: Coda
episode_acts.summary: Tobin Low tells us which camp he falls in — math or magic. (2 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: People staring down that hardest of questions: Is now the time? To leave?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Russian forces have besieged the town of Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine. Shelling is constant.

episode_acts.name: Act One: First, Do No Harm
episode_acts.summary: Dr. Amelia Huntsberger loves everything about her rural town in northern Idaho.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Leaving Expert
episode_acts.summary: Masha Gessen has fled their home country, Russia, twice. First as a teenager, then again as an adult.

fields.episode_descript: The ghosts that visit us, the ghosts that never do, and the ghosts that walk among us.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Chaunte Vaughn’s mother recently died of Parkinsons. Even though Chaunte doesn't believe in ghosts, she is visited by her mom's ghost multiple times.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Ghost Industrial Complex
episode_acts.summary: Reporter Chenjerai Kumanyika visits Savannah, Georgia to learn about the city’s popular ghost tours. He’s heard the tourist attractions actually include the brutal reality of slavery.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Wedding Crasher
episode_acts.summary: Abby Stein’s youngest sister got married last month, the last of 13 kids in their family.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Seance Fiction
episode_acts.summary: In the 1920s, at the height of the Spiritualism movement, a friendship blossomed between two men with opposing views on the topic: Harry Houdini and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Houdini was a skeptic.

fields.episode_title: So Close and Yet So Far
fields.episode_descript: People ​so close to each other, ​in ​extremely intimate situations​,​ who are also a million miles apart.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Valerie Kipnis tells Ira about riding the subway, shoulder-to-shoulder with someone she knows quite well, pretending she doesn’t see him.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Love and Other Exports
episode_acts.summary: How much can you trust whether somebody who you think is close to you really is close to you? Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr.’s been thinking about that question since a recent visit with some of his childhood friends in Sierra Leone. (37 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Fire Sale
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Tig Notaro has the story of someone as close as her actual bedside yet who, in another way, is impossibly far away. (9 minutes)To read more about the kids stuck in the sewer, check out Jake Offenhartz’s story in Gothamist.

fields.episode_descript: It’s been nine months since Roe v. Wade was overturned. We talk to people who wanted abortions right when the laws were changing in their states. They had to wait for appointments, for money to travel or abortion pills. And during that waiting, a lot of interesting things happened. We see how much life has changed, nine months later.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Nine months ago, these people wanted abortions. But then, the laws changed. They had to wait to get an appointment, figure out how to get out of state or order abortion pills.  In that waiting, other things happened. (5 minutes)Today’s show was inspired by the excellent reporting of Caroline Kitchener.

episode_acts.name: Act One: First Trimester
episode_acts.summary: In the months following the court’s decision, two women are stalled getting abortions. Reporter Caroline Kitchener follows Kae and Taylor in those early months, as they try to figure out what to do.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Second Trimester
episode_acts.summary: Doctors say one effect of the new bans is people seeking abortions much later into their second trimesters. Caroline got interested in a girl like that in Oklahoma.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Third Trimester
episode_acts.summary: It’s been nine months since the first group of people who wanted abortions couldn’t get them in their states. How have their lives changed, or not.

fields.episode_descript: Summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: A beloved drawing goes missing from Mr. Ablao’s third grade classroom.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Music of the Night after Night after Night
episode_acts.summary: The musicians in the orchestra for Phantom of the Opera tell reporter Jay Caspian Kang about what it’s like to play the exact same music every single night—for decades.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: How I Met My Mother
episode_acts.summary: Producer Elna Baker’s mom doles out some very harsh feedback for her daughter, which goes unnoticed for ten years. (15 minutes)

fields.episode_title: What I Was Thinking As We Were Sinking
fields.episode_descript: It's funny the things that go through your head during a disaster.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass has fallen off his bike a number of times at this point. He reflects on what goes through his head as he’s going down.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Pirates of the Cari-BEAN-TOWN
episode_acts.summary: Producer Ike Sriskandarajah revisits a maritime disaster that left an impact on a group of friends from his youth. What he learns forever changes their impressions of that day.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Going Down With the Censorships
episode_acts.summary: When to leave Twitter is a question lots of executives faced when Elon Musk took over the company — those who weren't immediately fired, anyway. We hear an insider’s account from the man who ran Trust & Safety at the company, until he couldn’t stand it anymore.

fields.episode_descript: A week after Jerry Springer’s death, we go back to a story we first broadcast years ago, about a side of Springer most people don’t know and can’t imagine: his years as an idealistic politician in the mold of Bobby Kennedy. Plus other stories of people who try to leave some moment in their life behind, which can be hard.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira explains the premise of this week’s show, where most of the stories were first broadcast in 2004.

episode_acts.name: Act One: He Contains Multitudes
episode_acts.summary: Alex Blumberg tells the true story of Jerry Springer's life before he was a talk show host.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: God and Hockey
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with Shalom Auslander, who was raised as an Orthodox Jew and who made a pivotal break with his faith at a Rangers game.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Would You Like to Come Up to First Class?
episode_acts.summary: The journalist E. Jean Carroll is in court this week with her rape case against Donald Trump.

fields.episode_descript: Looping thoughts about people you barely know, or don't know at all.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: We get a tip that an entire town is consumed by a huge, elementary-school-style crush on a local veterinarian.

episode_acts.name: Act One: So…I Hear You’re Hot
episode_acts.summary: We do the thing the people in town would rather die than do – spill the crush to the legendary Dr. Artz himself.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Who Is Sarah Blust?
episode_acts.summary: Producer Alix Spiegel talks to one of her closest friends, Sarah Blust, about the time Sarah met a stranger who, unbeknownst to her, had already spent years thinking about her. (29 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: If These Dogs Could Talk
episode_acts.summary: There are certain jobs where thinking about someone else’s life is just built into it. Aviva DeKornfeld has a theory that petsitting is a job like that.

fields.episode_descript: Five years after the #MeToo explosion, what’s happened in the lives of the women who stepped forward and went public with their stories? We tell the story of a teenager who spoke out against one of the most powerful people in her state, and what happened next.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Some powerful and well known men lost their jobs after #MeToo. But what about the women at the center of all this who’ve been way less visible after they told what happened to them? We hear about big and small ways the aftermath of coming forward continues to pop up in their daily lives.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Intern
episode_acts.summary: Back in 2021, a 19-year-old intern at the Idaho state legislature reported that a state Representative named Aaron von Ehlinger raped her. She went by the name Jane Doe.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Witness
episode_acts.summary: Jane Doe walks into a public ethics hearing at the Idaho state capitol and navigates the aftermath. (23 minutes)Song: “Here We Have Idaho” 	Fiona Apple (vocals)	Amy Wood (drums and percussion)	David Garza (acoustic guitar, electric guitar, piano, vocals)	Sabastian Steinberg (bass, electric autoharp, vocals)	John Would (tremolo guitar)	Engineered by John Would, Amy Wood, Fiona Apple	Mixed and mastered by John Would

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Doe Meets Doe (podcast only)
episode_acts.summary: Jane Doe sent some questions for us to ask Chanel Miller. For years, Chanel was known as Emily Doe.

fields.episode_title: Must Be Rats on the Brain
fields.episode_descript: The one animal we can’t seem to live without, even when we really, really want to.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: At this spring’s announcement of New York City’s inaugural rat czar, we meet Darneice Foster, who despises the rats outside her apartment.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Fifty First Rats
episode_acts.summary: Producer Elna Baker meets Todd Sklar, a man who can’t quit rats. (22 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: The Big Bag Theory
episode_acts.summary: Fifty years ago, New York City started to put garbage out in plastic bags. This has become the number one food source for rats.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Alberta? More Like I’ll-Murdah…A-Lotta Rats
episode_acts.summary: How did Alberta, Canada pull off a feat that has eluded the rest of human civilization? Ira visits the largest rat-less land in the world. (15 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Put That Down, You Can’t Eat That
episode_acts.summary: We drop a hot mic into a hot mess of a rats’ nest. You’ll never believe what happens next.

fields.episode_descript: Ira's own father, Barry Glass, co-hosts this special Father's Day show.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks with his father and co-host for this show, Barry Glass, about his own early days working in radio.

episode_acts.name: Act One: How the World Sees Your Father
episode_acts.summary: LA writer/performer Sandra Tsing Loh discovers that a local rock band has recorded a song about her own father, wildly misinterpreting who he is. They think he’s a free spirit; she believes he’s a worried, miserly grump.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: And If That Diamond Ring Don’t Shine
episode_acts.summary: Ian Brown explains the lengths a normal dad will go to give his daughter a memorable birthday party, including a birthday stunt so crass that he and his wife shocked all of their friends.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Moment Dad Left
episode_acts.summary: Audio artist Jay Allison and writer Dan Robb present an audio montage on the moment Robb’s parents divorced.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Reconciling With Dad
episode_acts.summary: Chicago playwright Beau O’Reilly talks about how he reconciled with his estranged father years ago by becoming an alcoholic just like him.

fields.episode_descript: Humans encounter non-human intelligences of various kinds and try to make sense of them.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira has some thoughts about our country’s long history of alien invasion movies.

episode_acts.name: Act One: First Contact
episode_acts.summary: In this past year we’ve witnessed a revolution in A.I. since the public rollout of ChatGPT.  Our Senior Editor David Kestenbaum thinks that even though there’s been a ton of coverage, there’s one thing people haven’t talked much about: have these machines gotten to the point that they’re starting to have something like human intelligence? Where they actually understand language and concepts, and can reason? He talks with scientists at Microsoft who’ve been trying to figure that out.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Meat Cute
episode_acts.summary: A short piece of fiction from the perspective of aliens who’ve been scouting Earth, from writer Terry Bisson. It’s called “They're Made Out of Meat.” It’s performed by actors Maeve Higgins and H Jon Benjamin. (5 minutes)More information about Terry Bisson on his website.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Yacht Rocked
episode_acts.summary: A species of massive, mysterious, highly intelligent beings have recently been making contact with humanity. Or our boats, anyway.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Jorts and All
episode_acts.summary: Many of us, especially when we’re young, feel like we’re the alien, trying to understand and fit in with the humans on this planet. Producer Diane Wu spent some time recently with a teenage humanoid who feels that way.

fields.episode_descript: At a Yale fertility clinic, dozens of women began their I.V.F. cycles full of expectation and hope. Then a surgical procedure caused them excruciating pain. In the hours that followed, some of the women called the clinic to report their pain — but most of the staff members who fielded the patients’ reports did not know the real reason for the pain, which was that a nurse at the clinic was stealing fentanyl and replacing it with saline. What happened at that clinic? What are the stories we tell about women's pain and what happens when we minimize or dismiss it?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass introduces the first episode of a new podcast from longtime This American Life producer and editor Susan Burton. (1 minute)

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: Susan Burton introduces some of the many women who went to a Yale fertility clinic for IVF treatment, and charts their experience from hopeful beginning to excruciatingly painful egg retrieval.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Act Two
episode_acts.summary: Often bypassing logic, the women go to great lengths to construct elaborate stories to make sense of their inexplicable pain. And then, a letter arrives.

fields.episode_descript: Governor Ron DeSantis is running for president on the argument that he'll do for America what he's done for Florida. So what's it like in Florida?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Florida is now the fastest growing state, and DeSantis says people are moving there from all over because of him.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Prescription for Freedom
episode_acts.summary: Among the big items in DeSantis's run for president is medical freedom. Producer Zoe Chace wanted to understand its appeal and its growing popularity.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Their Eyes Were Watching Tallahassee
episode_acts.summary: DeSantis has passed law after law about what can and can’t be taught in Florida classrooms, starting as early as elementary school. And last spring, Florida Republicans introduced a bill initially proposing to ban things like critical race theory and identity politics, or students majoring in things like gender studies in Florida universities. Reporter Emmanuel Dzotsi followed how things unfolded at one of the biggest universities there, Florida State, from the bill’s introduction all the way to its passage.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Goodbye Sunshine (podcast only)
episode_acts.summary: Among the legislation introduced by DeSantis that has passed is a ban on minors receiving transition care. The bill passed into law a few months ago.

fields.episode_descript: People  on the verge of a big change, not wanting to let go. And the people who give them the final push.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest Host Sean Cole gets some scary news about his health, and decides to quit smoking. (5 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Straw That Broke Joe Camel's Back. / Can I Still Be a Joker and a Midnight Toker? / The Unbearable Lighterlessness of Being.
episode_acts.summary: Sean Cole attempts to kick his 35 year-long smoking habit, using a book that’s said to have helped millions of people to quit. (33 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: A Spoonful of Sugar
episode_acts.summary: Someone writes into the advice column Dear Sugar to ask whether or not they should quit a relationship, and gets a strange but very persuasive response. (9 minutes)An adaptation of some of Cheryl Strayed’s columns is now streaming on Hulu.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Tender Resignation
episode_acts.summary: Even people who vehemently disagreed with Heider Garcia wanted him to stay in his job. But then something happened that made staying impossible.

fields.episode_descript: Nadia's family is split between Russia and Ukraine, which is pretty common. And when Russia invaded Ukraine, it didn’t just start fighting on the battlefield. It sparked family conflict, too. An intimate story of the war from writer Masha Gessen.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: An extended family, and eight fights.

episode_acts.name: Fight #1: Where Does Luka Go?
episode_acts.summary: Luka’s parents – Nadia and Karen – try to figure out where to take him once war breaks out. (6 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Fight #2: Who Is Russian? And Who Is Ukrainian?
episode_acts.summary: Nadia and Karen have been arguing over Russian-ness since they needed to pick a school for Luka.

episode_acts.name: Fights #3 and #4: Crimea and the Globe
episode_acts.summary: Nadia remembers the times that Luka’s father would suggest going to Crimea for vacation, as if it wasn’t Ukrainian land occupied by Russia.

episode_acts.name: Fight #5: Bucha
episode_acts.summary: Nadia tells the story of her father, Alex, who lives near Bucha, and how differently he and she view the Russian atrocities there. (10 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Fight #6: About Giving Money to the Russian Government
episode_acts.summary: Nadia tells the story of her mother, who lives in Russia, and how she won’t do the one thing Nadia keeps asking her to do. (2 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Fight #7: The Nice Showdown
episode_acts.summary: Karen sends Nadia a photo which drives them to a final showdown. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Fight #8: The Fight That Wasn’t
episode_acts.summary: Nadia’s step-father works for the Russian government. How to manage that? (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Epilogue: Epilogue
episode_acts.summary: Nadia and Karen’s son, Luka, who most of these fights are about, gets the last word. (3 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: Legendary radio broadcaster Paul Harvey had a popular show called “The Rest of the Story.” Today on our show, we do just that. We hear from people who, whether they want to or not, find themselves face-to-face with the rest of their stories.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Legendary broadcaster Paul Harvey had one of the most popular radio shows of all time.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Burning Down The Couch
episode_acts.summary: Psychiatry used to be all talk. Then came a patient named Ray Osheroff.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Oh Mother Where Art Thou?
episode_acts.summary: Contributor Samuel James thought he knew what happened to his mother. But he was wrong.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Righteous Gemstone
episode_acts.summary: A new resident in Berlin is greeted like a minor celebrity wherever she goes.

fields.episode_descript: One call to a very unusual hotline, and everything that followed.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about a priest who set up what may have been the first hotline in the United States. It was just him, answering a phone, trying to help strangers who called.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Jessie
episode_acts.summary: The Never Use Alone hotline was set up so that drug users can call if they are say, using heroin by themselves. Someone will stay on the line with them in case they overdose.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Stephen
episode_acts.summary: An EMT learns he was connected to the call, in more ways than he realized.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Jessie
episode_acts.summary: Jessie, who took the call, explains how she discovered the hotline. She keeps in touch with Kimber.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Kimber
episode_acts.summary: We learn what happened to Kimber after she called the line.

fields.episode_descript: Friends and ex-friends finally talk about the one thing between them they've been avoiding.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass tells a story he’s never told anyone before, about something someone said to him. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: What Are Friends For? No Seriously. What Are They For?
episode_acts.summary: Gabe Mollica had something important he needed to discuss with his friend  — stewed about it for eight years. But rather than go to that friend, he talked about it with everyone other than that one person. (28 minutes)Gabe Mollica’s “Solo: a show about friendship” re-opens in October for runs in New York, Los Angeles, Boston, and Chicago.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Pinky Swear
episode_acts.summary: Jasmine and Gabbie are best friends. BFFs! But there’s something major that they’ve never been able to talk about.

fields.episode_title: The One Place I Can’t Go
fields.episode_descript: Spots we’re avoiding in our private maps of the world.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Bim Adewunmi talks to her cousin Kamyl about a funny thing Kamyl did when she was small, regarding a dog named Foxy. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: I Coulda Grown Big in Japan
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Atsuko Okatsuka moved suddenly from Japan to the U.S. when she was eight years old, and has long joked that it was because her grandmother kidnapped her from her dad. But she'd never talked to anyone in her family about what had actually happened. (31 minutes) Tickets for Atsuko’s comedy tour at atsukocomedy.com.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Killing Me Softly
episode_acts.summary: Producer Emmanuel Dzotsi has a tale about something he avoids at all costs, even though it seems to follow him everywhere he goes. (8 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lost In Space
episode_acts.summary: Writer Tamsyn Muir spent her childhood craving a world that she could not find on earth. So as an adult, she just created it.

fields.episode_title: The Bear at the End of the Tunnel
fields.episode_descript: People who have a good, long time to think about what they’re doing, look hard at what’s ahead of them, and decide to keep moving forward anyway.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Brothers Wes and Jeff spent a winter tagging black bears in Bryce Canyon National Park. One of the bears they needed to tag decided to hibernate at the end of an usually long tunnel.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Everybody Knows, You're Not Supposed to Poke a Sleeping Bear
episode_acts.summary: The story of Wes and Jeff venturing into the bear den continues. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 2: The Devil Is in the Details. And There Are So Many Details.
episode_acts.summary: Miki Meek reports on the situation for pregnant women in Idaho under the state’s new, post-Roe abortion laws, which are some of the most restrictive in the country. OB-GYNs say the state is in a crisis.

fields.episode_title: Is That What I Look Like?
fields.episode_descript: You've been seeing yourself, getting to know what you look like, your whole life. So why does it often take an outsider to see things about you that are obvious, and set you straight?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest host Nancy Updike talks about learning something new, and unpleasant, about herself in, where else, a makeup store. She also talks with other people about moments where someone made an observation about them that was shocking.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Blunt Force
episode_acts.summary: Writer Domingo Martinez tells a story from his memoir, "The Boy Kings of Texas," about when he was forced to face how he might look in 20 years if he kept doing what he was doing. (12 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Not My First Time at the Rodeo
episode_acts.summary: A man has a very clear vision of how he always stood up to his father, protected his mother and fought hard for the truth. Until one day he discovers actual raw data — secretly recorded conversations — that threaten to change his picture of everything.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Blunder Years
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass interviews actress Molly Ringwald about what happened when she watched one of her own movies, "The Breakfast Club" with her daughter. Ringwald talks about how for the first time, she saw the movie from the parents' point of view, not the kids'.

fields.episode_descript: What happens when you realize the people in charge don’t have the answers.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Guest Host Chana Joffe-Walt asks her kids when they first encountered adult fallibility.

episode_acts.name: Act One: See Something, Slay Something
episode_acts.summary: A middle schooler really wants to trust the adults have her best interests in mind. But some of the most powerful people at her school begin to make that very difficult.

episode_acts.name: Postscript: Postscript
episode_acts.summary: In Israel and Gaza, children are directly facing the fact that the adults around them cannot protect them. (4 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Dad’s Big Idea
episode_acts.summary: Comedian Gary Gulman on a choice his dad made for him when he was seven years old.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Ride or Die
episode_acts.summary: There are many kids who do not gradually discover that grown ups don’t have a handle on everything.  These kids already know. Miriam Toews’s novel, “Fight Night,” is about a nine-year-old named Swiv who takes care of her grandma and manages her mom’s mental health struggles.

fields.episode_descript: Things our dads taught us, whether they intended to or not.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira talks about the time his dad taught him to shave, and how unusual that was.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Am I My Father's Trapper Keeper Keeper?
episode_acts.summary: When Jackie read the obits for the man who had invented the famous Trapper Keeper notebook, she was very surprised. As far as she knew, the inventor was very much alive.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Raised By Wolf
episode_acts.summary: A father and son find themselves in a very traditional relationship. Until the end. (21 minutes)Rick McIntyre told this story in his book The Rise of Wolf 8: Witnessing the Triumph of Yellowstone's Underdog.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Storycorps, the Post-Apocalypse Edition
episode_acts.summary: Simon Rich reads his short story "History Report," in which a father explains the sex robots of the future.

fields.episode_descript: During the highest turkey consumption period of the year, we bring you a This American Life tradition: stories of turkeys, chickens, geese, ducks, fowl of all kinds—real and imagined—and their mysterious hold over us.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Ira Glass talks with Scharlette Holdman, who works with defense teams on high profile death row cases, and who has not talked to a reporter in more than 25 years. Why did she suddenly end the moratorium on press? Because her story is about something important: namely, a beautiful chicken.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Witness for the Barbecue-tion
episode_acts.summary: Scharlette Holdman's story continues, in which she and the rest of a legal defense team try to save a man on death row by finding a star witness — a chicken with a specific skill.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Chicken Diva
episode_acts.summary: Yet another testimony to the power chickens have over our hearts and minds.  Jack Hitt reports on an opera about Chicken Little.  It's performed with dressed-up styrofoam balls, it's sung in Italian and, no kidding, able to make grown men cry. (14 minutes)The official website for the opera "Love's Fowl" by Susan Vitucci and Henry Krieger is pulcina.org.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Trying To Respect The Chicken
episode_acts.summary: Ira accompanies photographer Tamara Staples as she attempts to photograph chickens in the style of high fashion photography. The chickens are not very cooperative. (15 minutes)Tamara's photos have been collected in a book, The Magnificent Chicken: Portraits of the Fairest Fowl.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Winged Migration
episode_acts.summary: Kathie Russo's husband was Spalding Gray,  who was best known for delivering monologues onstage—like "Monster in a Box," and "Swimming to Cambodia." On January 10, 2004, he went missing. Witnesses said they saw him on the Staten Island Ferry that night.

fields.episode_descript: When you realize that help is not on the way, what do you do next?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: Saddam Sayyaleh’s job right now is trying to get trucks filled with aid into Gaza and he knows it’s nowhere close to what’s actually needed.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Serious as a Heart Attack
episode_acts.summary: Tim Reeves runs a hospital in rural Pennsylvania, and he’s trying to do something that is so hard to do and that he knows is completely up to him.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor, Your Huddled Masses...Or Don't
episode_acts.summary: One of our producers, Nadia Reiman, talked to officials who work in the asylum and refugee branches at the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services.

fields.episode_title: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors
fields.episode_descript: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants. We take a look at how that’s going.

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In the middle of the night, host Ira Glass meets a woman on a mission at Port Authority bus station. (13 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act One: No Sleep ‘Till Brooklyn
episode_acts.summary: Producer Valerie Kipnis follows a group of people who’ve just arrived at their new home, a tent shelter in the middle of nowhere. (11 minutes)Reporting help from Jika Gonzalez.

episode_acts.name: Act Two: 150 Days of Bummer
episode_acts.summary: Producer Diane Wu talks to an asylum seeker trying to hustle his way through bureaucratic limbo. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Three: Lullaby of Broadway
episode_acts.summary: Host Ira Glass meets some of the city’s newest arrivals in every New Yorker’s least favorite place. (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Four: The New Kids
episode_acts.summary: Three girls, whose families traveled thousands of miles to get to New York, navigate their latest challenge: American middle school. (11 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act 5: Harlem Shuffle (podcast only)
episode_acts.summary: One woman needs to find shelter for 27 young men in a matter of hours. (15 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: One of our producers, Chana Joffe-Walt, had a series of conversations with a man in Gaza over the course of one week. They're so immediate – and particular to this moment in the war in Gaza – that we're bringing them to you now, outside of our regular schedule.

episode_acts.name: Act One: Act One
episode_acts.summary: No summary available.

fields.episode_title: It Wouldn’t Be Make-Believe If You’d Believe In Me
fields.episode_descript: A major political party in a major swing state bets on a new leader: a total political outsider. How does that work out for them?

episode_acts.name: Prologue: Prologue
episode_acts.summary: In 2022, Michigan Republicans ran anti-establishment candidates who claimed the last presidential election was stolen. And they lost big.

episode_acts.name: Act One: The Lonely Island
episode_acts.summary: The Michigan GOP’s newly elected leader, Kristina Karamo, faces her first big test: Can she organize and pull off the state party’s fabled, expensive Mackinac Island conference as a political outsider – with no fundraising experience or establishment connections? (9 minutes)

episode_acts.name: Act Two: Another Purity Test
episode_acts.summary: Two young Michigan GOP vice chairs are totally on board with Kristina Karamo’s take on politics and hate the establishment like her.

episode_acts.name: Act Three: The Insurrectionists Insurrect Again
episode_acts.summary: At the start of the year, Warren Carpenter was a Kristina Karamo supporter; helped her get elected.

episode_acts.name: Act Four: Karamo Fights Back
episode_acts.summary: Kristina Karamo and her camp defend themselves against Warren’s attacks that they’re bad at fundraising and bad at leading the party. (13 minutes)

fields.episode_descript: People finding themselves in situations that are worse than they thought and deciding to really go with it.
